Spherical map of galaxy superclusters is the most complete picture of our cosmic neighbourhood to date . It will help astrophysicists understand how matter is distributed in the universe and provide key insights into dark matter . The map spans nearly two billion light years from side to side .

Malé is the capital and most populous city of the Maldives. With a population of 190,000 in 2014, it is also the country's largest city by population. Malé is located on the southern coast of the atoll of Male, about north-east of the island nation's capital, Malé. The city has been ruled by a succession of sultans since its establishment in the 12th century as an outpost of the Maldivian Hindu Rajaateyya Dynasty. The city has been subjected to periodic fires and plague outbreaks throughout its history, but has frequently rebuilt and revitalized itself. It is now a modern and rapidly developing city, with many new tourist destinations and luxury hotels. The city hosts an annual festival, the Malé Arts Festival. The name "Malé" probably derives from the Old Sinhalese word "Mala", meaning "port", giving rise to the alternative names "Port Malé" or "Port Maldives". The earliest references to a settlement on Male are from Arab traders who visited the atoll in the 10th century AD. The first written mention of Malé dates from 1303 AD when Sultan Qasim Ghuri referred to it as a settlement called Dhibbanu. The present town was founded by Sultan Thakurufaanu Mamoon in 1296 AD as an outpost of his empire on an islet east of Male. The original settlement was destroyed by a fire in 1369 AD but was rebuilt and renamed D

Auguste-Maurice Tessier (July 20, 1879 – May 2, 1949) was a French composer and music educator. He is considered one of the leading representatives of French Impressionist music. Tessier was born in La Rochelle, France, the son of a wine merchant. He studied at the Paris Conservatory with Vincent d'Indy and Charles-Marie Widor. In 1902 he won first prize in the Prix de Rome for his cantata "Le pardon". After a year at the University of Berlin, he returned to France and taught at the Conservatory from 1906 to 1920. From 1922 to 1924 he served as Director of the Paris Conservatory. Tessier's best-known works are his orchestral pieces, which are marked by a sensitivity to the sound of the human voice and a penchant for evocative titles such as "Le jardin suspendu" or "L'oiseau de feu". His notable pupils include Darius Milhaud and Olivier Messiaen. Tessier died in Paris at the age of 76.

Talismanic (foaled February 28, 2013) is a retired British-bred, French-trained Thoroughbred racehorse who achieved his greatest success in America in the 2017 Breeders' Cup Turf. Background Talismanic is a "photogenic" dark bay horse with a large white blaze and four white stockings. He was bred by Darley Stud, which purchased his sire Medaglia d'Oro in 2009. Medaglia d'Oro was the most successful performer on the dirt of El Prado, a son of Sadler's Wells, with major wins including the Travers Stakes, Whitney Handicap and Donn Handicap. As a sire, Medaglia d'Oro is best known for his American runners on the dirt, including champions Rachel Alexandra and Songbird, but has also had success with turf performers in Australia and Europe.  Talismanic's dam Magic Mission is a stakes-winning daughter of Machiavellian. She descends from the outstanding mare Highclere, winner of the 1000 Guineas and Prix de Diane. Other members of this family include Deep Impact, Nayef, Nashwan and Unfuwain.

Reschensee (; Italian: Lago di Resia ) is a lake in the Alps, located in the canton of Graubünden. It is the second largest of the four Reschense lakes (the others being Lago Maggiore, Lago di Lugano and Lago di Como). At its deepest point it is 57 metres (184 ft) deep. The name Reschensee is derived from the German word "Reish", meaning "marsh". The marshy character of the lake's basin was due to its former location at the confluence of the three main rivers flowing into it: the Inn, the Ticino and the Rhine. The present-day configuration of the lake owes much to damming of these rivers in the 20th century. The Reschensee is well known for its trout fishing and for its many resorts, including those of Zermatt, Saas Fee and St Moritz.

Dunyazad is a large crater on Saturn's moon Enceladus. The crater is located near the south pole and was formed by a large impact event that occurred about 300 million years ago. Dunyazad is approximately 160 kilometers in diameter and has a depth of about 50 kilometers. The crater's rim is sharply defined and its floor is covered by a smooth, icy surface. Dunyazad is one of the most prominent features on Enceladus, and it is easily visible from Earth. The crater was first observed by scientists in 1988, and it was given its name by the International Astronomical Union in 2002. Dunyazad is one of the largest and deepest craters on Enceladus, and it is likely that it was formed by a powerful impact event. The crater contains several fractures, which may indicate that it has recently undergone tectonic activity.

Wang Changshun (; born 1957) is a Chinese billionaire businessman and politician. He is the chairman and chief executive officer of the China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), and one of the richest men in China. Wang was born in 1957 in Wuhan, Hubei province. He received his undergraduate degree from Wuhan University of Technology in 1979, and his master's degree from Peking University in 1982. Wang started his career as an engineer with CNPC in 1982. In 1991, he was appointed president of CNPC's Hubei Branch. In 1997, he was named president of CNPC's Beijing Branch. In 2001, Wang was appointed president of CNPC. In 2002, Wang was elected to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPC). He served on the NPC until 2007, when he resigned to become the chairman and chief executive officer (CEO) of CNPC. Since becoming CEO of CNPC, Wang has led CNPC through a period of rapid growth and transformation. Under his leadership, CNPC has become China's leading oil and gas company, with a market share that exceeds 50%. In addition, Wang has made significant contributions to China's energy security and development initiatives. He has been credited with spearheading CNPC's aggressive expansion into overseas markets, including Africa, Southeast Asia, and South America. In December 2013, Wang was awarded the title of "Honorary Fellow" by Peking University. Wang is a member

Liberal Christianity, also known as liberal theology, is a theological movement within Protestant Christianity that stresses the importance of individual liberty and freedom of conscience. It is sometimes considered synonymous with the mainline Protestant denominations, though it also has adherents in other traditions. Liberal Christianity began to emerge in the late eighteenth century as a reaction against traditional Protestantism. The leaders of this movement believed that the doctrines of predestination and election were antithetical to human freedom and equality, and that the sacraments should be viewed merely as symbols of grace rather than as means of salvation. They also believed that the Bible should be read without comment or interpretation, and that biblical morality should be applied without regard to social customs or economic conditions. Today, liberal Christianity is represented by a variety of religious denominations and groups. It is strongest among Protestant denominations in North America and Europe, but has also adherents among Catholics, Orthodox Christians, and members of other religious traditions. Liberal Christianity has played an important role in the development of critical thinking and religious pluralism within Protestantism, and has helped to foster relationships between different religious groups.

Ruby M. Rouss (3 December 1921 – 5 December 1998) was an American author and professor of English. She was the first African American woman to receive a Doctor of Letters degree from Yale University. Born in Lansing, Michigan, Ruby M. Rouss was the daughter of a civil rights activist father and a mother who was a librarian. After graduating from high school in 1939, she attended both Spelman College and Yale University, where she received her bachelor's degree in 1943 and doctorate in 1965. During her time at Yale, Rouss was a member of the Delta Sigma Theta sorority. After completing her graduate studies, Rouss taught at Smith College from 1965 to 1978, when she moved to Yale University as the first African American woman professor of English. She served as chair of the English department from 1978 to 1984, and remained active in the department until her death in 1998. Rouss's literary career began with the publication of her first book, Fire and Ice: A Personal History of the Civil Rights Movement, in 1968. Her later books include Blues Legacies: The Music of Bessie Smith (1981), The Woman Writer: A History of Our Own (1989), Harlem on My Mind: A Memoir (1991), and The Ruby Meanies: Reflections on Black Women (1995). She also wrote articles for journals such as The New York Times Magazine and Ebony. In 1995, Rouss received the prestigious National Book Award for Blues Leg

Alexander L. Yarin is a Russian-Lithuanian-Israeli-American applied mathematician who has made significant contributions to the theory of partial differential equations, particularly in the areas of fragmented solutions, numerical methods for large problems, and stochastic partial differential equations. He is currently a professor of mathematics at Tel Aviv University. Alexander Yarin was born in Moscow, Russia, in 1970. He received his B.S. from Lomonosov Moscow State University in 1992 and his M.S. and Ph.D. from Moscow State University in 1995 and 1999, respectively. He was a post-doctoral fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1999 to 2001 and a professor at Tel Aviv University from 2001 to 2005. In 2005, he moved to the Department of Mathematical Sciences at the University of California, Berkeley as a professor and chair of the mathematics department. In 2019, he moved back to Tel Aviv University as a professor of mathematics. His research focuses on the theory of partial differential equations, particularly in the areas of fragmented solutions, numerical methods for large problems, and stochastic partial differential equations. He has made significant contributions to these fields and has been recognized for his work by numerous awards and prizes, including the Lester R. Ford Award (2003), the Chern-Simons Prize (2010), and the Abel Prize (2018).

Richard Darryl Zanuck (December 13, 1934 – July 24, 1994) was an American film producer and director who worked in the motion picture industry for more than four decades. He is best known as the head of production at 20th Century Fox from 1966 to 1987. Zanuck was born in Los Angeles, California, the son of Darryl F. Zanuck, a movie producer and vice president at 20th Century Fox, and Edyth (née Kiefer), a secretary. Zanuck began his career in the mail room of 20th Century Fox in 1953. He later worked his way up through the production ranks, becoming vice president in charge of production. In 1966, Zanuck was appointed head of production at 20th Century Fox, a position he held for nearly four decades. He became a member of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association in 1975. Zanuck directed or produced many box office hits during his tenure at 20th Century Fox, including "The Sting", "The Towering Inferno", "The Godfather", "The Godfather Part II", "The Three Musketeers", "Cleopatra", "The Verdict", and "Apocalypse Now". In 1987, he retired from filmmaking and returned to 20th Century Fox as chairman of the studio's board of directors. He died of cancer two years later at the age of 68. Troopergate is the popular name for a political scandal that occurred in the United States during the presidency of Bill Clinton. The term refers to allegations that the president had sexual relations with a White House intern, Monica Lewinsky, which led to his impeachment by the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998. The scandal first came to light in late 1995, when Lewinsky told friends that she had an affair with the president. Clinton initially denied any knowledge of the affair, but after reports emerged in the media alleging sexual misconduct by him, he admitted to having had an inappropriate relationship with Lewinsky. After a lengthy investigation, Clinton was found guilty by a federal grand jury of perjury and obstruction of justice, and was subsequently impeached by the U.S. House of Representatives on December 19, 1998. He was later acquitted by the Senate on February 12, 1999.

William McGinnis, Ph.D. is a molecular biologist and biochemist who has been working on the genetic engineering of microorganisms and their applications in biotechnology. McGinnis has been involved in research on the use of recombinant DNA technologies to create genetically modified organisms (GMOs), and he has also worked on the development of new methods for the production of antibiotics. McGinnis was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in 1956. He received his bachelor's degree from Swarthmore College in 1978, and his doctorate from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1983. After obtaining his doctorate, McGinnis began working as a research fellow at Oxford University, where he remained until 1988. He then moved to the University of Washington, where he served as chair of the department of molecular biology and biochemistry from 1998 to 2002. In 2002, McGinnis was appointed professor and chair of the department of molecular biology at UC Berkeley. He retired from UC Berkeley in 2014. McGinnis's work has focused on the genetic engineering of microorganisms and their applications in biotechnology. Specifically, he has worked on the development of new methods for the production of antibiotics, as well as on the genetic engineering of microorganisms to produce biofuels and other products. McGinnis has also been involved in research on the use of recombinant DNA technologies to create genetically modified organisms (GMOs).

Sanjeev Talwar (Sanjay Talwar) (born January 11, 1963) is an Indian-born Canadian actor, producer and director. He is the son of Rishi Talwar, a Hindi film and television actor who has appeared in more than 150 films and television programs. Talwar was born in Mumbai, Maharashtra, India, to parents Rishi Talwar and Dimple Kapadia. He moved to Canada with his family when he was three years old and grew up in Toronto. He has two sisters, one of whom is actress Priyanka Talwar. He began his acting career in the early 1980s, appearing in several Canadian films and television programs. In 1988, he made his debut as an actor in the English-language feature film The Boys from Brazil. He subsequently appeared in several other films, including the thriller Deadly Silence (1991), the mystery thriller The Keep (1992), the comedy-drama The Cat's Meow (1993), and the drama The Unbearable Lightness of Being (1998). In 1997, he produced and directed his first film, the psychological thriller City of Joy. The following year, he starred in the action film Rustom (1998), which was directed by his father. Talwar has since appeared in several other films and directed two more movies himself: 2003's crime drama The Namesake and 2006's romantic drama Kaminey.

S. Semmalai is an Indian politician active in the state of Tamil Nadu. He is a member of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) and has served as the party's secretary-general since 1995. Semmalai was born on 3 January 1949 in Tirunelveli, Tamil Nadu, India. He completed his intermediate education from Government Arts College, Tirunelveli and did his post-graduate studies at the Madras University, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1971. Semmalai began his political career in 1971, when he was elected to the Tirunelveli Municipal Corporation as an Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (ADMK) candidate. He served as the Corporation's deputy mayor from 1976 to 1978, and was elected Mayor in 1978. He was re-elected Mayor in 1982 and 1986, and served until 1990. Semmalai served as the DMK's secretary-general from 1995 to 2003, and was appointed as the state party president in 2003. He was re-elected as party president in 2007, and again in 2011. Semmalai is a member of the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of India's Parliament), serving since 2004. He is also a member of the Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly, serving since 1989 as an ADMK candidate from Tirunelveli district.

Fangfoss is a village and civil parish in the southeast of Iceland, located on the Vatnajökull National Park, about halfway between Reykjavik and Hvítárvatn. The village has a population of 248 people. Fangfoss is located in the southeast of Iceland, at the foot of Vatnajökull National Park. The village is situated on the banks of the Fangafoss waterfall, a powerful waterfall with a height of . The village is connected to Reykjavik by Route 1 and to Hvítárvatn by Route 4. The village has a population of 248 people. The main industries are tourism and agriculture. There are two restaurants in the village and a grocery store. There is also a petrol station and a post office. The village has a playground, a football field, a pond, a church, and several hiking trails in the vicinity. There is also an air strip close to the village which can be used for small aircraft.

Charles F. Thompson (December 11, 1882 – June 15, 1954) was a career officer in the United States Army. A veteran of World War I and World War II, he attained the rank of major general and was notable as the first Chief of the United States Army Reserve and for his command of 3rd Infantry Division and I Corps. A native of Jamestown, North Dakota, Thompson graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1904. He served in Infantry assignments in the United States and the Philippines at the start of his career, and was posted to the Texas-Mexico border during the Mexican Border War. During World War I, Thompson served as an intelligence staff officer on the American Expeditionary Force staff and the staffs of both First and Second U.S. Armies. From 1921 to 1924, Thompson served as chief of the Press Relations section in the Intelligence (G-2) division of the Army staff and in 1923 he performed additional duty as head of Army Reserve affairs, the first officer to hold the position.

Neomercantilism (also spelt as neo-mercantilism) is a theory of economic policy which advocates the increase of exports to promote economic growth. Neomercantilism is the dominant school of thought in mainstream economics, which holds that increasing exports and creating a trade surplus is the key to sustained economic growth. The theory has been discredited by many economists, who argue that it is not always feasible to increase exports, and that trying to do so can lead to trade wars and other harmful consequences. The term "neo-mercantilism" was first used in the 1930s by economist Joseph Schumpeter to describe the policy of governments during the Great Depression of trying to increase exports to revive their economies. Neomercantilism has been a dominant school of thought in mainstream economics since its inception, and has been criticized for its adherence to mercantilist thinking, which holds that the wealth of a nation is determined by the amount of goods and services it exports.

Abdulaziz al-Shubaily is a prominent Saudi human rights advocate. In 2010, al-Shubaily joined the Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association (ACPRA), which has advocated for release of political prisoners and greater respect for human rights in Saudi Arabia. al-Shubaily has served as a lawyer for families of men held arbitrarily and without charge by Saudi authorities for months and years after their arrests, and has signed public statements calling for the release of arbitrary detainees, establishment of a constitutional monarchy, the right to peaceful assembly, and the popular election of members of the Saudi Shura Council. On May 29, the Specialized Criminal Court convicted him and sentenced him to eight years in prison and an eight-year ban on travel abroad for his peaceful activities. He remains out on bail pending appeal. On January 10, 2017, the Specialized Criminal Court re-sentenced al-Shubaily to eight years in prison, an eight-year travel ban, and an eight-year ban on using social media after his release. The charges against him included "incitement against public order," "insulting the judiciary," "describing the ruling Saudi state – unjustly and wrongly – as a police state," and "participating in an unlicensed association." , he remained out of prison on bail, pending appeal.

Gbudwe State was a state of South Sudan that existed between 2 October 2015 and 22 February 2020.It was created from Western Equatoria state. Tambura State was split from Gbudwe State on January 14, 2017. Gbudwe State was located in the Equatoria region. Gbudwe bordered the states of Lol, Maridi, Tambura, and Western Lakes, and also the province of Haut-Uélé in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Haut-Mbomou in the Central African Republic. The state had a population of 364,272 in 2008. History Before the creation of the state, Gbudwe State was part of Western Equatoria. On 2 October 2015, President Salva Kiir issued a decree establishing 28 states in place of the 10 constitutionally established states. The decree established the new states largely along ethnic lines. A number of opposition parties and civil society groups challenged the constitutionality of the decree. Kiir later resolved to take it to parliament for approval as a constitutional amendment. In November the South Sudanese parliament empowered President Kiir to create new states.

Luis Carlos Montalvan (April 13, 1973 – December 2, 2016) was an American soldier and author. He was born in Washington, DC and grew up in Potomac, MD, received a BA from the University of Maryland and a Master’s in Journalism from Columbia University. He served two tours of duty in Iraq and was an advocate for the use of service dogs. He also raised awareness about PTSD and its impact on veterans. He was also known for his New York Times Bestselling memoir, Until Tuesday: A Wounded Warrior and the Golden Retriever Who Saved Him, co-written with author, Bret Witter, in 2011. Tuesday, Luis's service dog and the subject of the eponymous book, passed away in September 2019. Montalvan was born in Washington D.C., and grew up in Potomac, Maryland. He was Cuban-American. When he was 17, he joined the United States Army, though he was discharged. He was later in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps while he attended the University of Maryland. In 2003, he was deployed to Iraq. On December 21, 2003, Montalvan describes how he was stabbed by a knife at a checkpoint in Al-Waleed. However, other members of the military have disputed the exact details of how Montalvan was injured and exactly what happened that night. An Associated Press report also disputed Montalvan’s description of the event and other descriptions written in his memoir, Until Tuesday. Montalvan addresses these differences in his book.

In computer science, formal specifications are mathematically based techniques whose purpose are to help with the implementation of systems and software. They are used to describe a system, to analyze its behavior, and to aid in its design by verifying key properties of interest through rigorous and effective reasoning tools. These specifications are formal in the sense that they have a syntax, their semantics fall within one domain, and they are able to be used to infer useful information. Motivation In each passing decade, computer systems have become increasingly more powerful and, as a result, they have become more impactful to society. Because of this, better techniques are needed to assist in the design and implementation of reliable software. Established engineering disciplines use mathematical analysis as the foundation of creating and validating product design. Formal specifications are one such way to achieve this in software engineering reliability as once predicted. Other methods such as testing are more commonly used to enhance code quality.

Legion Condor is a 1939 German war film directed by Karl Ritter and starring Paul Hartmann, Albert Hehn and Fritz Kampers. The film portrays the German Condor Legion which fought in the Spanish Civil War. Because of the Nazi-Soviet Pact, the production was halted after 15 days of film-shooting, on 25 August 1939, to avoid offending the Soviets who had supported the other side in Spain and who were negatively portrayed in the film. Karl Ritter's diary entry that day states that Hermann Göring had called the Ufa studio to tell him to abort the film. The film is often confused with the full-length documentary film by Karl Ritter, IM KAMPF GEGEN DEN WELTFEIND (In the Battle against World Enemy #1), released on 15 June 1939 on the same subject. LEGION CONDOR was planned as a sequel to Ritter's highly successful 1938 feature film, POUR LE MERITE, also starring Paul Hartmann, Albert Hehn, Fritz Kampers, Carsta Löck, amongst others.

Cleanliness is both the abstract state of being clean and free from germs, dirt, trash, or waste, and the habit of achieving and maintaining that state. Cleanliness is often achieved through cleaning. Culturally, cleanliness is usually a good quality, as indicated by the aphorism: "Cleanliness is next to Godliness", and may be regarded as contributing to other ideals such as health and beauty. In emphasizing an ongoing procedure or set of habits for the purpose of maintenance and prevention, the concept of cleanliness differs from purity, which is a physical, moral, or ritual state of freedom from pollutants. Whereas purity is usually a quality of an individual or substance, cleanliness has a social dimension and direction or implies a system of interactions. "Cleanliness," observed Jacob Burckhardt, "is indispensable to our modern notion of social perfection." A household or workplace may be said to exhibit cleanliness, but not ordinarily purity; cleanliness also would be a characteristic of the people who maintain cleanness or prevent dirtying.

The Wolseley Eight is a four door, six passenger saloon car that was produced by the Wolseley Motors Ltd. from 1934 to 1939. It was the first car to be marketed as a "luxury" car and is considered one of the most successful models ever made by Wolseley. The Eight was designed by Alec Issigonis, who had worked for the previous manufacturer, Morris Motors, before leaving to start his own company. The Eight was a departure from the traditional British saloon car of the time, which was a four door sedan. The Eight was instead a stylish four door saloon with a sleek design and features that were not available on other cars of its time. The Eight was available in both standard and luxury versions, with the latter featuring such features as a sunroof and an automatic transmission. The Eight was a major success and remained in production until 1939. It is considered one of the most iconic cars of the 1930s and has been featured in several films and television shows.

Danny Wynn (born September 25, 1983 in St. Louis, Missouri) is an American soccer defender who spent one season with the New England Revolution in Major League Soccer. He currently plays for the St. Louis Illusion in the Professional Arena Soccer League. Wynn grew up in St. Louis, Missouri. He was an All State soccer player at Chaminade College Preparatory School (Missouri). He then attended Saint Louis University where he was part of the men's soccer team from 2002 to 2005. In March 2006, the Milwaukee Wave of the Major Indoor Soccer League selected Wynn in the MISL Draft. However, the same month, the New England Revolution selected him in the first round (11th overall) in the 2006 MLS Supplemental Draft and signed him to a developmental contract. He played two games and was waived at the end of the season. In July 2007, the New Jersey Ironmen of Major Indoor Soccer League selected Wynn in the 16th round (136th overall) in the MISL Supplemental Draft, but he did not sign with them. In November 2008, Wynn signed with the newly established St. Louis Illusion of the Professional Arena Soccer League. And currently works at WWT. Part time lover.

Amina Rizk (; April 15, 1910 – August 24, 2003) was a classic Egyptian actress who appeared in around 208 artworks including more than 70 movies between 1928 and 1996. She was calm in her later years, but described as a clown when she was young. Life Amina Rizk came from a poor rural area. She and her aunt, Amina Mohamed, moved to Cairo with their mothers; the pair were locked in the house after their first theatrical performance. She was popular for her roles as the kind-hearted mother in plays and films, appearing in major pictures such as Doa al karawan in 1959 in which she appeared alongside actors such as Faten Hamama and Ahmed Mazhar, and Bidaya wa nihaya, in which she played the role of the Mother to Omar Sharif, Farid Shawqi and Sanaa Gamil. She also starred in many TV Series between the 1980s until her death before which she was filming a TV series for the holy month of Ramadan.

John Brown (May 9, 1800 – December 2, 1859) was an American abolitionist and militant abolitionist leader. He is best known for leading a raid on Harpers Ferry, Virginia, in 1859 during the American Civil War, in which he and nine others were killed. Brown was born in 1800 in Torrington, Connecticut. He worked as a carpenter and joiner before becoming involved in the abolitionist movement. In 1837, Brown moved to Springfield, Ohio, where he became a leader of the local antislavery movement. In 1841, he married Lucy Brown. In 1846, Brown moved to Kansas Territory to help organize an antislavery movement there. He became involved in the Civil War when the Union Army invaded Kansas in 1861. Brown was arrested and tried for treason but was released after a public outcry. He then led a series of raids on pro-slavery settlements in Missouri and Kansas. On October 16, 1856, Brown led a raid on a log cabin near Harpers Ferry, Virginia, which is now part of West Virginia. The raiders intended to free slaves owned by John Brown's friends William Wells Brown and Harriet Tubman. The raiders were opposed by Confederate forces led by John C. Breckinridge and Robert E. Lee, and they were eventually defeated after a prolonged battle. Nine of the raiders were killed, including John Brown himself. The remaining captives were eventually freed after the war ended. The drone carrying asparagus crashed and exploded mid-journey in the Netherlands. Owner Ronald Peijenburg used a Formula 1 racing car, hot air balloon and a helicopter to deliver first crop of the seasonal vegetable. The drone crashed and exploded mid-journey in the Netherlands.

Doug Tracht is an American radio, television, and movie personality. He is nicknamed "The Greaseman". Personal Tracht was born and grew up in the South Bronx, New York City with his younger sister, Diana, and parents, Alfred and Gertrude Tracht. His father was a native New Yorker who sold dental supplies; his mother was a Lutheran immigrant from Germany who stayed home to raise her two children until they were in high school, then became a noted educator. Tracht attended DeWitt Clinton High School and graduated in 1968. He majored in broadcasting at Ithaca College and landed a job at the college radio station. "From the first day I got on the air, I was trying to do comedy bits and tell jokes. After my first year in college, I had this station (WYSL) in Buffalo, New York, offer me a big time job." Tracht got a job at WTKO, a low-power top-40 station in Ithaca. The following year, he had moved up to night DJ at a larger station in Binghamton, New York, WENE. Tracht graduated from Ithaca College in 1972 and married Marie Massara who was the sales secretary at WENE.

Desmond Steven McAnuff (born June 19, 1948) is an American actor, director, and producer. He has appeared in over 100 films and television shows during a career spanning more than five decades. McAnuff was born in Los Angeles, California, the son of actress Jean McAnuff and producer Desi Arnaz, Jr. He is of Irish and Italian descent. He began his career as a child actor in the 1950s, appearing in several television shows before making his feature film debut in The Towering Inferno (1974). McAnuff achieved stardom for his roles as Lt. Terence Fletcher on the NBC police drama Hill Street Blues (1981–1987) and as Virgil Fairburn on the ABC soap opera General Hospital (1963–1997). He also directed two episodes of Hill Street Blues. In addition to his acting and directing work, McAnuff has produced and written several films, including The Last Detail (1973), Tootsie (1982), Bull Durham (1988), The Great Gatsby (2013), and Nine Lives (2018). He has received three Emmy Awards, a Golden Globe Award, and a Screen Actors Guild Award. McAnuff was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2018 and died from the disease on November 25th, 2018 at the age of 71.

Rodrigo Vélaz (died June 1144) was the "count of Galicia, who held Sarria" according to the near-contemporary Chronica Adefonsi imperatoris. During his long public career he was the dominant figure in mountainous eastern Galicia while the House of Traba dominated its western seaboard. He served under three monarchs—Alfonso VI, Urraca, and Alfonso VII—and was loyal to all of them, never figuring in any rebellion. The contemporary Historia compostellana is a valuable source for his life, since there are no aristocratic archives surviving in Spain from this period. Rodrigo's career must be pieced together from the few references in the chronicles and the (copies of) charters preserved in various ecclesiastical archives. He was a son of Count Vela Ovéquiz and Aldonza Muñoz, daughter of Count Muño Fernández and Elvira. Rodrigo married Urraca Álvarez, daughter of Álvar Fáñez and Mayor Pérez, a daughter of Pedro Ansúrez. Rodrigo and his wife were descended on all sides from the highest ranks of the nobility of León and Castile. The couple had three daughters—Aldonza, Berenguela, and Elvira—and one son, Álvaro Rodríguez, who was later a count like his father. On 6 August 1130 Rodrigo and Urraca made a donation to the Cathedral of Lugo, their first recorded act as husband and wife.

Orval Howard Hansen (August 3, 1926 – November 2, 2017) was an American politician who served as a congressman from Idaho. He served three terms as a Republican in the House from 1969 to 1975, representing the state's 2nd district. Early years Born in Firth, Idaho to Lily Dorothy Miriam (née Wahlquist) and Farrel L. Hansen, his mother the daughter of Swedish immigrants and his father of Danish descent. Hansen was raised in Idaho Falls and graduated from Idaho Falls High School in 1944. After military service in World War II, he attended the University of Idaho in Moscow, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Chi fraternity, and extremely active with campus activities. Hansen earned a B.A. summa cum laude in 1950 from UI and then attended George Washington University in Washington, D.C. and received a J.D. from its Law School in 1954. He also earned an LLM (awarded in 1973) and a Ph.D. in political science (awarded in 1986) from GWU.

James "Jim" William Truman is an American chronobiologist known for his seminal research on circadian rhythms in silkmoth (Saturniidae) eclosion, particularly the restoration of rhythm and phase following brain transplantation. He is a professor emeritus at the University of Washington and a former senior fellow at Howard Hughes Medical Institution Janelia Research Campus. Background Truman was introduced to biological research as an undergraduate at the University of Notre Dame in the laboratory of George B. Craig. He was intrigued by Craig's discoveries relating to the hormonal regulation of mosquito mating behavior. As a graduate student, he continued to study hormonal control of insect behavior at Harvard University where he received his PhD in 1970. His doctoral advisor was Lynn Riddiford, whom he later married. He began his research in chronobiology as a junior fellow at Harvard University and continued this work when he established his own laboratory in 1973 at the University of Washington.

Pancharatra (IAST: Pāñcarātra) was a religious movement in Hinduism that originated in late 3rd-century BCE around the ideas of Narayana and the various avatars of Vishnu as their central deities. The movement later merged with the ancient Bhagavata tradition and contributed to the development of Vaishnavism. The Pancharatra movement created numerous literary treatises in Sanskrit called the Pancharatra Samhitas, and these have been influential Agamic texts within the theistic Vaishnava movements. Literally meaning five nights (pañca: five, rātra: nights), the term Pancharatra has been variously interpreted. The term has been attributed to a sage Narayana who performed a sacrifice for five nights and became a transcendent being and one with all beings. The Pancharatra Agamas constitute some of the most important texts of many Vaishnava philosophies including the Madhva Sampradaya or Brahma Sampradaya of Madhvacharya and the Sri Vaishnava Sampradaya of Ramanuja. The Pancharatra Agamas are composed of more than 200 texts; likely composed between 600 AD to 850 AD.

Eric Malcolm Senior (6 October 1920 – 14 September 2014) was an Australian rules footballer who played with Carlton in the Victorian Football League (VFL).   He was the son of Australian rules footballer and coach Malcolm Senior and the brother of fellow VFL footballer Gordon Senior.   Senior played 190 games for Carlton between 1940 and 1949, including 86 consecutive games from 1945 to 1948. He was a member of the 1945 premiership team and played in seven other grand finals for the club. He also played for North Melbourne in 1949.   After retiring from playing, Senior coached Carlton in 1954 and 1955. He later served as president of the Victorian Football Association (VFA) between 1966 and 1968. He died at the age of 94 in 2014.

Baron Gustav Evertsson Horn of Marienburg (28 May 1614 – 27 February 1666) was a Finnish-Swedish military man and politician. He was a member of the Privy Council of Sweden and Governor General. Horn, the son of Field Marshal Evert Horn, was born in 1614 in Southwest Finland, at the time a part Sweden. He became captain in 1635, and a colonel in 1640. In 1651, he was, along with cousin Henrik Horn, raised to a baron. Gustav Horn became a member of the Swedish Privy Council in 1653, and in the following year, he was assigned the role of Governor General of Ingria and Kexholm, an office he left for the assignment of Governor General of Finland in 1657. In 1656 he was appointed general, in 1658 rikstygmästare and in 1663 field marshal. The latter year he also became Governor General of Bremen-Verden. Gustav Evertsson Horn died in Stade, Germany, in 1666.

"Deep in Love" is a song by American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars. The song was written by Mars, Philip Lawrence, and Ari Levine, with production being handled by the latter two. Musically, "Deep in Love" is a midtempo ballad that blends elements of R&B, soul, and funk. Lyrically, the song is about a strong and passionate love. The song was released as the lead single from Mars's fourth studio album "24K Magic" (2016). It was initially released as a promotional single on October 7, 2015, and later made available for digital download on October 9. The song has since peaked at number one on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 chart and became Mars's fourth number-one single in the country. The accompanying music video was directed by Marc Klasfeld and premiered on November 18, 2015. It has been watched more than 150 million times on YouTube. The song was nominated for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance at the 58th Annual Grammy Awards. Julia Van Herck , 42 , from Fulham , West London , ballooned to 23 stone . She wore a size 26 to size 28 and would comfort eat tubs of ice-cream and family-sized pizzas because she was scared that her husband might leave her .

Frances Bedingfeld, I.B.V.M. (1616–1704) led the first foundation in England of the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary, better known as the Sisters of Loreto, which had been founded by the Venerable Mary Ward. In 1677, Bedingfeld founded Bar Convent in York, the oldest surviving Roman Catholic convent in England and also the first Roman Catholic School for Girls in Britain ( Bar Convent School For Girls). Life Frances was the daughter of Francis and Katherine Fortescue Bedingfeld. Born in Norfolk, England, in 1616, she came from a recusant family which had remained Roman Catholic through the Reformation. She and her 11 sisters all entered religious orders. Sent to the continent for her education due to the Penal Laws then in effect, Bedingfeld enrolled at the school run by the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Munich, then in the Electorate of Bavaria, known there as the "English Ladies". She later entered the Institute herself in Rome and was professed in September 1633 in the church of Santa Maria Maggiore. She later became the superior of the mother house of the order in Munich.

Kearny is a town in the western part of Hudson County, New Jersey, United States and a suburb of Newark. As of the 2010 United States Census, the town's population was 40,684, reflecting an increase of 171 (+0.4%) from the 40,513 counted in the 2000 Census, which had in turn increased by 5,639 (+16.2%) from the 34,874 counted in the 1990 Census. Kearny is named after Civil War general Philip Kearny. It began as a township formed by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on April 8, 1867, from portions of Harrison Township. Portions of the township were taken on July 3, 1895, to form East Newark. Kearny was incorporated as a town on January 19, 1899, based on the results of a referendum held two days earlier. The Arlington section of town was named for Arlington Station on the Erie Railroad at the Arlington Mill plant, owned by Arlington Mills of Lawrence, Massachusetts.

Ben Perowsky (born May 12, 1966) is an American entrepreneur, investor, and philanthropist. He is the co-founder and CEO of the social media company Blue Apron. Ben Perowsky was born on May 12, 1966 in Baltimore, Maryland. After graduating from high school in 1984, he attended the University of Maryland, where he earned a degree in economics. After college, Perowsky worked as a financial analyst for two investment firms. In 1991, he co-founded a marketing company called TradeMarkX with business partner Jonathan Teo. The company developed and sold a computer software program that helped companies analyze their online marketing campaigns. In 2000, Perowsky and Teo established Blue Apron, an online meal delivery service. The company has since been acquired by Amazon.com. In 2015, Perowsky founded The Weave Foundation, which focuses on improving access to quality education for underserved students. He has also donated millions of dollars to charity through his various philanthropic initiatives. Ben Perowsky has received numerous accolades over the years for his work in business and philanthropy. In 2013, he was named one of Fast Company's "Most Innovative Business People". He has also been awarded an honorary doctorate from Stony Brook University and an honorary degree from Johns Hopkins University.

"Epiphany" is episode 16 of season 2 of the supernatural drama series "Supernatural". Sam and Dean Winchester are trying to track down a serial killer in Missouri and they come across a young woman, Lisa Braeden, who has been targeted by the killer. Lisa says that she cannot remember anything that has happened to her since she was abducted, but Sam and Dean believe that she is lying and they start to investigate her background. They find out that Lisa is a devout Christian and that she has a lot of faith in God. Dean starts to doubt his own beliefs and starts to question what really happened to him after he was possessed by a demon. Meanwhile, Sam is trying to find a way to cure Lisa of her amnesia and he comes across an angel named Epiphany who tells him that he can help. The episode ends with Lisa being killed by the killer and Sam and Dean finding out that she was lying about her memory loss. Dean starts to question his own faith again and wonders if it was all a dream.

Ganga Prasad Chaurasia is an Indian politician who has been a member of the Indian Parliament since 1998. He is a member of the Indian National Congress (INC) and has been a minister in the Indian government twice, first in the UPA Government led by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and then in the current Modi Government. He is also the President of the Uttar Pradesh Congress Committee. Ganga Prasad Chaurasia was born on 1 December 1949 in a small town in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. He completed his schooling from DAV Public School, Pilibhit and his undergraduate studies from Lucknow University. He holds a law degree from Law College, Allahabad. Chaurasia started his political career as an activist with the Indian National Congress. He was elected to the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly in 1984 and served as a minister in the state government led by Ram Nath Kovind. In 1998, he was elected to the Indian Parliament from Pilibhit constituency, and has since been re-elected seven times. In 2002, he was appointed Minister of State for Agriculture in the UPA Government led by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, and he held this position until 2004. In 2006, he was appointed Minister of State for Petroleum and Natural Gas in the UPA Government led by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, and he held this position until 2009. In 2014, he was appointed Minister of State for Power in the Modi Government led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Chaurasia is also

Edward Jay Blum is a politically conservative legal strategist known for his activism against affirmative action based on race and ethnicity. Blum is not an attorney. He connects potential plaintiffs with attorneys who are willing to represent them in "test cases" which he tries to use to set legal precedents. He is the director and sole member of the Project on Fair Representation, which he founded in 2005. According to its website, the Project focuses specifically on voting rights, education, government contracting, and employment. Since the 1990s, Blum has been heavily involved in bringing six cases to the United States Supreme Court, and the Court has partially or fully ruled in his favor in four of those cases. He is a key figure in the Students for Fair Admissions v. President and Fellows of Harvard College lawsuit. Early life Blum was born into a Jewish family in Benton Harbor, Michigan, where his parents owned and operated the local shoe store. He graduated from the University of Texas at Austin in 1973. He then studied West African writers for a year at the State University of New York at New Paltz. He describes his parents as generally left-wing liberals who supported Democratic presidents like Franklin Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman and that he was, eventually, "the first Republican my mother ever met".

The Fundamentalist–Modernist controversy is a major schism in the history of Christianity, with Fundamentalist Christians defending the traditional view of the Bible against Modernists who argued that the Bible should be read in light of current scientific and historical knowledge. The Fundamentalist–Modernist controversy emerged in the early 20th century as a battle between two schools of thought within Christianity: Fundamentalists, who defended traditional interpretations of the Bible, and Modernists, who argued that the Bible should be read in light of current scientific and historical knowledge. The debate intensified in 1925 when Christian theologian Reinhold Niebuhr published his book The Nature and Destiny of Man, which attacked traditional Protestant doctrines in favor of a synthesis of Christianity and secular philosophy. The Fundamentalist–Modernist controversy reached a critical point in 1948 when the General Assembly of the World Council of Churches met in Amsterdam to discuss the issue. There, Modernists gained a majority and passed a resolution calling for a reconsideration of the Bible's teachings on science, history, and other subjects. This resolution led to a decline in membership in mainline Protestant churches, which were now perceived as being too aligned with Modernism. The Fundamentalist–Modernist controversy has largely subsided since then, but it remains a significant issue within Christianity. Today, there are still some Fundamentalists who defend traditional interpretations of the Bible against Modernists, but the majority of Christians have moved away from the Fundamentalist–Modernist controversy and have adopted a more moderate stance.

Joseph (Yossi) Keshet (Hebrew: יוסי קשת; born October 5, 1938) is an Israeli-American musician and composer. Keshet is noted for his work in creating innovative and experimental music for the theater and film, as well as his collaborations with other leading Israeli composers. Born in Jerusalem to a secular family, Keshet became interested in music at an early age; he studied violin with Mischa Mischkin and composition with Moshe Leiser at the Israel Academy of Music and Dance. After completing his studies, he worked as a violinist and arranger in the Tel Aviv Philharmonic Orchestra before moving to New York City in the early 1970s. There, he began working on projects for theater and film, eventually establishing himself as one of the leading Israeli composers of his generation. He has written music for numerous plays, films, and concerts, including collaborations with leading Israeli composers such as Shlomo Argov, Itzhak Perlman, and Yair Sheleg. In 2006, Keshet was awarded the Israel Prize for his contributions to Israeli culture.

The Southwold Earthworks is the remains of a pre-contact village site of the Neutral people, occupied about AD 1450 to 1550. The entrance to the site is located on Iona Road, approximately three kilometres south of Iona Ontario, Canada. A double oval ring of raised earthworks surrounds the remains of the village. Background Occupied between AD 1450 and 1550, it is located in southwestern Ontario in rural Elgin County, near the banks of a tributary of Talbot Creek, approximately 20 km west of St. Thomas, Ontario. Archaeological investigations have indicated the presence at one time of eighteen longhouses of various sizes within the village, with an estimated population of 800-900 people. These native inhabitants were the Attiwandaronk (Attarawandon) Indians, an Iroquoian-speaking people called the Neutrals by the French colonists. An open area in the centre of the community appears to have provided a common activity area or meeting place. The archaeological interpretation concludes that Southwold was a typical pre-contact Neutral village, palisaded for defensive purposes.

Ernst von Bergmann (16 December 1836 – 25 March 1907) was a Baltic German surgeon. He was the first physician to introduce heat sterilisation of surgical instruments and is known as a pioneer of aseptic surgery. Biography Born in Riga, Livonia Governorate (now Latvia), in 1860 he earned his doctorate at the University of Dorpat. He then worked as an assistant at the surgical clinic, and trained for surgery under Georg von Adelmann (his future father-in-law), and Georg von Oettingen. He received his certification in 1864. From 1871 to 1878 he was a professor of surgery at Dorpat. In 1878 he became a professor at Würzburg; in 1882 he relocated to the University of Berlin as a successor to Bernhard von Langenbeck. He continued as a professor of surgery at Berlin for the remainder of his career. Two of his assistants in Berlin were Curt Schimmelbusch (1860–1895) and Friedrich Gustav von Bramann (1854–1913). His son, Gustav von Bergmann (1878–1955) was a noted doctor of internal medicine.

Ayi Kwei Armah (born 28 October 1939) is a Ghanaian writer best known for his novels including The Beautyful Ones Are Not Yet Born (1968), Two Thousand Seasons (1973) and The Healers (1978). He is also an essayist, as well as having written poetry, short stories, and books for children. Early life and education Ayi Kwei Armah was born in the port city of Sekondi-Takoradi in Ghana to Fante-speaking parents, descending on his father's side from a royal family in the Ga nation. From 1953 to 1958 Armah attended the Prince of Wales's College (now known as Achimota School), and won a scholarship to study in the United States, where he was between 1959 and 1963. He attended Groton School in Groton, MA, and then Harvard University, where he received a degree in sociology. He then moved to Algeria and worked as a translator for the magazine Révolution Africaine. In 1964, he returned to Ghana, where he was a scriptwriter for Ghana Television and later taught English at the Navrongo Secondary School.

Muisca numerals were the numeric notation system used by the Muisca people in the Altiplano Cundiboyacense, Colombia. The system consisted of up to twenty symbols, each of which represented one of the 20 units in the Muisca decimal system. The Muisca were a people who lived in the highlands of present-day Colombia during the Early Pre-Columbian period. They were one of the most important cultural and linguistic groups in South America, and their numerals were one of the most complex and advanced systems used in the region. The Muisca numerals were based on a vigesimal system, using 20 symbols to represent 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 20, 50, 100, and 500. Each symbol represented one of the units in the Muisca decimal system: 1 = cuzco; 2 = biti; 3 = quinchu; 4 = yanacona; 5 = tukurí; 10 = cincuenta; 20 = doscientos; 50 = cien; 100 = mil; 500 = quinientos. The Muisca numerals were first documented by Spanish chroniclers in the 16th century. At that time, they had been lost to history for centuries thanks to their remote location and lack of contact with outsiders. It was not until the early 21st century that researchers began to rediscover and study the Muisca numerals. Today, they are still used

Deborah Jeanne Dawkins is an American politician and atheist who is currently a fellow at the Center for Inquiry. Dawkins was born in New Jersey and raised in West Orange, where she attended West Orange High School. She earned a B.A. from Brown University in 1985 and an M.Phil from the University of Oxford in 1987. After completing her graduate studies, Dawkins worked as an assistant professor of philosophy at Rutgers University from 1988 to 1990. In 1991, she became a research associate at the Center for Inquiry, where she served until 2003. From 2003 to 2007, she was the editor-in-chief of the Skeptical Inquirer magazine. In 2007, Dawkins was appointed a Fellow at the Center for Inquiry. Dawkins is also a columnist for The Guardian and The New Republic and has appeared on several television shows, including Late Night with Conan O'Brien and The Daily Show with Jon Stewart.

Blanck Mass is a British electronic solo artist and composer. He is the founder, vocalist and sole member of the electronic music group Blanck Mass. Blanck Mass was founded in 1995 by English musician and composer Steven Stapleton. The group's music is characterised by its use of sound-based textures and harsh, noise-like elements, with a focus on tape manipulation and electronic instrumentation. Their debut album, "Mass", was released in 1998 on the British label Cuneiform Records. In 2002, Blanck Mass released their second album, "Tenebrae". The album was praised by critics for its bleak and dark soundscape, which drew comparisons to early industrial music acts like Throbbing Gristle and Einsturzende Neubauten. The group toured extensively in support of the album, playing shows in Europe, North America and Japan. In 2004, Blanck Mass released their third album, "Imaginarium", which again received critical acclaim. The album explored more abstract musical territory than previous releases, featuring extended ambient pieces and experimental electronic music. Since the release of "Imaginarium", Blanck Mass has largely focused on studio work, releasing only sporadic updates to their official website. In 2013, they collaborated with British composer Ben Frost on the soundtrack for the film "The Act of Killing". Shake Away is the sixth studio album by American country music artist George Jones. It was released on February 26, 1972, by MCA Records. Jones had just completed his scheduled tour for his fifth album, "The Grand Tour", and was feeling restless. So he assembled a new band, consisting of guitarists Joe Bonamassa and Doug Clifford, bassist Paul Hornsby, and drummer Jerry Scheff. He also recruited backing vocalists Susan Tedeschi and Linda Ronstadt, and recorded the album in a three-day session at the RCA Studios in Nashville. The album was produced by Jones and Chips Moman, who had previously produced his breakthrough album "Jones Country" (1970). Some of the songs on "Shake Away" reflect Jones's newfound interest in soul music. The title track is a cover of the 1967 hit by The Temptations. "I Can't Quit You Baby" is a cover of the Willie Dixon song that had been a Number One country hit for Johnny Cash in 1968. And "Who's Gonna Ride Your Wild Horses" is an updated version of a song that had been a Number One pop hit for The Rolling Stones in 1969. The album reached No. 3 on the "Billboard" country albums chart, while the title track became Jones' fourth Number One country hit on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles chart. University Avenue is a discontinuous street in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. It runs from 102nd Street to 111th Street, and from Jasper Avenue to Gateway Boulevard. The street is designated as a major arterial by the City of Edmonton. University Avenue is one of Edmonton's oldest streets. It was laid out in 1892 as a route between the city centre and the University of Alberta. The street was named for the University of Alberta, which was founded in 1908. The street was once lined with prominent commercial buildings, but many have been demolished or replaced by modern buildings. University Avenue is home to a number of cultural institutions, including the Royal Alexandra Theatre, the Edmonton Art Gallery, and the Edmonton Symphony Orchestra. The street has also been home to a number of high-end retailers, including Saks Fifth Avenue, Holt Renfrew, and Nike Canada.

Mita Taupopoki ( – 14 January 1935) was a notable Māori tribal leader of New Zealand. He identified with Ngāti Wāhiao, a hapū (subtribe) of the Tūhourangi iwi of Te Arawa. He was born near Lake Rotorua, New Zealand, probably in 1845 or 1846. His father, Hēmana Te Whareiro of Ngāti Wāhiao, lived mostly at Whakarewarewa. His mother, Kanea II, was of Tūhourangi, and the Ngāti Tūnohopū hapū of Ngāti Whakaue. In 1864 Mita joined other Te Arawa who fought for the government in the wars of the 1860s. He returned to Whakarewarewa in 1874. In 1883 he represented several hapū of Ngāti Wāhiao in the Native Land Court in a case relating to land claimed by Ngāti Whakaue, including Whakarewarewa, and succeeded in claims to the land on the east side of the Puarenga Stream at Whakarewarewa, although other land was won by Ngāti Whakaue. His success in the land court contributed to a recognition of his leadership among the wider Tūhourangi, in addition to within Ngāti Wāhiao. The 1886 eruption of Mount Tarawera killed many Tūhourangi, and survivors took refuge with Mita and his people at Whakarewarewa and Ōhinemutu. Mita continued to act in the Native Land Court, representing Tūhourangi, and in 1887 won recognition of their claims of the 211,000-acre Rotomahana–Parekārangi block. In 1910 he toured Australia, England and the United States with Maggie Papakura's cultural group. He died in hospital in Rotorua on 14 January 1935.

Altınordu Futbol Kulübü (formerly known as Altınordu AŞ), is a Turkish professional football club based in the city of İzmir. The club was founded in 1949 and has played its home matches at the Altınordu Stadı since 1973. Altınordu was founded on 15 May 1949 in İzmir by a group of young people who were looking for a place to play football. The club's first president was Dr. Halil İbrahim Şahin. The club's colours were black and white and the team played its first official match against Altınordu SK from Istanbul on 15 July 1949. The club's first success came in the 1951–52 season when it won the regional championship. In the 1954–55 season, Altınordu reached the final of the Turkish Cup but lost to Galatasaray. In 1957, Altınordu became champions of the Mediterranean League and also reached the final of the Turkish Cup but again lost to Galatasaray. In 1968, Altınordu became champions of the First Division and won promotion to the Süper Lig. The following season, 1969–70, they finished as runners-up in their first season in the Süper Lig, qualifying for the European Cup for the first time. Pulse-density modulation, or PDM, is a form of modulation used to represent an analog signal with a binary signal. In a PDM signal, specific amplitude values are not encoded into codewords of pulses of different weight as they would be in pulse-code modulation (PCM); rather, the relative density of the pulses corresponds to the analog signal's amplitude. The output of a 1-bit DAC is the same as the PDM encoding of the signal. Pulse-width modulation (PWM) is a special case of PDM where the switching frequency is fixed and all the pulses corresponding to one sample are contiguous in the digital signal. For a 50% voltage with a resolution of 8-bits, a PWM waveform will turn on for 128 clock cycles and then off for the remaining 128 cycles. With PDM and the same clock rate the signal would alternate between on and off every other cycle. The average is 50% for both waveforms, but the PDM signal switches more often. For 100% or 0% level, they are the same. Jerrelle Benimon (born August 1, 1991) is an American football cornerback for the Baltimore Ravens of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Florida State. Benimon was drafted by the Ravens in the fourth round of the 2013 NFL Draft. Benimon was born in Pensacola, Florida, to Haitian parents. He attended Pensacola High School, where he played football and basketball. As a senior in 2010, he tallied 73 tackles, eight interceptions and five sacks. Benimon also lettered in track and field as a sprinter and jumper. Benimon played college football at Florida State University. As a freshman in 2011, he appeared in all 14 games and made nine starts at cornerback. Benimon recorded 41 tackles (26 solo), one interception, two pass defenses, one forced fumble and one fumble recovery. As a sophomore in 2012, he appeared in 12 games and started 11 at cornerback. Beniman recorded 46 tackles (24 solo), two interceptions, three pass defenses, one forced fumble and one fumble recovery. As a junior in 2013, Benimon appeared in 12 games and started 11 at cornerback. He finished the season with 55 tackles (37 solo), two interceptions, four pass defenses, one forced fumble and one fumble recovery. Benimon was named First Team All-ACC by ACC coaches and Third Team All-American by Sports Illustrated. He was also named to the 2013 All-ACC Academic Team. Benimon was drafted by the Baltimore Ravens in the fourth round of the 2013 NFL Draft.

P-047, also known as Tae Peang Phuong, is a compound that was first synthesized in 1962. It is a potent, selective β-blocker that has been used to treat hypertension, coronary artery disease, and heart failure. P-047 is also a prodrug that is converted into the active drug pindolol by the liver. P-047 was discovered in 1962 by scientists at Hoffmann-La Roche. It was initially developed as a potential treatment for hypertension, coronary artery disease, and heart failure. P-047 was found to be a potent and selective β-blocker that blocked the activity of the β-1 and β-2 receptors in the heart. P-047 is also a prodrug that is converted into the active drug pindolol by the liver. P-047 has been used to treat a variety of diseases over the years. P-047 was found to be particularly effective in treating hypertension and coronary artery disease. P-047 has also been found to be safe and well-tolerated when taken orally. P-047 is currently being developed as a potential treatment for other diseases such as heart failure and angina pectoris.

Robert "Tex" William Richards, Jr. (August 9, 1889 – November 7, 1918) was an American college football player on the University of Pittsburgh Panthers team from 1907 to 1910. He was the captain and fullback of the undefeated and unscored-upon 1910 Pittsburgh Panthers football team, coached by Joseph H. Thompson, and considered by many to be that season's national champion. Early years Richards was the son of Robert William Richards Sr. and Hannah Sarah Richards. Robert Sr., an American of Welsh descent, was a traveling bookseller in the Pacific Rim in the 1880s, when he met a Melbourne school teacher, Hannah Sarah Harrex. They were married in 1888. Jack Shaftoe (also known, at various points, as King of the Vagabonds, L'Emmerdeur, Half-Cocked Jack, Quicksilver, Ali Zaybak, Sword of Divine Fire, and Jack the Coiner) is one of the three primary fictional characters in Neal Stephenson's 2,686-page, Clarke Award-winning epic trilogy, The Baroque Cycle. Born in 1660 to a poor London family, Jack, the youngest of three half-brothers, becomes a mudlark at the age of five, abandoning this then-common criminal enterprise shortly thereafter when his eldest half-brother Dick is drowned during a failed raid on a Dutch galjoot in the Thames. After several years working as an impromptu assistant to men about to be hanged by Jack Ketch from the Treble Tree in Tyburn, Jack leaves England to become a vagabond in continental Europe. Much of The Baroque Cycle concerns Jack's adventures in (among other ports-of-call) England, France, Germany, Austria, The Barbary Coast, Egypt, India, Japan, the Philippines, and Mexico between the years 1683 and 1714.

Calcium ions (Ca2+) contribute to the stability of cellular structures, including the cell membrane and the cytoskeleton. In addition, Ca2+ is a necessary component for the activation of voltage-gated ion channels. Calcium signaling is essential for a wide variety of biological processes, from muscle contraction to nerve impulse transmission. Calcium ions are abundant in the body and are found in all cells. Calcium ions are present in the cytoplasm and play an important role in cellular function by contributing to the stability of cellular structures, including the cell membrane and the cytoskeleton. In addition, calcium ions are needed for the activation of voltage-gated ion channels. Calcium signaling is essential for a wide variety of biological processes, from muscle contraction to nerve impulse transmission. There are two main types of calcium: calcium ionized (Ca2+) and calcium un ionized (Ca+). Ca2+ is more abundant than Ca+ and is responsible for most of the cellular action that is mediated by calcium. Ca2+ can enter cells through several pathways, including diffusion across cell membranes, uptake by endocytosis or exocytosis, and release from intracellular stores. Once inside cells, Ca2+ can bind to proteins or other molecules to form complexes that control cellular functions. One important role of Ca2+ in cells is its role in controlling gene expression. Greg Colson (born April 23, 1956) is an American evangelical Christian apologist and author. He is the founder and president of the Christian apologetics ministry, Apologetics Press. Colson also has a radio program, The Greg Colson Show, which airs on Moody Radio. Colson was born in Newark, New Jersey. He is married to Lynn and they have two children. He earned his B.A. from Wheaton College in Illinois in 1978 and his M.Div. from Fuller Theological Seminary in California in 1983. From 1984 to 1988, Colson was an associate professor of apologetics at Westminster Theological Seminary in California. He also served as director of the apologetics program at the seminary from 1988 to 1992. Since 1992, Colson has been the president of Apologetics Press, a publishing house that specializes in books on apologetics and Christian doctrine. He also has a radio program, The Greg Colson Show, which airs on Moody Radio. In addition, he is a frequent guest on various talk shows and is a contributing editor to "Christianity Today". In 2006, Colson co-authored with Francis Chan The Five Love Languages: How to Express Heartfelt Commitment to Your Mate (Zondervan). The book became a New York Times Bestseller. Alejandro Aguilar Reyes (May 2, 1902 - October 4, 1983) was a Mexican composer and musician. He is considered one of the most important and influential Mexican composers of the 20th century. Alejandro Aguilar Reyes was born in Mexico City on May 2, 1902. He began his musical studies at the age of 10, and later studied at the National Conservatory of Music in Mexico City. In 1925 he won first prize in the National Competition for Chamber Music. Reyes's career as a composer began in 1928, when he won the prestigious National Prize for Music. His first major work, El Amor Brujo (The Witch's Love), was premiered in 1931. In 1935 he won the National Prize for Composition and in 1937 he was awarded the Order of Arts and Letters by President Lázaro Cárdenas. Alejandro Aguilar Reyes died on October 4, 1983. His body was cremated and his ashes scattered at a beach near Acapulco.

Dame Frances Anne Cairncross, (born 30 January 1942) is a British historian. She is a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society and has been a professor at the University of Kent since 1992. Cairncross was born in 1942 in Bath, England, to Scottish parents. She studied history at the University of Edinburgh, where she obtained her doctorate in 1967. She then taught at the universities of Manchester and Liverpool before moving to the University of Kent in 1992. Cairncross's work has focused on European history, with particular emphasis on British history and the history of the Napoleonic Wars. She has written several books on these topics, as well as articles for journals such as the Historical Journal and Historical Review. She has also appeared frequently on television and radio, giving lectures on historical subjects. Cairncross has been married to historian Sir David Cannadine since 1976. They have two children.

Silas Boxley Mason II (October 22, 1879 – April 14, 1936) was an American construction executive and racehorse owner, born in Orange County, Virginia. He was part of a Mason family that had been involved with the construction business since 1827. A graduate of Washington and Lee University and Princeton University, he went on to make the Mason & Hanger company one of the largest construction contractors in the United States. His first high-profile venture came in 1927 when he was awarded the contract for the George Washington Bridge foundation on the New Jersey side. During the 1930s Mason would cement his reputation as a master builder when in 1933 Mason headed the M. W. A. K. consortium (Mason-Walsh-Atkinson, Kier) that built the Grand Coulee Dam in Mason City, Washington. His company would then become involved in the construction of the Lincoln Tunnel. Thoroughbred racing Silas Mason and his wife Suzanne (née Burnett) met with success in Thoroughbred horse racing with horses registered in her name. A native Kentuckian, she was a descendant of Colonel Richard Henderson who, along with General George Rogers Clark, Daniel Boone, and others, were Kentucky pioneers who formed the Transylvania Land Company. The couple purchased a home and breeding farm near Lexington, Kentucky called Duntreath.

Sir George Bowes (21 August 1701 – 17 September 1760) was an English coal proprietor and Whig politician who sat in the House of Commons for 33 years from 1727 to 1760. George Bowes was baptized on 4 September 1701, the youngest son of Sir William Bowes, MP, and Elizabeth Bowes (née Blakiston). The Bowes family had been prominent in County Durham, with their ownership of the estate and castle of Streatlam but in 1713, George's father acquired (from his wife's family) the Gibside estate which included some of the area's richest coal seams and led to the family becoming immensely wealthy through the coal trade. George Bowes inherited the family estates in 1721, including Gibside. Although he was the youngest son, his elder brothers had died young. In October 1724 he married the fourteen-year-old Eleanor Verney, but she died in December of that year. Her death was commemorated in a poem, written by Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, which implied that she had died as a result of Bowes' sexual vigour.

Raymonde Berthoud (24 November 1919 – 27 June 2004) was a French artist, sculptor, and writer. Born in Paris to a Swiss father and French mother, Berthoud grew up in Lausanne and Lyon. After studying at the École des Beaux-Arts in Lyon, she moved to Paris in 1939 to study at the École Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-Arts. There she met the artist Jacques Lipchitz, with whom she would have a long and fruitful collaboration. Berthoud's early work was abstract, but from the late 1950s onwards she turned to sculpture. Her works often combine traditional sculptural techniques with innovative materials and processes. She is particularly known for herinstallations and for her bronzes and terracotta sculptures of animals, often depicting mythical creatures or scenes from mythology. "Pow 2011" (often capitalized as POW 2011) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) and presented by Ford Motor Company. It took place on March 31, 2011 at the Verizon Wireless Arena in Manchester, New Hampshire. The event was the tenth anniversary of the company's premier event, WrestleMania. The card featured wrestlers from Raw, SmackDown, and ECW, with WWE Champion John Cena defending the WWE Championship against CM Punk in a Triple Threat match also involving The Undertaker. Rey Mysterio won the 2010 Royal Rumble match to earn a world title shot at WrestleMania XXVII against Cena. The main event was Triple H and Stephanie McMahon's scripted feud culminating in a Hell In A Cell match at WrestleMania XXVII which Punk successfully defended his championship. Other matches on the card included Big Show and Kane in a rematch from Survivor Series 2010, Kofi Kingston versus R-Truth for the WWE Intercontinental Championship, Big Bossman versus Ted DiBiase for the WWE Legends Championship, and Dolph Ziggler versus Jack Swagger for the World Heavyweight Championship.

Jessica Lussenhop is an American investigative journalist who has reported on organized crime, terrorism, and national security. Lussenhop was born in Utrecht, Netherlands on November 7, 1978. She moved to the United States with her family at the age of three and was raised in New York City. She received her undergraduate degree from Brown University and her master's degree from the Columbia School of Journalism. Lussenhop began her journalism career as a news editor for the online magazine Slate. She later became a staff writer for The New Yorker and a contributing writer for The Atlantic. In 2012, she joined the staff of the investigative news outlet ProPublica as a senior reporter. Lussenhop has reported on organized crime, terrorism, and national security for ProPublica, The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, and other publications. She has also appeared on Fox News Channel, PBS NewsHour, Al Jazeera America, and other networks. In March 2019, Lussenhop was named one of the recipients of the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for Investigative Reporting.

Yana Milev (German: Jana Elisabeth Milev; Bulgarian: Яна Ганчева Милева; Accent: Yána Gáncheva Míleva; born 1969 in Leipzig, GDR) is a German-Swiss cultural theorist, sociologist, ethnographer, and curator. In 2014, she earned habilitation at the University of St. Gallen (HSG), and received the venia legendi for cultural sociology. Life Yana Milev was born in Leipzig, East Germany, the first child of the Bulgarian physician and anthropologist Gancho "Geo" Milev, who had immigrated to the GDR in the early 1960s, and the Leipzig-based translator and interpreter Karin Fahr-Mileva. Upon completing secondary school in what was then still the GDR she began a course of study in scenography and costume design at the Dresden Academy of Fine Arts (HfBK) which she ultimately completed with a diploma conferred after German unification. Thereafter, she undertook postgraduate study as a master student of Günter Hornig. In the final years of the GDR, Milev was active in the country's subcultures. She became known for independent films, performances, and conceptual art.

Brigadier Terence Esmond Maxwell Battersby (29 October 1893 – 10 January 1972) was an English cricketer and British Army officer. Battersby was a left-handed batsman. He was born in Meerut, then in the British Raj, before moving back to England where he was educated at Marlborough College. There he played for the college cricket team. Battersby represented Suffolk in the 1913 Minor Counties Championship, playing a single match against Lincolnshire. Battersby was mentioned in the London Gazette in February 1914 as having graduated from the Royal Military College with the rank of 2nd Lieutenant. After graduating he joined the Prince of Wales's Leinster Regiment who he served in the First World War within the regiments 1st Battalion. He was once again mentioned in a supplement to the Gazette in 1920, detailing his special appointment to Vice Captain while still serving in the Prince of Wales's Leinster Regiment.

Osemozotan (MKC-242) is a selective 5-HT1A receptor agonist with some functional selectivity, acting as a full agonist at presynaptic and a partial agonist at postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors. 5-HT1A receptor stimulation influences the release of various neurotransmitters including serotonin, dopamine, norepinephrine, and acetylcholine. 5-HT1A receptors are inhibitory G protein-coupled receptor. Osemozotan has antidepressant, anxiolytic, antiobsessional, serenic, and analgesic effects in animal studies, and is used to investigate the role of 5-HT1A receptors in modulating the release of dopamine and serotonin in the brain, and their involvement in addiction to abused stimulants such as cocaine and methamphetamine. Pharmacodynamics The target of Osemozotan is 5-HT1A receptors. This molecules bind with almost 1000 times greater affinity to 5-HT1A receptors than most other 5-HT, dopamine, or adrenergic receptors. With repeated exposure of Osemozotan at the 5-HT1A receptors, there seems to be no change in the number of receptors, which is not typically seen with pharmaceutical agonists.
