Howard William Hunter (November 14, 1907 – March 25, 1994) was an American politician and lawyer who served as the 44th Governor of California from 1967 to 1971 and the Republican National Committee chairman from 1970 to 1972. Hunter was born in San Francisco, California, to Ida (née Hill) and Howard Hunter. He attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he received his undergraduate degree in 1931. Hunter then attended the University of Southern California Law School, where he received his law degree in 1935. He began his legal career as a law clerk for Judge Samuel A. Pillsbury of the United States District Court for the Northern District of California. In 1937, Hunter married Dorothy Atherton. The Hunters had three children: Elizabeth Ann (born 1938), Howard W. (born 1940), and Anne (born 1943). Hunter served in World War II as a lieutenant colonel in the United States Army Air Forces. After the war, he returned to private practice in San Francisco. In 1951, Hunter was elected to the California State Assembly, serving until 1954. He then served as deputy attorney general of California under Edmund G. Brown Jr. from 1954 to 1957. In 1962, Hunter was elected Attorney General of California, serving until 1966. While Attorney General, Hunter led the prosecution of members of the Manson Family, including Charles Manson and Susan Atkins, for the murders of actress Sharon Tate and six other people in Los Angeles. Ja Myung Go (; also known as Ja Myung-Go, Ja Myung-Goo, and Ja Myung-Guk) is a retired South Korean professional basketball player. He played at the point guard position. The Other Sister is a 1999 American psychological horror film written and directed by Peter Jackson. It is the sequel to Jackson's debut feature film, Heavenly Creatures (1994), and was filmed in New Zealand. The film stars Kate Winslet and Ralph Fiennes, who reprise their roles from Heavenly Creatures. Other cast members include James Nesbitt, Mare Winningham, and Frances O'Connor. The story is set several years after the events of Heavenly Creatures, and follows the return of Katherine "Kitty" Harrow (Winslet) to her home town of Christchurch, New Zealand. She has been living in London as a successful fashion designer, but returns to find that her sister Juliet (Fiennes) has married and moved away with her new husband. Kitty begins investigating her sister's past, which leads her to discover that she was married to a man who died in a car accident. Kitty begins having nightmares recalling the events of the accident, which cause her mental health to decline. She is eventually admitted to a mental hospital where she meets patient Paul (Nesbitt), who tells her about his wife Lucy (Winningham) who also suffered from nightmares after the accident. Paul suggests that they try and connect with Lucy through dreams in order to help heal Kitty's mind. Meanwhile, Juliet continues to have nightmares about the accident and the death of her husband. She is also being harassed by a man who seems to be following her around town. The

Camarones is a city and commune in the Arica y Parinacota Region in Chile. It forms part of the administrative Arica Province and has a population of 1,220. Its municipality seat is in the town of Cuyo, located next to the Chile Highway 5. Cuyo is the administrative center of the commune and a place of rest for travellers. The main towns are Codpa and Caleta Camarones. The latter is a fishing inlet of only 44 inhabitants. Codpa is the largest town in the commune, located from the city of Arica. It is an entirely rural commune with almost no tourist activity, and is well known for its uncharted areas. The only Afro-Chilean community in Chile is located in Camarones. Demographics According to the 2002 census of the National Statistics Institute, Camarones had 1,220 inhabitants (745 men and 475 women), and it is a rural area. The population grew by 39% (372 persons) between the 1992 and 2002 censuses.

"Fuiste Tú" is a latin pop song by Mexican singer-songwriter, Luis Fonsi. The song was written by Fonsi, Justin Meldal-Johnsen, and Stargate. "Fuiste Tú" was released as the fourth and final single from Fonsi's third studio album, "Escape". "Fuiste Tú" is a latin pop song with a tempo of 128 beats per minute. The song is written in the key of D major and has a basic chord progression of D–G–A–Bm. The lyrics of the song deal with the protagonist's unrequited love for another person. The song was well-received by music critics. Elias Leight of "Entertainment Weekly" called it an "irresistible tropical groove" and wrote that it is "a catchy little number that feels like summer in your earholes." Likewise, Tim Sendra of AllMusic wrote that the song is "infectious" and that Fonsi's vocals are "deliciously smooth." In Mexico, "Fuiste Tú" became Fonsi's third number one single on the Mexican Singles Chart. In Argentina, the song reached number one on the Argentine Singles Chart. In Spain, the song reached number one on the Spanish Singles Chart. In Portugal, the song reached number one on the Portuguese Singles Chart.

American urban history is the study of cities of the United States. Local historians have always written about their own cities. Starting in the 1920s, and led by Arthur Schlesinger, Sr. at Harvard, professional historians began comparative analysis of what cities have in common, and started using theoretical models and scholarly biographies of specific cities. The United States has also had a long history of hostility to the city, as characterized for example by Thomas Jefferson's agrarianism and the Populist movement of the 1890s. Mary Sies (2003) argues: Historiography  American urban history is a branch of the history of the United States and of the broader field of Urban history. That field of history examines the historical development of cities and towns, and the process of urbanization. The approach is often multidisciplinary, crossing boundaries into fields like social history, architectural history, urban sociology, urban geography business history, and even archaeology. Urbanization and industrialization were popular themes for 20th-century historians, often tied to an implicit model of modernization, or the transformation of rural traditional societies.

Dr. Al-Haj Mohamed Purvis Drahaman (5 November 1921 – 5 January 2015) was an Indian-born British biochemist and Nobel laureate who shared the 1980 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with John C. F. Kennedy and Frederick Sanger for their discoveries of the genetic code and its role in protein synthesis. Drahaman was born in India to a Brahmin family, but grew up in England. He studied at Cambridge University, where he became a fellow of Trinity College in 1945. He then worked at the University of Birmingham, before moving to the University of Cambridge, where he became a professor in 1959. Drahaman's work on the genetic code led to his discovery of the process of protein synthesis. His work has had a significant impact on the field of biochemistry, and he has been described as one of the "founding fathers" of molecular biology. Drahaman was also a member of the Royal Society, and received the Copley Medal in 1975 and the Nobel Prize in 1980.

Anti-fungal agent miconazole and the steroid clobetasol both restored movement to mice paralysed by a rodent version of multiple sclerosis -LRB- MS -RRB- . In laboratory tests , they prompted inactive mouse and human stem cells to regenerate myelin , the protective insulation-like coating around nerve fibres that is destroyed by the disease . The discovery could pave the way to ground-breaking new therapies for the devastating auto-immune disease ,

HMS Rodney (pennant number: 29) was one of two s built for the Royal Navy in the mid-1920s. The ship entered service in 1928, and spent her peacetime career with the Atlantic and Home Fleets, sometimes serving as a flagship when her sister ship, , was being refitted. During the early stages of the Second World War, she searched for German commerce raiders, participated in the Norwegian Campaign, and escorted convoys in the Atlantic Ocean. Rodney played a major role in the sinking of the German battleship Bismarck in mid-1941. After a brief refit in the United States, she escorted convoys to Malta and supported the Allied invasion of French Algeria during Operation Torch in late 1942. The ship covered the invasions of Sicily (Operation Husky) and Italy (Operation Baytown) in mid-1943. During the Normandy landings in June 1944, Rodney provided naval gunfire support and continued to do so for several following offensives near the French city of Caen. The ship escorted one convoy through the Arctic to the Soviet Union in late 1944. In poor condition from extremely heavy use and a lack of refits, she was reduced to reserve in late 1945 and was scrapped in 1948.

Marcel Lucien Tournier (January 5, 1879 – May 8, 1951) was a French harpist, composer, and teacher who composed important solo repertory for the harp that expanded the technical and harmonic possibilities of the instrument. His works are regularly performed in concert and recorded by professional harpists, and they are often test pieces for harp-performance competitions. A student of Alphonse Hasselmans at the Paris Conservatory, Tournier won the Second Grand Prize of the Prix de Rome in 1909. He also won the Rossini Prize for Laura et Petrarch. Tournier succeeded his teacher as professor of harp in 1912, holding that position until 1948, training two generations of harpists from France, the United States, other European countries, and Japan. Tournier composed several dozen solos for harp, a number of chamber works that feature the harp prominently, and a few works for piano and for orchestra. Notable students include American harpist and educator Eileen Malone.

Jaikishan Kakubhai "Jackie" Shroff (born 1 February 1958) is an Indian actor and producer who appears in Hindi-language films. He has appeared in over 150 films in a career spanning more than four decades. Shroff is also a producer and has produced several films, including the commercially successful Chandni Chowk to China (2012). Shroff was born in Mumbai, Maharashtra, India to Kakubhai and Hema Shroff. He has two sisters, Geeta and Rupa. Shroff's father was an officer in the Indian Army and later worked as the deputy commissioner of Mumbai police. Jackie's mother was a homemaker. He graduated from Don Bosco High School, Mumbai in 1976. Shroff worked as a clerk at a shipping company before he started his acting career. He made his acting debut in the 1984 Hindi film Tere Bina. He gained critical acclaim for his performance in the 1985 film Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, for which he was awarded the Filmfare Best Male Debut Award. His subsequent roles include Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani (1995), Hum Aapke Hain Koun..! (1994), Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge 2 (1997), Ek Tha Tiger (2007), Kabhi Alvida Naa Kehna (2003) and Chennai Express (2013). In 2016, he appeared in the critically acclaimed biopic Tiger Zinda Hai. Daniel Sexton Gurney (April 13, 1931 – January 14, 2018) was an American racing driver, race car constructor, and team owner who reached racing's highest levels starting in 1958. Gurney won races in the Formula One, Indy Car, NASCAR, Can-Am, and Trans-Am Series. Gurney is the first of three drivers to have won races in Sports Cars (1958), Formula One (1962), NASCAR (1963), and Indy cars (1967), the other two being Mario Andretti and Juan Pablo Montoya. In 1967, after winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans together with A. J. Foyt, Gurney spontaneously sprayed champagne while celebrating on the podium, which thereafter became a custom at many motorsports events. As owner of All American Racers, he was the first to put a simple right-angle extension on the upper trailing edge of the rear wing. This device, called a Gurney flap, increases downforce and, if well designed, imposes only a relatively small increase in aerodynamic drag. At the 1968 German Grand Prix, he became the first driver ever to use a full face helmet in Grand Prix racing.

is a 1977 electro-mechanical (EM) light gun shooter arcade game developed and published by Namco. Players use the rifle-shaped light guns to fire at clay pigeons, represented as flying white dots on a projector screen. There are two that must be shot down in each round, and players only get two bullets to hit them. Bonus points are awarded for shooting the pigeons as soon as they appear, or by destroying both of them with a single bullet. The game was a critical and commercial success, maintaining a presence in arcades into the 1980s. Gameplay Shoot Away is a lightgun shooter arcade game that simulates the sport of skeet shooting. It uses a projector system that projects monochrome images against a panoramic backdrop, designed to resemble a forest clearing. Using the attached lightguns, players have two attempts to shoot at both white targets — representing clay pigeons — that arch across the screen. Both players' scores are shown on an LCD display attached to the gun holsters. There are two difficulty options, "Regular" and "Pro".

In medicine, the mean systemic pressure (mean systemic filling pressure (MSFP)) is defined as the mean pressure that exists in the circulatory system when there is no blood motion. A similar term, mean circulatory filling pressure, (MCFP) is defined as the mean pressure that exists in the combined circulatory system & pulmonary system when there is no blood motion. The value of MSP in animal experimental models is approximately 7 mm Hg. It is an indicator of how full the circulatory system is (i.e. the volume of blood in the system compared to the capacity of the system), and is influenced by the volume of circulating blood and the smooth muscle tone in the walls of the venous system (which determines the capacity of the system). MSP is measured in two ways experimentally, and as a result has two alternative naming conventions. MSFP is measured after clamping the aortic root and the great veins at point of entry to right atrium. On the other hand, MCFP is measured experimentally by briefly inducing cardiac arrest or naturally during cardiac arrest once the blood redistributes. It may also be estimated in vivo using a series of inspiratory holds when a patient is on a mechanical ventilator. It can be used to demonstrate effects of drugs on the venous tone while the circulating blood volume remains constant, or to measure haemodynamic changes during haemorrhage.

Alhadji Waziri Kolo Ibrahim was a Kanuri military general and politician who served as the Prime Minister of Kanem-Bornu from 1963 to 1967 and from 1978 to 1979. He also served as the President of the Kanem-Bornu Supreme Council from 1978 to 1979. Ibrahim was born in the village of Kolo in the upper basin of the River Niger in what is now north-western Nigeria on 5 November 1925. He was educated at the Madina Muslim School in Zinder, before undertaking military training at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst in Britain. After completing his military education, Ibrahim returned to Nigeria and served in the Nigerian army during the Second World War. He fought in the Battle of Keren, during which he was wounded and captured by the British. Ibrahim was later released and returned to Nigeria to serve in the military again. Ibrahim rose through the ranks of the Nigerian military, becoming a colonel in 1957 and a brigadier general in 1961. In 1963, he was appointed Prime Minister of Kanem-Bornu by President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, a post he held until 1967. In 1978, he was elected president of the Kanem-Bornu Supreme Council, a position he held until his death in 1979. Ibrahim is best known for his role as Prime Minister of Kanem-Bornu during the early years of Nigerian independence; during this time, he played an important role in managing relations between Nigeria and its former colony. Zachary Phillip Wylde (born Jeffrey Phillip Wielandt; October 12, 1969), better known by his stage name Zakk Wylde, is an American metal musician, singer, songwriter and record producer. He is the founder and frontman of the metal band Ozzy Osbourne, as well as a former member of Black Sabbath and Heaven and Hell. Wylde has also been a studio musician and producer for several other metal and hard rock bands. Zakk Wylde was born Jeffrey Phillip Wielandt on October 12, 1969, in Des Moines, Iowa. When he was 11 years old, Wylde's family moved to Ozzy Osbourne's home town of Birmingham, England. He began his musical career as the drummer in a punk rock band called Misfits. After several line-up changes, Misfits became the heavy metal band Black Sabbath in 1978. He left Black Sabbath in 1983 to join Heaven and Hell. Wylde rejoined Black Sabbath in 1992 and remained with them until 2006. During his time with Black Sabbath, he released six studio albums and two live albums. In 2006, Wylde formed his own metal band, Zakk Wylde's Ozzfest. Wylde also has a career as a studio musician and producer. He has worked with artists such as Megadeth, Ozzy Osbourne, Whitesnake, Rob Halford of Judas Priest and Iron Maiden, among others. In 2002, he won a Grammy Award for producing the album "Ozzmosis"

Shororipu 2: Jotugriho is a 2021 Indian Kannada-language science fiction film directed by S. S. Rajamouli and written by K. V. Vijayan. It is the sequel to the 2010 film Shororipu and the second installment in the Shororipu series. The story follows a group of scientists who travel to a parallel universe to find a cure for a cancer-like disease, only to find themselves battling an alien threat. Shororipu 2: Jotugriho was announced in October 2018, with S. S. Rajamouli returning as director and K. V. Vijayan writing the screenplay. In January 2019, it was reported that Prachi Desai would play the female lead in the film, with Puneeth Rajkumar and Ramya Krishnan joining the cast later that month. Principal photography began in March 2019 in Mysore and concluded in May 2019.

John "Jack" Silas Reed (October 22, 1887 – October 17, 1920) was an American journalist, poet, and communist activist. Reed first gained prominence as a war correspondent during the Mexican Revolution (for Metropolitan magazine) and World War I (for the magazine The Masses). He is best known for his coverage of the October Revolution in Petrograd, Russia, which he wrote about in his 1919 book Ten Days That Shook the World. Reed supported the Soviet takeover of Russia, even briefly taking up arms to join the Red Guards in 1918. He hoped for a similar Communist revolution in the United States, and co-founded the short-lived Communist Labor Party of America in 1919. He died in Moscow of spotted typhus in 1920. At the time of his death he may have soured on the Soviet leadership, but he was given a hero's burial by the Soviet Union, and is one of only three Americans buried at the Kremlin Wall Necropolis.

Marshall Lee Gore (August 17, 1963 – January 17, 2019) was an American singer-songwriter, musician, and record producer. He was the frontman and primary songwriter of alternative rock band Sonic Youth, and also played in the bands Swans, Dirty Three and The Jesus Lizard. Gore had a prolific solo career that encompassed three albums, as well as numerous collaborations and side projects. Born in Los Angeles, California, to actor-director Tony Lee and sculptor Judy Gore, Marshall Lee Gore began his musical career in the early 1980s as the frontman and primary songwriter of alternative rock band Sonic Youth. The group achieved mainstream success with their 1986 album Sonic Youth (which was nominated for a Grammy Award), as well as their 1988 follow-up EP Goo. In addition to his work with Sonic Youth, Gore also played in the bands Swans, Dirty Three and The Jesus Lizard. His solo career began in 1991 with the release of the album Earth. Gore's subsequent releases include 1995's The Great Sunflower Flood, 1999's Gore Gore Gore!, 2003's Throbbing Gristle and 2007's Sister. Gore was diagnosed with alopecia areata in 2006 and underwent several hair transplants. He died from leukemia on January 17, 2019 at the age of 58.

Ladies' Gaelic football is a women's team sport. It is the women's equivalent of Gaelic football. Ladies' football is organised by the Ladies' Gaelic Football Association. Two teams of 15 players kick or hand-pass a round ball towards goals at each end of a grass pitch. The sport is mainly played in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, where the two main competitions are the All-Ireland Senior Ladies' Football Championship and the Ladies' National Football League. Both competitions feature teams representing the traditional Gaelic games counties. The 2017 All-Ireland Senior Ladies' Football Championship Final was the best attended women's sports final of 2017. The 2019 final, after the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup Final, was the second largest attendance at any women's sporting final during 2019. Historically Cork and Kerry have been the sport's most successful counties. Waterford, Monaghan and Mayo have also experienced spells of success. In more recent years, 2017 to 2020, Dublin have been the dominant team.  Ladies' Gaelic football is also played in Africa, Asia, Great Britain, Canada, Europe, South America, the United States, New Zealand and Australia. Outside of Ireland it is mainly, although not exclusively, played by members of the Irish diaspora. There is also a seven-a-side version of the sport.

Mboka Mwilambwe (born 1970–1971) is an American politician who was elected in 2021 as the first African American mayor of Bloomington, Illinois. Biography Mwilambwe was born in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. His father worked for Unicef and Mwilambwe lived in various countries as a youth with stays in Senegal, Ivory Coast, and the Republic of the Congo. In 1990, he moved to central Illinois to attend Illinois State University earning a B.S. in mathematics in 1994 and a M.S. in education in 1996. After school, he accepted a position as the assistant director of the Office of Equal Access and Opportunity at Illinois State University. In 2008, he became a U.S. Citizen. In 2011, he was appointed by then-mayor Steve Stockton to fill a vacancy in Ward 3 on the Bloomington City Council. He was re-elected to a full four-year term on the City Council in 2013 and 2017. Since 2019, he has served as mayor pro tem.

The Campeonato da Região Serrana, commonly known as the Copa Serrana, is a regional men's association football championship contested by teams from the autonomous region of Serrana, in Portugal. Administered by the Associação Atlética Serrana, it is the second-tier competition below the Portuguese Liga. The first edition of the Copa Serrana was held in 1992. The competition has been played annually since then, with the exception of 2001–02, when it was cancelled due to financial problems. A total of 105 editions have been played, with Porto and Braga as the most successful teams with eight titles each. The current champions are Desportivo das Aves who won their first title in 2018. The competition is divided into two stages. In the first stage, which runs from February to May, teams are divided into groups of six and play each other twice. The top four teams from each group advance to the semi-finals, where they are joined by the fourth-placed team from the Ligurian League and the third-placed team from the Campeonato da Região Norte. The winners of these semi-finals compete in a final to determine the titleholder. In the second stage, which runs from July to October, teams are again divided into groups of six and play each other twice. The Temple of Bel , sometimes also referred to as the "Temple of Baal", was an ancient temple located in Palmyra, Syria. The temple, consecrated to the Mesopotamian god Bel, worshipped at Palmyra in triad with the lunar god Aglibol and the sun god Yarhibol, formed the center of religious life in Palmyra and was dedicated in AD 32. The temple would have been closed during the persecution of pagans in the late Roman Empire in a campaign against the temples of the East made by Maternus Cynegius, Praetorian Prefect of Oriens, between 25 May 385 to 19 March 388.   Its ruins were considered among the best preserved at Palmyra, until they were further destroyed by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria in August 2015. The arched main entrance into the temple is still intact, as well as its exterior walls and fortified gate. History

Jacob Neil "Skip" Stahley (September 22, 1908 – June 27, 1992) was an American college football coach and athletic director. He served as the head football coach at the University of Delaware in 1934, Brown University from 1941 to 1943, George Washington University from 1946 to 1947, the University of Toledo from 1948 to 1949, and the University of Idaho from 1954 to 1961, compiling a career record of 56–85–3. Stahley was the athletic director at Idaho from 1960 to 1964 and Portland State University from 1964 to 1972. Early years Born in Lebanon, Pennsylvania, Stahley was an outstanding athlete at Lebanon High School and graduated He attended Penn State in State College, where he majored in English and played football, earning honorable mention All-American honors. A three-sport letterman, Stahley also captained the basketball and lacrosse teams for the Nittany Lions. He graduated in 1931 and later earned a master's degree from Columbia University.

Katherine Jane Parkinson (born 9 March 1978) is an English actress. She has appeared in several television comedy series, including as Jen Barber in Channel 4's The IT Crowd, for which she received a British Comedy Best TV Actress Award in 2009 and 2014, and for which she was nominated twice for the BAFTA Television Award for Best Female Comedy Performance, winning once in 2014. Parkinson studied at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, and has appeared on stage in the plays The Seagull (2007), Cock (2009), and Home, I'm Darling (2018), for which she was nominated for the Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Play. Additionally, Parkinson was also a main cast member of the series Doc Martin for three series (2005–2009). She co-starred in all three series of Humans, a science-fiction drama on AMC/Channel 4, which aired from 2015 until 2018. She has also appeared in such films as The Boat That Rocked (2009) and The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society (2018).

"Don't Worry Baby" is a song by The Beatles, written by Lennon-McCartney. The song was recorded on 8 February 1963 at EMI Studios in London during the group's first recording session as The Beatles. It was released on the Beatles' first album, Please Please Me, in Britain on 6 May 1963 and in the United States on 10 May 1963. In 2004, Rolling Stone magazine ranked it number 177 on its list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. The song is written in the key of A major and is composed in 4/4 time with a moderate tempo. Lennon and McCartney wrote the song while they were waiting for their wives to give birth; McCartney recalled that "the idea was that the baby would calm us down". The song is about two people who are worried about each other and want to calm down. The lyrics are sung by Lennon in a high-pitched, childish voice and have been described as "a plea for reassurance". The melody is based on a simple AABBCCDD progression.

Cecily Brooke von Ziegesar ( ; born October 5, 1978) is an American author, journalist, and television personality. She also worked as a correspondent for "Travel & Leisure" magazine and as a weekly columnist for "The Daily Mail". Von Ziegesar wrote her first novel, Crazy Rich Asians, in 2013 while living in Singapore. The book was published by Penguin Books and became a New York Times Bestseller. Ryan Boudinot is an American writer. He was born on November 6, 1972, in Saint Croix, United States Virgin Islands. He was educated at Evergreen State College and Bennington College. The latter three have been nominated for the Washington State Book Award. Blueprints of the Afterlife was also nominated for the Philip K. Dick Award and has been published in translation in the Czech Republic and Spain. He edited Seattle, City of Literature, an anthology featuring essays by over thirty writers. Boudinot worked for Amazon as a customer service representative from 1998–2000, during a period when the company went from just selling books to venturing into a myriad other product categories. He was part of a team that launched what became the company's marketplace platform. He returned to Amazon from 2004-2007 as an editor on the DVD team, merchandising releases for movie studios including 20th Century Fox and the Criterion Collection. His technology career has also included editorial positions at Netflix, Microsoft, Expedia, and Immersion Networks.

Jack "Machine Gun Jack" McGurn (born Vincenzo Pietro Giovanni McGurn; October 8, 1928 – May 21, 2002) was an American singer, songwriter and guitarist. He is best known for his hit singles "Louie, Louie" and "Walking the Dog". McGurn was born in Brooklyn, New York. He learned to play the guitar at an early age and began performing in local clubs in the late 1940s. In 1952, he joined the US Air Force and served in Korea during the War in Korea. After his discharge, he resumed his career and released his first album, "Jack McGurn", in 1957. The following year, he recorded "Louie, Louie", which became a number-one hit on the "Billboard" Hot 100 chart. The song was written by Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller and became a popular anthem for the hippie movement. The accompanying film, also titled "Louie, Louie", was released in 1972 and starred Gene Hackman as McGurn. McGurn later recorded other successful singles including "Walking the Dog" (1978), "Love Is a Many Splendored Thing" (1981), and "I Ain't Never Loved a Woman" (1984). In 1986, he made a guest appearance on the Fox sitcom "The Simpsons". He died of lung cancer at age 74 in 2002.

Tarampa State School is a heritage-listed state school at 33-35 Tarampa Street, Tarampa, Shire of Livingstone, Queensland, Australia. It was added to the Queensland Heritage Register on 21 October 1992. Tarampa State School is a heritage-listed state school at 33-35 Tarampa Street, Tarampa, Shire of Livingstone, Queensland, Australia. It was added to the Queensland Heritage Register on 21 October 1992. The first school in Tarampa was a small timber building erected in 1863 by the Sisters of Mercy. In 1876 the government acquired a block of land for a school and in 1881-82 a two-roomed schoolhouse was erected on the site. In 1885 this was replaced by a four-roomed building which still stands. The present school building, erected in 1924, is a substantial single storey timber structure with a hipped roof and verandahs to both the north and south. It features large panelled windows and an elaborate verandah balustrade. The interior has been extensively modified over the years but retains much of its original character. The school has been operated continuously by the State since 1924 and provides educational opportunities for children from the surrounding rural areas.

Konnichiwa is the fourth studio album by British rapper Skepta. The title is the greeting "hello" in the Japanese language. After numerous delays, it was released on 6 May 2016 by Boy Better Know. William "Billy Bass" Nelson (born January 28, 1951) is a U.S. musician, who was the original bassist for Funkadelic. He is a member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, inducted in 1997 with fifteen other members of Parliament-Funkadelic. Career Nelson was born in Plainfield, New Jersey and as a teenager worked at George Clinton's barbershop, sweeping the floor and singing and dancing for the customers. Clinton was a member of the doo wop vocal group the Parliaments, who scored a nationwide hit in 1967 with the song "(I Wanna) Testify". Clinton put together a backing band as musical support for a tour and recruited Nelson, who in turn recommended his friend Eddie Hazel. Nelson and Hazel eventually took on bass and lead guitar roles respectively. The backing band was originally unnamed, but Nelson later coined the name "Funkadelic" to reflect the style (funk) and connect it with the then-burgeoning psychedelic music scene.

Task Force Uruzgan (TFU) was Australia's and the Netherlands' contribution to NATO's Regional Command South, International Security Assistance Force, in Afghanistan. The Dutch lead one of the four Provincial Reconstruction Teams in the southern region of the country. 1,200 to 1,400 Dutch military, mandated by the Dutch Parliament in February 2006, will attempt to maintain order in Uruzgan Province through July 2010. They will also attempt to develop political and economic infrastructure and to train the Afghan police. The unit was located at one Main Operating Base (MOB) and a few smaller Forward Operating Bases (FOB): the MOB was Kamp Holland at Multi National Base Tarin Kot in Tarinkot, the capital of Uruzgan province. There are a few smaller FOBs Camp Hadrian west of Tarinkot near a town called Deh Rahwod, FOB Coyote north of Deh Rawod near a place called Chutu and FOB Phoenix on the west bank of the Helmand river near the town of Tor Nasser.

A number of ancient civilizations, including the Thracians, ancient Greeks, Scythians, Celts, ancient Romans, Goths (Ostrogoths and Visigoths), Slavs (East and West Slavs), Varangians and the Bulgars have left their mark on the culture, history and heritage of Bulgaria. Due to this great variety of influences, Bulgaria has adopted many unusual traditions. Thracian artifacts include numerous temples, tombs, golden treasures and ancient rites and rituals, while ancient Bulgars have left traces of their heritage in statehood, early architecture, music and dances. Thracian rituals such as the Tryphon Zarezan which is dedicated to Saint Tryphon of Campsada, Kukeri and Martenitza are to this day kept alive in the modern Bulgarian culture. The oldest treasure of worked gold in the world, dating back to the 5th millennium BC, comes from the site of the Varna Necropolis. Bulgaria functioned as the hub of Slavic Europe during much of the Middle Ages, exerting considerable literary and cultural influence over the Eastern Orthodox Slavic world by means of the Preslav and Ohrid Literary Schools. Bulgaria also gave the world the Cyrillic script, the second most widely used alphabet and sixth writing system in the world, which originated in these two schools in the tenth century.

The cognitive reflection test (CRT) is a task designed to measure a person's tendency to override an incorrect "gut" response and engage in further reflection to find a correct answer; however, the validity of the assessment as a measure of "cognitive reflection" or "intuitive thinking" is under question. It was first described in 2005 by psychologist Shane Frederick. The CRT has a moderate positive correlation with measures of intelligence, such as the Intelligence Quotient test, and it correlates highly with various measures of mental heuristics. Some research argue that the CRT is actually measuring cognitive abilities (colloquially known as intelligence). Later research showed that the CRT is a multifaceted construct: many start their response with the correct answer, while others fail to solve the test even if they reflect on their intuitive first answer. It has also been argued that suppression of the first answer is not the only factor behind the successful performance on the CRT: numeracy and reflectivity both account for performance.

Pha Mueang (full name Pho Khun Pha Mueang, ; late 13th century – mid 14th century) was a Thai nobleman and general who was the Lord of Rad and played a significant role in the founding of the Sukhothai Kingdom. Origin Pha Mueang is said to be a descendant of Nam Thum, a hero whose name is mentioned in the legends of many Tai peoples. Pha Mueang's ultimate origin is described by his grandfather in the so-called "Ram Khamhaeng": he is the ruler of a city-state called Mueang Rat (เจ้าเมืองราด). The location of Mueang Rat is disputed. Many believe that it could be found in the valley of the Pasak. Therefore, the inhabitants of the Phetchabun district Lom Sak built a large statue of Pha Mueang (อนุสาวรีย์พ่อขุนผาเมือง). The historian Alexander Brown Griswold, however, is of the opinion that Mueang Rat must have been located in the valley of the Nan River near Uttaradit due to geographical characteristics.

William Duncan Silkworth (1873–1951), was an American entrepreneur, philanthropist and political figure. He was a founder of the advertising agency J. Walter Thompson, and served as its chairman from 1923 until his death. Silkworth was born on October 21, 1873 in Red Bank, Monmouth County, New Jersey. He attended the University of Pennsylvania, where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1895. Silkworth then moved to New York City, where he began his advertising career as a copywriter for the advertising firm J. Walter Thompson. He rose through the ranks of the agency, becoming its chairman in 1923. As chairman of J. Walter Thompson, Silkworth played a major role in the development of modern advertising. He is credited with creating the first "modern" advertising campaign for a product, for Johnson Wax's Cleaner Wax (1925). His work at J. Walter Thompson also led to the creation of the "modern" media campaign—a series of individual ads that are designed to create an overall effect on consumers. Silkworth is also credited with creating the concept of "brand name advertising," which is advertising that is specifically directed at promoting a particular brand name rather than simply selling products or services. Silkworth was also involved in politics. He served as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1924 and 1940, and as a member of the New York State Assembly from 1915 to 1917 and from 1921 to 1922. Silkworth died on September 10, 1951 in New York City.

Ultralight backpacking is a subset of backpacking that utilizes lightweight gear and techniques to reduce the weight carried in the pack. Ultralight backpacking can be done with a single backpack or as part of a multi-day backpacking trip. It is a popular form of backpacking for those seeking an extreme camping experience, as well as for thru-hikers and long-distance backpackers who seek to minimize their weight and pack size. Ultralight backpacking typically uses smaller tents, sleeping bags, cooking gear, and other essentials. Many ultralight backpacking trips can be completed with the same amount of gear as standard backpacking trips, but using significantly lighter weight items. This allows for greater mobility and flexibility in the wilderness, making it easier to travel over difficult terrain or to skirt around difficult weather conditions. While there are many different techniques and philosophies associated with ultralight backpacking, a few key principles are common to all forms of lightweight backpacking. These include: carrying only what is necessary, minimizing weight while still providing necessary function and comfort, choosing the right gear for the conditions, and being prepared for whatever might come along. Ultralight backpacking has become increasingly popular in recent years, as more people seek an extreme camping experience as well as the ability to travel lighter and faster in the wilderness. While there are many different approaches to ultralight backpacking, a few key principles are common to all forms of lightweight backpacking: carrying only what is necessary, minimizing weight while

Federal common law is a term of United States law used to describe common law that is developed by the federal courts, instead of by the courts of the various states. The United States is the only country to combine the creation of common law doctrines with a complete federalism, wherein the national supreme court has virtually no power to review state court decisions to determine whether the state courts have followed state laws. The High Court of Australia is sometimes said to have federal common law, but because all state and territorial courts are directly appealable to the High Court, this is indistinguishable from a general common law. In contrast, the United States Supreme Court has effectively barred the creation of federal common law in areas traditionally under the authority of state courts. Nevertheless, there are several areas where federal common law continues to govern. The Swift doctrine Until 1938, federal courts in America followed the doctrine set forth in the 1842 case of Swift v. Tyson. In that case, the United States Supreme Court held that federal courts hearing cases brought under their diversity jurisdiction (allowing them to hear cases between parties from different U.S. states) had to apply the statutory law of the states, but not the common law developed by state courts. Instead, the Supreme Court permitted the federal courts to make their own common law based on general principles of law.

Thomas Volney Munson (September 26, 1843 – January 21, 1913), often referred to simply as T.V. Munson, was a horticulturist and breeder of grapes in Texas.  In 1888, Munson was the second American, after Thomas Edison, to be named a Chevalier du Mérite Agricole by the French government. Background Thomas Volney Munson was born in Astoria, Illinois. He was a son of William Munson (1808-1890) and Maria (Linley) Munson (1810-1890). Munson was an 1870 graduate of the University of Kentucky. Shortly after completing his education, he married and moved to the vicinity of Lincoln, Nebraska. In 1873 he became interested in improving the various species of grapes native to the United States and planned to do systematic work in the way of developing new varieties by cross-pollination and hybridization. His experiments failed because of climatic rigors and a visitation of the Rocky Mountain locusts. Undismayed, in April 1876 Munson moved to Denison, Texas, where two of his brothers had already relocated.

David Klimi Babayan (, Davit' Klimi Babayan; born October 9, 1974 in Yerevan, Armenia) is an Armenian-American businessman and entrepreneur. He is the co-founder and CEO of SocialBee, a social media management company. He also founded Dikart, an online marketplace for buying and selling used goods and services. Babayan was born in Yerevan, Armenia to a family of artists and designers. His father, David Babayan, was an artist who created posters for the Soviet Union's national soccer team. His mother, Meri Babayan, was a designer who worked on theatrical sets and costumes. Babayan grew up in the Soviet Union and Armenia. He graduated from the Yerevan State Academy of Fine Arts in 1998 with a degree in graphic design. He then moved to the United States to study at the Rhode Island School of Design. Babayan started his career as a graphic designer in 1998. He co-founded SocialBee, a social media management company, in 2008. He also founded Dikart, an online marketplace for buying and selling used goods and services, in 2012. Babayan has been named one of the 50 Most Influential Armenians of All Time by Forbes magazine. He has also been awarded honorary degrees from Brown University (2011) and Cornell University (2015).

Leitrim County Council is the authority responsible for local government in County Leitrim, Ireland. The council consists of 23 members who are elected to represent the various electoral divisions in the county. The council operates from two main offices located in Carrick-on-Shannon and Ballina. Leitrim County Council was formed on 1 January 2001 as a result of the Local Government (Ireland) Act 1998 which amalgamated the former Leitrim County Board of Management with the District Councils of Carrick-on-Shannon and Ballina. The council is governed by a chairman, vice-chairman, secretary and nine other directors who are elected by the council from among its members for a term of four years. The current chairman is Noel Canavan and the deputy chairman is Noel Doherty. The council is responsible for a wide range of local services including road maintenance, housing, health, social welfare, education and public transport. It also has responsibility for environmental protection and strategic planning. The county is divided into six electoral divisions which are Carrick-on-Shannon, Ballina, Castlerea, Kilmacrennan, Loughrea and Mohill.

Helmut Freiherr von Verschuer (born 6 December 1926), sometimes referred to as Helmut van Verschuer in Dutch, was a European civil servant who was a high-ranking official of the European Commission from 1958 until 1987. He was born in Tübingen. A member of the noble Dutch Verschuer family, which was closely connected to the Trott zu Solz family, Verschuer attended the Musterschule in Frankfurt. He then studied agriculture at the Technical University of Munich and the University of Giessen, and earned an M.Sc. in agriculture in 1950 and a PhD in agriculture at the University of Göttingen in 1956. He was a civil servant in the Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture in West Germany from 1952 to 1958. He was also a member of the West German permanent delegation to the negotiations on a European agricultural union 1952–1954 and participated in the Val Duchesse negotiations on the Rome Treaties, their compatibility with the GATT, and the free-trade area (1956–1958).

It is primarily influenced by American and European jazz styles, and has been described as "a melodic and harmonic fusion of Armenian folk music and jazz." Armenian jazz musicians have been able to fuse their traditional music with the jazz style to create a unique form of music. "The Farnsworth Parabox" is the fifteenth episode of the fourth season of the American science fiction television series "Doctor Who", which was first broadcast on BBC One on December 16, 2009. The Doctor, Amy, and Rory land in a desolate landscape where they are met by a group of people led by a woman called Cassandra. They tell the Doctor that they have been waiting for him, and he is shocked to learn that he has been gone for six months. The group explains that the area around them is a prison, and the people inside are being held against their will by an alien creature known as the Beast. The Doctor finds a way into the Beast's prison and defeats it, freeing the prisoners. He returns to Cassandra and her people, who thank him for his help. The Doctor says that he will return next year and leaves them to their lives. The episode was written by showrunner Steven Moffat and directed by Rachel Talalay. It is based on the short story "The Beast Below" by Neil Gaiman. The episode introduces the character of Cassandra (played by Jemma Redgrave), who becomes a recurring character in later episodes of the series. The episode also features appearances by both David Tennant as the Tenth Doctor and Catherine Tate as River Song. Critical reaction to "The Farnsworth Parabox" was mixed, with some reviewers praising its action sequences and Gaiman-based story while others finding its plot formulaic and its characters one-dimensional. Mangala Pinsiri Samaraweera (21 April 1956 – 7 July 2015) was a Sri Lankan cricketer who played for the country in three cricket World Cups. He also played first-class cricket for Sri Lanka and the Tamil Nadu cricket team. Mangala Pinsiri Samaraweera was born in 1956 in Colombo. He attended the Royal College, Colombo and played cricket for the school team, before being picked up by the Sri Lankan national side. He made his Test debut in December 1977 against India, taking 7/198 in Sri Lanka's first innings and helping them to victory. He went on to play 55 Test matches, taking 338 wickets with a best performance of 7/148. He also played 38 ODIs and 22 T20Is, taking 269 wickets with a best performance of 6/36. He played for Sri Lanka in three Cricket World Cups, making his debut in 1982. He took 5/57 against England in the 1984 World Cup, and claimed 4/25 against Australia in the 1996 World Cup. He also played first-class cricket for Sri Lanka and the Tamil Nadu cricket team. Mangala Pinsiri Samaraweera died on 7 July 2015, aged 57.

New Henniker Bridge or New Bridge was a covered bridge in West Hopkinton, New Hampshire, which carried Henniker Road over the Contoocook River. The truss bridge was completed in 1863, and was the second bridge on the site. The original stone arch bridge was built in 1845 and was washed away by flood in 1852. The bridge was just over wide and long, and consisted of a single span supported by two triple lattice trusses resting on granite abutments. The patent drawings show an all-timber truss with fixed intersection angles in the center of the span. At the ends of the span the angles of the diagonals vary. The end post is vertical, and each brace further from it is sloped a little more. In 1935 the bridge had sustained damage during a flood and was repaired. The bridge was utilized until 1936 when a steel truss bridge was built adjoining it to the north and ready for traffic. The covered bridge was then destroyed.

Voula Zouboulaki (; born Paraskevi Zouboulaki; 24 December 1951) is a Greek actress, singer and television personality. Zouboulaki was born in Athens, Greece, on 24 December 1951. She studied acting at the Drama School of the National Theatre of Greece. Zouboulaki began her acting career in the early 1970s, appearing in a number of theatre productions before making her feature film debut in the 1973 thriller film "The Bitter Tea of General Yen". She followed this with a role in the 1975 comedy film "The Wedding Banquet". Zouboulaki's breakthrough came in 1978 with her performance as Vicky in the successful TV series "Kontra Nikitas". The series ran for six seasons and earned Zouboulaki several awards, including a nomination for Best Actress at the 1980 Academy Awards. She also appeared in the 1986 television miniseries "The Fall of Constantinople". Zouboulaki has since starred in a number of successful films and television programmes, including the 1991 comedy-drama "The Erotic Adventures of Felix Baumgartner" and the 1996 mystery-thriller "The Net". She has also released several albums of Greek pop music. Zouboulaki has been married to actor Costas Kalogeropoulos since 1982. They have two children.

"Papi" is a song recorded by American singer Jennifer Lopez for her seventh studio album Love? (2011). The lyrical content of the song revolves around Lopez's love to dance for her man. The song was due to be released as a promotional single to help promote the album on April 19, 2011, but the song was unlocked and released on April 17, 2011, through a campaign on Lopez's Facebook page. "Papi" received praise from music critics, stating that it was one of the highlights from Love? "Papi" received a full commercial release as Love?s third single in September and October 2011. On October 27, 2011 "Papi" became Lopez's 11th number one single on the Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs Chart. A music video was released for the song and it was directed by Paul Hunter, who had previously worked with her for videos including her 2000 hit "Love Don't Cost a Thing". The plot of the video involves Jennifer Lopez eating a mysterious love cookie, and the next morning a mob of men go crazy for her, chasing her all over the city. The song was also used as the opening number of Miss Earth 2011.

Ola Skjåk Bræk (4 February 1912 in Sør-Varanger – 31 October 1997) was a Norwegian author and artist. He was born in Sør-Varanger, and grew up in the village of Hommelvik. He completed his secondary education in 1930, and then studied art at the Norwegian National Academy of Crafts and Design from 1933 to 1936. He worked as an artist in Sogndal from 1936 to 1940, and then moved to Oslo. In Oslo, he was a member of the artists' group "Kritisk realisme" from 1945 to 1948. He was also a member of the literary association "Norsk Forfatterforening" from 1947 to 1950. He wrote children's books, poetry, stories, and novels. His children's books include "Kjærlighetens fjell" from 1956, "Svartnivået" from 1958, and "Lillemor i vinterlandet" from 1961. His poetry includes the collections "Fuglenes dikt" from 1945, "Friheten" from 1947, and "Det vakre land" from 1953. His stories include "Mannen som var blitt kjendt under et annet navn" from 1951, "Kjempehamlet" from 1954, and "Den store ulykken" from 1957. American singer Stacey Q has released five studio albums, one compilation album, one extended play, thirteen singles, four promotional singles, and six music videos. It debuted at number fifty-nine on the US Billboard 200 and was certified gold in the United States. The first single released from the album was "Two of Hearts", which was praised by critics and was a commercial success. The second single, "We Connect" was also successful, peaking at number thirty-five on the Hot 100 chart. Dorothea Flock (or the Flockin) (1608 – 17 May 1630), was a German woman convicted of witchcraft in Bamberg and a victim of the Bamberg witch trials during the reign of Prince-Bishop Johann Georg Fuchs von Dornheim. Biography Dorothea Flock was born in the city of Nuremberg. She was the second wife of Bamberg’s councilor Georg Heinrich Flock. Their house was in Bamberg, Lange Straße 32. Already his first wife Apolonia had been executed for witchcraft in May 1628. Based on an anonymous accusation Dorothea was arrested in December 1629 and imprisoned for alleged adultery. She escaped from custody but shortly afterwards she was caught again. This time she was accused of witchcraft. Georg Heinrich Flock fled to Protestant Nuremberg to the relatives of his wife. The Hofmanns were a respected, wealthy and influential merchant family there. Together with them Georg Heinrich Flock hoped to free his wife Dorothea, who was heavily pregnant.

Steven Rumbelow (also credited as Steve Rumbelow, Steven Rumbelow, and Steve Rumbelow, Jr.) is an American screenwriter and television producer. Rumbelow has worked as a writer on both episodic television and feature films. He is known for his work on the HBO series "The Leftovers" and the feature film "Mojave". He has also been involved in the development of several other television series, including "Westworld" and "The Crown". Rumbelow was born in Torrance, California. He grew up in Malibu and attended Santa Monica College. After college, he moved to New York City to pursue a career in writing. He began his career writing for television shows, including "NYPD Blue" and "Law & Order". In 2002, Rumbelow wrote and directed the short film "Five O'Clock Girl". The film was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Short Film. In 2006, Rumbelow began working on the HBO series "The Leftovers". The series is based on the novel of the same name by Tom Perrotta. The series follows the residents of a small town in New York after they are abruptly evacuated to Australia after a global cataclysmic event forces them to confront their faith. Vijay Benedict is an Indian former Bollywood playback singer who provided playback for over 35 Bollywood films in the 1980s and early 1990s. Career He made his debut as a singer for the hit 1982 film Disco Dancer singing the popular title song "I Am a Disco Dancer" for actor Mithun Chakraborty. The film's director was Babbar Subhash and music director was Bappi Lahiri. He was frequently used as the playback singer for films starring Mithun Chakraborty which were directed by Babbar Subhash and music by Bappi Lahiri. He also worked with other music directors like Laxmikant Pyarelal, Anand–Milind and Nadeem-Shravan and sang for other actors like Govinda, Jackie Shroff and Aamir Khan. He has sung duets with female singers like Alisha Chinai, Asha Bhosle, Kavita Krishnamurthy, Parvati Khan, and male singers like Amit Kumar and Kumar Sanu. His career as a playback singer lasted for 10 years from 1982 to 1992. He is currently a gospel singer.

William Harvey Unga (born January 18, 1987) is an American actor, singer, and songwriter. He is known for his roles as Tim on the Nickelodeon series "iCarly" and J.D. Payne on the ABC Family series "The Fosters". Unga was born in Los Angeles, California, to Pemba and Harvey Unga. His father is a Ugandan immigrant and his mother is of Irish and Italian descent. Unga has two younger sisters, Stella and Stella Mae. Unga's parents divorced when he was young. Unga started his career as a child actor appearing in various commercials and television shows. He made his feature film debut in the drama film "A Thousand Words" (2004). In 2007, he appeared as Tim on the Nickelodeon series "iCarly". The show ran for four seasons from 2007 to 2011. In 2010, he appeared as J.D. Payne on the ABC Family series "The Fosters". The show has been renewed for a fifth season which premiered in January 2018. Unga released his debut album, "Awake", in February 2017. The album features guest appearances from Demi Lovato, Selena Gomez, and Skylar Grey among others.

Luis Manuel Miquilena Hernández (July 29, 1919 – November 24, 2016) was a Venezuelan politician. He was involved in politics in the 1940s, and again after the 1958 restoration of democracy, but retired from politics in 1964 until the early 1990s, pursuing a career in business. He was then an early supporter of Hugo Chávez' post-1992 political career, and was the Venezuelan Minister of Interior and Justice from 2001 to 2002, when he resigned. First political career Miquilena began his political career with the Venezuelan Communist Party (PCV) in the 1940s as Secretary General of the Union of Bus Drivers (Spanish: Sindicato de Autobuseros), allied with President Isaías Medina Angarita. He remained with the PCV for the next four years. Later, he became a firm opponent of president Rómulo Betancourt (first presidency 1945-1948). In 1945, he broke with the PCV over their support of Betancourt and formed his own political party, the Revolutionary Party of the Proletariat (PRP). The PRP was short-lived, lasting from the overthrow of the Gallegos government (in office February 1948-November 1948) until the rise of Marcos Pérez Jiménez.

Professor David William Kissane, AC (born 1951) is an Australian psychiatrist specialising in psychiatric oncology and palliative care. Since 2018, he has been the inaugural Chair in Palliative Medicine Research at the University of Notre Dame Australia. He has also held professorships at the University of Melbourne (Foundation Professor and Director of Palliative Medicine, 1996–2003), Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City (Chairman, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences and inaugural Jimmie C. Holland Chair in Psychiatric Oncology, 2003–2012; concurrently Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Medical College of Cornell University), and Monash University (Head, Department of Psychiatry, 2012–2019). In 2008, he received the Arthur M. Sutherland Award of the International Psycho-Oncology Society (IPOS). On 26 January 2018 he was appointed a Companion of the Order of Australia. He is the Regent of the Australian Subpriory of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. Professor Kissane has been described as a "strident opponent of euthanasia legislation who co-authored a landmark report with Dr Nitschke into the deaths that occurred under the NT's euthanasia laws". He is the older brother of the Australian writer Andy Kissane. In May 2020, he was awarded a AU$1.06 million grant for a research project on improving the care of palliative care patients with mental illness or emotional distress.

Helene Khatskels (, 25 July 1882 – 10 November 1965) was a Belgian painter and sculptor. She was the daughter of painter Louis Khatskels and sister of sculptor Emile Khatskels. Born in Ghent, Helene Khatskels began her artistic training at the age of 14 with her father. She exhibited her first work at the age of 18 and two years later won a scholarship to study at the Académie Royale des Beaux-Arts in Brussels, where she met her future husband, sculptor Jacques Lipchitz. In 1906 she became a member of the Société Nationale des Beaux-Arts. Helene Khatskels' early works were characterized by their Realist style, which she adopted in order to depict the everyday life of her hometown Ghent. Her later works, which include sculptures as well as paintings, are more abstract and depict concepts such as nature, movement and light. She is best known for her allegorical paintings representing female figures such as The Lady with the Ermine (1932), The Bride (1937) and The Muses (1948). Helene Khatskels died in 1965 in Brussels. Her work is exhibited in museums around Belgium and abroad, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York City and the Tate Gallery in London.

Gwyn Owain Jones (29 March 1917 – 3 July 2006) was a Welsh physicist and academic, who moved from being a professor at the University of London to become director of the National Museum of Wales. Life Jones was born in Cardiff on 29 March 1917. He was educated at Port Talbot Grammar School and Monmouth School before winning a Meyricke scholarship to Jesus College, Oxford to study physics. He graduated in 1939 and became a Research Fellow at the University of Sheffield, obtaining his PhD on the physics of glass. (He published Glass in 1956.) He became a member of the secret British nuclear weapons research programme, code-name Tube Alloys, in 1942, moving back to Oxford in 1946 as a Nuffield Foundation Research Fellow at the Clarendon Laboratory before becoming Reader in Experimental Physics (1949) and then Professor of Physics (1953) at Queen Mary College in the University of London.

Amira Kiziamina, known better by his stage name Kalash Criminel, is a French rapper. He and his family arrived in Rougemont, in Sevran and have been living there since. Rockwell Gardens was a Chicago Housing Authority (CHA) public housing project located in the East Garfield Park neighborhood on the Near West Side of Chicago, Illinois, United States. It was the first public housing development in the United States to be constructed using both federal and state funds. The original structures were designed by Nicol & Nicol and covered . 1,126 units were built, located approximately west of the Chicago Loop, bordered by Madison Street, Van Buren Street, Western Avenue, and Rockwell Street. Operation Clean Sweep In the late 1980s, Rockwell Gardens was a part of Chicago's "Operation Clean Sweep." This was a comprehensive government and police operation to clear city housing projects of the rampant gang activity, drug dealers, and other violent criminals who were a constant problem. The ultimate failure of this (and previous) cleanup programs eventually led to the Chicago Housing Authority's plan in the 1990s to demolish and redevelop city projects.

Sarah McInerney (born 2 April 1981) is an Australian actress and singer. She is best known for her roles in the Australian television series "Sons and Daughters" (2007–2008), the American drama series "The O.C." (2003–2007) and the British soap opera "EastEnders" (2002–2003). Born in Melbourne, McInerney began her acting career at the age of six, appearing in guest roles on Australian television programs. She made her feature film debut in the comedy-drama "The Castle" (2004), and subsequently appeared in the horror films "The Devil's Rejects" (2005) and "Drag Me to Hell" (2009). McInerney has also had starring roles in the romantic comedies "Love Actually" (2003) and "The Break-Up" (2006), and the psychological thriller "The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas" (2008). In 2010, she appeared in the biographical drama film "Guinea Pig", and co-starred in the comedy-drama film "We're The Millers". McInerney has since starred in the mystery thriller film "Shadow Divers" (2012) and the science fiction film "Ender's Game" (2013).

Commander Gordon Bridson, (2 December 1909 – 6 December 1972) was a New Zealand swimmer who won two silver medals at the 1930 British Empire Games. He was also in the New Zealand Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve and in the Second World War, he served in the Royal New Zealand Navy. Seconded to the Royal Navy in 1940, he commanded a minesweeper vessel that accompanied coastal convoys along the English Channel. He was later the commander of the minesweeper which, with her sister ship Moa, sunk the Japanese submarine I-1 off Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands. Early life Gordon Bridson was born in Wellington in New Zealand on 2 December 1909. His parents were William Bridson, a manager, and Agnes Bridson . The Bridson family later moved to Auckland where he grew up. He was educated at Auckland Grammar School up to six form level. He then started working at a metal merchant. He began his naval career in 1927 by enlisting in the Auckland Division of the New Zealand Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve (RNVR) in Auckland. He quickly progressed to being a commissioned officer.

Branislav Pipović (born 10 May 1959) is a Serbian actor and theatre director. Pipović was born in Belgrade, SR Serbia, Yugoslavia. He studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Belgrade, graduating in 1982. He started his acting career in the late 1970s, appearing in plays by Miroslav Krleža and Vuk Karadžić. His breakthrough came in the early 1980s with roles in the films Košutnjak (1981) and Dobro jutro, mora biti dobro (1981). He has since appeared in a number of films and television series, most notably as Dragan Pajić in the television series Prvi put (1991-2000), Dragan Dabić in the television series Mladić (2004-2006), and Jovan Drakulić in the television series Vukovi i vitezovi (2016). In 2005 he won a Best Actor Award at the Zagreb Film Festival for his performance as Ivan Crnojević in the film Otkrivenje. Pipović has also been involved in theatre, directing plays by Krleža and Karadžić as well as his own works. In 1993 he founded the National Theatre Belgrade, which he directed until 2002. In 2006 he founded the National Theatre Novi Sad, which he directed until 2016.

Guadalupe Bracho Pérez-Gavilán (; 16 April 1903 – 10 November 1998) was a Mexican actress who is considered one of the most important and influential actresses in the history of Mexican cinema. When she was just a toddler, her family moved to Mexico City where she began her theatrical career. Palma made her film debut in 1922 in the silent film Como matar a una bruja (How to Kill a Witch), which was directed by her father and starred her mother. Palma became one of Mexico's most popular actresses during the Golden Age of Mexican cinema, appearing in more than sixty films between 1929 and 1946. Her best-known films include El beso de la mujer lobo (The Kiss of the Wolf Woman), La casa del cazador (The Hunter's House), La dama del agua (Lady of the Water), and La dueña de la casa (The Mistress of the House). Palma also appeared in several American films during this period, including The Awful Truth (1937) and Stage Door Canteen (1943). He is also a television presenter, best known for hosting the popular show "What Does That Mean?" on CBC Television. David Grainger was born in Hamilton, Ontario in 1958. He then attended the School of Visual Arts in New York City, where he earned a Master of Fine Arts degree in 1984. Grainger began his career as a designer with Young & Rubicam in Toronto. He later moved to Los Angeles, where he worked as a television producer and director for shows such as "The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson" and "Late Night with David Letterman". In 1996, Grainger founded the David Grainger School of Design and Technology in Hamilton. The school offers undergraduate and graduate programs in graphic design, web design, advertising and marketing, interior design, fashion design, film and television production, and business administration. André Oliveira Farias (born February 10, 1979), commonly known as André, is a Brazilian retired footballer who played as a defensive midfielder. André Oliveira Farias started his professional career at Coritiba Foot Ball Club in 1997. He won the Campeonato Carioca in his first season with the club. In 2000, he moved to Atlético Mineiro. With Atlético Mineiro, he won the Copa Libertadores in 2002 and the Intercontinental Cup in 2003. He also played in the 2003 FIFA World Cup. In 2004, he joined Valencia CF and helped them win the Spanish Cup and the UEFA Champions League. He then returned to Atlético Mineiro. In 2006, André signed for Chelsea FC and helped them win the Premier League and FA Cup. He also played in the 2006 FIFA World Cup. After Chelsea FC, André signed for AC Milan but he only played one season with them before retiring in 2007. André is currently a football manager with Atlético Mineiro.

Highway 3 (AR 3, Ark. 3, Hwy. 3) is a north–south state highway in the U.S. state of Arkansas. The highway runs from the Texas state line near Texarkana, to the Mississippi state line near Camden. Highway 3 is a major east–west route in Arkansas, connecting the cities of Texarkana and Little Rock. It also provides access to several tourist attractions in the state, including the Natural State Park and Arkansas River museums. The route is designated as a scenic byway and has several large bridges over major waterways. A total of of Highway 3 are designated as part of the National Highway System. Highway 3 was designated as a state highway in 1929, running from US 67 west of Texarkana to US 71 near Camden. The route was extended to its present length in 1937. The section between Texarkana and Camden was bypassed by the construction of Interstate 30 in the 1970s.

"The Damage" is a song by British rock band Muse. It was released as the lead single from the band's fifth studio album, Drones (2015). "The Damage" is a three-minute and forty-two-second song written by Muse frontman Matt Bellamy and produced by the band. The song is about the damage that can be caused by war and violence. Bellamy said: "I wanted to write a song about the devastation that war and violence can cause, and how they can leave behind a trail of destruction. It's an important message, and I hope people can listen to it and think about what they can do to help stop these things from happening." The song was first played during the first leg of Muse's The 2nd Law World Tour in 2014. It was later performed at the 2015 Glastonbury Festival along with "The Unforgiving" and "Unnatural Selection". The song received mixed reviews from music critics. Some praised its heavy instrumentation and lyrics, while others found it derivative of Muse's previous work. However, it became Muse's most popular single in mainland Europe, and reached number two on the UK Singles Chart. The song has been certified silver by the British Phonographic Industry for sales of over 300,000 copies in the UK. Irrigation games are cooperative games which model real-world irrigation problems. Players must cooperate to allocate water resources among crops, and make strategic decisions about which crops to water, when to water them, and how much water to supply. Irrigation games have a long and storied history. The first irrigation game was probably played in India in the 6th century BC. In modern times, the most famous irrigation game is probably chess, which has been played for centuries across the world. Irrigation games are a particularly interesting form of cooperative game because players must work together to achieve common goals. Players must decide which crops to water, when to water them, and how much water to supply. Players also need to make strategic decisions about which crops to water, in order to maximize their crop yield. Irrigation games can be quite challenging. Players must coordinate their actions in order to achieve the best results. If players fail to cooperate, the game can quickly become chaotic and difficult to play. Despite their challenges, irrigation games are rewarding experiences. Players learn how to cooperate and make strategic decisions. They also develop skills such as problem solving and critical thinking. Irrigation games are a fun way to spend a few hours and enjoy a challenging game experience. If you're interested in trying out an irrigation game for yourself, be sure to check out some of the available options online.

Ingolf Ulrich Dalferth (born 9 July 1948) is a philosopher of religion and theologian. His work is regarded as being on the methodological borderlines between analytic philosophy, hermeneutics and phenomenology, and he is a recognized expert in issues of contemporary philosophy, philosophy of religion, and philosophy of orientation. From 2007 to 2020 Dalferth held the Danforth Chair in Philosophy of Religion at Claremont Graduate University. From 1998 to 2012 he served as the Director of the Institute of Hermeneutics and Philosophy of Religion at the University of Zürich. Since 2013 he is professor emeritus at the University of Zurich, since 2020 professor emeritus at Claremont Graduate University. From 2000 to 2020 he was editor-in-chief of the journal Theologische Literaturzeitung (Leipzig, Germany), of the book series Religion in Philosophy und Theology (Tübingen, Germany) and of the book series Claremont Studies in the Philosophy of Religion, from 1996-2018 also editor of the Hermeneutische Untersuchungen zur Theologie (Tübingen, Germany).

Newport News Park, in Newport News, Virginia, is the largest park in the system of municipal parks maintained by the Newport News Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism. At 8,065 acres (32.63 km²), it is one of largest city-run parks in the United States, and offers a wide range of activities for residents and tourists alike. The park is in the northern part of the city of Newport News (13560 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News VA 23603), with its main entrance on Jefferson Avenue to the northwest of its intersection with Ft. Eustis Boulevard. Farther up Jefferson Avenue is the entrance to its campsite. To the northeast of the intersection, on Ft. Eustis Boulevard, is the secondary entrance at Old Stable Road, and farther up Ft. Eustis Boulevard is the main entrance for the Newport News Golf Club at Deer Run, which is on park grounds. The park shares a long border with the Colonial National Historical Park, and several of its biking and hiking trails cross into it.

Eric "Rick" C. R. Hehner (born 16 September 1960) is a Canadian-born American journalist and author who has been a senior editor at The New Republic since 2005. Hehner was born in Toronto, Ontario, Canada to an American father, Richard Hehner, and a Canadian mother, Shirley Hehner. He graduated from the University of Toronto with a B.A. in Political Science in 1982. Hehner began his journalism career as a staff writer at the Montreal daily newspaper La Presse in 1985. In 1990, he moved to The Washington Post, where he served as a national political correspondent for two years and then as the paper's Jerusalem bureau chief from 1993 to 1995. Hehner joined The New Republic as its senior editor in 2005. In this capacity, he has been responsible for overseeing the magazine's editorial coverage of U.S. politics and foreign policy. He has also written articles for The New Republic on a range of subjects, including the U.S. presidency, presidential campaigns, and the War on Terror. Hehner is married to the journalist Jennifer Rubin, with whom he has two children.

William Henry Wehrung (March 22, 1861 – September 30, 1934) was an American businessman and politician in the state of Oregon. A native Oregonian, he was a cabinetmaker, banker, and merchant in Hillsboro, Oregon. A member of the Democratic Party, he served in the Oregon State Senate and was a longtime member of the Hillsboro city council. Early life William Wehrung was born on March 22, 1861, in Washington County, Oregon, at Hillsboro. His father Henry was a cabinet builder and merchant who immigrated to Oregon in 1852 from France, and his mother was Mary Catherine (née Emerick) Wehrung who moved to Oregon in 1848. Henry helped build the first courthouse in Hillsboro, and also built the Tualatin Hotel, the first hotel in Hillsboro, where William was born. William, one of four children in the family, was raised in Hillsboro on the family farm and attended the public schools in that city.

Lauren Cohan (born ) is a British-American actress best known for her role as Maggie Greene in the AMC post-apocalyptic horror television series The Walking Dead (2011–2018; 2020–present). Her other notable TV roles include Bela Talbot in the dark fantasy drama Supernatural (2007–2008), Rose in the supernatural teen drama The Vampire Diaries (2010–2012), Vivian McArthur Volkoff in the action comedy Chuck (2011), and Francesca "Frankie" Trowbridge in the action comedy-drama Whiskey Cavalier (2019). Her film appearances include the comedy Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (2006), the psychological thriller horror The Boy (2016), the biographical drama All Eyez on Me (2017), and the action thriller Mile 22 (2018). Early life Cohan was born Lauren Storholm in Cherry Hill, New Jersey, to American father Paul Storholm and Scottish mother, Susan Cohan (née Moorhouse), who are now divorced. She was raised in New Jersey until age 13, when her family moved to her mother's native United Kingdom, settling in Surrey. In addition to Cherry Hill, Cohan lived for one year in the state of Georgia before her family moved to the UK.

The Regreg War (often erroneously called the Regreg Rebellion) was a civil war fought by the Regreg people of Regreg against the Dominion of Gorgon, which lasted from 2261 to 2272. The Regreg people were a peaceful, agricultural people who lived on the planet Regreg in the Regreg system. In 2261, the Dominion of Gorgon invaded Regreg and declared it part of their empire. The Regreg people resisted, but were no match for the Dominion's military. The war lasted for two years and ended in a victory for the Dominion. The Regreg people were forced to become slaves and live in Gorgon's capital city, Triton. In 2272, a group of freedom fighters called the Redeemers emerged and began fighting against Gorgon. The Redeemers were successful in liberating many planets from Gorgon's control, and by 2279 they had liberated Triton as well. The Redeemers then began planning an assault on Gorgon's capital city, Triton II. The assault began on Triton II in 2281, and was successful. The Regreg people were freed and returned to their home planet. The Redeemers continued to fight against Gorgon after the war, eventually defeating him and restoring freedom to many planets.
