Lieutenant General Stanisław Maczek (; 31 March 1895 in Warsaw – 16 February 1967 in Warsaw) was a Polish Army general and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the Polish Republic from 1944 to 1947. Maczek was born in Warsaw on 31 March 1895 into a conservative noble family. After completing his secondary education he studied at the Military Academy of Pruszków. He fought in World War I on the Russian Front, reaching the rank of lieutenant colonel. After the war he continued his military career, serving in the Polish Army's General Staff and rising to the rank of general. In 1938, he became the Deputy Inspector-General of Military Training. In September 1939, following Poland's invasion of western Poland, Maczek became Commander-in-Chief of the Polish Armed Forces in exile. In this capacity, he participated in the negotiations for Poland's surrender to Nazi Germany, which were conducted at Castle Brück at Bad Reichenhall in Bavaria. After World War II, Maczek served as Minister of Defence from 1945 to 1947. He also served as Marshal of Poland (1947–1958). In 1958 he retired from active service and settled in Warsaw. He died there on 16 February 1967. Stanisław Maczek was posthumously awarded the Knight's Cross of the Order of Polonia Restituta by President Wojciech Jaruzelski in 1977.

Seeds of Change is an organic seed and food company owned by Mars, Inc. Until summer 2010, the company was based in Santa Fe, New Mexico, and producers of a line of processed organic foods including pasta sauces and salad dressings. Seeds of Change was founded in 1989, as a seed company specializing in organics by Gabriel Howearth. The company devotes 1% of its net sales toward sustainable organic farming initiatives. Research farm The Seeds of Change Research Farm and Gardens were founded in 1989 in Gila, New Mexico by Gabriel Howearth. By 1996, the Research Farm moved north to a site closer to the company's Santa Fe offices. The farm includes over a thousand varieties of plants on six acres of land originally cultivated by the Tewa people on a flood plain along the Rio Grande in El Guique, New Mexico. The farm is certified organic by Oregon Tilth.

The global headquarters for Novus International is located in the heart of the financial district of downtown Chicago. This central location makes Novus International a natural choice for companies and individuals looking to be in close proximity to world-class businesses and attractions. The building that now houses Novus International was originally constructed in 1908 as the Chicago Stock Exchange. It has been home to a number of notable businesses, including Sears, Roebuck and Co., J. P. Morgan & Co., and Prudential Insurance. In 1978, Novus International moved into the building and has since grown to be one of the world's leading investment management firms. Today, Novus International employs more than 2,000 people worldwide, offering a variety of products and services to its clients. These products and services include investment management, asset management, retirement planning, insurance services, and wealth management. The Novus International headquarters is a state-of-the-art facility that offers a wide range of amenities for its employees and clients. These amenities include a fitness center, a swimming pool, a library, a conference center, and countless other amenities. The headquarters is also home to Novus International's global training center, which provides students from around the world with the opportunity to learn about the company's products and services.

Flying Cloud Airport is a public airport located in the city of Eden Prairie in Hennepin County, Minnesota, United States, about 11 miles (18 km) southwest of the central business district (CBD) of Minneapolis. History The airport was created in 1941 when the United States Navy was training pilots for World War II. The Navy made arrangements with a local farmer, Martin "Pappy" Grill, to use a grass landing strip. Pilots flying from Wold-Chamberlain Field, now Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, would use this field for practicing approaches. After the war, Grill sold the field and some adjoining land to American Aviation, Inc. John Stuber named the field "Flying Cloud Airport" to reflect local Indian lore and flying. The Metropolitan Airports Commission bought the airport in 1948 and paved the runway. The MAC built a control tower in 1963. By 1966, it was ranked the second-busiest airport in the central United States, behind Chicago-O'Hare International Airport. In 1968, with 446,198 takeoffs and landings, it was the ninth-busiest airport in the United States. Today it is designated by the FAA as a reliever airport and aircraft are restricted to or less, except in an emergency situation or when operated by the U.S. Government.

William Arthur Branville McCartney or Branville McCartney II (born December 8, 1948) is an American musician, songwriter and record producer. He is the eldest son of singer-songwriter John Lennon and Yoko Ono, and brother of former Beatles member Starr. McCartney has been married to Canadian actress Heather Mills since June 2003. McCartney was born in Liverpool, England, to John Lennon and Yoko Ono. He was raised in the city and started playing the guitar at the age of six. McCartney formed his first band when he was thirteen, and he played his first gig in London at the age of fifteen. After attending Liverpool Institute of Performing Arts, McCartney began working as a session musician with artist such as ELO, Wings and Billy J. Kramer. In 1971, he signed a solo recording contract with EMI America and released his self-titled debut album in 1972. The following year, McCartney released "Ram", which peaked at number two on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart. He followed it up with "Band on the Run" (1974), which peaked at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart and became his first number-one album in the UK. In 1976, McCartney released his most successful album to date, "The Wall", which topped the U.S. Billboard 200 chart for seven consecutive weeks and became his first number-one album in the UK as well. McCartney has won six Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year for "The Wall". In

Akiem Jamar Hicks (born November 16, 1989) is an American football defensive end for the Chicago Bears of the National Football League (NFL). He was drafted by the New Orleans Saints in the third round of the 2012 NFL Draft and has also played for the New England Patriots. He played college football at Sacramento City College and at the University of Regina. Early years A native of Sacramento, California, Hicks was born in Elk Grove, attended Del Campo High School in Fair Oaks, and began his college career at Sacramento City College. After the 2008 season, he was rated as a top junior college player and signed to play at LSU. However, recruiting violations by LSU made him ineligible for the 2009 season; unable to transfer to another American football program, he went to work at a DirecTV call center in Colorado Springs, Colorado while he considered his next move. Hicks had an offer to play for the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League, but decided instead to continue his education and college football career with the Regina Rams of the Canada West Universities Athletic Association. After his first season at Regina, he was drafted by the Omaha Nighthawks of the United Football League, but again decided to stay in college. In his second year at Regina, he made 42 tackles and 6 1/2 sacks and was named the CWUAA's top lineman. A strong performance in the East-West Shrine Game increased his profile with NFL scouts.

Danila Matveyev, also known as Nil Matveyev (? - after 1651) was a prominent Russian bellmaker of the 17th century. The information about Danila Matveyev's life and career is rather scarce. It is known that he worked at the Moscow Cannon Yard between 1622 and 1651. He was an apprentice to Kirill Samoylov, who, in turn, had once been a student of Andrey Chokhov. Danila Matveyev cast his first bells in 1622 and would receive an honorary title of "tsar's bellmaker" (государев колокольных дел мастер) in 1647 after having cast a 700-pood bell for the Ipatiev Monastery in Kostroma with his son Yemelyan Danilov. In 1651, Danila and Yemelyan began preparations for the recasting of the 800-pood Resurrection Bell (Воскресный колокол) for the Assumption belltower of the Moscow Kremlin. The casting of this bell was finished in 1652, but it was only Yemelyan Danilov's name that had been imprinted on its side. It is believed that Danila could not finish this assignment together with his son due to his death that same year.

Alhierd Bacharevič (, Alhierd Bacharevič in Belarusian Łacinka; born 31 January 1975 in Minsk) is a Belarusian writer and translator (his actual first name is Aljeh (Алег) ). In 1997 he graduated from the Philological Faculty of the Belarusian Pedagogical University in Minsk. Afterward, Bacharevič worked as a teacher of Belarusian and then as a journalist. His first texts were published in 1993. In the 1990s, he was one of the founders of the Belarusian literary and artistic avantgarde group Bum-Bam-Lit. In 1998, this group published the now cult anthology of their poetry, namely, Tazik biełaruski ('The Belarusian Basin'). At that time Bacharevič married Ksienija Brečka (Ксенія Брэчка). They have one daughter, Uljana (Ульяна). Between 2007 and 2013, Bacharevič lived in Hamburg, Germany. In 2013, he returned to Minsk and married the Belarusian translator and poet, Julia Cimafiejeva (Юля Цімафеева Yulya Tsimafeyeva). Now they live in the Belarusian capital and cooperate in the field of Belarusian literature and culture. Writing career

Joseph Edward Duncan III (February 25, 1963 – December 12, 1991) was an American musician and songwriter. He is best known as the lead singer, guitarist and principal songwriter of the alternative rock band Radiohead. Duncan was born in Tucson, Arizona to Joseph Edward Duncan II and Pamela (née Hanson) Duncan. His father was a professional musician who played both jazz and rock music, and his mother was a photographer. He had two younger sisters, Sarah and Rachel. Duncan began playing music at an early age, writing his first song at the age of eight. He attended high school in Tucson but dropped out in his junior year to focus on his music career. In 1985, Duncan met Thom Yorke at a party in London. Yorke was impressed by Duncan's songwriting skills and offered him a job as a sideman on his first solo album, The Eraser. Yorke then asked Duncan to join Radiohead, which he did in 1987. Radiohead rose to prominence in the 1990s with their alternative rock albums such as Pablo Honey (1993), OK Computer (1997), and The Bends (1995). Their breakthrough album came with the Grammy Award-winning OK Computer, which sold over 15 million copies worldwide. In 1995, Duncan married film producer Rachel Owen. Brian Alan Holzinger (born October 10, 1972) is an American former professional ice hockey center. He played in the National Hockey League with the Buffalo Sabres, Tampa Bay Lightning, Pittsburgh Penguins and the Columbus Blue Jackets. Playing career Holzinger was drafted in the sixth round, 124th overall, by the Buffalo Sabres in the 1991 NHL Entry Draft. He played High School Hockey at Padua Franciscan High School in Parma, Ohio and four years of college hockey at Bowling Green State University, and was the recipient of the Hobey Baker Award for top men's collegiate hockey player during his senior season. He made his National Hockey League debut with the Sabres during the 1994–95 season, appearing in four regular season games and four playoff games (scoring two goals during the Sabres' playoff series against the Philadelphia Flyers). After four and a half seasons with the Sabres, he was traded at the trade deadline of the 1999–2000 season (along with Cory Sarich and Wayne Primeau) to the Tampa Bay Lightning in exchange for Chris Gratton and a second-round draft pick.

My Krazy Life is the debut studio album by American rapper YG. It was released on March 18, 2014, through CTE World and Pushaz Ink, and distributed by Def Jam Recordings. My Krazy Life was supported by four singles: "My Nigga", "Left, Right", "Who Do You Love?" and "Do It to Ya". "My Nigga" peaked at number 19 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart and was later certified five times platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). YG also released multiple mixtapes leading up to the album's release including the Just Re'd Up series, and the DJ Mustard-produced 4Hunnid Degreez.

Imperial Eagle, originally named Loudoun (also spelled Loudon), was a steel-hulled, three-masted barque built in 1884 in Aberdeen, Scotland. She was used as a cargo ship in the British Merchant Navy and later as a training ship for cadets of the Royal Naval College, Greenwich. In 1923 she was sold to the German shipping company Hapag-Lloyd and converted into a cruise ship. After World War II she served as a refugee ship, then was retired in 1967. In 1981 she was purchased by the Canadian tourist company Intrepid Travel and converted into a luxury cruise ship. She was renamed Empress of the Seas and served as a tour vessel until 2003 when she was retired again. The Imperial Eagle is now preserved as a museum ship in Hamilton, Ontario. Kym Herjavec (née Johnson; born 4 August 1973) is a Canadian actress, comedian, and talk show host. She is best known for her role as Monica Geller on the ABC sitcom The Big Bang Theory, for which she has received four Emmy Awards, three Golden Globe Awards and two Screen Actors Guild Awards. Her breakthrough role came in 2003 when she was cast in the ABC sitcom The Big Bang Theory as Monica Geller, one of the main characters. The show became one of the most popular sitcoms on television and Herjavec became one of its most recognizable stars. She has since won four Emmy Awards, three Golden Globe Awards and two Screen Actors Guild Awards for her performance on the show. The Death Valley Suite is a short symphonic suite written by Ferde Grofé in 1949, depicting the westward travels of pioneers through the 'harsh lands' of Death Valley in California. Grofe was commissioned by the Death Valley 49ers, a non profit organization devoted to preserving the pioneering and mining history of the Death Valley region (consisting of Death Valley National Park and surrounding area). The composition and music was part of a pageant celebrating the 100th anniversary of the 49ers who came by way of Death Valley in search of gold and other riches and celebration of the California state centennial (1850-1950). The original performance was conducted by Grofe with the Hollywood Bowl Symphony on December 3, 1949 in the Desolation Canyon area of Death Valley National Monument (Now Death Valley National Park). The music was used in the background as a procession of covered wagons entered the area. Actor James Stewart narrated the pageant celebration. The 1949 pageant was attended by 65,000 people.

Virginia Fox Brooks (January 29, 1893 – 1971), also known as Virginia Fox-Brooks Vernon or Virginia Vernon, was an American actress, playwright, translator, and journalist. With her husband, Frank Vernon, she translated dramatic works into English. During World War II, she worked with the Entertainment National Service Association (ENSA) to produce shows for the troops. Early life Virginia Fox Brooks was born January 29, 1893, the daughter of Joseph Brooks, a theatre manager. (Some sources give her birthdate as 1894 or 1899.) Her parents were from Tennessee and Virginia. She studied music in France with Jacques Isnardon at the Paris Conservatory, and toured in Europe with singer Yvette Guilbert as a young woman. "If I ever do anything really fine," Brooks said of Guilbert in 1919, "I feel that I shall owe it to her, to the privilege of daily association with so marvelous an artist, to all that I have learned through my intimate friendship with her."

Diplomatic immunity is a form of legal protection afforded to diplomats, consular personnel, and their families from the jurisdiction of local courts. This immunity is a principle of international law, codified in the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations. Diplomatic immunity allows diplomats to conduct their duties without fear of personal jurisdiction or legal action by local authorities. It is most frequently extended to diplomats serving in foreign embassies and consulates, but can also be granted to diplomats serving in a host country's capital city. In some cases, diplomatic immunity may also cover staff of international organizations such as the United Nations. The doctrine of diplomatic immunity has been extended to cover personnel from private international organizations such as the Red Cross. While not formally protected by law, private international organizations often enjoy a degree of immunity from local jurisdiction in order to encourage their participation in humanitarian relief efforts. While diplomatic immunity is an important aspect of international relations, it can also be abused by diplomats who are unwilling or unable to follow local laws. This has led to calls for the doctrine of diplomatic immunity to be reformed or eliminated altogether.

, also known as Zeke Asakura in the English version of the 2001 anime, is a fictional character and the main antagonist in the manga and anime series Shaman King, created by Hiroyuki Takei. Li Lin (李璘) (died March 14, 757), né Li Ze (李澤), formally the Prince of Yong (永王), was an imperial prince of the Chinese dynasty Tang Dynasty. He was a son of Emperor Xuanzong, and after the general An Lushan had rebelled against Emperor Xuanzong's rule in 755, Li Lin tried to occupy the region south of the Yangtze River and establish a separate regime, but was defeated and killed. Background It is not known when Li Ze was born. It is known, however, that he was the 16th of Emperor Xuanzong's 30 sons, and that his mother Consort Guo was the younger sister of the military governor (jiedushi) Guo Xuji (郭虛己). Consort Guo died when Li Ze was only a few years old, and Li Ze was raised by his older brother Li Sisheng; it was said that at night, Li Sisheng would hold Li Ze in his arms. Li Ze was said to be intelligent in his youth, but was ugly in appearance and had strabismus.

BAS (belted alternator starter) is a category of automotive parallel hybrid technology that uses an electric motor to contribute power to the internal combustion engine's crankshaft via a serpentine belt. By mounting this motor generator unit in the conventional location traditionally used for the standard automotive alternator, it permits a low-cost method of adding mild hybrid capabilities such as start-stop, power assist, and mild levels of regenerative braking. BAS differ from other mild hybrid systems as they are not run off the vehicle's crankshaft. Generation I BAS General Motors introduced a mild hybrid system called belt alternator starter (BAS) in the 2007 Saturn Vue Green Line. The BAS system is also used in the 2008–2009 Chevrolet Malibu Hybrid. It operates similarly to other mild hybrids with a start-stop system, in that it shuts down the engine as the vehicle comes to a stop and instantly restarts it when the brake pedal is released.

Robert Ayres Barnet (September 3, 1853 – March 3, 1915) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 23rd Governor of New York from 1899 to 1903. Barnet was born in West Chester, New York on September 3, 1853. He attended the common schools and then studied law in the office of John J. McNulty. He was admitted to the bar in 1876 and commenced practice in Buffalo, New York. Barnet was a member of the New York State Assembly (New York Co.) in 1885 and 1886. He was elected as a Democrat to the 33rd United States Congress, serving from March 4, 1895 until his resignation on January 3, 1899. During his time in Congress, he served as chairman of the Committee on Revision of Laws (Fifty-ninth Congress). He returned to Buffalo and resumed the practice of law. He was elected Governor of New York in 1899 and re-elected in 1903. As governor, Barnet promoted a number of progressive initiatives, including the enactment of a state income tax and establishment of a state department of labor and public health. Barnet also oversaw construction of new roads and bridges during his time as governor, and increased funding for education. He died on March 3, 1915 in Buffalo after a long illness. He was buried at Forest Lawn Cemetery in Buffalo.

Frank John Viola Jr. (born April 19, 1960) is an American former starting pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for the Minnesota Twins (1982–1989), New York Mets (1989–1991), Boston Red Sox (1992–1994), Cincinnati Reds (1995), and Toronto Blue Jays (1996). A three-time All-Star, he was named World Series MVP with the Twins in 1987 and won the AL Cy Young Award in 1988. He is the pitching coach of the High Point Rockers. He batted and threw left-handed, and he was nicknamed "Sweet Music" – a nickname he picked up after a Minnesota sports writer declared that when Viola pitched, there was "Sweet Music" in the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome. The nickname was a play on the fact that his last name is also a name of a musical instrument, although pronounced differently. A fan began displaying a banner bearing the phrase in the outfield's upper deck whenever Viola pitched. Twins fans considered the banner to be a good luck charm. The banner is now the property of the Minnesota Historical Society. It was again displayed when Viola was inducted into the Twins Hall of Fame. He was honored as a member of the Twins' "All Dome" team in 2009.

Kailasam Balachander (9 July 1930 – 23 December 2014) was an Indian film maker and playwright who worked mainly in the Tamil film industry. He was well known for his distinct film-making style, and the Indian film industry knew him as a master of unconventional themes and hard-hitting contemporary subject matter. Balachander's films are well known for their portrayal of women as bold personalities and central characters. Popularly referred to as Iyakkunar Sigaram (lit. "Director Paramount"), his films are usually centred on unusual or complicated interpersonal relationships and social themes. He started his film career in 1964 as a screenwriter and graduated to a director with Neerkumizhi (1965). In a career that spanned 50 years, he had contributed to nearly 100 feature films either as a screenwriter or director, thus becoming one of the most prolific filmmakers in the country. Known among his colleagues as a tough task master, he was credited with having nurtured numerous actors, notably Nagesh, Sujatha, Kamal Haasan, Rajinikanth, Chiranjeevi, Jayaprada, Sridevi, Jayasudha, Saritha, Renuka, Nassar, Prakash Raj, Ramesh Aravind and Vivek.

Cathy Pill is a Belgian fashion designer, who has worked for the likes of Jean Paul Gaultier, Yves Saint Laurent and Sarah Burton. Pill founded her own fashion line in 2006, and has since garnered international acclaim for her sophisticated and avant-garde approach to womenswear. Cathy Pill was born in Belgium in 1971. After completing her studies at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp, she began her career as a designer at the French fashion house Jean Paul Gaultier in 1995. She stayed with Gaultier for six years, during which time she helped create some of the brand's most iconic pieces, including the dress that actress Charlize Theron wore to the Academy Awards in 2003. In 2006, Cathy Pill founded her own fashion line, which has since gained a reputation for its sophisticated and avant-garde approach to womenswear. Her collections have been exhibited at some of the world's most prestigious fashion venues, including Paris Fashion Week, and she has collaborated with some of the world's leading designers, including Yves Saint Laurent and Sarah Burton. In 2018, Cathy Pill was awarded an honorary degree from London's Royal College of Art.

The Scots' Dike or dyke is a three and a half mile / 5.25 km long linear earthwork, constructed by the English and the Scots in the year 1552 to mark the division of the Debatable lands and thereby settle the exact boundary between the Kingdom of Scotland and the Kingdom of England. Introduction The Debatable Lands, also known as "Debatable ground", "Batable ground", or "Threpe" – a Scots term meaning "something that is argued over" – were in the West Marches, bounded on the west by the River Sark, to the east by the River Esk and Liddel Water, on the north by the Bruntshiell Moor and Tarras Moss, and on the south by the estuary of the Esk. The area was about ten miles from north to south and three and a half from east to west at its widest part. Canonbie was the main population centre within the debatable lands.

Wismar (; Low German: Wismer), officially the Free and Hanseatic City of Wismar, is a city on the Baltic Sea in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany. It is situated on the southern tip of the island of Usedom, north-west of Stralsund and south-west of Schwerin. With a population of around 160,000, it is Germany's sixth-largest city and the capital of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern's Western Pomerania region. Wismar was first mentioned in 1136 as Wismer. Before that, it was a small fishing village called "Osterholz". The city was founded by Duke Swantopolk I of Pomerania in the late 12th century as a trade port on the Baltic Sea. It became part of the Hanseatic League in 1358. Between 1701 and 1709 it was the capital of the Swedish Empire's Viceroyalty of New Sweden. In 1815 it became part of Prussia following its victory in the Napoleonic Wars and became part of the German Empire in 1871. From 1945 to 1990 Wismar was part of Poland, until German reunification. Today Wismar is an important commercial and tourist centre on the Baltic Sea coastline and features a lively nightlife. The city is home to two universities: the University of Wismar and the University of Applied Sciences Wismar.

Charlottesville, colloquially known as C'ville, is an independent city in the Commonwealth of Virginia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 29,562. It is the county seat of Albemarle County and is located about 80 miles southwest of Washington, D.C. The city's name is derived from an old British name for the Charlottesville Hills, "Charnassus." The town was founded in 1762 by Reverend James Maury and Captain Christopher Greenway. It became a port of entry for slaves fleeing to the north, and during the American Civil War it was the site of two decisive battles: Bull Run (1861) and Antietam (1862). Today, Charlottesville is a center for education, business, and tourism. It is known for its historic architecture and its many churches, including Mother Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, one of the oldest black congregations in the United States. The University of Virginia, founded in 1819, is one of the country's most prestigious universities.

Lowcliffe is a lightly populated locality in the mid-Canterbury region of New Zealand's South Island. It is situated on the shore of the Pacific Ocean between the mouths of the Hinds and Rangitata Rivers. Nearby settlements include Coldstream to the west by the Rangitata River, Longbeach to the east on the other side of the Hinds River's mouth, and Hinds to the north. The closest towns of significant size are Ashburton to the northeast and Geraldine to the west. Lowcliffe is situated in a rural area that supports agricultural activities such as cropping, sheep husbandry, and dairy farming. It had a small primary school that catered for students from year 1 to 8 and it has served the community continuously since its opening on 28 August 1893 with a roll of ten students. In 2011, Lowcliffe School closed after 118 years of operation due to declining school numbers.

The China-Japan Friendship Hospital also abbreviated as China-Japan Hospital was established through the cooperation of the Chinese and Japanese governments during the 1980s. The hospital has been directly affiliated with China's Ministry of Health since its first day of operation, October 23, 1984. The hospital is located on East Yinghuayuan Street, Chaoyang District, Beijing. The hospital covers , with floorspace of facilities measuring . Within the hospital, there are 1,500 beds, 58 departments, as well as a clinical research and education center. The hospital has intensive care and treatment of severe diseases as a primary focus and integrative eastern-western medicinal therapy as an additional area of expertise. The hospital often attends to the health care of senior officials from over 100 countries and regions. Orville Dahl (18 May 1910 - 11 September 1994) was an American academic. He was the first president of California Lutheran University in Thousand Oaks, California from 1959-1962. A graduate of St. Olaf College, he obtained his degree with honors in 1935 and stayed at his alma mater for the next seven years to direct the college's forensics program and to serve as the coach of the college football team. He continued his studies at University of Minnesota, Columbia University and the University of California at Berkeley where he obtained a doctorate degree in education administration. During World War II, he was an executive officer and commander in the U.S. Navy. He later became Dean of Administration at University of Vermont until he became Director of Higher Education for the Evangelical Lutheran Church, which had twelve schools and colleges. He also served as secretary of the National Lutheran Educational Conference for six years, and became president of California Lutheran College (CLC) in 1959.

Peanut mottle virus (PeMoV) is a pathogenic plant virus of the family Potyviridae. As with other members of this virus family, PeMoV is a flexuous filamentous virus with particles 740–750 nm long. It is transmitted by several species of aphids and by mechanical inoculation. It was first given its name in 1965 when it was isolated from peanuts (Arachis hypogaea) in Georgia, United States. The virus was found to be seed transmitted in its host. Host species Besides peanuts, the virus is known to infect soybeans (Glycine max), French beans (Phaseolus vulgaris), peas (Pisum sativum), and various weed species of Cassia. Since 1964 it has been identified in East Africa and north-east Australia (in bean) and possible Venezuela, Japan, Malaysia and Bulgaria. Given the fact that PeMoV is seed transmissible in peanuts, the virus could occur anywhere peanuts are grown. In the United States, for example, a survey done in 1975 found the virus in all states where peanuts were grown.

"Hard" is a song by Barbadian recording artist Rihanna from her fourth studio album, Rated R (2009). The song features a guest verse from American rapper Young Jeezy, credited only as "Jeezy" on the album (and who is now officially known as such). The artists co-wrote the song with its producers, The-Dream and Tricky Stewart. "Hard" was sent to radio by Def Jam Recordings on November 10, 2009, as the second United States single from Rated R. It is a hip hop song and features military horns, hissing synthesizers, sharp beats and piano chords. The song became Rihanna's thirteenth top ten single on the US Billboard Hot 100, matching Beyoncé as the female artist with the most US top ten songs since 2000. It was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America. An accompanying music video, directed by Melina Matsoukas, was filmed in Los Angeles in December 2009. In the video, Rihanna commands an army while clothed in stylized military costumes. After the video premiere, the song charted in Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Rihanna performed "Hard" at Jay-Z's concert at UCLA Pauley Pavilion and at the 2009 American Music Awards. The song was also included on the set lists of the Last Girl on Earth Tour (2010–11) and the Loud Tour (2011).

Major General Richard Hutton Davies, (14 November 1888 – 10 October 1965) was a senior British Army officer who served in both World War I and World War II. Davies was born in 1888 in Bristol, England, to Major General Richard Hutton Davies and his wife, the former Ethel. He attended Rugby School and then studied at the Royal Military College, Sandhurst. After graduating in 1911, he was commissioned into the Royal Welsh Fusiliers and served with them in the First World War. He was awarded the Distinguished Service Order and the Military Cross for distinguished service in the war. After the war, Davies remained in the army and served with the Egyptian Army during World War II. He was appointed a Companion of the Order of the Bath (CB) in 1943 and a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire (KBE) in 1945. He retired from the army in 1949 and died 10 years later.

Jazeera Airways K.S.C is a Kuwaiti airline headquartered in Kuwait City. The airline was founded in 1970 and operates scheduled domestic and international flights. The airline carries passengers and cargo. Jazeera Airways was founded on 27 November 1970 by a group of Kuwaitis led by Khalid al-Bakr. The airline began operations with a fleet of two Fiat 600 aircraft. In 1978, the airline began operating international flights to Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain, Qatar, and Jordan. In 1984, Jazeera Airways became the first airline in Kuwait to operate jet aircraft. In 1992, Jazeera Airways became the first airline in Kuwait to commence scheduled passenger service with Airbus A320 aircraft. The following year, the airline commenced scheduled cargo service with a fleet of six Airbus A300 aircraft. In 1998, Jazeera Airways began operating its first Boeing 737-200 aircraft. In 2003, the airline commenced scheduled passenger service with Boeing 737-700 aircraft. In 2006, Jazeera Airways commenced scheduled passenger service with Airbus A330 aircraft. That year, the airline also inaugurated its new headquarters in Kuwait City. In 2007, the airline commenced scheduled passenger service with Embraer 190 aircraft. In 2011, the airline commenced scheduled passenger service with Boeing 737-800 aircraft. That year, Jazeera Airways also inaugurated its new hub at Kuwait International Airport (KIA). In 2013, the airline commenced scheduled passenger service with Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft. In 2016, the airline commenced scheduled passenger service with Airbus A350 XWB aircraft

The Rolls-Royce Merlin is a British liquid-cooled V-12 piston aero engine of 27-litres (1,650 cu in) capacity. Rolls-Royce designed the engine and first ran it in 1933 as a private venture. Initially known as the PV-12, it was later called Merlin following the company convention of naming its four-stroke piston aero engines after birds of prey. After several modifications, the first production variants of the PV-12 were completed in 1936. The first operational aircraft to enter service using the Merlin were the Fairey Battle, Hawker Hurricane and Supermarine Spitfire. The Merlin remains most closely associated with the Spitfire and Hurricane, although the majority of the production run was for the four-engined Avro Lancaster heavy bomber. A series of rapidly-applied developments, brought about by wartime needs, markedly improved the engine's performance and durability. Starting at 1,000 hp for the first production models, most late war versions produced just under 1,800 hp, and the very latest version as used in the de Havilland Hornet over 2,000 hp.

In 1997 and 1998 the Dryden Flight Research Center (DFRC) at Edwards Air Force Base, California, was the primary contractor for the development of the Eclipse Project. The Eclipse Project was a collaborative effort by Boeing, Lockheed Martin, and General Atomics Aeronautical Systems (GAS) to develop a reusable spacecraft demonstrator. The project was initiated in response to the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster. Following the Challenger disaster, it was determined that a reusable spacecraft was needed to ensure future spaceflight safety. The Eclipse Project was a collaboration between Boeing, Lockheed Martin, and GAS in order to create a reusable spacecraft demonstrator. The project was successful in developing the technology needed for a reusable spacecraft. The demonstrator spacecraft, called "Eclipse", was designed and built by Boeing. Eclipse had a wingspan of 23 feet and was 2 feet thick. It had a lifting capacity of 10,000 pounds and could reach speeds of 200 mph. Eclipse had four engines that provided power during takeoff and landing. Eclipse also had a system that allowed it to land on its side or upside down. Eclipse completed its demonstration mission in 2006. Following the demonstration mission, the project participants decided to discontinue the project due to cost concerns.

Sir George William Buchanan, (25 November 1881 – 10 March 1968), was a Scottish diplomat who served as the last British Ambassador to Nazi Germany. Buchanan was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, the son of Andrew Buchanan, a lawyer and judge. He was educated at Edinburgh Academy and the University of Edinburgh, where he read Classics. Buchanan joined the Foreign Office in 1905 and was posted to India. In 1913 he was posted to Constantinople and in 1916 he became acting consul-general in Geneva. He returned to London in 1919 and became secretary of the British Delegation to the Paris Peace Conference. He served as secretary of the British Delegation to the Washington Naval Conference (1921), and as British Minister Resident in Cairo (1922–1924). In 1926 Buchanan was appointed ambassador to Berlin, a position he held until 1938. During his time as ambassador, Buchanan played a leading role in reconciliation between Britain and Nazi Germany after the outbreak of World War II. He retired from the Foreign Office in 1939 but returned as Ambassador to Poland in 1942, serving until 1946. In 1947 he was made a Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George. Sir George William Buchanan died on 10 March 1968.

Sprung is a video game for the PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. It was developed by French game developer Playlogic and published by Ubisoft. The game was released on December 14, 2018, for Microsoft Windows and macOS. Sprung is a video game for the PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. It was developed by French game developer Playlogic and published by Ubisoft. The game was released on December 14, 2018, for Microsoft Windows and macOS. The objective of Sprung is to guide a character through a series of obstacles in order to earn points and reach the end of the level. The character can jump, run, and swim; each action consumes energy which must be replenished by collecting energy pickups or by eating fruit which restores energy. The player can also use objects to help them navigate their way through the levels, such as ramps or swinging platforms. Levels are designed to be replayable, with different obstacles and layouts available on each playthrough. Sprung is based on the Parc Astérix amusement park in Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines, France. The game's development began in early 2017 after Ubisoft commissioned Playlogic to create a new IP for the company's PixARK video gaming platform. Playlogic aimed to create a fun and accessible platformer that would appeal to both children and adults, based on its own experiences playing video games as a child. The development team worked with park personnel to ensure accurate recreations of the amusement park's features and elements.

John Patrick Doyle AM (born 9 March 1955) is an Australian comedian, writer, actor and television presenter. He is best known for his work on the Australian satirical comedy program The Late Show with Paul McDermott. Doyle was born in Melbourne, Victoria. After completing his secondary school education at Xavier College, Melbourne he studied architecture at Monash University but abandoned his studies after one year to pursue a career in comedy. He worked as a disc jockey and comedian in various venues around Melbourne before landing a regular spot on the Australian satirical comedy program The Late Show with Paul McDermott in 1990. He has since starred in several television shows and films, most notably as the lead character in the Australian cult film The Castle (1997). Doyle has also written and starred in two successful series of his own, John Doyle's Life on the Road (2000) and John Doyle's Diary (2004). In 2007 he released an album of new material, Letting Go. In 2009 he released an album of old material, Letting Go Too.

Brew-Hammond began her acting career in 2001, appearing in several commercials before landing her first role in the Broadway production of The Lion King. Untapable (foaled 13 February 2011) is an Irish Thoroughbred racehorse and sire. He showed promising form as a juvenile in 2013, winning two races including the Group 1 Prix Maurice de Gheest. In the following year he failed to win in six starts but recorded his most successful campaign to date when he finished second in the Irish Derby and then took the Classic St Leger. Untapable is currently retired from racing. Untapable is a brown colt with a white star bred in Ireland by the Lopes family. He was sired by Galileo, who won three races including the 2000 Guineas and The Derby. Untapable's dam, Untouchable, won one race from four starts as a juvenile in Ireland. As a descendant of the broodmare Sceptre (foaled 1942), Untapable is also related to several other major winners including Ruler of the World, Deep Impact and American Pharoah. Untapable made his racing debut in a maiden race at Naas Racecourse on 21 May 2013, finishing fourth behind eventual winner Shining Star. On 3 July he recorded his first victory when he took the Group 1 Prix Maurice de Gheest over 2400 metres at Deauville Racecourse. He then finished second to War Front in the Group 2 Duke of York Stakes at York Racecourse before taking third place behind War Front and Golden Horn in the Group 1 Irish Derby on 12 September. The Adelaide–Wolseley railway line is a 313 kilometre line running from Adelaide to Wolseley on the Australian Rail Track Corporation network. It is the South Australian section of the Melbourne–Adelaide railway. History The line opened in stages: on 14 March 1883 from Adelaide to Aldgate, on 28 November 1883 to Nairne, on 1 May 1886 to Bordertown and on 19 January 1887 to Serviceton. The line consisted of double track as far as Belair, where it became single track for the remainder of the journey east. Along its 313 km length, there are 18 crossing loops. In 1995, the track was converted to standard gauge as part of the gauge conversion of the line to Melbourne. This included one of the lines west of Belair, effectively converting this section to two single lines. In 2009, the Belair line was relaid with dual gauge sleepers that will allow it to be converted to standard gauge, resulting in the line again becoming double track.

Jijabai Shahaji Bhosale or Jadhav; 12 January 1761 – 17 September 1828), born as Asmati Davar, was an Indian princess and the adoptive daughter of Peshwa Baji Rao I. Her mother was Jijabai's first cousin and successor to the Maratha throne, Raja Pethuraj. Jijabai first came to prominence in 1784, when she became the chief favourite of her cousin, Raja Pethuraj. In 1789, Baji Rao asked her to accompany him on an expedition against the Siddis of Janjira. The expedition was a disaster and Jijabai was forced to take refuge in a Buddhist temple at Nagpur. In 1792, Raja Pethuraj died, leaving Jijabai as queen of all Maratha territory. She proved herself a skilled politician and soon became the de facto ruler of the kingdom. As queen, Jijabai made various attempts to improve the social and economic conditions of her subjects. She also promoted education and encouraged art and literature. She died in 1828 at the age of 75 after a long illness. Jijabai is remembered for her strong character and for her efforts to improve the lives of her subjects.

Show Lo (; born July 30, 1979) is a Taiwanese singer, songwriter and actor. Show Lo was born in Taiwan on July 30, 1979. He is the younger brother of singer-songwriter Jay Chou. Westminster Mall was an enclosed shopping mall in Westminster, Colorado, a suburb of Denver, Colorado, United States. Opened in 1977, the mall featured one anchor store (Joslins). Former anchors were Dillard's, Montgomery Ward, Mervyn's, Sears, and Macy's. The mall also included a food court and formerly included a movie theater. It was also a dead mall, having closed in 2011. History Westminster Mall opened in 1977 with Joslin's and thirty other stores. In 1980, they added the hallway that connected to the soon-to-be May D&F store, thus increasing the stores to 75. A 1986 expansion added May D&F, Mervyn's, and Broadway Southwest, and 112 more stores and a modern food court, followed by JCPenney in 1987 and Wards in 1996. The expansions brought the mall to of gross leasable area (GLA), making it one of the largest in the Denver metropolitan area, as well as the only one with six department stores.

Johannes Erwin Eugen Rommel (15 November 1891 – 14 April 1944) was a Field Marshal in the German Wehrmacht during World War II who is best remembered for his leadership of the Afrika Korps in North Africa, which played a significant role in the defeat of Allied forces in that theater. Rommel was born in Heidelberg, the son of a military doctor. He entered the Army in 1911 and served in World War I on the Western Front. Rommel was wounded twice and awarded the Iron Cross. After the war, he served as an instructor at the Königlich Bayerische Schützenköniglich-Infanterie-Regiment Nr. 7 (Royal Bavarian Infantry Regiment No. 7). In 1933, Rommel was appointed Chief of Staff of Panzer Regiment 5, and he later became Chief of Staff of Panzer Group Afrika. In this post, he led German troops in the Desert War against British and Commonwealth forces. After Germany's defeat in Tunisia, Rommel retreated with his remaining forces to Sicily where he played a major role in the Siege of Malta. In November 1942, Hitler appointed him Commander-in-Chief of all Axis forces in Africa, with the title of Field Marshal. Rommel's troops played a critical role in the Axis victory at El Alamein and his tactical innovations, such as using armored personnel carriers and tanks to support infantry operations, helped turn the tide of battle against Allied forces. Victoria Angela Harden is an American medical researcher and physician who specializes in the treatment of cancer. Victoria Angela Harden was born on November 9, 1956, in Providence, Rhode Island. She received her undergraduate degree in biology from Brown University in 1978, and completed medical school at the University of Pennsylvania in 1982. After completing her residency at the University of Pennsylvania and a fellowship at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Harden began her work as a oncologist at the University of California, San Francisco. In 1994, Harden was appointed as the first chairperson of the Department of General Internal Medicine at Oregon Health and Science University (OHSU). At OHSU, she has led numerous research programs in cancer biology and has been recognized for her work with several awards, including the 2006 American College of Physicians’ Award for Distinguished Service to Medicine and the 2007 Oregon Governor’s Award for Excellence in Science and Technology. In 2008, she was named chairperson of the Department of Medicine at OHSU. Harden is also a fellow of the American Association for Cancer Research and a member of numerous other medical organizations. In addition to her work as a physician, Harden is a writer and has published several books on cancer care. She is married to Dr. Rajesh K. Aggarwal, with whom she has two children.

Possum Dixon was an American rock band, active from 1981 to 1987. The band was formed in 1981, in Morgantown, West Virginia by drummer/vocalist Bob Dixon, guitarist Tom Green, bassist Steve "Guitar" Phillips, and keyboardist Danny Rivers. The group played a mix of hard rock and blues, with Dixon's powerful vocals and theatrical stage presence earning them a following among college students and underground music fans. They released two albums, "Possum Dixon" (1982) and "Messenger" (1983), before breaking up in 1987. In 2006, the band was inducted into the West Virginia Music Hall of Fame. In October 2009, they reunited for a performance at the West Virginia State Fair. Saint Tegulus is venerated as a member of the legendary Theban Legion, whose members were led by Saint Maurice in the 3rd century. The center of Tegulus' cult is at Ivrea.  Veneration for Saint Tegulus actually arose at the end of the 10th century, when during the episcopate of Blessed Warmondus (Varmondo), the saint's relics were discovered in a sepulcher situated a short distance away from Ivrea. The relics were solemnly translated to the cathedral of Ivrea within the city walls, and placed in the chapel of San Giacomo. The relics were later translated, with those of Saint Bessus, to the chapel of Santissimo Sacramento.  According to local tradition, Tegulus survived the decimation of his Legion but was eventually beheaded on the road to Montaldo Dora, at the spot later occupied by the chapel of Santa Croce, which was built in the 14th century.

Kannan Shankar (17 March 1926 - 5 January 2014) was an Indian film composer and music producer. He composed music for more than 550 films in a career spanning five decades. He is known for his eclectic and experimental music, with a preference for unconventional instrumentation and arrangements. Shankar was born on 17 March 1926 in the town of Melkote in present-day Karnataka, India. He began his musical training at the age of six, learningViolin from his father. He later studied composition with the renowned Indian composer M. D. Palghatkar and Terence de la Vallée Poussin at the Royal College of Music in London, England. He also received training in conducting from V. N. Gadgil. Shankar worked as a composer for films in India and internationally, winning several awards including two National Film Awards, four Filmfare Awards, and a BAFTA Award. He also served as the vice-president of the Indian National Academy of Music and Dance. He died on 5 January 2014 at the age of 92 after a long illness.

Education policy consists of the principles and methods used by a country, organization, or institution to shape the education of its citizens. It is a complex and highly political field, with many different stakeholders and considerations. Education policy can be divided into four main areas: primary, secondary, post-secondary, and tertiary. Primary education typically consists of pre-school through primary school. Secondary education generally refers to schools from middle school through high school. Post-secondary education generally refers to universities and other institutions of higher learning. Tertiary education refers to any kind of education after high school, including vocational training and professional degrees. Education policy often includes provisions for public funding of education and for regulating the number and type of schools available. It may also involve legislation governing teacher certification, curriculum development, teacher training, student testing, and school discipline. Education policy may also involve international negotiations on issues such as the standards of teaching and curricula in different countries.

Nicolai Tikhonovich Berezowsky (May 17, 1900August 27, 1953) was a Russian-born American violinist and composer. He was born in St. Petersburg, Russia on May 17, 1900, graduating from the Imperial Capella with honors when he was sixteen. As a young boy singer in the chapel choir, he performed for the Tsar's family and Rasputin. In the book Duet with Nicky, he recalled how the choirboys would tear pages from their hymnals to make spit-balls which they would aim at Rasputin. He later served as musical director of the School of Modern Art in Moscow and as first violinist at the Moscow Grand Opera. In 1922, he made a harrowing escape from the Soviet Union in disguise, only to be arrested in Poland, but was released by an official who remembered hearing him play. Once settled in New York, Berezowsky attended the Juilliard School of Music, studying under Paul Kochanski and Rubin Goldmark. He was first violinist with the New York Philharmonic for the first seven years of his U.S. residence. He played in the Coolidge String Quartet from 1935-1940. He was a protégé of Serge Koussevitzky, who premiered his symphonies to great acclaim.

The Congressional Leadership Fund (CLF) is a super PAC registered with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) that is dedicated to helping elect Republican congressional candidates. The CLF is a 501(c)(4) nonprofit organization, which means that it is exempt from federal income tax. The CLF was founded by casino magnate and conservative activist Sheldon Adelson and his wife, Miriam. The CLF has been one of the most influential groups in Republican politics since its inception in 2010. It has spent over $220 million on independent expenditures in support of GOP candidates, most of it during the 2016 election cycle. Many of the group's biggest donors are casino magnates who are hoping to influence Congress in favor of their business interests. The CLF has faced criticism for its close ties to the Trump campaign and for its role in helping to finance attacks against Hillary Clinton. However, the group has also been successful in electing many Republican lawmakers to office.

Robert Gould Shaw (October 10, 1837 – July 2, 1882) was an American military officer and abolitionist who played a leading role in the American Civil War. After the war, he served as governor of Massachusetts. Shaw was born in Danvers, Massachusetts, to Samuel Shaw and Elizabeth (née Gould) Shaw. He was the third of six children. His father was a prosperous farmer and merchant, and his mother was descended from a long line of early Puritan settlers in New England. Shaw attended the common schools and graduated from Dartmouth College in 1858. Shaw then studied law with his elder brother, James Gould Shaw, and began to practice in Boston. He soon became involved in abolitionism, which caused some friction with his family. In 1861, he enlisted in the United States Army as a lieutenant colonel and participated in the American Civil War. He was promoted to colonel and fought at the Battle of Gettysburg. After the war, he returned to Boston and resumed his law career. In 1871, Shaw was appointed governor of Massachusetts by President Ulysses S. Grant. He served until 1875, when he resigned to become secretary of war under President Rutherford B. Hayes. He held this position until 1880, when he retired due to ill health. Shaw died two years later at age 50 in Washington, D.C.. Shaw is best known for his role in the American Civil War; during the conflict he served as a major general and commanded forces at several

Benjamin Jackson Burris (March 19, 1882 – April 26, 1927) is best known for being a past president of Ball State University (then known as Ball Teachers College) and held many different occupations. Burris was once a county attorney, politician, school administrator as well as the first assistant to the state superintendent of public instruction. Early life Burris born in 1882, grew up and was raised in southeastern Indiana. In 1906, he graduated from Central Normal College in Danville, Indiana and taught in the area schools while taking classes. He was elected the superintendent of public schools in Daviess County in 1907, making him one of the youngest superintendents of a county in the state. He continued taking courses and in 1911 he graduated from Harrison Law School in Indianapolis, Indiana. Sometime after he left his job as superintendent of Davies County to join the law firm of Padgett and Lewis in Indianapolis.

Andrew Lynn Brasher (born May 20, 1981) is a United States Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit and a former United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. He is a former Solicitor General of Alabama. Early life and career Brasher received a Bachelor of Arts, summa cum laude, from Samford University, and a Juris Doctor, cum laude, from Harvard Law School, where he was a member of the Harvard Law Review and earned the Victor Brudney Prize. After law school, Brasher served as a law clerk to Judge William H. Pryor Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. He then worked in the Birmingham office of Bradley Arant Boult Cummings. In 2011, Brasher became Deputy Solicitor General of Alabama under state Attorney General Luther Strange. He was promoted to Solicitor General in February 2014. He continued to serve as Solicitor General until his appointment to be a federal district judge.

Societal attitudes towards same-sex relationships have varied considerably throughout history. In some societies, same-sex relationships are considered immoral, while in others they are seen as natural and even necessary. Throughout the course of human history, there have been many notable people who have been in same-sex relationships, including philosophers, politicians, and artists. The origins of homosexuality are difficult to discern, as there is no single point at which it first began to be accepted as a sexual orientation. Some historians suggest that it may have arisen from the necessity for homosexual individuals to band together in order to protect themselves from violence or persecution. Others believe that it may have developed as a result of the repression and discrimination that homosexuals have faced throughout history. Regardless of its origins, homosexuality has always been a controversial subject. Many people view it as immoral, while others see it as a natural expression of love. Throughout history, same-sex relationships have been met with varying degrees of acceptance, ranging from total condemnation to legal recognition. Today, most countries have laws that protect homosexuals from discrimination, but there is still much work to be done in terms of fully understanding and accepting homosexuality as a valid form of sexuality

Nightflight to Venus is the third studio album by progressive metal band Dream Theater, released on September 25, 1994 through Atlantic Records. It is the follow-up to their commercially successful album Images and Words and was produced by Kevin Elson. The album debuted at number one on the Billboard charts and has since been certified triple platinum in the United States. It also reached number four on the UK Albums Chart. The album has been certified gold in Canada and platinum in Sweden. The song "Night Flight to Venus" is featured in the video game Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock. Dream Theater's third album, Nightflight to Venus, marks a shift in their sound that would be continued on subsequent releases. Gone are the virtuosic technical displays of Images and Words, in its place is a more progressive style with strong melodies. Producer Kevin Elson pushed Dream Theater to their limits, requiring them to record at a faster tempo than ever before. "He wanted us to go for it," said drummer Mike Portnoy. "He didn't want us to hold back." The end result was an album that was heavier and more aggressive than their previous two releases. The title track is perhaps the most well-known song from Nightflight to Venus due to its inclusion in Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock. The song was also used as the opening theme for the Japanese anime series Cowboy Bebop.

Harold Anthony Knapp was an American mathematician. He made significant contributions to the theory of operator algebras and to the study of commutative algebra. Harold A. Knapp was born in Brooklyn, New York, on September 25, 1925. He received his undergraduate degree from Princeton University in 1945, and then went on to receive his doctorate from Cornell University in 1949. After completing his doctorate, Knapp moved to the University of California, Berkeley, where he worked for the remainder of his career. He was a professor at Berkeley from 1951 until his retirement in 1993. Knapp made significant contributions to the theory of operator algebras and to the study of commutative algebra. His work on operator algebras has led to the development of a new approach to quantum mechanics known as the Knapp-Tarski transformation. His work on commutative algebra has led to new methods for solving equations and for analyzing mathematical structures. Harold A. Knapp died on May 15, 2003.

Hugh Clark (May 6, 1867 – May 13, 1959) was an educator, newspaper editor and political figure in Ontario, Canada. He represented Bruce Centre in the Legislative Assembly of Ontario from 1902 to 1911 and Bruce North from 1911 to 1921 as a Conservative. He was born in Kincardine Township, Canada West, the son of Donald Clark and Mary McDougall, both Scottish immigrants, and was educated there. Clark taught school for several years. From 1890 to 1925, he published the Kincardine Review. In 1894, he married Katherine McKay Ross. Clark was editor for the Walkerton Herald in 1890 and managing editor for the Ottawa Citizen from 1897 to 1898. His election to the Ontario assembly in 1902 was overturned but he was elected again in the by-election which followed in 1903. Clark served as lieutenant-colonel for the Bruce militia from 1906 to 1911. He resigned his seat in the Ontario assembly in 1911 to enter federal politics. From 1917 to 1921, he was a member of the Tory-led Unionist Party. He was parliamentary secretary of Militia and Defence from 1918 to 1920. Clark was defeated when he ran for reelection as a Conservative in 1921, 1925 and 1926.

The 24th Army (German: 24. Armee) was a World War II field army of the German Army. History The army was formed in October 1944 and was tasked with the defence of southern Germany. The army was commanded by General der Infanterie Hans Schmidt. Formed on the basis of the staff of the V. Armeekorps, between February and April 1945, the army had no units assigned to it. Part of the Alpenfestung, its immediate task was to stop a possible Allied advance through neutral Switzerland. In April 1945, the 405th Division was transferred to it from the 19th Army to serve as the nucleus around which the 24th Army was to be built, but the army never had a paper strength of more than 9,000 men and capitulated to the American VI Corps commander Edward H. Brooks, along with the 19th Army, in May 1945 without having engaged in combat operations.

Ozwald Boateng, OBE (born 28 February 1984) is a German professional footballer who plays as a centre back for Premier League club Leicester City. Boateng began his career at Hamburger SV, before joining Bayern Munich in 2003. He spent six seasons at the club, winning the Bundesliga twice and the DFB-Pokal once. He joined English club Manchester City in 2013, helping them to win the Premier League in his first season. He then moved to Leicester City in 2017, where he has won the Premier League twice and the League Cup. Boateng has also represented Germany at international level, making over 60 appearances. He was part of their squads that reached the semi-finals of both the 2006 FIFA World Cup and the 2010 FIFA World Cup. Ozwald Boateng was born on 28 February 1984 in Lüneburg, Lower Saxony, West Germany. His father is Ghanaian and his mother is German. He started playing football at a young age and played for local side Rot-Weiß Lüneburg before joining Hamburger SV's youth system in 1999. After impressing during trials with Hamburger SV's reserve side, he made his first-team debut on 6 October 2002 in a Bundesliga match against Werder Bremen; he finished the match with two yellow cards. Boateng progressed through Hamburger SV's youth system and made his Bundesliga debut on 6 October 2002 in a 2–1 victory over Werder Bremen. He made 74 appearances

William King (February 9, 1768June 17, 1852) was an American politician who served as the seventh Governor of New York from 1828 to 1832. He also served as a United States Senator from 1837 to 1841. Born on February 9, 1768, in New York City, King was the son of a wealthy merchant and manufacturer. He attended the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University) and then studied law. He was admitted to the bar in 1792 and commenced practice in Albany, New York. King was elected as a Federalist to the Ninth United States Congress and served from March 4, 1803, until his resignation on December 2, 1804. During his congressional tenure, he supported Andrew Jackson's successful campaign for the presidency in 1828. After leaving Congress, King was appointed by President John Quincy Adams as Governor of New York on January 24, 1828. He served until March 3, 1832. During his time as governor, he presided over major improvements to the state's infrastructure, including the construction of canals and roads. He also enacted a number of social reforms, including a bill providing pensions for retired soldiers and a law providing for universal schooling. King subsequently served as a United States Senator from New York from March 4, 1837, until his resignation on December 12, 1840. In this capacity, he played an important role in passing legislation designed to protect American businesses from British competition. Chaoyangia is an extinct genus of euornithean turtle from the Early Cretaceous of China. The genus Chaoyangia is an extinct genus of euornithean turtle from the Early Cretaceous of China. The type and only known species is Chaoyangia zhengi. The genus was first described by Ji Xing in 1984. The fossils are from the Chaoyang Formation, which is located in the Liaoning Province. The type and only known species of Chaoyangia zhengi was described by Ji Xing in 1984. The fossils are from the Chaoyang Formation, which is located in the Liaoning Province. The genus is currently considered to be a valid taxon based on the results of phylogenetic analysis conducted by Ji and his colleagues. Chaoyangia zhengi is a small euornithean turtle that was approximately 2 meters long and 0.7 meters wide when alive. The shell of Chaoyangia zhengi was composed of several well-preserved scutes that covered its entire body. The skull of Chaoyangia zhengi was relatively small, having a length of just over one meter and a width of just over fifty centimeters. The teeth of Chaoyangia zhengi were very small and closely spaced, which suggests that the animal ate primarily fish and other aquatic creatures.

Cretacladoides ("cladodont likeness from the Cretaceous") is a genus of tyrannosauroid dinosaur that lived during the Upper Cretaceous period, about 112 to 110 million years ago. The type and only known species is Cretacladoides imperator, which was discovered by Argentine paleontologist Alejandro Kappelman and his colleagues in La Rioja Province, Argentina in 2011. The specimen consists of a partial skeleton including the skull, mandible, and spinal column. The describers assigned it to the Tyrannosauridae, and named it after the Latin word for "emperor", "imperator". Cretacladoides is a small tyrannosauroid, measuring at in length. The holotype specimen has a long snout and small eyes. The teeth are fused into a single jagged blade in the upper jaw, similar to those of other tyrannosauroids such as Tarbosaurus and Albertosaurus. The lower jaw is much more primitive, with smaller teeth that may have been used for feedings on vegetation. The skeleton is heavily damaged, hindering determination of many anatomical details. It is currently assumed that Cretacladoides was a herbivore, based on the large size of its teeth and the fact that other tyrannosauroids were also herbivores at this time. However, further study is needed to confirm this hypothesis.

Colin Ernest John Guest (7 October 1937 – 7 December 2018) was an Australian cricketer who played in the Third Test at Sydney in the 1962–63 Ashes series. A fast-medium bowler, Guest played first-class cricket for Victoria from 1958–59 to 1963–64 and for Western Australia in 1966–67. Cricket career During the 1962–63 season Guest took his best innings and match figures (7 for 95 and 10 for 134) for Victoria against Western Australia in Melbourne. He was brought in to the Test side to replace Ken Mackay. Guest was used to support Alan Davidson and Garth McKenzie. Although Australia won the Test, and Guest took part in an important partnership with Barry Shepherd for the tenth wicket, Guest failed to take a wicket and was dropped in favour of a return for Mackay. He maintained his good form at interstate level and, topping the Sheffield Shield averages with 39 wickets at 18.28, he helped Victoria to win the competition.

The Cairo Conference against U.S. hegemony and militarism was an international conference convened in Cairo, Egypt in December 2001. The main topics debated at the conference were the U.S. occupation of Iraq, the role of Israel in the region, and U.S. support for terrorism. Participants also expressed concerns about U.S. plans to expand NATO eastward, and called for an end to all military intervention in Afghanistan. Rudolf Breitscheid (2 November 1874 – 28 August 1944) was a German politician and leading member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD) during the Weimar Republic. Once leader of the liberal Democratic Union, he joined the SPD in 1912. He defected to the Independent Social Democratic Party of Germany (USPD) in 1917 due to his opposition to the First World War, and rejoined the SPD in 1922. He served as a senior member of and foreign policy spokesman for the SPD Reichstag group during the Weimar Republic, and was a member of the German delegation to the League of Nations. After the Nazi rise to power, he was among the members of the Reichstag who voted against the Enabling Act of 1933, and soon after fled to France to avoid persecution. He was arrested and handed to the Gestapo in 1941, and died in Buchenwald concentration camp in 1944. Early life Breitscheid was born on 2 November 1874 in Cologne to working-class Protestant parents. His father Wilhelm worked in a bookshop, and died when Rudolf was nine years old. His mother Wilhelmine was the daughter of a tailor. He began studying law at Cologne's Friedrich-Wilhelm Gymnasium in 1894, but moved within the year to Marburg to study politics. In 1898 he completed his PhD with a dissertation on "land policy in the Australian colonies".

Paul Ludwig Hans Anton von Beneckendorff und von Hindenburg (; 2 August 1847 – 3 August 1934) was the last German Emperor, as well as the first president of the Weimar Republic. A member of the German National People's Party (DNVP), he was Chancellor of Germany from 1925 to 1933. He played an important role in the development of the Weimar Republic, and helped to bring about World War II by his aggressive foreign policy. Hindenburg is widely considered to have been one of the most unsuccessful German leaders of his time. After his death, he was succeeded by his son, Adolf Hitler. Hindenburg was born in Potsdam, then part of Prussia, into a wealthy family. After studying at the universities of Berlin and Heidelberg, he became an officer in the Prussian Army in 1869. In 1876, he married Hermine von Einem, with whom he had five children. In 1911, Hindenburg became president of the German Central Power Association (Zentralverband Deutscher Kraftwerke or DVK), a position he held until 1919. In 1918–1919, Hindenburg served as President of Germany and presided over a period of significant transformation in Germany following World War I. As head of state, Hindenburg encouraged economic reform and made efforts to resolve disputes between political parties. The Canongate is a street and associated district in central Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland. The street forms the main eastern length of the Royal Mile while the district is the main eastern section of Edinburgh's Old Town. It began when David I of Scotland, by the Great Charter of Holyrood Abbey c.1143, authorised the Abbey to found a burgh separate from Edinburgh between the Abbey and Edinburgh. The burgh of Canongate that developed was controlled by the Abbey until the Scottish Reformation when it came under secular control. In 1636 the adjacent city of Edinburgh bought the feudal superiority of the Canongate but it remained a semi-autonomous burgh under its own administration of bailies chosen by Edinburgh magistrates, until its formal incorporation into the city in 1856. The burgh gained its name from the route that the canons of Holyrood Abbey took to Edinburgh - the canons' way or the canons' gait, from the Scots word gait meaning "way". In more modern times, the eastern end is sometimes referred to as part of the Holyrood area of the city.

The Cross de l'Acier is an annual cross country running competition that is held in late November in Leffrinckoucke, France. First held in 1990, it is one of the foremost competitions of its type in France. Ten races are held at the event for athletes of varying abilities. Around 2200 runners took part in the day's event in 2010. The course of the competition is held around the Fort des Dunes – part of a set of military fortifications used in the First World War known as the Séré de Rivières system. The men's international elite race covers 9.95 km while the women's race takes place over 6.55 km. These races are used by French athletes to gain selection for the national team at the European Cross Country Championships, which is held a month after the event. The elite competition currently holds permit status from European Athletics, alongside the Cross Internacional de Soria among others.

Classical Anatolia is Anatolia during Classical Antiquity. Early in that period, Anatolia was divided into several Iron Age kingdoms, most notably Lydia in the west, Phrygia in the center and Urartu in the east. Anatolia fell under Achaemenid Persian rule c. 550 BC. In the aftermath of the Greco-Persian Wars, all of Anatolia remained under Persian control except for the Aegean coast, which was incorporated in the Delian League in the 470s BC. Alexander the Great finally wrested control of the whole region from Persia in the 330s BC. After Alexander's death, his conquests were split amongst several of his trusted generals, but were under constant threat of invasion from both the Gauls and other powerful rulers in Pergamon, Pontus, and Egypt. The Seleucid Empire, the largest of Alexander's territories, and which included Anatolia, became involved in a disastrous war with Rome culminating in the battles of Thermopylae and Magnesia. The resulting Treaty of Apamea in (188 BC) saw the Seleucids retreat from Anatolia. The Kingdom of Pergamum and the Republic of Rhodes, Rome's allies in the war, were granted the former Seleucid lands in Anatolia. Anatolia subsequently became contested between the neighboring rivalling Romans and the Parthian Empire, which frequently culminated in the Roman-Parthian Wars.

Chiu has also appeared in several minor film roles. In 2003, Chiu was cast in the role of Denise Ng on the Australian soap opera Neighbours. Monism attributes oneness or singleness (Greek: μόνος) to any entity or concept, including individual beings, objects, and ideas. Monism is the philosophical position that attributes oneness or singleness to any entity or concept, including individual beings, objects, and ideas. This might be called "unitary monism" if it regards a single thing as the source of all existence or "plural monism" if it regards multiple things as being essentially equivalent. In both cases, the term "monism" is used pejoratively to suggest that the thinker in question poses thinking about entities and concepts in an insufficiently complex way. The history of the concept of monism is complex and has many different interpretations. One of the earliest recorded mentions of the idea comes from the 6th century BCE philosopher Parmenides, who argued that there is only one thing in the universe, which he named "the One". Parmenides's student Zeno of Elea also argued for monism, but in a more sophisticated way that has since been abandoned. Monism was popularised in the 3rd century BCE by Plato, who argued that there is only one kind of thing in the world: Forms. Forms are eternal and unchanging, and exist outside of time and space. Action regulation theory (or Activity regulation theory) is a model of organizational behavior that postulates that individuals and groups regulate their behavior in order to maintain a desired level of activity within organizations. The model was first proposed by researchers at the University of Minnesota in the 1970s, and has been influential in the study of work and organizational behavior. The theory is based on the premise that organizations are dynamic systems that are constantly seeking to maintain a desired level of activity. This level of activity is typically determined by three factors: the level of customer demand, the amount of available resources, and the organization's ability to respond to customer demand. The theory is based on the assumption that individuals and groups regulate their behavior in order to maintain a desired level of activity within organizations. The model was first proposed by researchers at the University of Minnesota in the 1970s, and has been influential in the study of work and organizational behavior. The theory has been used to explain a wide range of phenomena, including employee motivation, performance management, team dynamics, communication patterns, and organizational change. It has also been used to develop a number of empirically based models for studying these phenomena. The theory has been criticized for its lack of empirical support, its reliance on static assumptions about the nature of organizations, and its failure to account for variation across organizations. However, the theory remains an important tool for studying organizational behavior and remains an important part of research on work and employee motivation
