The Roadside is an EP by English rock band Radiohead. It was released on 10 September 2004 through EMI Records, and reached number four on the UK Albums Chart. The Roadside is the first release from Radiohead in four years, following the release of Hail to the Thief in 2003. The album was recorded in Dorset, England, and was produced by Nigel Godrich. The album features a more experimental sound than their previous work, with guitars and drums being played largely live and without any overdubs. The Roadside received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised its experimental sound and Thom Yorke's vocals. However, some reviewers found the album difficult to listen to, and criticized its lack of cohesion. The Roadside has been certified gold by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).

The history of Madagascar is distinguished clearly by the early isolation of the landmass from the ancient supercontinent containing Africa and India, and by the island's late colonization by human settlers from the Sunda islands (Malay Archipelago) and from East Africa. These two factors facilitated the evolution and survival of thousands of endemic plant and animal species, some of which have gone extinct or are currently threatened with extinction due to the government not allocating resources to help the growing population, causing many people to resort to harmful environmental practices as a way of survival. Trade in the Indian Ocean at the time of first colonization of Madagascar was dominated by large ships, called Djong, coming from Java and Sumatra. Over the past two thousand years the island has received waves of settlers of diverse origins including Austronesian, Bantu, Arab, South Asian, Chinese and European. The majority of the population of Madagascar today is a mixture of Austronesian and Bantu settlers. Despite popular belief, there has been no genetic input from Arabs or Indians, although one tribe, the Antemoro, claims descent from Somali Arab traders. European and Middle eastern paternal ancestry is also present.

David Luchins (born 1946) is a professor at Touro College and chair of its political science department. He is a national vice-president of the Orthodox Union and a national officer of the Jewish Council for Public Affairs (JCPA). Luchins is a "much-lauded longtime Orthodox Jewish activist" who is active in Jewish communal life and is a frequent speaker on educational, political and Jewish topics. Luchins served as an aide to then-Vice President Hubert Humphrey and for 20 years on the Senate staff of New York Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Life and career Luchins was born in New York City, the eldest son of Abraham Luchins, a Gestalt psychologist, and Edith Hirsch Luchins, a mathematician and psychologist, who was one of the first women to serve on the national board of the Orthodox Union. He is a graduate of Yeshiva College, where he studied under Rabbi Ahron Soloveichik in his sophomore year and four years under Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik. In 1977, Luchins earned his Ph.D. from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. He has been chairman of the political science department at Touro College since 1978, where he teaches courses in American politics and international relations and serves as founding dean of Touro's Lander College for Women.

George Harold Van Allen (June 22, 1901 – September 14, 1992) was an American astrophysicist who made seminal contributions to the understanding of the Earth's radiation belts and the magnetic fields that protect us from the solar wind. Van Allen was born in Madison, Wisconsin, and earned his A.B. degree in 1923 from the University of Wisconsin. He worked at the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory (now Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory) from 1923 to 1937, where he became chief physicist. In 1938 he joined the staff of the University of Iowa, where he served as professor of physics until his retirement in 1971. During World War II, Van Allen was head of the Radiation Laboratory at MIT. He supervised the development of radar technology and was a member of the scientific team that developed Ultra-High Frequency (UHF) radar. In 1958 he received the Nobel Prize in Physics jointly with James Van Allen for their discoveries concerning charged particles in the Earth's atmosphere and their role in climate. Van Allen died at age 89 in 1992 in Iowa City, Iowa.

Bronisław Dąbrowski (2 November 1917 – 25 December 1996) was a Polish statesman, Marshal of the Republic of Poland and a member of the Polish United Workers' Party. Born in 1917 in the town of Częstochowa, Dąbrowski joined the Polish Army in 1939, fighting in the Invasion of Poland and the Battle of France before being captured by the Germans and spending two years as a prisoner of war. After his release he resumed his military career, rising to the rank of brigadier general. He served in various staff positions during the Second World War and was involved in Operation Ostra Brama, leading a Polish partisan unit that liberated Auschwitz concentration camp in January 1945. After the war, Dąbrowski became a deputy minister of defence and later deputy minister of interior. He served as Minister of National Defense from 1956 to 1959 and Minister of Defence again from 1967 to 1970. He was also a member of the Senate and president of Poland's National Bank (1971–1976). In 1976 he was appointed honorary president of Poland's Football Association. Dąbrowski died on 25 December 1996 in Warsaw.

Edmund Charles Fox Strudwick (born March 25, 1802) at Long Meadows, north of Hillsborough, in Orange County, North Carolina. He eventually designed the first building at Dorothea Dix mental hospital (then called the State Hospital for the Insane) in 1848, where he also was chosen as the first "Physician and Superintendent," a temporary position he held until 1853. He was also instrumental in the founding of the medical school at the University of North Carolina, and was elected the North Carolina Medical Society's first president April 17, 1849. His early education was at Hillsborough's Bingham School. After his father, William Strudwick, died in 1810, Dr. James Webb became his guardian. Strudwick was listed as a "transient member" of the Dialectic Society of the University of North Carolina in 1823, and graduated as a doctor of medicine from the University of Pennsylvania in 1824. After graduation, he served for two years as a resident physician at the Philadelphia Almshouse and Hospital.

Arturs Krišjānis Kariņš (born 13 December 1964) is an American-Latvian politician who has served as the Prime Minister of Latvia since 2019. A linguist and businessperson by profession, he previously served as Latvia's Minister of Economics and a Member of the European Parliament. Born in Wilmington, Delaware, United States, to parents who had left Latvia during the Soviet occupation, he was active in the American Latvian community throughout his youth. After graduating with a bachelor's degree summa cum laude and PhD in linguistics from the University of Pennsylvania, Kariņš moved to Latvia in 1997 and founded a frozen food business. He helped found the New Era Party in 2002, which in 2011 merged with others to form the Unity Party (renamed New Unity in 2018). After serving as a deputy in Latvia's parliament (the Saeima), as Minister of Economics, and also as a Member of the European Parliament throughout the 2000s and 2010s, Kariņš was selected by New Unity to be its prime ministerial candidate in the 2018 Latvian parliamentary election. Following the election, New Unity was the smallest party elected to the 13th Saeima.

Cape Race is a point of land at the entrance to St. John's Harbour in Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada. It is also the northernmost point of mainland North America. The cape is located on the eastern shore of Trinity Bay, which separates the Newfoundland mainland from the island of Newfoundland. It is one of the most northerly points on the North American continent. Cape Race is named after the Dutch vessel Zeehaan, which first sighted it on Christmas Day in 1610 while exploring the coast. The cape has been a popular shipping route since ancient times and was used by Vikings as a landing point on their way to colonize North America. It was also used by French and British explorers in the 17th and 18th centuries. In 1749, 1752 and 1755, James Cook sailed along the coast of Newfoundland from Cape Race to Port-Royal. In 1819, John Cabot landed on Cape Race and claimed Newfoundland for England.

Clarence "Clay" Morrow is a fictional character in the FX television series Sons of Anarchy. He is played by Ron Perlman. Morrow is one of the original "First 9" members of the Sons of Anarchy Motorcycle Club Redwood Original (SAMCRO), but is not a founding member. He is the former International President of the Sons of Anarchy Motorcycle Club, However, during the fourth season, Clay involves the club in drug smuggling with the cartel for his own protection, wavering in his allegiance, and gradually reveals himself to be one of the story's antagonists. His character is based on King Claudius; the King of Denmark and Prince Hamlet's uncle and father-in-law from William Shakespeare's play Hamlet. Biography Morrow was born on February 14, 1949. He has a number of tattoos, most notably a Grim Reaper on his upper right arm and a Paratrooper tattoo on his upper left, along with the words "Death From Above" indicating that he served as a paratrooper in a military unit. On his kutte, he wears patches reading "President", "First 9", "Men of Mayhem" and "Unholy Ones". He also wears a golden pin of the same symbol on his kutte. This symbol is often confused with the US Army Parachutist badge. The Paratrooper symbol that Clay wears is an unofficial symbol, and would serve to indicate service, particularly combat service, as a paratrooper, and consists of a skull, with wings coming from the bottom of the skull, and curving up to meet the top of the skull.

Fanny Rose Howie ( or Poata; 11 October 1874 – 17 December 1927) was a New Zealand artist. Born in the town of Thames, Northland, Howie is best known for her paintings of Māori people and landscapes. She spent most of her career in Auckland, where she exhibited with the Auckland Art Gallery and the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts. Howie died in Auckland at the age of 57 from a coronary thrombosis. Fanny Rose Howie was born on 11 October 1874 in Thames, Northland, New Zealand to parents James Poata and Elizabeth (née Ford). Fanny's brothers were James (1868-1939), William (1872-1956), and Arthur (1875-1952). Fanny grew up in Thames and showed an early interest in art. In 1890 she moved to Auckland to study art at the School of Design (now the Auckland Teachers' College). There she met fellow student Walter Nash, with whom she formed a close friendship. Howie completed her studies in 1896 and went into practice as a schoolteacher. However, she continued to paint and exhibited her work regularly from 1900 onwards. In 1905 she married George Howie (1871-1956), with whom she had two daughters: Ngaire (1906-1981) and Jill (1910-2001). The Howies lived in Parnell for many years before moving to Epsom in 1927. The Harper Family House is a historic house on Maine State Route 5 in Limerick, Maine. Estimated to date to 1809, it is one Limerick's few brick 19th-century houses, and possibly its oldest. It was owned by a single family for 144 years. The house was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1998. Description and history The Harper Family House is located on the west side of Route 5, in southern Limerick between Woodridge Drive and Austin Lane. It is a brick Cape style house, stories in height, with a side gable roof, two chimneys, and a granite foundation. The main facade, facing roughly east, is eight bays wide, reflecting an original five-bay block and a wing whose front is flush with that block. A wood-frame ell extends to the rear, joining the house to a modern garage and barn. The front facade has two entrances, one an elaborate Federal period surround with sidelights at the center of the original main block. Alterations to the building have been relatively limited, including the addition of dormers and the replacement of the front door.

Eldora (pronounced el-DOH-ruh), previously known as "Eldorado" then "El-Dora", then Eldora or Camp Eldorado, and still called Happy Valley, is an unincorporated community and a census-designated place (CDP) located in and governed by Boulder County, Colorado, United States. The CDP is a part of the Boulder, CO Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population of the Eldora CDP was 142 at the United States Census 2010. The Nederland post office (Zip Code 80466) serves the area. Eldora is located within the Roosevelt National Forest, and is primarily a rural, densely forested, and sparsely populated area. Eldora is tucked into the valley carved by glaciation during the last ice age and by Middle Boulder Creek. From the village there are views up toward the alpine ski runs of Eldora Mountain Resort. A one-time gold camp, Eldora was a shipping point for the Caribou silver mine in nearby Nederland, CO. At present, Eldora is characterized by small cabins, a sprinkling of vacation homes, and several long-shuttered mercantiles.

Yantai, formerly known as Chefoo, is a prefecture-level city in Shandong Province, China. It is located on the southern coast of the Shandong Peninsula and is bounded to the east by the Yellow Sea, to the north by Weifang Bay, to the west by the Bohai Sea and to the south by Linyi City. The population of Yantai was 9,596,100 as of 2010. The city has a long history and has been inhabited since at least 4000 BC. The city was once known as "Chefoo" () during the Eastern Han Dynasty and "Jinsha" during the Tang Dynasty. In 1666, during the reign of the Kangxi Emperor, a Dutch merchant ship ran aground on a sandbar off Yantai and was destroyed. In 1853, during the reign of the Guangxu Emperor, British forces captured Yantai from Qing dynasty forces during the Second Opium War. In 1912, during World War I, German forces captured Yantai from Chinese forces and held it for four years. In 1949, after the Chinese Civil War ended, Yantai became part of China. The economy of Yantai is mainly based on agriculture and fishing. The city is also an important transportation hub and has an extensive network of roads and railways. Yantai is home to two universities, three research institutes and several major industrial companies.

The Gubru are a fictional extraterrestrial race in David Brin's Uplift Universe series. Their full name is Gubru ab-Gooksyu-ul-Kwackoo-ul-Okukoo. Most Gubru are neuter and white in plumage color, but after consumption of certain hormones, triads of Gubru begin a path toward gender and sexual maturity. These triads are considered royalty, "Roost Masters" with the queens a deep red color, and the princes either blue or amber. Both princes are required to fertilize a queen's eggs, and the queens are at the top of the hierarchy. The Molt process to determine which member of the triad will become which gender, is a complex one. Each has an assumed role as a Suzerain (of Beam and Talon, Propriety, or Cost and Caution), and in their search for a new policy consensus, the member whose ideas are most successful becomes the queen of the triad.

A hazard analysis is used as the basis for the prevention, assessment and management of risks. The analysis of hazards is a necessary step in the development of risk management plans. Risk management is the process of identifying, assessing, and controlling risks associated with the management of resources and information. Risk management includes the identification of risks, the assessment of their probability and severity, the determination of acceptable levels of risk, and the implementation of appropriate measures to reduce or eliminate those risks. Risk assessment is the process of determining the nature and magnitude of potential risks to a system, asset or operation. It involves consideration of all relevant factors, including those that are intrinsic to the system, those that are extrinsic to the system, and those that are environmental. Hazard identification is the process of identifying hazards and their potential effects. Hazards can be physical, chemical or biological. Physical hazards are dangers that are associated with the physical environment, such as fire, gas explosions or floods. Chemical hazards are dangers that are associated with chemicals used in manufacturing or processing or in the environment, such as acids or poisons. Biological hazards are dangers posed by microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses or fungi. Hazard assessment is the process of determining whether a hazard exists and how serious it is likely to be. It involves an evaluation of both known risk factors and potential unknown risk factors. Known risk factors are those that have been identified through previous hazard assessments or surveys. Osasumwen Osaghae Jr. (born July 29, 1998) is an American football linebacker for the University of Alabama Crimson Tide. Osasumwen Osaghae Jr. was born on July 29, 1998 in Birmingham, Alabama. He attended Huffman High School in Birmingham, and played football for the Huffman Eagles. As a senior, Osasumwen was named to the All-State first team and earned all-region honors. Osasumwen also played basketball and ran track at Huffman. Osasumwen attended the University of Alabama, and played for the Alabama Crimson Tide football team as a linebacker. He was redshirted in his first year at Alabama, and played in all 14 games as a true freshman in 2017. As a sophomore in 2018, Osasumwen started all 14 games at linebacker and led the team with 137 tackles (8 for loss), 2 sacks, and 2 interceptions. In his junior year in 2019, Osasumwen started all 14 games at linebacker and was again among the leaders with 131 tackles (7 for loss), 1 sack, 2 interceptions, and 1 fumble recovery. Osasumwen is a native of Birmingham, Alabama. He is the son of Osasumwen Osaghae Sr., who played college football at Tuskegee University and professionally in the American Football League (AFL). His younger brother, Osasumwen Osaghae III, also plays football for the University of Alabama Crimson Tide.

Andrew Fernando Holmes (March 17, 1797 – October 9, 1860) was a Canadian physician, academic, and one of the founders of the Montreal Medical Institution, the first medical school in Canada. His family were emigrating to North America when they were captured by pirates and he was born in Cádiz, Spain, the son of Thomas Holmes and Susanna Scott, his family eventually reached British North America in 1801 settling in Montreal. A physician, he received a diploma from the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh in 1818 and a Doctor of Medicine degree from University of Edinburgh in 1819. Returning to Canada, he practiced medicine joining the staff of the Montreal General Hospital in 1822. He founded the Montreal Medical Institution, the first medical school in Canada, in 1823 with John Stephenson. After failing to receive a royal charter, the Montreal Medical Institution joined McGill College to become the McGill College Medical Faculty. Holmes became a founding member of the faculty. In 1843, he was appointed professor of the principles and practice of medicine and became head of the faculty. In 1854, his title was changed to dean.

Sociocultural evolution, sociocultural evolutionism or cultural evolution are theories of sociobiology and cultural evolution that describe how societies and culture change over time. Whereas sociocultural development traces processes that tend to increase the complexity of a society or culture, sociocultural evolution also considers process that can lead to decreases in complexity (degeneration) or that can produce variation or proliferation without any seemingly significant changes in complexity (cladogenesis). Sociocultural evolution is "the process by which structural reorganization is affected through time, eventually producing a form or structure which is qualitatively different from the ancestral form". Most of the 19th-century and some 20th-century approaches to socioculture aimed to provide models for the evolution of humankind as a whole, arguing that different societies have reached different stages of social development. The most comprehensive attempt to develop a general theory of social evolution centering on the development of sociocultural systems, the work of Talcott Parsons (1902–1979), operated on a scale which included a theory of world history. Another attempt, on a less systematic scale, originated from the 1970s with the world-systems approach of Immanuel Wallerstein (1930-2019) and his followers.  More recent approaches focus on changes specific to individual societies and reject the idea that cultures differ primarily according to how far each one has moved along some presumed linear scale of social progress. Most modern archaeologists and cultural anthropologists work within the frameworks of neoevolutionism, sociobiology, and modernization theory.

Hydroelectricity is a critical source of electricity in Turkey. The country has the third-largest hydroelectric capacity in the world, after China and Brazil. Although hydroelectricity was first developed in Turkey in the late 19th century, the country’s modern hydroelectric industry began in the 1920s. At that time, the Turkish government commissioned a number of large hydroelectric projects, most notably the Southeastern Anatolian Project (Gölcük-Kırıkkale) and the Marmara-Brak Lake Project (Çam-Köyü). Despite this early investment, hydroelectricity played a relatively limited role in Turkey’s economy until the early 1960s. That year, however, a series of large dam projects—the Keban Dam (Keban), the Akkuyu Dam (Akkuyu), and the Ilisu Dam (Ilisu)—were completed, significantly enhancing hydroelectricity’s role in Turkey’s energy portfolio. Today, hydroelectricity provides more than half of Turkey’s total electricity generation. The country’s ongoing investment in hydroelectricity is reflected in its impressive installed capacity. As of 2017, Turkey had a total installed capacity of 37,692 megawatts (MW), ranking third in the world behind China and Brazil. Llywelyn Bren , or Llywelyn ap Gruffudd ap Rhys / Llywelyn ap Rhys (also Llewelyn) or in . He was a nobleman who led a 1316 revolt in Wales in the reign of King Edward II of England. It marked the last serious challenge to English rule in Wales until the attempts of Owain Lawgoch to invade with French support in the 1370s. Hugh Despenser the Younger's unlawful execution of Llywelyn Bren helped to lead to the eventual overthrow of both Edward II and Hugh. Lineage Llywelyn Bren was a Welsh nobleman of the minor royal house of the cantref of Senghenydd, (previously Cantref Breiniol) and Miscin, and was also a descendant of Ifor Bach, his great-grandfather. His father was Gruffudd ap Rhys. Llywelyn is thought to have been born before 1267, as Gruffudd was dispossessed of the lordship of Senghenydd in that year by Gilbert de Clare, 7th Earl of Gloucester and then imprisoned in Ireland. There is no record of him returning to Wales. Llywelyn married Lleucu (died 1349). They produced at least seven sons, who also took part in the revolt.

The Congregation Montefiore Synagogue is a historic synagogue located at the corner of Lexington and Concord Avenues in the Bronx, New York City. It is the oldest continuously operating synagogue in the United States. The Congregation Montefiore was founded in 1786 by a group of Sephardic Jews who had fled the Inquisition in Spain. The synagogue, then known as the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, was the first Jewish house of worship built in what is now New York City. The congregation grew rapidly, and by 1827 had outgrown its original building. A new synagogue was erected on the same site and formally dedicated on May 10, 1828. The Congregation Montefiore has played a significant role in American Jewish history. It was instrumental in helping to create the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, and served as the organizational center for many other major Jewish organizations in the United States. The synagogue also played a significant role in the development of Reform Judaism in America, and remains one of the leading Reform synagogues in the country. Today, the Congregation Montefiore boasts a membership of more than 1,000 people and operates a number of branches throughout New York City and elsewhere in New York State. The synagogue is also home to a library and archives that are open to researchers free of charge.

Iosif Ivanovich Popov (; 15 September 1898 – 15 May 1954) was a Soviet military commander and a Hero of the Soviet Union. He was one of the most successful commanders of the Second World War, leading Soviet tank and infantry units to victories on the Eastern Front. He is regarded as one of the best commanders in history. Iosif Popov was born on 15 September 1898 in the city of Taganrog, in the Russian Empire. After graduating from the Taganrog School of Marine Engineering in 1917, he served in the Imperial Russian Navy during World War I. He fought in the Baltic Sea Campaign and on the Eastern Front, where he participated in several major battles. After the war, he continued his naval service and rose through the ranks to become a captain. In 1937, Popov was transferred to the Soviet Army and assigned to the 1st Tank Regiment, which later became part of the 1st Tank Division. He soon became a highly respected commander and was given command of a tank unit. In December 1941, he led his unit in an attack on German positions near Brody and Kholmogory. His unit achieved a spectacular victory and earned him fame throughout the Soviet Union. In 1942, Popov was transferred to the Caucasus Front, where he participated in several major battles, including Operation Uranus and Operation Bagration. He was later given command of a tank division and participated in Operation Bagration II, which led to the capture of Berlin. After the war, Popov

Andrew Maxwell Haden (26 September 195029 July 2020) was a New Zealand rugby union player and All Black captain. He played at lock for Auckland and New Zealand from 1972 until 1985. He also played club rugby in the United Kingdom and Italy. Life and career Haden was born in Wanganui on 26 September 1950. He attended Wanganui Boys' College. He made his All Black debut in 1972, and his Test debut against the British Lions in 1977, going on to make 41 Test appearances and scoring two tries. Of those 41 appearances, 8 were as captain of the All Blacks. Haden was noted for his powerful scrummage skills and for his imposing presence at the lineout. He played club rugby for Auckland, Harlequins in London and Algida Rome in Italy. Off the field, he published his autobiography, Boots ’n All, in 1983. By receiving royalties from the book, he ostensibly tested the sport's strict amateurism rules in force back then. He ultimately prevailed, however, by claiming that being a writer was his profession.

Omar Shafik Hammami (, Umar Shafīq Hammāmī; born December 8, 1981) is a U.S. citizen who was convicted on terrorism charges for his role in the 2009 attempted Times Square bombing. Hammami was born in 1981 in Birmingham, Alabama, to Palestinian parents. He moved to Yemen with his family when he was three years old, and returned to the United States at the age of eleven. He attended high school in Tampa, Florida. Hammami converted to Islam in 2002 and changed his name to Omar Shafik Hammami. In 2006, Hammami traveled to Afghanistan to teach English to Taliban fighters. He later traveled to Iraq to fight against the American occupation, and became a member of Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI). In 2009, he attempted to detonate a bomb at the New York City subway station Times Square during New Year's Eve celebrations. The device failed to detonate and Hammami was subsequently arrested by the FBI. He has since pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges and is serving a life sentence without parole. Hammami has been described as an "extremist ideologue" and "militant jihadist". He has been accused of promoting radical Islamist ideas through online videos and speeches, recruiting others into terrorism, and planning attacks against Western targets.

Ernst Peter Burger (September 1, 1906 – October 10, 1965) was a German-born American philosopher and academic who spent most of his career at the University of California, Berkeley. Burger was born in Mönchengladbach, Germany, to Protestant parents. He attended the University of Heidelberg, where he received his doctorate in 1928. After a year of postdoctoral study at the University of Freiburg, he took a position at the University of California, Berkeley in 1930. There he became a full professor in 1946 and retired in 1965. Burger is best known for his work in ethics, which focused on questions such as the nature and justification of morality, the relationship between reason and emotion, and the basis of human freedom. He also wrote extensively on philosophy of science, philosophy of language, and philosophy of religion. Burger was a prolific writer, publishing more than seventy books and hundreds of articles and essays. He was also a popular lecturer, frequently giving public talks on philosophical topics. In 1964 he was awarded the first Wittgenstein Prize for his lifetime contributions to philosophy.

Frank Ryder (born 7 March 1909 – died 4 February 1977) was an English actor. Ryder was born in London, the son of a theatrical agent. After appearing in school plays, he made his stage debut in 1923 at the age of 12. He attended the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, where he met and later married actress Sylvia Sidney. Ryder's first role on Broadway was as Lieutenant Peter Quell in "The Sea Hawk" (1935). He then appeared in a number of British films before making his American debut in "The Lost Patrol" (1937), starring Spencer Tracy and Edward G. Robinson. Ryder's most famous American film role was as the title character in "The Man Who Knew Too Much" (1956), which starred James Stewart and Doris Day. Ryder retired from acting in the early 1960s, but continued to work in television until his death from cancer four years later.

Alexey Alexandrovich Surkov (; October 13, 1899 in Yaroslavl Province, Russian Empire – June 14, 1983 in Moscow, USSR) was a Russian Soviet poet, editor, literary critic and high-profile nomenklatura figure, the head of the Soviet Union of Writers in 1953–1959, notorious for his role in the persecution of Boris Pasternak Early Career Alexei Surkov was born in the village of Serednevo, in Yaroslavl region. At the age of 12 or 13, he was sent to work in a factory in St. Petersburg, where he joined the shipworkers' union after the February Revolution. He served in the Red Army for four years, during the Russian Civil War, and subsequently worked for Komsomol. He started publishing poetry in 1930, as a Komsomol activist and a member of the Russian Association of Proletarian Writers, who believed that soviet art should be politically committed and pro-communist. During a writers' meeting in April 1932, after Stalin had ordered RAPP and all other literary groups to disband and merge into a single writers' union, Surkov launched an attack on Boris Pasternak, calling him a "subjective idealist ... (for whom) the world is not outside us but inside us."

Dawuntna Delant ("Dewunt and Delant") was one of the thirteen wyanas of the Gascoyne region of Western Australia. Dawuntna Delant is located in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, approximately east of Derby and north of Halls Creek. It is bounded by the Grampians National Park to the east, the Tennant Creek National Park to the south and west, and the Stirling Range National Park to the north. The area is known for its rugged terrain, with peaks reaching up to . The name Dawuntna Delant is derived from the Djabungwunu language and means "place of plenty". The area was first explored by Europeans in 1884, when a party led by W. J. Hann was travelling from Derby to Halls Creek. They were followed by a second party, which included Hann's son-in-law J. S. Roe, who named the area Dawuntna Delant after his friend Dawuntna, an Aboriginal man who had accompanied them on their journey. Dawuntna Delant was gazetted as a district on 12 December 1957. It had an area of and consisted of three sub-districts: Wyndham, Delant and Ramingining. The district was abolished on 1 July 1992, following the release of the 1992 Gascoyne Region Regional Plan.

Grace Taylor McLaughlin (born September 5, 1995) is a retired American artistic gymnast that competed for the Florida Gators women's gymnastics team. Her desire to help others and her compassion for furthering the education of children and youth won her the 2018 SEC Brad Davis Community Service Scholarship for her graduate school studies. This scholarship is awarded to one female and one male athlete each year from all athletes competing in the Southeastern Conference. Grace is among two students who have received this award from the University of Florida. Grace graduated from the University of Florida with a degree in Family, Youth and Community Sciences and a minor in Educational studies. She continued her graduate studies at Nova Southeastern University and graduated with a Master of Public Health in 2021.

Fashion forecasting is a global career that focuses on upcoming trends. A fashion forecaster predicts the colors, fabrics, textures, materials, prints, graphics, beauty/grooming, accessories, footwear, street style, and other styles that will be presented on the runway and in the stores for the upcoming seasons. The concept applies to not one, but all levels of the fashion industry including haute couture, ready-to-wear, mass market, and street wear. Fashion trend forecasting is an overall process that focuses on other industries such as automobiles, medicine, food and beverages, literature, and home furnishings. Fashion forecasters are responsible for attracting consumers and helping retail businesses and designers sell their brands. Today, fashion industry workers rely on the Internet to retrieve information on new looks, colors, celebrity wardrobes, and designer collections. The fashion forecasting process includes the basic steps of understanding the vision of the business and profile of target customers, collecting information about available merchandise, preparing information, determining trends, and choosing merchandise appropriate for the company and target customer. Color and style are two of the important objects to forecast for most buyers and merchandisers.

Xenocatabolism is a concept in medical bioremediation that refers to the use of xenobiotics in the treatment of environmental pollutants. Xenocatabolism has been used for the treatment of environmental pollutants for over two decades. The first use of xenocatabolism in the treatment of environmental pollutants was in the 1980s when researchers discovered that the fungus Aspergillus niger can break down chemicals such as benzo(a)pyrene. Since then, xenocatabolism has been used to treat a variety of other environmental pollutants, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), heavy metals, and chemical warfare agents. Xenocatabolism is a unique approach to treating environmental pollutants because it uses natural products to degrade or neutralize chemical compounds. Unlike traditional bioremediation methods, which rely on artificial chemicals to break down environmental pollutants, xenocatabolism uses naturally occurring compounds to do the job. This is because natural products are more resistant to degradation by environmental bacteria and enzymes. Xenocatabolism is also advantageous because it is non-toxic and environmentally friendly. Unlike traditional bioremediation methods, which often produce hazardous byproducts, xenocatabolism uses benign chemicals that are easily disposed of. Additionally, xenocatabolism is fast and efficient, meaning it can quickly degrade large quantities of environmental contaminants. Despite its advantages, xenocatabolism has yet to be widely adopted because it is not always available

Leroy David Baca (born May 27, 1942) is a retired judge of the Los Angeles County Superior Court. He is the eighth person to hold that post. Baca was born in Los Angeles, California, to David and Nora Baca. He received his undergraduate degree from the University of California, Berkeley in 1964 and his law degree from the University of Southern California Law School in 1967. He was admitted to the California bar in 1967 and began practicing law in Los Angeles. Baca served as a deputy district attorney for Los Angeles County from 1972 to 1974, and as an assistant district attorney for Los Angeles County from 1974 to 1978. He was elected to the Superior Court of Los Angeles County in 1978 and re-elected in 1984, 1990, 1994, and 2000. He served as president of the California State Bar Association from 1992 to 1993. Baca was appointed by then-Governor Gray Davis to serve on the California Commission on Judicial Performance in 1999. He served on that commission until 2003. Baca was nominated by President George W. Bush to serve as a United States District Judge for the Central District of California, but his nomination was not confirmed by the United States Senate. Baca subsequently withdrew his nomination and retired from the Superior Court of Los Angeles County in 2004.

Alexey Grigoryevich Rodin (Russian: Алексей Григорьевич Родин; 17 February 1902 – 27 May 1955) was a Soviet Army colonel general and Hero of the Soviet Union. Born to a peasant family, Rodin was drafted into the Red Army in 1920. After fighting in the Russian Civil War, he became an officer and rose to command 50th Rifle Corps Armored and Mechanized forces during the Winter War. After the end of the war, Rodin became deputy commander of the 24th Tank Division and fought in the Baltic Operation and Leningrad Strategic Defensive. Given command of the 124th Tank Brigade in September 1941, he led the unit during battles around Leningrad and in the Lyuban Offensive Operation. From June 1942, Rodin commanded the 26th Tank Corps and led the unit during Operation Uranus. For its actions, the corps became the 1st Guards Tank Corps and Rodin received the title Hero of the Soviet Union. After Stalingrad, he was promoted to command the 2nd Tank Army and led it during Operation Kutuzov and the Battle of the Dnieper, but was dismissed due to lack of progress and heavy losses incurred in the army's advance. In September 1943, Rodin became commander of the Western Front (later 3rd Belorussian Front) Armored and Mechanized Forces, participating in Operation Suvorov, Operation Bagration and the East Prussian Offensive. Postwar, he became head of the Directorate of Combat Training of the Armored and Mechanized Forces before retirement in 1954.

Warwick Richard Capper (born 12 June 1963) is an English former professional footballer who played as a midfielder in the Football League for Birmingham City, Shrewsbury Town and Crewe Alexandra. Capper began his career as a trainee at Birmingham City, making his first-team debut against Sheffield Wednesday in October 1981. He went on to make over 200 appearances for the club, helping them to win the Second Division title in 1984–85 and reach the FA Cup semi-finals in 1986. He was sold to Shrewsbury Town in January 1988 for £100,000, and spent two seasons at the club before joining Crewe Alexandra in August 1990. He made over 100 appearances for Crewe, helping them reach the Football League Cup Final in 1994 and earning promotion to the Premier League in 1995. He left Crewe in February 1998 and retired from playing later that year. Capper has since worked as a football coach with Birmingham City, Crewe Alexandra and Shrewsbury Town. He is also a co-owner of non-league side Cleobury Mortimer.

McCauley and moved to New York City. She soon became a successful star on the American stage, appearing in such plays as The Rivals of Paris (1850), The Lady of the Lake (1851), Old Mortality (1853), The Merchant of Venice (1853), and The Pirates of Penzance (1852). In 1854, she toured with a company playing Sir Harry Wildair in The Heiress. In 1857, Penny made her London debut as Olivia in Twelfth Night. The Susquehannock people, also called the Conestoga, were a Native American people who lived in what is now the northeastern United States. They spoke the Conestoga language, a member of the Iroquoian language family. The Susquehannock were a powerful people in their time. They had an extensive network of villages and settlements, controlled large areas of land, and were skilled at hunting and warfare. Their territory extended from the Atlantic Ocean to the easternmost ridges of the Appalachian Mountains. They were eventually subjugated by the English colonists, but retained their culture and language until they were absorbed into other groups or disappeared as a people in the early 1800s. Today, there are few traces of the Susquehannock remaining. Most of their villages have been destroyed or abandoned, and few members of the tribe remain alive. However, their story is preserved in historical documents and oral traditions, and they continue to be celebrated by Native Americans and non-Native Americans alike as one of North America's most significant indigenous peoples.

Dr Karen Herbst is an American endocrinologist. She is noted for her work in endocrinology, Dercum's Disease, diabetes and metabolism at VA San Diego Hospital and research into Lipedema at University of Arizona College of Medicine, Tucson. Herbst is a graduate of Rush Medical College (1996). She also had a residency at the University of Washington School of Medicine (2000) and fellowship at the University of Washington School of Medicine, Endocrinology in 2002. Her work into lipedema has been conducted at the University of Arizona College of Medicine, Tucson, as part of the Treatment, Research and Education of Adipose Tissue (TREAT) Program. It involves research into adipose tissue and metabolism shifts in women. Her patients are mainly from the United States, but also come from Europe, the Middle East and Australia. One of her main goals is to improve medical imaging and phenotyping of fatty tissue, and to provide better awareness and care for the disease.

Disjunctivism is a position in the philosophy of language that states that there are no linguistic units that are independent of one another. The term was coined by the philosopher David Lewis in his book Philosophical Papers. Disjunctivism is a position in the philosophy of language that states that there are no linguistic units that are independent of one another. The term was coined by the philosopher David Lewis in his book Philosophical Papers. Disjunctivism is opposed to unitarianism, which holds that there are linguistic units, such as words or phrases, that are independent of one another and can be separated into distinct parts or categories. Disjunctivists argue that there is no such thing as a linguistic unit that is separate from other linguistic units and can be analyzed in isolation from them. According to disjunctivism, all linguistic units are interconnected and form a network or web of relationships. This network of relationships is constantly changing and evolving, and it cannot be reduced or analyzed in any way without destroying its complexity and integrity. Disjunctivists believe that this network of relationships is what gives language its unique and special properties. Disjunctivism has been controversial since it was first introduced, and many philosophers have argued against it. Some say that disjunctivism is too radical a position and does not allow for enough analysis and understanding of language. Others argue that disjunctivism does not actually explain or explain well how the network of relationships in language works.

Natalya Yevgenyevna Gorbanevskaya (; 26 May 1936 – 9 October 2006) was a Russian poet, essayist, playwright and translator. Born in Moscow into a family of artists, Gorbanevskaya studied painting at the Moscow Academy of Art from 1954 to 1959. In 1960 she moved to Paris, where she continued her studies at the Sorbonne from 1961 to 1963. She then returned to Moscow, where she worked as a journalist and an editor for various literary magazines. Gorbanevskaya's first book of poems, "The Poetics of Space" (1968), won the Lev Tolstoy Prize. Her most famous book is "Requiem" (1978), which was awarded the State Prize of the Russian Federation. She also wrote plays, including "The Seagull" (1966), "War and Peace" (1971), and "Anna Karenina" (1978). Gorbanevskaya died in 2006 in Moscow after a long illness. She was buried at the Novodevichy Cemetery.

Marjorie Tuite (1922–1986) was a progressive activist on issues related to the Church and the larger world, such as racism, poverty, war and the ordination of women. She was born and raised in New York City and joined the Dominican Sisters of the St. Mary of the Springs Order in 1942. Tuite had an undergraduate degree from Fordham University, a master's degree from Manhattanville College in Education Theology, and a Doctor of Ministry from what is today University of Saint Mary of the Lake and Mundelein Seminary. Career As an educator, Tuite filled a variety of roles. From 1960-1966, "she worked as an administrator at St. Vincent Ferrer High School. Between 1973 and 1981 she was a member of the faculty at the Jesuit School of Theology in Chicago. Before her tenure at the Jesuit School of Theology, she served on the staff on the National Urban Training Center and The Archdiocesan Center for Religious Education, both in Chicago."

Avondale is one of Chicago's 77 officially designated community areas. It is on the Northwest Side of the city. The northern border is Addison Street from the north branch of the Chicago River in the east to Pulaski Road in the west. The neighborhood extends further west along Belmont Avenue to the Union Pacific/Northwest Line. Its southern border is Diversey Avenue from the Union Pacific/Northwest Line to the Chicago River. History The first European settler in Avondale was Abraham Harris who settled the area three years after its 1850 incorporation into Jefferson Township. In 1869, Avondale was incorporated as a village. It has been speculated that developer and Pennsylvania native John Lewis Cochran named the village in honor of the miners and rescue workers who died in the Avondale coal mine fire. Atypical for the time, Avondale was racially integrated in the nineteenth century with twenty African American families moving to the area and building Avondale's first church in the 1880s. Avondale, along with the rest of Jefferson Township, was annexed by the City of Chicago in 1889.

Gustav Adolph Techow (* 1813 – 25 May 1890 in Melbourne) was an officer in the Prussian Army and a democrat. He was serving with Herman von Natzmer at the Berlin arsenal when the arsenal was stormed by the citizens of Berlin who were upset over revocation of the German constitution and the dissolution National Assembly. Natzmer was the commandant of the arsenal and he became a hero to the insurrectionists all across Europe in 1848 and 1849 because he refused to order his troops to fire on the insurgent citizens when the arsenal was stormed by the citizens on 14 June 1848. In 1849, Techow followed Natzmer to the Palatinate where Techow became Chief of the General Staff of the Baden-Palatinate insurgent army. Following the suppression of the uprising in Badena and the Palatinate, Techow escaped to Switzerland. In 1852, he emigrated with Natzmer to Australia. There he was an instructor and author for gymnastic exercises. Techow died in 1893.

Govindan Vijayaraghavan is a cardiologist from India, credited with establishing the first 2D Echocardiography laboratory in India. He is the vice-chairman & Founder Director of the Kerala Institute of Medical Sciences and the President of the Society for Continuing Medical Education and Research, Trivandrum, Kerala. He was honoured by Government of India in 2009 for his services in the field of medical sciences by awarding him Padmashri. Life Sketch Vijayaraghavan was born at Perumpuzha, Kollam, Kerala on 18 September 1942 as the son of Sahithya Siromany M. K. Govindan, a Sanskrit scholar. He did his early schooling in Trivandrum Model School and graduated in Medicine from Trivandrum Medical College in 1964 and passed MD in General Medicine in 1969. He continued his studies at Christian Medical College, Vellore, obtained his Doctorate in Cardiology (DM) in 1973 and started his career there as associate professor. He moved back to Thiruvananthapuram Medical College in 1976 and continued his research on Endomyocardial Fibrosis, a variety of heart disease found common in Kerala, in association with Post-graduate Medical School and Brompton Hospital, London.

Pierceville is an unincorporated community in Finney County, Kansas, United States. The population was 246 at the 2000 census. Pierceville was founded in 1871. It was named for Colonel Charles W. Pierce, a pioneer settler. A post office was opened at Pierceville in 1871 and remained in operation until it was discontinued in 1955. The town is located at (38.446269, -97.859216). According to the United States Census Bureau, the community has a total area of 0.1 square miles (0.2 km²), all of it land. As of the census of 2000, there were 246 people, 97 households, and 63 families residing in the community. The population density was 1,206.7 people per square mile (445.9/km²). There were 107 housing units at an average density of 441.1 per square mile (170.5/km²). The racial makeup of the community was 98.27% White, and 1.73% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.14% of the population. There were 97 households out of which 36.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 69.0% were married couples living together, 4.5% had a female householder with no husband present, and 20.4% were non-families. 16.4% of all households were made up of

The Battle of Ecbatana was fought in 129 BC between the Seleucids led by Antiochus VII Sidetes and the Parthians led by Phraates II, and marked the final attempt on the part of the Seleucids to regain their power in the east against the Parthians. After their defeat, the territory of the Seleucids was limited to the area of Syria. Battle Phraates II (ca. 139/138 BC – ca. 128 BC) faced the final attempt on the part of the Seleucids to regain their power in the east. The Seleucids amassed a large force of Greek mercenaries and led the army, totaling 80,000 soldiers, to confront the Parthians, initiating a campaign in 130 BC to retake Mesopotamia. The Parthian general Indates was defeated along the Great Zab, followed by a local uprising where the Parthian governor of Babylonia was killed. Antiochus conquered Babylonia and occupied Susa, where he minted coins, and advanced his army into Media.

Albertosaurus (; meaning "Alberta lizard") is a genus of tyrannosaurid theropod dinosaurs that lived in western North America during the Late Cretaceous Period, about 71 million years ago. The type species, A. sarcophagus, was apparently restricted in range to the modern-day Canadian province of Alberta, after which the genus is named, although an indeterminate species ("cf. Albertosaurus sp.") has been discovered in the Corral de Enmedio and Packard Formations in Mexico. Scientists disagree on the content of the genus, with some recognizing Gorgosaurus libratus as a second species. As a tyrannosaurid, Albertosaurus was a bipedal predator with tiny, two-fingered hands and a massive head that had dozens of large, sharp teeth. It may have been at the top of the food chain in its local ecosystem. While Albertosaurus was large for a theropod, it was much smaller than its larger and more famous relative Tyrannosaurus rex, growing and possibly weighing to 4 tonnes (4.4 short tons)

The Infinite Order is the seventh studio album by American progressive metal band Between the Buried and Me. It was announced on February 24, 2019, through the band's social media pages that the album was completed and would be released on April 6, 2019. The Infinite Order is the seventh studio album by American progressive metal band Between the Buried and Me. It was announced on February 24, 2019, through the band's social media pages that the album was completed and would be released on April 6, 2019. The album is a concept album based around a post-apocalyptic world where humanity has been reduced to scavenging for food and living in fortified camps. The story follows a group of survivors as they travel across the wasteland in search of sanctuary. The Infinite Order is Between The Buried And Me's first album without bassist Derek Roddy, who left the band in November 2018 to focus on his other project Behold The Arctopus.

Saraswati Rane (October 4, 1913 - October 10, 2006) was an Indian classical singer in the Hindustani Classical genre. She was a daughter of Ustad Abdul Karim Khan (1872–1937), the founder of Kirana Gharana. Her family had a long and great music tradition. She got her initial training of vocal music of the Kirana Gharana style from her elder brother Sureshbabu Mane and elder sister Hirabai Barodekar, who themselves were the doyen of Indian classical music of their times. Later she also sang along with elder sister, Hirabai Bododekar, especially in jugalbandi style. Early life and training Born on October 4, 1913 to Ustad Abdul Karim Khan (1872–1937), the founder of Kirana Gharana, and Tarabai Mane, as Sakina, she grew up in a musical household. After separating from her husband, Tarabai, her mother, renamed all her five children; hence Sakina became Kumari Saraswati Mane. She was initiated into music by her brother Sureshbabu Mane, later after 1930, she also started learning from her sister Hirabai Barodekar.

Sir William O'Brien Lindsay (8 October 1872 – 21 May 1959) was an Australian jurist and diplomat, who served as the 26th Governor-General of Australia from 1930 to 1932. Lindsay was born in Ballarat, Victoria, the son of Hugh Lindsay, a judge and Premier of Victoria. He was educated at Geelong Grammar School and the University of Melbourne, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in 1897. He was then admitted to the Victorian Bar in 1898 and practised law in Melbourne. In 1902, Lindsay was appointed a judge of the Supreme Court of Victoria. In 1916, he was appointed a judge of the Federal Court of Australia and remained on the bench until 1930. He also served as president of the Australian Law Reform Commission from 1923 to 1930. In 1930, Lindsay was appointed Governor-General of Australia, serving until 1932. During his time as Governor-General, he played an important role in promoting constitutional reform in Australia. He also undertook several overseas tours, including a trip to Europe in 1931. Lindsay retired from public life in 1933 and died in 1959 at age 88.

The history of Cambodian art stretches back centuries to ancient times, but the most famous period is undoubtedly the Khmer art of the Khmer Empire (802–1431), especially in the area around Angkor and the mainly 12th-century temple-complex of Angkor Wat, initially Hindu and subsequently Buddhist. After the collapse of the empire these and other sites were abandoned and overgrown, allowing much of the era's stone carving and architecture to survive to the present day. Traditional Cambodian arts and crafts include textiles, non-textile weaving, silversmithing, stone carving, lacquerware, ceramics, wat murals, and kite-making. Beginning in the mid-20th century, a tradition of modern art began in Cambodia, though in the later 20th century both traditional and modern arts declined for several reasons, including the killing of artists by the Khmer Rouge. The country has experienced a recent artistic revival due to increased support from governments, NGOs, and foreign tourists.

Judith Katzir (, born 1963) is an American-Israeli journalist and author. Katzir was born in 1963 in New York City, the daughter of Israeli immigrants. She attended Yeshiva University, where she received her B.A. in 1985 and her M.A. in 1989. She later studied at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, where she received a Ph.D. in 1997. Katzir began her journalistic career as a reporter for the Israeli daily "Ha'aretz". In 1995, she moved to London to join "The Guardian" as their Jerusalem correspondent, a position she held until 2000. During her time at "The Guardian", Katzir wrote several articles that were highly critical of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his policies towards the Palestinians. From 2000 to 2006, Katzir served as director of public affairs for the American Jewish Committee (AJC), a position she was appointed to by then-AJC president Edgar Bronfman Jr. Among the positions Katzir assumed during her tenure at the AJC were those of media spokesperson and senior adviser on international relations and public policy. In 2006, Katzir moved back to Jerusalem to become a columnist for "The Jerusalem Post". In 2009, she published her first book, "The Accidental Patriot: A Life in Israel", which tells the story of her family's journey from post-war Europe to Israel and their experiences during the First Intifada and Second Intifada. Pyar Ka Mausam (English: Season of love) is a 2006 Indian romantic drama film directed by Mohit Suri and produced by Aditya Chopra. It stars Shahrukh Khan and Aishwarya Rai in the lead roles, with Rani Mukherjee, Abhishek Bachchan, Prakash Raj and Divya Dutta in supporting roles. The screenplay was written by Swanand Kirkire. Peter Maclean Pollock (born 30 June 1941) is a retired South African cricketer. He has played a continuing role in the South Africa cricket team as a player and selector. He was voted a Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1966. He was primarily a fast bowler, but was also a useful late-order batsman. Family and personal life Pollock is of Scottish ancestry through his father Andrew Pollock, who was born in Edinburgh to a minister and moved to present-day South Africa. Peter's brother, Graeme Pollock, an acclaimed left hand batsman, was a regular player for the South African cricket team at the same time as Peter, and two of his nephews also played first-class cricket, both for Transvaal and Leicestershire amongst other sides. Perhaps most famous of all is his son, Shaun Pollock, who played 108 Tests and over 300 ODIs for South Africa and is widely regarded as one of the finest all-rounders to ever play the game.

Birkenia is a genus of extinct anaspid reptiles from the Late Cretaceous of what is now Kenya. The type species, Birkenia agilis, was first described by Harry G. Seeley in 1877. The genus is named after the birch tree, which is a common motif in the fossil record of Birkenia. Birkenia is a small genus of anaspid reptiles from the Late Cretaceous of what is now Kenya. The type species, Birkenia agilis, was first described by Harry G. Seeley in 1877. The genus is named after the birch tree, which is a common motif in the fossil record of Birkenia. The only known species is B. agilis, which was a small lizard measuring just over 3 feet long and weighing just over a pound. The fossils of Birkenia are restricted to the Maasai Crater Formation of central Kenya. This formation dates to the late Campanian stage of the Late Cretaceous and preserves a great deal of evidence for the ecology and evolution of dinosaurs in central Africa at this time. The fossils of Birkenia are among the most abundant dinosaurs found in this formation and thus have been used extensively to study the ecology and evolution of these animals. The fossils of Birkenia show that these animals were quite diverse and adapted to a variety of ecological niches. Helen Cristina Santos Luz (born November 23, 1976), better known by her stage name Helen Luz, is a Brazilian singer, songwriter and actress. Born in Curitiba, Paraná, Luz began her music career in 1996, when she was signed to Pitbull's record label Miami Records. Her self-titled debut album was released in 1999, and spawned the singles "Tempo Novo" and "Mulher". The album was certified platinum in Brazil. In 2002, Luz released her second album, "Amor à Vida". The album spawned the singles "Se Todas Fossem Iguais a Ti" and "Quero Ser Tua". The album was also certified platinum in Brazil. In 2004, Luz released her third album, "Por Amor ao Mel". The album spawned the singles "Pra Te Amar" and "Amar Pelos Dois". The album was also certified gold in Brazil. In 2006, Luz released her fourth album, "Amor & Sexo". The album spawned the singles "Amor & Sexo" and "Pra Te Amar (No Ar)". The album was also certified gold in Brazil. In 2007, Luz released her fifth album, "Só por Mim". The album spawned the single "Só por Mim", which became her first number one hit in Brazil. The album was also certified platinum in Brazil.

The Tosa Obake Zōshi is a Japanese yōkai emaki. Set in the Tosa Province (now Kōchi Prefecture), and 16 sections about yōkai in total, its creation period has been determined to be from the Edo period. Its author is unknown. There are two kinds, the private collection, and the collection of the Sakawa Education Committee of Sakawa, Kōchi Prefecture. Summary At the opening of all sixteen yōkai tales, yōkai from each area of Japan gather at Tosa, and in the end, at dawn, the yōkai disperse and bring the scene to a conclusion. The yōkai are presented with a rich local colouring but it is a work that has attracted deep interest as an iconization of the yōkai tales of those times. The depictions present the yōkai in an aspect of mischievous naivety and playfulness, allowing the reader to feel close to the yōkai rather than showing their dreadfulness. The fact that it takes in folktales told in Tosa in the Edo period like the Kechibi and the Yamajijii among others is another characteristic that is brought up.

A pretext (adj: pretextual) is an excuse for doing something that may not be in one's best interest. In law, a pretext is a reason for not prosecuting someone. In politics, a pretext is an event or statement used to justify or explain an action that was not originally motivated by the stated purpose. Pretexts are often used by people in power to avoid being held accountable for their actions. They can be used to cover up wrongdoings, or to justify illegal or immoral behavior. Pretexts can also be used to mislead people into thinking that an acceptable behavior is actually illegal or morally wrong. Pretexts are often difficult to detect, because they are usually subtle. They can be constructed based on plausible explanations, and they may be based on facts that are true but misleading. Pretexts can also be fabricated entirely out of thin air, without any real justification. Pretexts can have a significant impact on the lives of innocent people. They can enable abusers to continue abusing their victims, corrupt officials to commit crimes undetected, and dishonest businessmen to scam their customers. Mount Tuscarora is a mountain in the Southern Tier of New York. It is located south-southeast of Steamburg in Cattaraugus County. In 1928, a steel fire lookout tower was built on the mountain. The tower remains on the mountain but needs to be restored. History In 1928, the Conservation Department's Division of State Parks built a Aermotor LS40 steel fire lookout tower on the mountain. By the end of 1928, the park had five towers in operation including the three main towers on Mount Irvine, Mount Tuscarora, and Summit, as well as two more on Red House and Bova Mountain. In 1931, the jurisdiction of many State Park towers was transferred to Forest Fire Control. However, the Alleghany State Park retained jurisdiction and staffed the tower on Mount Tuscarora during times of high fire danger. The lookout tower remains on the mountain, but is in serious need of adoption and restoration.

Sven Magnus Øen Carlsen (born 30 November 1990) is a Norwegian professional chess player who holds the world record for the most championships won by a chess player, with seven. He has also been ranked world number one for a record 280 weeks, from November 2013 to January 2017. In March 2017, he became the first player ever to score two perfect scores in a classical tournament, and in October 2017 he became the first player ever to win four classical tournaments in a row. Carlsen was born in Hønefoss, Norway. He started playing chess at the age of six and won his first tournament at age eleven. By thirteen, he had become Norwegian Junior Champion. In 2006 he was runner-up in the World Youth Chess Championship behind Vladimir Kramnik. Carlsen played for Norway in the 28th Chess Olympiad in Turin, Italy and won a silver medal. In May 2009, Carlsen achieved international Master status with a performance rating of 2587. In November 2009, he achieved his first grandmaster title with a performance rating of 2700. In July 2013, Carlsen defended his title as World Chess Champion by winning the Candidates Tournament in Moscow with 8/11, ahead of Sergey Karjakin and Veselin Topalov. In November 2013, he became world number one for a record 280 weeks. FC Stahl Brandenburg is a German association football club based in Brandenburg an der Havel, Brandenburg. History The club was formed in 1950 as BSG Einheit Brandenburg and played its earliest seasons in the II division of East German football. They took on the name BSG Stahl Brandenburg in 1955 to reflect the backing of the local steel company. With that support, the club was able to assemble competitive sides by offering attractive salaries to the castoffs of other teams. The strategy drew some capable players to their ranks and helped them develop a solid fan base. The side earned promotion to the DDR-Oberliga for the 1984–85 season and played there until German reunification in 1990. After a name change to BSV Stahl Brandenburg they spent the 1991–92 season in the 2. Bundesliga Nord. In 1993, with the closing of the local steel mill and the loss of their financial support, 'Stahl' was dropped from the team name. The club played in the tier three NOFV-Oberliga Nord from 1992 to 1994, won the league and earned promotion to the new Regionalliga Nordost. After a year at this level it dropped back to the Oberliga and down to the Verbandsliga Brandenburg in 1996.

The Reinheitsgebot (, literally "purity order") is a series of regulations limiting the ingredients in beer in Germany and the states of the former Holy Roman Empire. The best known version of the law was adopted in Bavaria in 1516 (by William IV), but similar regulations predate the Bavarian order, and modern regulations also significantly differ from the 1516 Bavarian version. Although today, the Reinheitsgebot is mentioned in various texts about the history of beer, historically it was only applied in the duchy of Bavaria and from 1906 in Germany as a whole, and it had little or no impact in other countries or regions. 1516 Bavarian law The most influential predecessor of the modern Reinheitsgebot was a law first adopted in the duchy of Munich in 1487. After Bavaria was reunited, the Munich law was adopted across the entirety of Bavaria on 23 April 1516. As Germany unified, Bavaria pushed for adoption of this law on a national basis (see Broader adoption).

Earl of Carbery, in the County of Cork, is a title in the Peerage of Ireland. It was created on 25 October 1821 for Thomas Carbery, 2nd Viscount Harcourt. The Harcourt family had previously been Earls of Cork. The second Earl was succeeded by his son, the third Earl. He served as Under-Secretary of State for War and the Colonies from 1885 to 1886 in the Conservative administration of Benjamin Disraeli. On his death in 1916 the title passed to his younger brother, the fourth Earl. He died without male issue and was succeeded by his niece, the fifth Earl. As of 2014 she is the only female holder of an Irish peerage. The fifth Earl's son, the sixth Earl, was also a Conservative politician and served as Secretary of State for Air from 1925 to 1929 in the first Conservative administration of Ramsay MacDonald. The sixth Earl's son, the seventh Earl, was a Conservative politician who served as Lord Lieutenant of Cork from 1937 to 1951 and as Secretary of State for War from 1951 to 1955 in the second Conservative administration of Anthony Eden. As of 2014 he is the longest-serving holder of an Irish peerage and one of only two living holders of a title in that peerage. The seventh Earl's son, the eighth Earl, was a Conservative politician who served as Secretary of State for Defence from 1970 to 1972 in the first Conservative administration of Edward Heath. As of 2014 he is also one of only two living holders of a title in that peerage

Muhammad Subuh Sumohadiwidjojo (born June 22, 1901, date of death unknown) was an Indonesian independence activist and politician. He was born in the village of Sumohadiwidjojo, in the Kediri Regency of East Java, Dutch East Indies. He studied at the Muhammadiyah School in Surabaya and then at the University of Amsterdam. After returning to Indonesia, Sumohadiwidjojo started his political career as a member of the youth wing of the Indonesian National Party (PNI). In 1929 he became a member of the PNI's executive committee. In 1934 he was elected to the Volksraad, the Dutch-Indonesian parliament. In February 1942 he was arrested by the Japanese army and sent to prison in Batavia. After the Dutch capitulation in March 1945 he was liberated by the Allied forces and returned to Indonesia. Sumohadiwidjojo became part of the Indonesian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in 1946. He also served as Indonesia's ambassador to France from 1947 to 1949. In 1950 he became chairman of the PNI party branch in East Java. In 1951 he was elected to the Indonesian National Assembly, serving until 1954. In 1955 he became chairman of the Indonesian cabinet, serving until 1957. He later served as Indonesia's ambassador to Czechoslovakia from 1958 to 1960 and to Yugoslavia from 1960 to 1963. In 1965 Sumohadiwidjojo was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his work for Indonesian independence. He died in Jakarta on unknown

He is a member of the ruling National Resistance Movement (NRM) and was first elected to Parliament in the 2007 parliamentary election. Gilbert Olanya was born on 4 September 1965 in Kyaddondo County, Uganda. He attended local primary and secondary schools before studying at Makerere University, where he earned a BSc in Economics in 1988. After university, Gilbert Olanya worked as an economist for the Ugandan Ministry of Finance until 1994, when he was appointed Director of Planning and Monitoring at the Ministry of Industry. In 1996, Gilbert Olanya was appointed Minister for Industry and Commerce in the cabinet of Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi. He held this position until 2001, during which time he also served as Chairman of the Uganda Development Corporation. In 2002, Gilbert Olanya was appointed Minister for Trade and Industry in the cabinet of Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi. He held this position until 2006, during which time he also served as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for National Security. Gilbert Olanya was first elected to Parliament in the 2007 parliamentary election, representing Kyaddondo County for the National Resistance Movement (NRM). He has served as a Member of Parliament since then, and is currently NRM's whip in Parliament. Acheron was an American death/black metal band from Baltimore, Maryland active from 1996 to 2003. Acheron was formed in 1996 by vocalist Erik Rutan and guitarist Tim Yeung. The pair recruited drummer Jamie King and bassist Matt Greiner, and the band released its debut album, "Acheron", in 1997. After Yeung left the band in early 2000, Rutan replaced him with John Cobb on guitars. The group toured extensively throughout the United States and Europe during this time, releasing two more albums, "The Ethereal Mirror" and "In the Shadow of the Apocalypse". In 2003, Acheron disbanded after Rutan decided to focus on other projects. Acheron is considered a seminal death/black metal band, and its sound has been cited as an influence by many bands in the genre. The band's music has been described as atmospheric and dark, with influences from black metal, death metal, and progressive metal.

Jackie Spencer Moore (born February 19, 1939) is an American former professional baseball player. A right-handed pitcher, Moore played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the New York Mets, Cincinnati Reds, and Baltimore Orioles. He was a member of the Mets' World Series championship team in 1969 and the Reds' championship team in 1990. Moore was born in Birmingham, Alabama, and attended high school in Mobile. He signed with the Mets as an amateur free agent in 1957 and made his MLB debut with them in 1962. He also played for the Reds and Orioles. Moore was a member of the Mets' World Series championship team in 1969 and the Reds' championship team in 1990. He retired after the 1993 season with a record of 284 wins and 208 losses. Moore was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 2000.

Lars Ulrich R (; ; born 26 October 1967) is a German musician, singer, songwriter and producer who is the founding and former leader of the heavy metal band Metallica. He has been with the band since its inception in 1981, and has helped to shape its image and sound. Ulrich was born in Hamburg, West Germany to a father who was an engineer and mother who was a housewife. He has two younger sisters. Ulrich began playing the drums at age four and later learned to play the guitar. He formed Metallica in 1981 with fellow students James Hetfield (guitar) and Dave Mustaine (bass). They played their first show at the Estrada Club in Copenhagen, Denmark. Metallica achieved mainstream success with their first album, Kill 'Em All (1983), which sold over 10 million copies. The band's second album, Ride the Lightning (1984), reached number two on the Billboard 200 chart. In 1986, Metallica released Master of Puppets, which became their most successful album to date; it reached number one on the Billboard 200 chart and sold over 15 million copies. The following year, Metallica released The Black Album, which was their first album to reach number one on the Billboard Hard Rock Albums chart. In 1991, they released ...And Justice for All, which was their only album to reach number one on both the Billboard 200 chart and the Billboard Hard Rock Albums chart. The James Blake House is the oldest surviving house in Boston, Massachusetts, United States. The house was built in 1661 and the date was confirmed by dendrochronology in 2007. It is located at 735 Columbia Road, in Edward Everett Square, and just a block from Massachusetts Avenue. The Dorchester Historical Society now owns the building and tours are given on the third Sunday of the month. History The house was built in a Western English style of post-medieval architecture by James Blake, an immigrant from England. The Blake family owned the house until 1825 when it was acquired by the Williams family. In 1891, the City of Boston acquired the house. In order to save the house from demolition in 1896, the Dorchester Historical Society acquired the property from the city and moved the house less than 500 feet from its original location by Massachusetts Avenue to its current location. In 1978, the interior and exterior of the house were designated as a Boston Landmark by the Boston Landmarks Commission.

William Graham Sumner (October 30, 1840 – March 31, 1910) was an American political scientist and philosopher. He was a leading theorist of the American South, and is considered one of the most influential and respected thinkers of his era. Sumner is best known for his theory of social Darwinism, which holds that social evolution is based on natural selection. Sumner was born in Graham County, Kentucky, to the Rev. George W. Sumner and the former Caroline Butler. He attended Williams College in Massachusetts before receiving his Ph.D. from Yale University in 1868. After teaching at Yale for several years, he became the first professor of sociology at Cornell University in 1883. Sumner remained at Cornell for the rest of his career, serving as president of the university from 1902 to 1904. He died in Ithaca, New York, aged 78. Sumner's ideas have had a significant influence on sociology, political science, and economics. His work has been credited with helping to shape the development of social Darwinism and Friedrich Nietzsche's theory of the Übermensch. In addition, he has been credited with having coined the term "civilization" and with being one of the first thinkers to discuss race in America.

Olímpio Mourão Filho (9 March 1900 – 3 November 1986) was a Brazilian economist, academic, and politician. He served as the 25th President of Brazil from 1961 to 1965. Olímpio Mourão Filho was born in São Paulo on 9 March 1900. He studied at the University of São Paulo, graduating with a degree in economics in 1923. He then began teaching at the university, eventually becoming a professor in 1930. Mourão Filho entered politics in 1951, when he was elected to the Brazilian Senate. He served as Minister of Finance from 1955 to 1958 and from 1958 to 1961, during the presidency of Juscelino Kubitschek. In 1961, Mourão Filho was elected president of Brazil, defeating incumbent João Goulart by a wide margin. As president, Mourão Filho presided over significant economic growth and improvements in social conditions. He resigned from office in 1965 after being defeated in an election by fellow economist Fernando Henrique Cardoso. Olímpio Mourão Filho died on 3 November 1986. He was 79 years old.

Manang, also called Manangba, Manange, Manang Ke, and Manange Ke, is an Austronesian language spoken by the Manang people of the Philippines. It is closely related to the Ilocano language, and together they form the Ilocano–Manang–speaking group. It is also closely related to Kapampangan and Pangasinan languages. The Manang people are one of the seven indigenous tribes of the Philippines and their language belongs to the Austronesian family. The Manang people are found in central Luzon, specifically in the provinces of Ilocos Sur and Pangasinan. In 2002, there were an estimated 2,000 speakers of Manang. Manang is a member of the Philippine linguistic family, which includes other languages like Ilocano, Kapampangan and Pangasinan. The Manang-Ilocano branch forms a dialect continuum with Kapampangan and Pangasinan on one end and with Ilocano on the other. The two main varieties are Central (or Central-Ilocano) and Southern (or Southern-Ilocano). Central Manang has about 4,000 speakers while Southern Manang has about 10,000 speakers. The Manang language is an Austronesian language closely related to Ilocano, Kapampangan and Pangasinan languages.
