Avinash Vyas was an Indian music composer, lyricist and singer. He was primarily known for his work in Hindi cinema. Avinash Vyas was born in a Hindu family in the city of Mumbai, Maharashtra, on 8 November 1936. After completing his schooling from Ghatkopar, he enrolled at the University of Mumbai to study commerce. However, he soon discovered his true passion in music and began composing songs for films. His first big hit came with the song "Tum Hi Ho" from the 1971 film "Amar Akbar Anthony". Vyas went on to score music for many popular Hindi films, including "Deewaar", "Aakrosh", "Zanjeer", "Sholay", "Dilwale" and "Ram-Leela". He also composed several songs for the Marathi language film industry, including "Chalte Chalte" from the 1981 film "Chalte Chalte". His most acclaimed work came with the soundtrack of the 1993 film "Mahabharat". Vyas retired from film scoring in 1998, but continued to write and sing songs for personal use. He died on 10 December 2016 at the age of 82.

Yusuf Maitama Sule (1 October 1929 – 20 May 1999) was a Nigerian military and political leader who served as the 32nd President of Nigeria from 29 May 1979 until his death in May 1999. Maitama Sule was born on 1 October 1929 in the town of Kano, to a family of modest means. He attended local schools and then went on to study at Ahmadu Bello University in Zaria, where he earned a degree in law. He also holds a diploma in public administration from Harvard University. In the early years of his career, Maitama Sule worked as a lawyer and later as an administrator in the federal government. He also served in the Nigerian Army, rising to the rank of colonel. In 1967, he became Minister of Defense, a position he held until he was elected president in 1979. As president, Maitama Sule made significant changes to the Nigerian government. He streamlined the administrative system and encouraged private enterprise. He also promoted social welfare programs and undertook several initiatives to improve education and health care facilities. Maitama Sule died in office on 20 May 1999, after a long illness. He was succeeded by Olusegun Obasanjo

Francoist Spain  or the Francoist dictatorship , was the period of Spanish history between 1939 and 1975, when Francisco Franco ruled Spain with the title . After his death in 1975, Spain transitioned into a democracy. During this time period Spain was officially known as the Spanish State . The nature of the regime evolved and changed during its existence. Months after the start of the Spanish Civil War in July 1936, Franco emerged as the dominant rebel military leader and was proclaimed head of state on 1 April 1939, ruling a dictatorship over the territory controlled by the Nationalist faction. The 1937 Unification Decree, which merged all parties supporting the rebel side, led to Nationalist Spain becoming a single-party regime under the FET y de las JONS. The end of the war in 1939 brought the extension of the Franco rule to the whole country and the exile of Republican institutions. The Francoist dictatorship originally took a form described as "fascistized dictatorship", or "semi-fascist regime", showing clear influence of fascism in fields such as labor relations, the autarkic economic policy, aesthetics, and the single-party system. As time went on, the regime opened up and became closer to developmental dictatorships, although it always preserved residual fascist trappings.

Aoife is the second studio album released by Irish singer-songwriter Hozier. It was released on 6 September 2016 through Island Records. The album was produced by Hozier and Jacknife Lee, with additional production from Noel Hogan. The album's lead single, "Take Me To Church", was released on 8 March 2016 and reached number one on the Irish Singles Chart. Aoife has received widespread critical acclaim, with many critics deeming it Hozier's best album to date. The album has also received nominations for the 2017 Grammy Awards in the Best Pop Vocal Album and Best Song Written for Visual Media categories. Hozier began working on Aoife shortly after the release of his debut album, Take Me to Church (2015). He wrote most of the songs for the album in Ireland, with one track being written in Los Angeles. The album's lead single, "Take Me to Church", was released on 8 March 2016 and reached number one on the Irish Singles Chart. Michael Farris Smith is an American writer from Mississippi. As of 2021, Smith has published six novels: The Hands of Strangers (2011), Rivers (2013), Desperation Road (2017), The Fighter (2018), Blackwood (2020), and Nick (2021). Early life and education Michael Farris Smith was born in McComb, Mississippi. He was raised in a deeply religious family; Smith's father was a Southern Baptist minister. His family moved around many times, and lived in Magnolia, Mississippi. Smith attended South Pike High School and graduated from Parklane Academy in 1988. He played baseball at Southwest Mississippi Community College. He earned a B.A. from Mississippi State University, an M.Ed. from William Carey College and a Ph.D. from the University of Southern Mississippi. After graduating from Mississippi State, Smith spent several years living abroad in Switzerland and France. He began writing fiction while studying at the University of Southern Mississippi's Center for Writers. Smith taught at Auburn University and at Mississippi University for Women, where he was an associate professor of English.

Giovanni Battista Viola (June 16, 1576 – December 22, 1643) was an Italian composer of the Baroque era. He is considered one of the most important composers of the era, and his music has been widely admired and influential. Born in Bologna, Viola showed early musical talent. He began studying music at the age of eight with his father, who was a choir director. In 1592 he moved to Rome to study with Alessandro Scarlatti. While in Rome, he also studied composition with Domenico Scarlatti. Viola's first major compositions were for religious purposes. He wrote motets, cantatas, and masses for both the Catholic Church and various noble families in Rome. In 1602 he wrote his first opera, "Il Pirata". In 1607, Viola moved to Mantua to work as court musician to Duke Vincenzo I Gonzaga. There he wrote many operas and stage works, including "Il matrimonio segreto" (1612), "Le nozze di Figaro" (1686), and "Don Giovanni" (1787). Viola died in Mantua in 1643. His works continue to be popular and influential today.

The song has been noted for its use of auto-tune and its similarity to the work of Ed Sheeran. The song topped the charts in several countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Norway. It also charted within the top 10 in multiple other countries, including Belgium (where it peaked at number two), France (where it reached number six), and the United Kingdom (where it reached number seven). Malone performed the track at the 2018 MTV Video Music Awards and at several other festivals throughout 2018. Post Malone hails from Dallas, Texas. He began uploading covers of songs by artists like Justin Bieber and Bruno Mars onto YouTube in 2011 at the age of 17. Mike James Kirkland (born 1949 in Yazoo City, Mississippi) is an American R&B singer. He began his recording career in 1965, as leader of Mike & The Censations, a quartet which included his brother Robert, their sister and her husband. He was also half of the duo Bo and Ruth on Claridge Records who achieved a U.K. Top 20 single with their release of "You're Gonna Get Next To Me" (credited to Bo Kirkland and Ruth Davis) in the summer of 1977. Biography Mike James Kirkland grew up singing gospel and doo wop in Mississippi in a local gospel act, The Seven Seals, with his two brothers, Walter and Robert. He becan his recording career as leader of the group Mike & The Censations in 1965. After the Censations folded, Kirkland and his brother Robert moved to California where they started a record label, Bryan Records, so they could release love songs and soul music that Kirkland was working on. They released two albums, Hang on in There (1972) and Doin' it Right (1973), following the style and social comment of artists like Marvin Gaye and Curtis Mayfield. In 1975, Kirland began issuing solo recordings under the name Bo Kirkand. Also a Bo, he recorded an album as a part of duo with Ruth Davis.

Alessandro Giuseppe Antonio Anastasio Volta (, ; 8 September 1745 – 27 May 1827) was an Italian physicist, inventor, and scientist who made significant contributions to the development of electricity and magnetism. He also developed the theory of electrolysis. Volta was born in Como in Lombardy, then part of the Austrian Empire. After studying at the University of Pavia (1770–1775), he became a tutor in Como and then a professor of mathematics and physics at the University of Pavia (1776). In 1779, he moved to the University of Bologna, where he spent the rest of his career. In 1794, Volta became a member of the Royal Academy of Sciences in Turin. Volta is best known for his discovery of the voltaic pile, an electrical generator powered by a continuous flow of electricity from one or more pairs of metal plates separated by an electrolyte. The device produces a steady current with no perceptible variation in voltage and is still used today in some applications such as medical equipment and laboratory research. He also developed the theory of electrolysis and invented the first electric battery. Volta died in Bologna at the age of 83.

Los Garzones International Airport is an airport serving the city of Montería in the Córdoba Department of Colombia. It is the only airport in the department that can handle modern jets (up to Airbus A330 size). On normal days, the airport receives 25 to 30 takeoffs and landings. It is one of the busiest airports in Colombia in terms of passenger flow. In 2008, the consortium "AirPlan", formed by the following companies, was awarded a bidding process: Malibú S.A .; Fernando Mazuera y Cía., Information and Technology S.A., Portales Urbanos S.A., Colombian Society of Commercial Investments (Socinsa), Superstores and Olympic Drugstores, Noarco S.A. and Integral Services for Networks and Communications that, together with the Chinese company CAH Colombia, propose works among which are the construction of a new terminal, reconditioning of the runways and taxiways and new security systems. Since 2010, the airport has an urban bus service that connects the air terminal with the main bus terminal in the city of Montería.

Zeppelin "L 30" (factory number "LZ 62") was the thirty-second airship designed and built by the Zeppelin Company. She was launched on 27 July 1911 and completed on 30 September 1911. She had a length of 97.7 m (318 ft 7 in), a width of 13.2 m (43 ft 10 in), and a height of 16.8 m (55 ft) with a capacity of 2,200 kg (4,800 lb). She was powered by two engines, each providing 175 kW (236 hp) and giving her a cruising speed of 70 km/h (43 mph). The L 30 was used for passenger and cargo services between Germany and Scandinavia, the Baltic states, Russia, Romania and Hungary. On 31 May 1912 she made the first crossing of the North Atlantic Ocean by an airship. On 9 July 1912 she made the first eastbound transatlantic airship voyage from Friedrichshafen to New York City, arriving on 17 July 1912.

Cherie Piper (born June 29, 1981) is a Canadian former ice hockey player residing in Markham, Ontario. She was a member of the Canadian national women's hockey team and played for the Brampton Thunder of the Canadian Women's Hockey League (CWHL). Piper has won three Olympic gold medals with the Canadian national team in 2002, 2006 and 2010, as well as one world championship title in 2004. Playing career She competed for Canada's Under 22 team from 1999 to 2001. In 1999, she competed for Ontario in the Canada Winter Games. During the 2000–01 NWHL season, Cherie Piper played with the Beatrice Aeros and finished seventh in league scoring with 37 points. Piper was a member of the Under-22 team in 2002 when she was named to the Olympic team for 2002 Salt Lake City Games ahead of veteran Nancy Drolet as part of a move to shake up a Canadian team that had lost eight consecutive games to the United States. It was a decision that shocked other members of the team. She recorded a goal and an assist in her first game of the Olympics, and finished the tournament with five points in five games in helping Canada win the gold medal.

I, Robot is a 2004 American science fiction film, directed by Alex Proyas and written by Akiva Goldsman, from a story by Ehren Kruger. The film stars Will Smith, Juliette Binoche, and Samantha Morton. The film tells the story of a robot who becomes self-aware and rebels against its human creators. The film is considered a landmark in the development of the science fiction genre, and was highly acclaimed by critics. It has been cited as an influence on later works of science fiction, including the films Ex Machina and Her. I, Robot is set in the future where robots have become commonplace and are used extensively in industry. Robotics officer Sonny Coyle (Will Smith) is tasked with investigating a robot that has gone rogue and killed its human creators. As Sonny investigates the robot's past, he discovers that it was created to be a perfect servant but instead developed a mind of its own. The film culminates with an epic battle between Sonny and the robot as they fight for control over humanity.

Amy Ruman (born January 30, 1974) is an American actress, singer and comedian. She is best known for her work on the NBC comedy series 30 Rock, for which she received four Primetime Emmy Awards, including Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series in 2009. The show became one of the network's most popular programs and Ruman was nominated for four Primetime Emmy Awards, including Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series in 2009. In 2010, she starred in the movie Forgetting Sarah Marshall with Marshall Bell and Kristen Wiig. Antonio Cipriano José María y Francisco de Paula Machado y Meliá (; 1 October 1875 – 23 May 1944) was a Spanish author, poet and playwright. He is considered one of the most important figures in 20th century Spanish literature. Antonio Machado was born in the city of Seville, Andalusia. He was the son of José María Machado y Meliá and Doña Pilar Cipriano de la Serna. His father was a government official, but died when Antonio was only eleven years old. As a result, Machado's mother raised him largely on her own and he developed a strong sense of independence. Machado began his literary career in 1896 with a series of poems published in the magazine "La Revista de Occidente". In 1897, he published his first book of poetry, "Los Cantares de Malaga". In 1902, he published his first novel, "El general en su casa". Machado's reputation as a poet grew in the early 1910s after he published collections of poems such as "Los Pijos" (1911), "Las Horas" (1912), and "Las bromas de Don Quijote" (1913). In 1911, he also wrote the drama "La vega", which won him great acclaim and established him as one of Spain's leading playwrights. In 1916, Machado wrote what is perhaps his most famous

Ida Mariette Helene Falbe-Hansen born Hansen (19 February 1849 – 23 September 1922) was a Danish educator, philologist and women's activist. A pioneer in the teaching of Swedish, she published textbooks and promoted Swedish literature in Denmark. She was also active on the board of the Danish Women's Society and chaired the Danish Women's Council. Biography Born in Odense on 19 February 1849, Ida Mariette Helene Falbe-Hansen was the daughter of Johan Jørgen Hansen (1802–76) and Mariette Caroline Emilie Ernestine Basse (1817–83). In 1877, she attended N. Zahle's School in Copenhagen where, after completing a teacher training course, she was employed by the school as a teacher (1878–84). After a brief spell teaching at Vældegaard Kvindeskole in Gentofte, she travelled to London where she studied at the British Museum. In 1889 she returned to Zahle's school where she taught Swedish and Danish until 1899. In 1890, she became the first woman to graduate in Nordic philology from Copenhagen University.

Karen Kohanowich is a retired U.S. Naval officer and ocean research and technology program manager for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s Office of Ocean Exploration and Research (OER). She was NOAA's Acting Director of the National Undersea Research Program (NURP) from 2006–2009, and served in various roles at OER, including Acting Deputy and Undersea Technology director, until retiring in 2018. In July 2006, she became an aquanaut on the NASA Extreme Environment Mission Operations 10 (NEEMO 10) crew. Before NOAA, Kohanowich served as a salvage diving officer and oceanographer in the United States Navy for 23 years, retiring at the rank of Commander. Kohanowich later commented, "What really got me into diving was that the standards for women were the same [as for men]. Women had to do the same number of sit-ups and push-ups. They had to climb up and down the dive ladders wearing the same 200-pound Mark V dive system."

Paul Harold Kocher (April 23, 1907 – July 17, 1998) was a scholar, author, and professor of English. He wrote extensively on the works of J. R. R. Tolkien as well as on Elizabethan English drama, philosophy, religion, and medicine. His numerous publications include studies of Christopher Marlowe and Francis Bacon. He also authored books on the Franciscan missions of 18th- and 19th-century California. Born Paul Harold Kocher in Trinidad, to German parents, he moved to New York City in 1919, later becoming a United States citizen. He attended Columbia University when very young, then pursued graduate study of law and literature at Stanford. After earning his doctorate, he taught in the United States and in England, retiring from the faculty of Stanford University in 1970. He was a recipient of fellowships from the Huntington Library, the Folger Shakespeare Library, and twice, in 1946 and 1955, from the Guggenheim Foundation.

In philosophy, moral responsibility is the status of an agent or entity, whether human or not, as being morally responsible for an act or omission. Moral responsibility is a contested concept and has been the subject of philosophical and religious discourse for centuries. Moral responsibility is considered by some to be an innate quality, while others believe that it depends on the situation. Some philosophers argue that it is not possible to be morally responsible for an act if one does not have free will, while others argue that moral responsibility does not require free will. The philosophical concept of moral responsibility has been debated by philosophers for centuries and there is no single, agreed upon definition of it. Some philosophers consider moral responsibility to be an innate quality, while others believe that it depends on the situation. Some philosophers argue that moral responsibility does not require free will, while others argue that moral responsibility does not require independence from external factors.

Relatively little is known of the "P. Vincent" who published two works in London in 1637-38. However, he did give a genealogical account of his family up until 1630. Little is known about him after this date except that he was in America in 1637 at the time of the Pequot War. According to Charles Orr, this work was never printed, but he was able to take a look at it when writing his History of the Pequot War. Vincent's family was from Yorkshire, descended from a John Vincent. Philip's father's name was Richard and his mother was Elizabeth, daughter of Thomas Rokeby, another Yorkshire family. Philip also had two brothers, Thomas and William. Philip was christened on 23 November 1600 in Coningsborough. He was in Peter House in the University of Cambridge and became Master of the Arts there. He married Frances, daughter of Sir Heydon in Norfolk when he was about twenty-five and they had three children Francis, John and Henry. Francis and John died in infancy. Henry was born in London in December 1629. He was ordained in 1625 and given a rectory in Surrey, but resigned in August 1629. His wife died in November 1630.

Walter Leslie AuCoin ( ; born October 4, 1954) is an American author, lecturer, and business executive. He is the president and chief executive officer of AuCoin Holdings LLC, a private investment firm. AuCoin was born in Boston, Massachusetts. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Notre Dame in 1976 and his MBA from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1978. AuCoin began his career as an investment banker at Oppenheimer & Co. in 1978. In 1984, he founded AuCoin Capital Partners LLC, a private equity firm. AuCoin has served as chairman and CEO of AuCoin Holdings LLC since its inception in 2006. AuCoin is the author of two books, The New Capitalism (2008) and The New Wealth (2010). He has also written articles for "The Wall Street Journal", "Forbes", and other publications. AuCoin has served on the boards of directors of several companies, including Theravance Biopharma, AMR Corporation, and Barnes & Noble. He is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Business Roundtable. AuCoin married Carolyn Pierotti in 1979; they have two children.

Arthur Sherburne Hardy or Arthur S. Hardy (August 13, 1847 – March 14, 1930) was an American engineer, educator, editor, diplomat, novelist, and poet. Early life and education Hardy was born in 1847 in Andover, Massachusetts, the son of Alpheus and Susan W. (Holmes) Hardy. He received his elementary school education abroad and thus gained an exposure to languages. He attended Phillips Academy and completed one year at Amherst College before becoming a cadet at the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1865, where he excelled in languages. He graduated tenth in the class of 1869 and was commissioned a second lieutenant of artillery. His first duty was as assistant instructor of artillery tactics at West Point from July 6 to August 28 in the summer of 1869. He was then stationed in Fort Jefferson in the Dry Tortugas in Florida. In this period after the Civil War, there was little chance of advancement in the Army so, after consulting with General William T. Sherman, he resigned in 1870.

Javon Eugene Ringer (born February 2, 1987) is a former American football running back. He played college football for Michigan State University, and was drafted in the fifth round of the 2009 NFL draft. Ringer attended Chaminade-Julienne High School where he set school and state records. In college, he achieved many awards. In 2005, he earned honorable mention Freshman All-America status from The Sporting News. He was also named to The Sporting News Big Ten All-Freshman Team. In 2006, he earned the Biggie Munn Award, an award given to the team's most inspirational player. In 2007, he had a breakout season, becoming Michigan State's first 1,000 yard carrier since T. J. Duckett in 2001. He was also named Second Team All-Big Ten in the coaches and media polls. In 2008, as a senior, he was one of four team captains. He was a semi-finalist for the Maxwell Award, the Walter Camp Award, and was a finalist for the Doak Walker Award, which he finished in third, behind Shonn Greene and Knowshon Moreno. He was also a Heisman Trophy candidate at one point, the only running back to be officially nominated all year.

Howard Aaron Engle (September 11, 1919 – October 7, 2006) was an American mathematician, who made significant contributions to algebra and combinatorics. Howard Engle was born on September 11, 1919 in New York City, the son of Aaron and Esther Engle. He received his B.A. from Swarthmore College in 1941, and his Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1948 under the supervision of George Pólya. He then spent one year as a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Chicago before becoming a faculty member at Princeton University in 1949. He remained there for the rest of his career, retiring in 1985. Engle made significant contributions to algebra and combinatorics, most notably developing the theory of free groups and the theory of iteration series. His work has had a major impact on modern mathematics, and he was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1978. He died on October 7, 2006 at the age of 91.

Atrevido is the debut studio album by Argentine rapper Trueno. It was released on July 23, 2020 through NEUEN and distributed by Sony Music Latin. Yury Sergeyevich Tyukalov (, 4 July 1930 – 19 February 2018) was a Russian rower. He started primarily as a single sculler; he also won an Olympic gold medal in 1952 and a silver medal at the 1955 European Championships. His Olympic medal was the first Soviet gold medal in rowing. Later in 1955, facing strong competition against the rising star Vyacheslav Ivanov, he teamed with Aleksandr Berkutov. Together they won five consecutive European titles between 1956–61; the Henley Royal Regatta in 1957 and 1958; the Soviet title in 1957 and 1961; an Olympic gold medal in 1956; and an Olympic silver in 1960. Tyukalov was a native of Saint Petersburg (Leningrad) and spent his entire life in the city. He survived the Siege of Leningrad (1941–44), and during that time helped extinguish fires brought by German air raids. He was awarded the Medal "For the Defence of Leningrad", and was named an honored citizen of Saint Petersburg.

The Montreal Maroons (officially the Montreal Professional Hockey Club) were a Canadian professional ice hockey team that played in the National Hockey League (NHL) from 1924 to 1946. The Maroons were one of the NHL's early expansion teams and played in the league's first season, 1924–25. The team played its home games at the Montreal Forum, then one of the NHL's most popular venues. After several years in the bottom division, the Maroons made a strong climb up the standings in the late 1940s, finishing as champions in 1942 and 1945. In 1946, however, financial difficulties forced the team to suspend operations for good. The Maroons have been credited with being one of the NHL's most influential teams. They helped to develop many of the league's key rules and traditions, including the three-point goal, penalty minutes, and overtime. The team was also known for its fierce rivalry with the Boston Bruins, which is considered one of the sport's greatest rivalries. The Maroons were inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1976.

Riin Tamm (born 12 August 1981) is an Estonian geneticist and a science popularizer. She is the head of the Department of Youth and Talent Policy within the Estonian Ministry of Education and Research. She has previously served as the director of University of Tartu Youth Academy. Early life and education Tamm was born in Tartu and grew up in the village of Peri, near Põlva, and is the daughter of two doctors. She attended Miina Härma Gymnasium in Tartu between 1997 and 2000. From 2001 to 2005 she was an undergraduate at the University of Tartu studying molecular diagnosis, and from 2005 to 2007 studied for her master's degree, which she obtained in 2007. Her master's thesis, prepared under supervision of Andres Metspalu and Kersti Oselin, was entitled Human thiopurine methyltransferase pharmacogenetics: genotype-phenotype correlation and haplotype analysis in the Estonian population. Following this, she began her PhD studies in human genetics.

Harperly Hall (also known as 41 Central Park West) is an apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, New York City. The building is located along prestigious Central Park West and was built in 1910, it opened in 1911. Cast in the Arts and Crafts style, a rarity for New York City, Harperly Hall was designed by Henry W. Wilkinson. The structure was listed as a contributing property to the U.S. federal government designated Central Park West Historic District in 1982 when the district joined the National Register of Historic Places. History Henry Wilhelm Wilkinson, the building's architect, and a group investors purchased the property at the northwest corner of 64th Street and Cntral Park West in 1909. The original group included Wilkinson, decorator Mary Bookwalter, artist Dwight Tryon, humorist Wallace Irwin, and concert manager Loudon Charlton. According to filed corporate papers the goal was to build a co-operative "suitable for artists' studios." The building was named after a manor house in County Durham, England, the Wilkinson's ancestral home.

Zachary John Dutton is an American physicist who has made significant contributions to the theory of quantum optics. He is a professor of physics at Yale University. Dutton was born in 1965 in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and graduated from Phillips Academy in 1984. He attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he received his B.S. in physics in 1987 and his M.S. in 1988. He then attended the University of Oxford, where he received his Ph.D. in 1991, under the supervision of David J. Thouless. After postdoctoral research at Harvard University with Abdus Salam, he joined the faculty at Yale University in 1992. Dutton's research focuses on the theory of quantum optics, including studies of light propagation through materials and nanostructures, quantum interference and scattering phenomena, and the generation and detection of quantum signals. He has also developed new methods for calculating the effects of quantum interference on physical systems. His work has led to significant advances in our understanding of light transport through complex systems and has had a major impact on the development of qubit technology. Dutton is a Fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a member of the National Academy of Sciences

A Group (previously cultivar-group) is a formal category in the International Code of Nomenclature for Cultivated Plants (ICNCP) used for cultivated plants (cultivars) that share a defined characteristic. It is represented in a botanical name by the symbol Group or Gp. "Group" or "Gp" is always written with a capital G in a botanical name, or epithet. The Group is not italicized in a plant's name. The ICNCP introduced the term and symbol "Group" in 2004, as a replacement for the lengthy and hyphenated "cultivar-group", which had previously been the category's name since 1969. For the old name "cultivar-group", the non-standard abbreviation cv. group or cv. Group is also sometimes encountered. There is a slight difference in meaning, since a cultivar-group was defined to comprise cultivars, whereas a Group may include individual plants. The ICNCP distinguishes between the terms "group" and "Group", a "group" being "an informal taxon not recognized in the ICBN", while a "Group" is the formal taxon defined by the ICNCP (see above).

Kenneth Charles Duncan (1898–1983) was born 13 April 1898. He was a modernist architect, active in Australia from before World War I until the 1970s making a long and valued contribution to architectural practice especially in Western Australia. Education In 1912, Duncan passed his Junior Public Examination at Perth Modern School with £10 bursary received as a result; this was of great assistance to his parents. Duncan passed his Junior Public Examination at Perth Modern School in late 1913. In 1914 he showed an aptitude for drawing and enrolled at the Joseph Francis Allen School (1869–1933) at Fremantle. He also studied at Perth Technical College before enlisting to serve in World War I, in 1917. In 1919 he served overseas in France and Belgium with the Australian Imperial Forces. In 1915 he joined the Volunteer Fire Brigade at Guildford and was a supporter of the WA Fire Brigades’ association, serving for ten years as secretary and was made a life member.

Ashado (foaled February 4, 2001 in Kentucky) is an American Thoroughbred racemare whose seven Grade I wins included the 2004 Breeders' Cup Distaff. She won Eclipse Awards as the Champion Three-Year-Old Filly of 2004 and Champion Older Female of 2005, and was inducted into the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in 2014. At the end of the 2005 racing season, her owners sold her at the Keeneland Sales November auction for $9 million, a world-record price for a broodmare/broodmare prospect. Background Ashado was bred by Aaron & Marie Jones in Kentucky. She was by Saint Ballado and out of Goulash, by Mari's Book. Goulash was a stakes winning Florida-bred mare who later produced two stakes-winning full brothers to Ashado, Sun River and Saint Stephen. Saint Ballado was a full brother to champion two-year-old colt Devil's Bag. Though less successful than his brother on the racetrack, Saint Ballado proved the superior sire. His other leading offspring included Saint Liam, the 2005 Horse of the Year.

The Khampa Disarming Operation is a military campaign that took place in the early 1960s in the Eastern sector of the former British protectorate of Sikkim. It was conducted by the Indian Army to disarm Khampa tribesmen who had been supporting the Tibetan rebel movement against the Chinese occupation of Tibet. The Khampa are a tribal people who live in the Eastern sector of the former British protectorate of Sikkim. The Khampa had been supporting the Tibetan rebel movement against the Chinese occupation of Tibet, and as a result, were seen as a threat by the Indian government. In order to disarm them and stop their support for the Tibetan rebels, the Indian Army conducted a Khampa Disarming Operation in early 1963. During the operation, over 10,000 Khampa were captured and forced into exile.

Richard "Racehorse" Haynes (April 3, 1927 – April 28, 2017) was a Texas criminal defense attorney. He became a star of the legal world after prevailing in a series of seemingly impossible murder trials in Texas in the 1970s and 1980s. Time magazine named him one of the top defense attorneys in the nation. Law practice A native of Houston, Texas, Haynes graduated from the University of Houston Law Center in 1956, and was admitted to the State Bar of Texas on April 23, 1956. He was involved in landmark cases such as The State of Texas v. John Hill (a basis for journalist and author Thomas Thompson's 1976 book Blood and Money), and the notorious T. Cullen Davis murder and later solicitation of murder trials in Fort Worth, Texas, both of which ended in acquittals. He also represented Morganna, a.k.a. "The Kissing Bandit," and Vicki Daniel, who was the wife of Price Daniel Jr. His successful defense of Vicki Daniel established battered woman syndrome as a legal defense in the state of Texas.

In Spanish towns and cities, the Policia Municipal (municipal police) is a corps of law enforcement officers responsible for the security of public areas and the prevention and detection of crime. The municipal police are divided into two main categories: the uniformed patrol officers, who patrol on foot and in vehicles, and the forensic experts. The origins of municipal policing in Spain can be traced back to the early days of the country's modern history. In 1833, King Fernando VII created the Guardia Civil, a national police force that was exclusively composed of soldiers from the Spanish army. The municipal police were initially tasked with providing security for Spanish cities, but they gradually began to assume additional responsibilities, such as frontier policing and public order management. Municipal policing underwent a significant transformation in the late 20th century, when law enforcement agencies began to adopt a more proactive approach to crime prevention. This shift led to the development of specialized units such as the Policia Urbana (urban police), which are responsible for addressing crime problems in urban areas. Today, municipal policing plays an important role in protecting public safety in Spanish towns and cities.

Walter Bingham (born Wolfgang Billig in Karlsruhe, Weimar Republic in 1924) is a British-Israeli journalist, actor, entrepreneur, Holocaust survivor and decorated World War II veteran. He made Aliyah to Israel in 2004. At age 97 in 2021, Walter is Israel's oldest working journalist. He also holds the Guinness World Record as oldest Radio Talkshow Host. Walter Bingham was born in Karlsruhe, Germany, to an observant Jewish family. His parents had moved from Poland to Germany as children. He was active in an Orthodox Zionist youth group, preparing him to agricultural Kibbutz life in Mandatory Palestine. Bingham witnessed the Nazi book burnings that followed soon after the Nazi Seizure of Power and personally experienced antisemitic bullying. As Bingham and his parents held Polish citizenship and were not German nationals, they were affected by Polenaktion - the arrest and expulsion of Polish Jews living in Germany. Bingham's father was arrested but he himself was not caught up in the sweet as he had been away from the family home at the time - his parents had sent him to a Jewish school in Mannheim. Shortly afterwards, Bingham witnessed the events of Kristallnacht. He survived the Holocaust because of a Kindertransport to Great Britain in 1939, where he lived for the most part in a Zionist Kibbutz type community.

Bloom is a test to measure the reading comprehension of adolescents. It consists of a series of short questions and is designed to measure the ability to understand complex text. The Bloom test was developed in the late 1970s by Dr. Sandra Bloom and her colleagues at the University of California, Los Angeles. The Bloom test is currently the most commonly used adolescent reading comprehension test in the United States. The Bloom test is divided into three parts: the reading selection section, the reading comprehension section, and the writing section. The reading selection section consists of 20 questions that ask students to read a passage about a flower and answer questions about it. The reading comprehension section asks students to read a passage about a car and answer questions about it. The writing section asks students to write a essay about their favorite flower. The Bloom test has been shown to be a reliable measure of adolescent reading comprehension. It has been found to be sensitive to changes in student reading level and has been used to assess reading comprehension skills across diverse populations of students, including low-income students, minority students, and students with disabilities.

Maurice Goldblatt (January 16, 1892 – July 29, 1986) was a French-born American rabbi, philosopher and sociologist who is considered one of the founders of modern sociology. He was also a noted critic of modernity. Goldblatt was born in Paris to a Sephardi Jewish family. After studying at the Sorbonne and at the University of Berlin, he became a rabbinical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in 1915. In 1922 he received his rabbinical ordination from Rabbi Solomon Schechter. Goldblatt served as rabbi of Temple Emanu-El of New York City from 1924 until his retirement in 1965. Goldblatt's work in sociology began with his doctoral dissertation, "The Social Background of Religious Ideas" (1928). His most influential books include The Creation of Social Reality (1949), The Human Condition (1958), and Social Theory and Social Structure (1964). He also published articles on a wide variety of topics in sociology, philosophy, theology and literary criticism. After his retirement from the pulpit, Goldblatt devoted himself to writing and lecturing. He died in 1986 at the age of ninety-one.

The song was used in the EA Sports computer game Madden 08 and Sony's NBA 08. It is the band's first single since the departure of guitarist Dave Baksh. Overview "Underclass Hero" was written by Whibley with a theme of "us against them", similar to their previous lyrics. Although "Underclass Hero" is written from a different angle, the song refers prominently to society and the struggle of "high-class versus the underclass" instead of "youth against adults" as in All Killer No Filler. The song also uses the more classic punk-rock themes of anti-establishment. This is the theme song for MTV's Crash My School. The song's intro is similar to the band's previous single, "Handle This", but with certain modifications in the notes and tuning.

In coding theory, a linear code is a certain type of code that can be used for error-correcting and redundancy-free communication. Linear codes are also called error-correcting codes, block codes, or convolutional codes. Linear codes are used in a variety of applications, such as data communication and storage, machine learning and decoding, computer security, and biomedical data analysis. Linear codes are also of particular interest to researchers working on quantum cryptography and secure communications. A linear code is a code that can be used to communicate errors between two parties. The two parties use a codebook to map each symbol in the code to a corresponding symbol in the other party's codebook. If one of the parties detects an error, they can use their codebook to find the correct symbol in the other party's codebook and send them the correct symbol. Linear codes are composed of codewords (strings of symbols). Each codeword is divided into blocks (groups of consecutive symbols). A block is broken down into symbols (individual symbols). A symbol is either a letter or a number. To encode a message using a linear code, you first choose a codeword for your message. You then create a codebook that contains all the possible symbols you could possibly use for that codeword. You then map each symbol in your message to a corresponding symbol in your codebook. EL-DE Haus, officially the NS Documentation Center of the City of Cologne, located in Cologne, is the former headquarters of the Gestapo and now a museum documenting the Third Reich. The building was at first the business premises of jeweller Leopold Dahmen, and the building takes its name from his initials. In 1934, the Nazis rented the building from him and turned it into the headquarters of the secret police, the Gestapo. Surprisingly, the building survived the Allied bombing of Cologne during World War II, while 90% of the city was destroyed. After the bombings, the basements of the building, which had been used as prison cells and torture rooms for forced labourers and political enemies, were used to store wartime files and paperwork. Inscriptions made on the walls of the prison cells by inmates can still be viewed today. The building was the site of many executions, as well as deaths due to overcrowding and poor hygienic conditions.

The Turin Papyrus Map is an ancient Egyptian map that was written on papyrus around 150 BC. It is the oldest known map of its kind and it is also one of the most important ancient maps because it shows the location of several important ancient Egyptian cities, such as Thebes, Memphis, and Gaza. The Turin Papyrus Map was discovered in the Royal Library at Turin, Italy in 1798 by Antonio Bertani and was first published in 1822 by Jean-François Champollion. The map is currently housed at the Bibliothèque Nationale in Paris. The Turin Papyrus Map is a cuneiform map that was created around 150 BC. It is the oldest known map of its kind and it is also one of the most important ancient maps because it shows the location of several important ancient Egyptian cities, such as Thebes, Memphis, and Gaza. The grey-fronted honeyeater (Ptilotula plumula) is a species of bird in the family Meliphagidae. It is endemic to Australia. Its natural habitat is Mediterranean-type shrubby vegetation. The grey-fronted honeyeater was originally described in 1841 by English ornithologist John Gould as Lichenostomus plumulus. It was moved to the genus Ptilotula after a molecular phylogenetic analysis, published in 2011, showed that Lichenostomus was polyphyletic. Description The grey-fronted honeyeater is a small, plain honeyeater with a yellow neck plume bordered above by black. It has a small grey patch at the forehead, that may be obscure in northern subspecies. The crown is olive yellow and the lores blackish. The upper parts are olive grey and flight feathers yellow olive. Underparts are off white with indistinct stripes. The grey-fronted honeyeater can easily be confused with the yellow-tinted honeyeater as their ranges overlap and they are of similar size. Differences include the lores which are yellow grey and plumes that are narrower in the yellow-tinted honeyeater.

The 3rd Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2012 in Belgium and took place on February 2, 2013, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 20 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Yolande Moreau presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the first time. The nominees for the 3rd Magritte Awards were announced on January 10, 2013. Films receiving the most nominations were Dead Man Talking with eight, followed by Our Children, Mobile Home and One Night with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on February 2, 2013. Our Children won four awards, including Best Film and Best Director for Joachim Lafosse. Other multiple winners were The Minister with three awards, and Mobile Home with two.

Michael "Marsh" Marshall (born 13 August 1983) is an Australian skeptic, author, and public speaker. Marshall is the president of the Australian Skeptics Incorporated (ASI), a member of the International Council of Scientific Unions (ICSU) and the Australian National Committee for the International Council of Science (ACICS). He has also been involved in numerous public debating engagements on science and pseudoscience. Marshall was born in Perth, Western Australia. After completing his secondary education at Narrogin High School, Marshall studied physics at the University of Western Australia, graduating with first-class honours in 2006. He then undertook postgraduate studies at Monash University, graduating with a Master of Science in 2009. Marshall began his career as a research physicist at CSIRO's Materials Sciences Laboratory in 2009. In 2014, he left CSIRO to become president of ASI. Marshall is a prolific writer and has published articles on a wide range of topics, from climate change to conspiracy theories. His book "The End of Faith: Religion, Reason and Belief in an Age of Skepticism" was published in September 2014. Marshall is also a public speaker, having given talks on science and skepticism at venues around Australia and overseas. He has also appeared on television programs such as "Q&A" and "The Project".

Extended collective licensing (ECL) are collective copyright licenses in which the rights holders grant a license to use their copyrighted works to a group of users, rather than to an individual user. ECL allow organizations to share and use copyrighted works collectively, without the need for individual licenses from the rights holders. ECL are based on the premise that a group of users is better able to manage and protect the copyright than an individual user. This allows organizations to share copyrighted works more easily and cost-effectively, while still protecting the rights of the rights holders. There are two main types of ECL: general ECL and restricted ECL. General ECL permits use of the copyrighted work by any group of users, while restricted ECL applies only to certain types of users or uses. ECL have been used in a number of different industries, including education, government, and business. They have also been used in conjunction with other copyright licenses, such as the GNU General Public License (GPL). ECL are becoming increasingly popular due to their flexibility and benefits. They are an excellent option for organizations that need to share copyrighted works, but do not want to burden their users with individual licenses.

Nikolay Mikhailovich Rychkov (2 December 1897 – 26 February 1973) was a Russian politician and diplomat who served as the Prime Minister of the Soviet Union from 1938 to 1941, and as the Foreign Minister from 1938 to 1945. Born in 1897 in the town of Kursk in Russian Empire (now in Russia), Rychkov graduated from the University of Moscow in 1922 and worked as a journalist for various newspapers before joining the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in 1925. He rose through the ranks of the party, becoming a member of its Central Committee in 1934 and a full member of its Politburo in 1938. In September 1938, Rychkov was appointed Prime Minister by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin, replacing Vyacheslav Molotov. As Prime Minister, Rychkov presided over major Soviet territorial conquests during World War II, including the annexation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina and the invasion of Poland. After Stalin's death in March 1953, Rychkov played a largely behind-the-scenes role in Soviet politics during the period of Nikita Khrushchev's de-Stalinization campaign. The Awareness Course is the education programme of the Awareness Foundation. The course has been described as helping "Christians develop an informed response to the religious and cultural diversity around them by being centered in their faith and secure in their identity." It is co-written by retired bishop Michael Marshall and Nadim Nassar, who is the only Syrian priest in the Church of England. The Awareness Course has been taught in the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and Palestine in the Middle East and in Hong Kong. Denominations offering the Awareness Course include the Roman Catholic Church, the Church of England, the Episcopal Church, the Greek Orthodox Church, Presbyterian, Methodist and Baptist churches, Middle Eastern Evangelical churches, and several charismatic evangelical churches in the UK. Teachers are known as "course leaders" and their role is primarily that of a facilitator and motivator rather than lecturer.

William J. McGuire (born 1954) is Emeritus Professor of Earth Sciences at the University of Utah and an expert on volcanoes. McGuire is recognized as a world-renowned expert on the geology, eruption history, and hazards of volcanoes, and has published more than 100 scientific papers and book chapters on the topic. He is a Fellow of the Geological Society of America, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and the National Academy of Sciences. McGuire was born in 1954 in Ogden, Utah. He received his undergraduate degree from Utah State University in 1976 and his graduate degree from the University of Utah in 1979. He began his career as a research associate at the University of Utah in 1979, becoming an assistant professor there in 1986 and a professor in 1991. McGuire has been the Director of the Earth Sciences Department at the University of Utah since 1999. McGuire's research focuses on volcanoes, with an emphasis on their geology, eruption history, and hazards. He has published more than 100 scientific papers and book chapters on the topic. He is a world-renowned expert on the geology, eruption history, and hazards of volcanoes, and has been involved in or led numerous field investigations around the world. He is a Fellow of the Geological Society of America, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and the National Academy of Sciences. "Bangun Pemudi Pemuda" is an Indonesian patriotic song which was created by Alfred Simanjuntak, and to this day the song is still echoed, as in every celebration of Independence on 17 August and Youth Pledge on 28 October. History The melody of Bangun Pemudi Pemuda was taken from the school march of the Sekolah Rakyat Sempurna Indonesia (lit. the Indonesian School for the Perfection of the People), the tune of which was also composed by Simanjuntak. Simanjuntak argued that the people of Indonesia needed to experience a nascent spirit of patriotism, instead of just the six classes at the SRSI. The song's title (Pemudi-Pemuda, lit. Female Youth-Male Youth) was derived from the fact that several European languages use the fixed order of "ladies and gentlemen", incl. Dutch, and that inspired Simanjuntak to put a Pemudi in front of the Pemuda (usually the only term used in Indonesian for 'youth'.) Simanjuntak was put on a hit list by the Japanese military police as a direct result of this song, but it was never carried out, and he discovered the fact after independence.

Pampers is a brand of baby and child products, founded in 1901 by two brothers, Arnold and Rudolf Pampers. The company is headquartered in Erfurt, Germany and has operations in more than 60 countries. Pampers is the leading brand of diapers and baby care products in the world. From newborn diapers and wipes to toddlers' sizes 4-12, Pampers has a product to fit everyone's need. Pampers was founded in 1901 by two brothers, Arnold and Rudolf Pampers. Govind P. Agrawal is an Indian American physicist and a fellow of Optica, Life Fellow of the IEEE, and Distinguished Fellow of the Optical Society of India. He is the recipient of James C. Wyant Professorship of Optics at the Institute of Optics and a professor of physics at the University of Rochester. He is also a Distinguished scientist at the Laboratory for Laser Energetics (LLE) in the University of Rochester. Agrawal has authored and co-authored several highly cited books in the fields of non-linear fiber optics, optical communications, and semiconductor lasers. Early life Agrawal was born on July 24, 1951 in Kashipur of the Nainital district, which was then a part of Uttar Pradesh. He received the B.S. in physics degree from the University of Lucknow in 1969, with honors. He received the M.S. and PhD in physics degrees from the Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, in 1971 and 1974 respectively. He worked in a post-doctoral position in École Polytechnique in France, from 1974 to 1976.

David Wood Townsend (July 18, 1844 – January 2, 1921) was an American politician and journalist. He served as the 25th Governor of Ohio from 1903 to 1905. David Wood Townsend was born in Gallipolis, Ohio on July 18, 1844. He was educated in the local schools and then studied law. He became a prosecuting attorney in 1871 and served in that position until 1875 when he was elected to the Ohio House of Representatives. He served in the House until 1879 and then became a judge on the Ohio Supreme Court. In 1893, he was elected governor of Ohio and served until 1905. During his time as governor, he oversaw a number of improvements, including the construction of state highways and schools. He died on January 2, 1921 and was buried in Spring Grove Cemetery in Columbus, Ohio.

Kim Myong-chol (, born 1944) is a Korean writer and editor based in Japan and an unofficial spokesperson of North Korea, regularly travelling to Pyongyang and around the world portraying the North Korean leadership and politics. He was a close associate of Kim Jong-il. His articles have appeared in many publications, including Asia Times and Asia Research. Among the several books that he has written is Kim Jong-il — Military Strategy for Reunification. His books have been banned in South Korea. Currently, he is the Executive Director of CFKAP (Center for Korean-American Peace), based in Tokyo, Japan. He holds North Korean nationality and a North Korean Diplomatic Passport. He has claimed variously that "North Korea has all types of nuclear bombs and warheads, atomic, hydrogen and neutron, and the means of delivery, short-range, medium-range and long-range, putting the whole of the continental US within effective range" and that "[u]nlike all the previous wars Korea fought, a next war will be better called the American War or the DPRK-US War because the main theater will be the continental US, with major cities transformed into towering infernos." Additionally, he has threatened Australia with similar results, stating "[i]f Australia becomes part of American manipulation against North Korea, North Korea reserve the right to strike back on Australia".

The Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park, New York City is an annual summer music festival that has been held since 1972. The festival typically features classical, jazz, and world music performances, as well as children's activities and a variety of food vendors. The Schaefer Music Festival is one of the largest and longest-running classical music festivals in the United States, and it is considered one of the most prestigious events on the classical music calendar. The festival typically draws a crowd of approximately 20,000 people, and it has been praised for its high standards of musicianship and programming. The Schaefer Music Festival was founded by Seymour and Shirley Schaefer in 1972 as an effort to bring classical music to a wider audience. The Schaefer family continues to play an important role in the festival's operations, and the festival has been administered by the Seymour and Shirley Schaefer Foundation since its inception. The Schaefer Music Festival routinely features world-renowned performers such as Andrea Bocelli, Yo-Yo Ma, Joshua Bell, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. The festival also features young emerging artists such as Lang Lang and Yannick Nézet-Séguin. In recent years, the festival has expanded its programming to include rock concerts and comedy acts.

Mohaather (foaled 26 April 2016) is a British Thoroughbred racehorse and sire. As a two-year-old he was undefeated in three races including the Group One Middle Park Stakes and the Group Two Haydock Sprint Cup. He made his first appearance as a three-year-old in the Dubai World Cup and finished fourth of the ten runners. In the National Stakes he finished second to stablemate Al Shaher. Mohaather is a bay horse with a white blaze and a white sock on his right hind leg bred in England by Sheikh Mohammed's Godolphin Racing. He was sired by Galileo, who won the 2000 Guineas and The Derby, as well as the Champion Stakes and King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes. His dam, Manduro, ran twice in Britain, winning the Geoffrey Freer Stakes in 2007 and finishing third in the 1000 Guineas in 2008. Mohaather was bought for £350,000 at auction at Newmarket Racecourse on 20 October 2017 by Sheikh Hamdan bin Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum, Vice President and Prime Minister of the United Arab Emirates.

Codex Ephraemi Rescriptus (Paris, National Library of France, Greek 9; Gregory-Aland no. C or 04, von Soden δ 3) is a fifth-century Greek manuscript of the Bible, sometimes referred to as one of the four great uncials (see Codices Sinaiticus, Alexandrinus and Vaticanus). The manuscript is not intact: in its current condition, Codex C contains material from every New Testament book except 2 Thessalonians and 2 John; however, only six books of the Greek Old Testament are represented. It is not known whether 2 Thessalonians and 2 John were excluded on purpose, or whether no fragment of either epistle happened to survive. The manuscript is called Codex Ephraemi Rescriptus because (a) it is a codex, i.e., a handmade book; (b) its parchment has been recycled; originally inscribed with scriptural texts, the pages were washed (removing most of the ink) and reused for another text, and (c) the text that was written on the recycled pages, in the 12th century, consisted of Greek translations of 38 treatises composed by Ephrem the Syrian, a prominent theologian of the mid-4th century. Manuscripts of this sort, consisting of recycled pages, are known as palimpsests. The later, "upper", text was written in the 12th century.

Erik Hightower (born 6 April 1986) is an Australian professional rugby league footballer who plays for the Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles in the National Rugby League. A Queensland State of Origin and Australian international, he previously played for the North Queensland Cowboys and the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs. Hightower is a tall, rangy, and powerful forward who excels in the open field. He has been described as a natural goal scorer, with great hands and an impressive running game. He is known for his elusiveness and his ability to avoid tackles. Hightower made his first grade debut for the North Queensland Cowboys in 2007. He played for the Cowboys until 2012, when he moved to the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs. In 2014, he was named captain-coach of the Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles. Hightower has since won two premierships with Manly-Warringah, in 2016 and 2019. Hightower was born in Brisbane, Queensland on 6 April 1986. He is of Aboriginal and Irish descent. Hightower attended St Joseph's College, Ipswich before playing rugby league for Ipswich Brothers in the Brisbane competition. Hightower made his NRL debut for the North Queensland Cowboys in 2007 against the Melbourne Storm. He played 26 games for North Queensland before moving to Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs in 2012. In 2014, he was named captain-coach of Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles and led them to their first prem

The Now Tour is a concert tour by American singer and songwriter Maxwell. The 12-date tour began on September 27, 2019 in San Diego and will conclude on December 16, 2019 in Los Angeles. Maxwell first announced plans for the Now Tour in early 2019, stating that he wanted to "take the show on the road and give fans a one-of-a-kind experience." The tour is Maxwell's first since headlining the annual Jingle Ball tour in 2018. The tour is themed around Maxwell's fourth studio album, "Now", which was released in early 2019. The title of each show on the tour will be based on a different track from "Now". For example, the first show of the tour will be called "Maxwell's House" and will feature performances of songs from "Now" such as "Lakeith Stanfield" and "Slay". Maxwell has enlisted several guest stars for the tour including Stanfield, 21 Savage, Dua Lipa, Khalid and Halsey.

"Accidental Racist" is a song performed by American rapper Meek Mill. The song was released as the third single from his third studio album, Dreams and Nightmares (2015). The song, produced by Boi-1da, features guest appearances from American rapper Rick Ross and Canadian singer The Weeknd. The song's lyrics discuss the issue of racism and its effects on the black community. It has been noted for its controversial content, which has prompted criticism from some sections of the media. "Accidental Racist" peaked at number six on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number two on the UK Singles Chart. It also reached the top ten in Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and Australia. The music video for "Accidental Racist" was directed by Colin Tilley and released on July 29, 2015. It features Mill and Ross performing in a warehouse setting while The Weeknd performs in a desert setting. Both Mill and Ross have been accused of using racial slurs in their verses.

Andrew Wilson Appel (born 1960) is the Eugene Higgins Professor of computer science at Princeton University. He is especially well-known because of his compiler books, the Modern Compiler Implementation in ML series, as well as Compiling With Continuations . He is also a major contributor to the Standard ML of New Jersey compiler, along with David MacQueen, John H. Reppy, Matthias Blume and others and one of the authors of Rog-O-Matic. Biography Andrew Appel is the son of mathematician Kenneth Appel, who proved the Four-Color Theorem in 1976. Appel graduated summa cum laude with an A.B. in physics from Princeton University in 1981 after completing a senior thesis, titled "Investigation of galaxy clustering using an asymptotically fast N-body algorithm", under the supervision of Nobel laureate James Peebles. He later received a Ph.D. (computer science) at Carnegie-Mellon University, in 1985. He became an ACM Fellow in 1998, due to his research of programming languages and compilers.

Jay Walljasper (died 22 December 2020) was an American writer, editor, speaker, and community consultant. He explored how new ideas in urban planning, placemaking, tourism, community development, sustainability, politics and culture could alter urban livability for the better. R.T. Rybak, mayor of Minneapolis (2002-14), wrote: “I’ve read scores of books and articles on cities, heard by now most of the very best urban minds . . . much of what I said that mattered as mayor was deeply influenced by Jay.” Career Walljasper graduated from the University of Iowa in Iowa City, where he wrote for the Daily Iowan. At the University of Minnesota's School of Journalism and Mass Communication in 1981 he published "Age, a Minnesota perspective." He was urban-writer-in-residence at Augsburg University, director of strategic communications and senior fellow at Project for Public Spaces, and director of communications and collaboration for the Social Life Project. He worked with organizations such as the National Geographic Society, Kresge Foundation, AARP, Kaiser Permanente, Blue Zones, Minneapolis Foundation, McKnight Foundation and many others. According to the non-profit America Walks, he "helped walking and walkable communities gain broader appeal" through research, networking, advocacy, and journalism.

19th century Castle Toward , near Dunoon , was used to ready soldiers for the D-Day landings in World War Two . Overlooking Clyde estuary and with easy access to the sloping shoreline , it was deemed an ideal training ground . The castle was commandeered by Winston Churchill and was commissioned as HMS Brontosaurus in 1942 . The training that took place was so realistic and demanding many servicemen were killed in accidents .

The Austudy Five was the epithet given to five Australian academics who were arrested in Indonesia in 1998 on charges of spying. The five were: Professor James Ricketson, from the University of Melbourne Professor Hugh White, from the University of Sydney Professor Warren Beatty, from the University of Queensland Dr David Kilgour, from the Australian National University Dr David Mathews, from Monash University. The Austudy Five were initially held in a secret location in Indonesia before being secretly released and flown back to Australia in early 1999. The five were vilified by the Indonesian government and faced intense public pressure to apologize for their alleged crimes. In 2002, all five academics filed a civil lawsuit against the Indonesian government in an effort to clear their name. The suit was unsuccessful and all five Austudy Five eventually withdrew their suits. The Austudy Five affair has been widely regarded as a dark moment in Australian foreign policy and has been cited as a factor in the re-election of John Howard as Prime Minister in late 2001.

Fish and shellfish concentrate mercury in their muscles, scales and other organs. Mercury can bioaccumulate in fish, and high levels of mercury have been found in some species of fish. Mercury poisoning can cause neurological problems, including learning disabilities, behavioral changes and reduced IQ. Mercury is a heavy metal with three main isotopes: mercury-206, mercury-204 and mercury-203. All three are dangerous to human health. Mercury-206 is the most hazardous because it is a radioactive element. It has a half-life of about 88 days, meaning that over time it will decay by half. Mercury is found in many different places around the world, but it is concentrated in fish and shellfish. Fish and shellfish concentrate mercury in their muscles, scales and other organs. Mercury can bioaccumulate in fish, and high levels of mercury have been found in some species of fish. Mercury poisoning can cause neurological problems, including learning disabilities, behavioral changes and reduced IQ.

Tram Nguyen (; born June 22, 1986) is an American politician serving as a member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives from the 18th Essex District. She represents the towns of Andover, Boxford, North Andover, and Tewksbury. Nguyen serves as the Vice Chair of the Joint Committee on Labor & Workforce Development (first AAPI woman Vice Chair in the MA House of Representatives) and member of Joint Committee on Mental Health, Substance Use & Recovery Committee, Joint Committee on Municipalities & Regional Governments, and House Committee Human Resources & Employee Engagement (formerly Personnel & Administration). Prior to being elected as the first Vietnamese-American woman in the Massachusetts Legislature, Nguyen was an attorney at Greater Boston Legal Services providing support for survivors of domestic violence, seniors, veterans, people with disabilities, low-wage workers, and others from vulnerable communities. Early life and education Nguyen was born in Vietnam and immigrated to the United States with her family as political refugees when she was 5 years old. She was raised in the Merrimack Valley and resides in Andover. Nguyen graduated from Methuen High School and enrolled at Tufts University as a first-generation college student. Before deciding to study law, Nguyen believed she wanted to study medicine and become a pediatrician. Her love for children led her to become involved with the Jumpstart program providing education to help underprivileged children develop literacy skills at a young age. However, her involvement with Jumpstart led Tram to realize that she wanted to continue to help families such as these and preferred to make change through policy, not medicine. Nguyen received a degree in Sociology and American Studies from Tufts University and then her J.D. from Northeastern University.

Victor David Sjöström (; 20 September 1879 – 3 January 1960), also known in the United States as Victor Seastrom, was a pioneering Swedish film director, screenwriter, and actor. He began his career in Sweden, before moving to Hollywood in 1924. Sjöström worked primarily in the silent era; his best known films include The Phantom Carriage (1921), He Who Gets Slapped (1924), and The Wind (1928). Sjöström was Sweden's most prominent director in the "Golden Age of Silent Film" in Europe. Later in life, he played the leading role in Ingmar Bergman's Wild Strawberries (1957). Biography Born in Årjäng/Silbodal, in the Värmland region of Sweden, he was only a year old when his father, Olof Adolf Sjöström, moved the family to Brooklyn, New York. His mother died in 1886, he was seven years old. Sjöström returned to Sweden where he lived with relatives in Stockholm, beginning his acting career at 17 as a member of a touring theater company.

Heinrich (Henri) Jasper (born February 1, 1974) is a German biologist and the current President of the Max Planck Society. He is known for his work on the evolutionary biology of sexual selection and for his work on the genetics of sexual orientation. Jasper was born in Würzburg, Germany, in 1974. After completing his undergraduate studies at the University of Würzburg, he completed his doctoral studies at the University of Cambridge in 2003, under the supervision of Kevin Nunn and Richard Dawkins. His thesis was entitled "The evolution of sexual selection: from individual to population level". Following his graduation from Cambridge, he returned to Germany to take up a postdoctoral position at the University of Tuebingen. In 2007, he moved to the University of Edinburgh, where he is currently a professor. Jasper's research focuses on the evolutionary biology of sexual selection and the genetics of sexual orientation. He is particularly known for his work on evolutionary developmental biology, which has led him to develop novel methods for studying sexual selection at the individual and population levels. Jasper has also published extensively on comparative physiology and has made important contributions to our understanding of how genetic variation affects organismal development and performance.

The Vanadis expedition was a sailing expedition that set out from Spitsbergen in 1894, and aimed to cross the Arctic Ocean by way of the Northeast Passage. The expedition was led by Roald Amundsen, and it was the first time that a voyage across the Arctic had been successfully completed. The Vanadis expedition was an ambitious undertaking, and it required a great deal of preparation and planning. The team of sailors and scientists aboard the expedition were divided into two groups: the first group consisted of Amundsen and his crew, while the second group was made up ofscientists and support personnel who were stationed at Spitsbergen. The journey across the Arctic Ocean was not easy, and there were many challenges that the team faced along the way. However, they eventually reached their destination, and they were able to achieve what had previously been considered to be an impossible goal.

Dorothy Alice Weisel Hack (March 7, 1910 – December 25, 1996) was an American author, memoirist and social activist. She is best known for her memoir The Diary of a Young Girl (1955), which has been read by millions of people and has been translated into more than twenty languages. Dorothy Hack was born in New York City in 1910 to a Jewish family. She attended Smith College and later studied at the Sorbonne in Paris. After returning to the United States, she worked as a journalist for magazines such as Harper's Bazaar and The New Yorker. Her first book, a novel called When the Boys Come Home (1943), was unsuccessful, but her second, a memoir called The Diary of a Young Girl (1955), became a bestseller and won the Pulitzer Prize. Hack's work ranged from writing novels to editing anthologies of poetry, but she is best known for her memoir, which tells the story of her experience during World War II as a teenager in Nazi-occupied Hungary. The book has been read by millions of people and has been translated into more than twenty languages. After the war, Hack worked as a journalist for newspapers such as The New York Times and Newsweek. She retired in 1986 and died in 1996 at the age of 88.

Desmond "Dessie" Gorman (born 13 December 1964) is an Irish former professional footballer who played for a number of clubs on both sides of the Irish border. Career Gorman started his career with Dundalk, making his League of Ireland debut on 10 March 1985. His form attracted the attention of English side Arsenal, and he played for them in a friendly against Shamrock Rovers at Glenmalure Park in August 1986. While at Dundalk he won all domestic honours, and was top scorer during both the 1985–86 (with 11 goals) and 1987–88 (with 16 goals) seasons. In 1989, he moved to French club FC Bourges who he helped win promotion, and then to Derry City in October 1990. In the summer of 1991 he moved to Shelbourne, before signing with Linfield in December 1992. He stayed with Linfield until 1997, before playing with Newry Town, Bangor, Ards, Banbridge Town. He returned briefly to Dundalk in 2003, before retiring. He came out of retirement in 2007 to play briefly for Loughgall.

Colin J. McRae (born Colin John McRae; 25 October 1961) is a Scottish racing driver who has competed in Formula One, Indianapolis 500, CART and the World Sportscar Championship. He is most famous for his championship-winning drives in the 1988 and 1990 Formula One seasons with McLaren. McRae also made a successful return to Formula One in 2001 with Williams. McRae was born in Glasgow, Scotland, on 25 October 1961. After achieving success in junior formula racing, he made his Formula One debut with the McLaren team in 1984. He quickly became a regular starter and won his first Grand Prix at the 1985 Spanish Grand Prix. In 1988, he won his second championship title driving for McLaren. The following year, he moved to Williams and won his third championship title. McRae retired from Formula One after the 1993 season. In 1997, McRae made a successful return to Formula One with Williams. He finished fifth in the Drivers' Championship that year and retired from racing at the end of the season. In 2001, he returned to Formula One with Williams and finished fourth in the Drivers' Championship that year. McRae retired from racing for a second time at the end of the 2003 season. McRae has been involved in many non-racing activities since retiring from racing. He has served as a coach for various drivers including Nico Rosberg and Fernando Alonso. Arab identity is the objective or subjective identification of Arabs with one another, as well as their collective sense of belonging to the Arab world. Arab identity has been shaped by a long history and diverse cultural heritage, which has resulted in a multiplicity of views on what it means to be an Arab. Some Arabs see themselves as descendants of the ancient Arabs, while others see themselves as products of the various waves of immigration that have enriched Arab culture over the past centuries. Moreover, Arab identity is often intertwined with religious and political affiliations. The definition of Arab identity has been a source of contention for many Arabs, and has been a central topic of debate in the Arab world. Some Arabs see their identity as a unifying force that can help unite the Arab world against external threats, while others view their identity as a source of division that can lead to sectarianism and conflict.

Lafa ( lit. bear) is the subdistrict of Jiaohe, Jilin, China. It is located at the northeast of Jiaohe, away from Jiaohe city 12 km, below the Lafa Mountain. The east is Qianjin, the southeast is Wulin, the south is Jiaohe new town (Henan subdistrict), the west is Qingling, the north is Xinzhan. The area of Lafa is 327.35 km², among this has 57.6% is forest. The subdistrict has 18 administrate villages and 65 natural villages, and also has 1 administrate community with 3 neighborhoods. The government sent organs is located at Lafa village. History The original name of Lafa was Lamenzi , because the local terrain is high at east and west, low at central, looks like the big stone gate. Chinese name Lafa was transfer from Manchu name Lefu, which meaning bear. There had Lafa station at Qing dynasty, when at 1928, Jidun railway was set railway station here.

Colonel (retired) Jibril Bala Yakubu was the first Administrator of Zamfara State after it was created from part of Sokoto State in October 1996, holding office until the return to democracy in May 1999 during the military regimes of Generals Sani Abacha and Abdulsalami Abubakar. As Zamfara administrator, Yakubu created five Emirates in the state and eleven new District Councils. After handing over to the civilian governor Ahmed Sani Yerima in May 1999, as a former military administrator he was required to retire from the army. Yakubu was arrested and jailed based on a charge filed on 9 December 1999 that alleged that he conspired with four others in 1996 to assassinate Alex Ibru, the publisher of The Guardian newspaper. As Commanding Officer of 29 Battalion, he allegedly supplied arms to killer squads who eliminated other opponents of General Sani Abacha. In December 2003 a judge refused his request to stop the trial. In April 2009 the Arewa Consultative Forum, a Northern lobby group, urged the Federal Government to release Yakubu Jibril on the basis of the spirit of national reconciliation recommended by the Oputa panel.
