A full-time job is employment in which a person works a minimum number of hours defined as such by their employer. Overview Full-time employment often comes with benefits that are not typically offered to part-time, temporary, or flexible workers, such as annual leave, sick leave, and health insurance. Part-time jobs are mistakenly thought by some to not be careers. However, legislation exists to stop employers from discriminating against part-time workers so this should not be a factor when making decisions on career advancement. They generally pay more than part-time jobs per hour, and this is similarly discriminatory if the pay decision is based on part-time status as a primary factor. The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) does not define full-time employment or part-time employment. This is a matter generally to be determined by the employer (US Department of Labor). The definition by the employer can vary and is generally published in a company's Employee Handbook. Companies commonly require from 32 to 40 hours per week to be defined as full-time and therefore eligible for benefits.

Carolyn C. Porco (born March 6, 1953) is an American astrophysicist and planetary scientist who has made significant contributions to understanding the atmospheres, surfaces, and interiors of terrestrial and planetary bodies in the Solar System. She is currently a professor at Vanderbilt University in the Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences. Porco was born on March 6, 1953, in Santa Monica, California. She completed her undergraduate studies at Stanford University in 1974 and then completed her graduate studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1978. Porco began her career as a research scientist at the Carnegie Institution for Science in 1982. She moved to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in 1984, where she worked until joining Vanderbilt University as a professor in 2007. Porco's research has focused on the atmospheres, surfaces, and interiors of terrestrial and planetary bodies in the Solar System. Her work on Venus has led to a better understanding of how that planet's atmosphere works and how that atmosphere may have been lost over time. Her work on Mars has revealed evidence for water ice at the Red Planet's poles, which could be useful for future human missions to that planet. Porco's work on Jupiter has shown that that gas giant may have had a thicker atmosphere in the past than is currently believed. Porco is also known for her work on using ground-based observations to improve our understanding of space weather events. Her work on using observational data to improve our understanding of solar storms has led to improved predictions of those events

Thomas Earl Pardoe (1885–1971) was the first head of the Brigham Young University (BYU) drama program. One of the main theaters in the Harris Fine Arts Center at BYU is named for him and his wife, Kathryn Bassett Pardoe, who was also an influential drama teacher at BYU. Pardoe was born and raised in Ogden, Utah. Pardoe was involved in high school and community dramatic productions, but when he went to Stanford University, it was to study engineering. In his studies, he discovered that he was more suited to a career in theatre. He returned to Ogden and worked as a stagehand and back-up actor for the Ogden Opera Company before going to study at the Leland Powers School in Boston. While there he also served as a missionary for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), in part because his uncle, Ben E. Rich, was the mission president. While in Boston, Pardoe also performed with the Boston Grand Opera and was a correspondent for the Deseret News. Pardoe graduated from Leland Powers in 1913.

Alström's warbler, or plain-tailed warbler (Phylloscopus soror) is a species of Old World warbler in the family Phylloscopidae. It was first described in 1999. It breeds only in China, and winters in Thailand, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam. Its natural habitat is temperate forests. Habitat and migration The alström's warbler often forages in a low, dense growth of forests. This bird is known to eat insects and catch prey during short flights. The bird is not currently globally threatened. This bird has a very large range and does not approach the potential of being a vulnerable species. The warbler typically breeds in warmer, temperate areas. These areas are found within evergreen broadleaf forest zones and lush undergrowth in mature forests.The warbler tends to breed in low to moderate height bushes and low trees, in recently cleared areas. This bird is a migratory species. The warbler migrates during the winter in southern Myanmar, Thailand, Cambodia, southern Vietnam, and southern China.

Brian "Nobby" Horton (born 4 February 1949) is a Welsh former professional footballer who played as a central defender. Brian Horton was born in Neath, Wales on 4 February 1949. He began his career with Welsh club Glamorgan where he made over 390 appearances before moving to English side Manchester United in 1974. He would make over 250 appearances for United before retiring in 1984. After retirement, Horton moved into management and was appointed manager of Brighton & Hove Albion in 1995. He would remain in the role for three years before leaving to take up a position as Director of Football at Wales national football team. He left his post with Wales in 2001, but returned to the role in 2007. In December 2009, Horton was sacked from his post as Director of Football at Swansea City after allegations of financial irregularities were made against him. In October 2011, Horton was arrested and charged with fraud after it was alleged that he had taken £130,000 from a sports charity he was involved in. The case against Horton collapsed after he appeared at Cardiff Crown Court and he was later released without charge. Upon his release, Horton announced his retirement from football. Brian Horton is married to Dawn and they have three children; two daughters and a son.

Dr. Bernard S. Baker (June 26, 1936 – June 21, 2004) was born in Philadelphia and a resident of Bethel, Connecticut in the United States. He was a pioneer in the field of electrochemistry and his career spanned 45 years. He was a founder and served as president, chief executive officer and chairman of Energy Research Corporation (now called FuelCell Energy, Inc., in Danbury, Connecticut), developer and manufacturer of direct fuel cells (MCFC) used to generate electric power. Power plants based on his concepts are providing electricity in distributed generation locations throughout the world. Baker was known worldwide as an expert in electrochemical systems. He directed research in and development of various electrochemical power generation devices, including different types of fuel cells, batteries and hybrid systems. Baker's expertise encompassed fundamental research as well as the technological, engineering, system and marketing aspects of these systems, including "direct fuel cells", which can process hydrocarbon fuels such as natural gas without an external reformer.

The Breach is a 1970 film written and directed by Claude Chabrol, based on the novel The Balloon Man by Charlotte Armstrong. The film was also known as The Breakup at times in its release in the United States. The film had a total of 927,678 admissions in France. Plot Hélène Régnier's (Audran) mentally ill husband Charles (Drouot) injures their son, Michel, in a violent rage. Hélène beats Charles to the floor with a frying pan, flees and starts divorce proceedings. Charles moves back in with his wealthy and manipulative parents, who never approved of his marriage and are determined to secure custody of Michel. While the boy is recovering in a local hospital, Hélène moves to a boarding house nearby. The Régniers hire Paul Thomas (Cassel), an impoverished family acquaintance, to find damaging material on Hélène to help them secure custody. Paul moves into the boarding house and, with the help of his girlfriend Sonia (Rouvel), plots to ruin Hélène's reputation.

Alpha Alexander (born June 9, 1954 in Nashville, Tennessee) was co-founder of the Black Women in Sport Foundation. Early life and education Alpha Alexander was born June 9, 1954 in Nashville, Tennessee to parents Alpha Omega Alexander and Rufus S. Alexander. Alexander's mother, Alpha Omega Alexander was an elementary school teacher in Dayton, Ohio. Alexander's father graduated from the University of Wisconsin and worked for the United States Post Office. Alexander later moved to Dayton, Ohio where she grew up. Alexander attended Blairwood Elementary and went to Jefferson High School. Alexander was unable to play sports at Jefferson High School due to sports not being offered to girls. Alexander then went on to attend The College of Wooster in 1976 where she attained her bachelor's degree in Physical Education. While there she played Volleyball (1973-1975), Lacrosse, Tennis, and Basketball (1972-1976). Alexander earned her master's degree in 1978 and Doctorate degree in 1981 at Temple University in Pennsylvania.

Animal sexual behaviour takes many different forms, from simple courtship rituals between animals of the same sex, to complex homosexual and bisexual behaviours. Some animals may have more than one form of sexual behaviour, and some may engage in sexual activities for reasons other than reproduction. Sexual behaviour can be a means of establishing or maintaining social relationships, competing for resources or mates, or satisfying individual desires. Animal sexual behaviour has been observed in a variety of species across the animal kingdom, from insects to large mammals. Some species display a great deal of sexual variation, with different populations of animals exhibiting differing levels of sexual activity. The study of animal sexual behaviour is an important tool for understanding the biology and evolution of sexuality, as well as the social dynamics of animal populations. It can also provide insights into human sexuality, since many animal behaviours are similar to those exhibited by humans.

Craig V. Hickman (born December 8, 1967) is an American composer and musician who has been involved in the music industry since the early 1990s. He is known for his work in video game music, film and television scoring, and has won several awards for his work. Craig Hickman was born on December 8, 1967, in Eureka, California. He grew up in the small town of Minden, Nevada, and started playing the piano at age four. Hickman studied music at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, where he earned a degree in music composition in 1990. Hickman began his career as a video game composer in the early 1990s. His credits include work on titles such as "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV: Turtles in Time", "The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past", "Super Mario RPG", "Street Fighter Alpha 2", and "Mega Man X". He later went on to score films and television shows, including "Beowulf", "The Omen", "Kiss the Girls", "The X-Files", and "The Vampire Diaries". In 2016, he composed the score for the video game "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare". Hickman has been nominated for several awards for his work, including an Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Series (for The X-Files), a Grammy Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media (for Street Fighter Alpha 2), and a Golden Globe Award for Best Original

The Horrorist was an occult and horror-themed comic book limited series written by Jamie Delano, with art by David Lloyd, published by the DC Comics imprint Vertigo. It was a spin-off of Vertigo's popular Hellblazer series and features the character John Constantine. The book consisted of two 52-page issues without advertisements, published in December 1995 and January 1996 respectively. Plot The story revolves around Angel, who as a young girl was rescued from war-torn Mozambique, and who witnessed the most unspeakable war crimes and atrocities. As an adult, in the present day, Angel becomes a "Horrorist", that is, someone who redistributes pain by unveiling to people the suffering of others. She travels America's roadways, annihilating people's solipsistic existence by exposing them to the unfettered scope of true oppression, famine and murder. Sometimes this takes the form of altered reality, such as several boys playing in the snow dying from landmines that were not there earlier.

Nelson Dingley Jr. (February 15, 1832 – January 10, 1900) was an American businessman and politician who served as the 36th Governor of New York from 1882 to 1884. Dingley was born on February 15, 1832 in Oneida County, New York to Nelson Dingley and Maria (née Clark). He attended the common schools and graduated from Hamilton College in 1853. Dingley engaged in the hardware business and became a partner in the firm of Dingley, Clarkson & Company. He served as president of the Albany and Oneida Railroad from 1872 to 1874. Dingley was elected as a Republican to the Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Congresses (March 4, 1879 – March 3, 1883). He was governor of New York from 1882 to 1884. Dingley died on January 10, 1900 in Albany, New York. He was buried at Albany Rural Cemetery.

is a series of video games by Sega. The first three games were developed in the 1990s by Sega's Team Andromeda for the Sega Saturn console. The fourth, Panzer Dragoon Orta (2002), was developed for Xbox by Sega's Smilebit team. The Panzer Dragoon games are rail shooters, except Panzer Dragoon Saga (1998), a role-playing game. All games follow the story of a hero or heroine fighting an evil empire in a post-apocalyptic world while riding a dragon. The series' name originates from its original concept designers referring to it as "armoured dragon", then feeling that this was too bland and deciding to transliterate it to German. The cutscenes feature its own language, Panzerese, which is a mixed language based on a combination of Ancient Greek, English, German, Japanese, Latin, and Russian. The parieto-frontal integration theory (P-FIT) considers intelligence to relate to how well different brain regions integrate to form intelligent behaviors. The theory proposes that large scale brain networks connect brain regions, including regions within frontal, parietal, temporal, and cingulate cortices, underlie the biological basis of human intelligence. These regions, which overlap significantly with the task-positive network, allow the brain to communicate and exchange information efficiently with one another. Support for this theory is primarily based on neuroimaging evidence, with support from lesion studies. The P-FIT is influential in that it explains the majority of current neuroimaging findings, as well as increasing empirical support for cognition being the result of large-scale brain networks, rather than numerous domain-specific processes or modules. A 2010 review of the neuroscience of intelligence described P-FIT as "the best available answer to the question of where in the brain intelligence resides". The theory General intelligence requires specific brain regions and incorporates: Sensory processing, primarily in the visual and auditory modalities, including specific temporal and parietal areas Sensory abstracting and elaboration by the parietal cortex (especially the supramarginal, superior parietal, and angular gyri) Interaction between the parietal cortex and frontal lobes for hypothesis testing available solutions Response selection and inhibition of competing responses by the anterior cingulate

"Greatest Love Story" is a song recorded by American singer Whitney Houston and written by Houston, La Toya Jackson, and Michael Masser. The song was released as the lead single from Houston's seventh studio album I Look to You (1990). "Greatest Love Story" is a ballad about the love between a man and a woman. It was well received by music critics, who praised its lyrical content and vocals. The song became Houston's seventh number-one single on the "Billboard" Hot 100 chart, and also topped the charts in Canada and the Netherlands. On the UK Singles Chart, it reached number two behind Jackson's "I Want You Back". "Greatest Love Story" was nominated for both the Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance and the Brit Award for Best British Single at the 1991 Brit Awards. Houston performed "Greatest Love Story" at the 1990 Grammy Awards, where it received two nominations: Best Female Pop Vocal Performance and Best Song Written for a Film. In 1992, she performed it at the Christmas Special of ABC's TV series "The Dick Van Dyke Show". In 1993, she performed it at Super Bowl XXVII. In 1998, she performed it at Super Bowl XXXVIII.

Frederick August "Fritz" Mollwitz (June 16, 1890 – February 12, 1941) was a German sculptor, painter, and printmaker. He is considered one of the most important artists of Expressionism. Fritz Mollwitz was born in Berlin, the son of a sculptor father and a painter mother. He studied at the Berlin Academy of Art from 1909 to 1913 and then at the Kunstgewerbeschule in Dresden from 1913 to 1915. In 1916 he moved to Vienna, where he became associated with the group Der Blaue Reiter. In 1918 he moved to Cologne, where he became associated with the Cologne School of Expressionism. Mollwitz was drafted into the German Army in 1918 and served in World War I as a artillery officer on the Eastern Front. After the war he returned to Cologne and continued to work until his death. Mollwitz is best known for his sculptures and paintings of human beings and animals in emotionally charged situations. His paintings are characterized by their thick brushstrokes, low tones, and often starkly contrasting colors. His sculptures are often monumental and figure-based, depicting individual characters with great psychological depth. Mollwitz was also one of the first artists to experiment with printmaking, producing unconventional etchings and lithographs that are often dark and unsettling.

Safetipin is a social organisation working with a wide range of urban stakeholders including governments to make public spaces safer and more inclusive for women. Safetipin collects data using 3 mobile phone applications (My Safetipin, which is available on the app store and play store; Safetipin Nite and Safetipin Site) and present this to relevant stakeholders with recommendations. The apps also generate a safety score based on the data collected and provide it in the My Safetipin app for users to make safe and informed decisions about their mobility. Organization and mission Based in India, Safetipin aims to make cities safer by providing data collected through technology tools and apps to its users. The data is collected and analysed on parameters that impact safety and walkability. Its end goal is to achieve movement without fear for women. It was co-founded by gender rights' activist Kalpana Viswanath and Ashish Basu in 2013.

Rijeka ( ,  , ; , ; local Chakavian: Reka; ; ) is the principal seaport and the third-largest city in Croatia (after Zagreb and Split). It is located in Primorje-Gorski Kotar County on Kvarner Bay, an inlet of the Adriatic Sea and in 2021 had a population of 108,622 inhabitants. Historically, because of its strategic position and its excellent deep-water port, the city was fiercely contested, especially between the HRE, Hungary (serving as the Kingdom of Hungary's largest and most important port), Italy and Croatia, changing rulers and demographics many times over centuries. According to the 2011 census data, the majority of its citizens are Croats, along with small numbers of Serbs, Bosniaks and Italians. Rijeka is the main city and county seat of the Primorje-Gorski Kotar County. The city's economy largely depends on shipbuilding (shipyards "3. Maj" and "Viktor Lenac Shipyard") and maritime transport. Rijeka hosts the Croatian National Theatre Ivan pl. Zajc, first built in 1765, as well as the University of Rijeka, founded in 1973 but with roots dating back to 1632 and the local Jesuit School of Theology.

Southern Airways Express is a commuter airline operating across the United States with headquarters in Palm Beach, Florida. Southern Airways acts as a local service airline for dozens of cities across all U.S. time zones, Approximately a third of its routes are subsidized through the Essential Air Service program by the United States Department of Transportation. In its Gulf, New England, and Hawaiian Regions, Southern operates from executive terminals at primary airports, meaning that passengers are not required to check-in at the main passenger terminals, nor are they required to pass through Transportation Security Administration (TSA) security screening. In Southern's mid-Atlantic, Rocky Mountain, and California footprints, passengers embark and disembark through the primary secured (TSA) terminals. In June 2018 Southern became an interline partner with American Airlines, allowing for single-ticketing and baggage transfers between Southern and American. Southern later added interline partnerships with Alaska Airlines and United Airlines.

Maryland Route 408 (MD 408) is a state highway in the U.S. state of Maryland. Known as Mount Zion-Marlboro Road, the highway runs from MD 4 at Waysons Corner east to MD 2 and MD 422 in Lothian. MD 408 is the old alignment of MD 4 in southern Anne Arundel County. The highway was constructed in the late 1910s and became the easternmost part of MD 4 in 1927. The highway received its present designation in the mid-1960s when MD 4 was rerouted south into Calvert County. MD 408's western end was relocated when MD 4 was upgraded to a freeway through Waysons Corner in the early 1990s. MD 408 was also applied to the old sections of MD 4 between Andrews Air Force Base and Upper Marlboro in Prince George's County. The number was assigned after the MD 4 freeway was completed in the mid-1960s. The Prince George's County portions of MD 408 were transferred to county maintenance in the late 1970s except the section through Upper Marlboro, which became MD 725. Route description

The recorded begins with the arrival of the Celts in the late 4th century BC and the Roman occupation of Britain. Scotland's indigenous people, the Picts, were defeated by the Roman Empire in AD 410 and thereafter largely disappeared from historical record. The early Middle Ages saw a series of invasions by the Angles, Saxons and Vikings. In 843, the kingdom of Strathclyde was founded by Kenneth MacAlpin after he defeated the Vikings. The kingdom reached its greatest extent under his son, Malcolm III, who is credited with establishing the first national parliament in Scotland in 1063. During the 12th century, Scotland became embroiled in a succession dispute between two branches of the royal family, known as the Wars of Scottish Independence. In 1296, Robert The Bruce defeated John de Balliol at the Battle of Bannockburn, thus securing Scottish independence. The following century saw extensive rebuilding work carried out by King Edward I of England following his invasion in 1303. In 1314, an English army led by Sir John de Segrave captured Edinburgh after a five-month siege. Scotland remained firmly under English control for the next 150 years. In 1469, James III became King of Scots after overthrowing his father, James II. He attempted to establish a monarchy dominated by Scots-born nobles and was opposed by the Scottish barons who formed the Council of Guardians. Ruth Pryor (1906-2001) was a Chicago ballet dancer and choreographer. She is best known for her collaborations with George Balanchine, for whom she created the roles of Allegra in the 1937 ballet Allegro and the title role in the 1954 ballet Sylvia. Ruth Pryor was born in 1906 in Chicago. She began her ballet training at the age of six at the Chicago School of Ballet. In 1925, she joined Balanchine's New York City Ballet, where she danced lead roles in many of his ballets and choreographed several works for the company. In 1937, Pryor created the role of Allegra in Balanchine's ballet Allegro. The following year, she choreographed the title role in his ballet Sylvia, which premiered at the New York State Theater. She later appeared in several productions of Sylvia throughout the United States and Europe. Pryor retired from dancing in 1961 and later taught dance at Illinois State University. She died in 2001 at the age of ninety-one.

Waldshut-Tiengen , commonly known as Waldshut, is a city in southwestern Baden-Württemberg right at the Swiss border. It is the district seat and at the same time the biggest city in Waldshut district and a "middle centre" in the area of the "high centre" Lörrach/Weil am Rhein to whose middle area most towns and communities in Waldshut district belong (with the exception of seven communities that belong to Bad Säckingen's area). There are furthermore complexities arising from cross-border traffic between this area and the Swiss cantons of Aargau, Schaffhausen and Zürich. This classification relates to Walter Christaller's Central Place Theory, however, and not to any official administrative scheme. The city, which was newly created in the framework of the 1975 municipal reform, at that time passed the 20,000 mark in population. City council then applied to have the city raised to Große Kreisstadt, which the government of Baden-Württemberg granted on 1 July 1976. Waldshut-Tiengen is also in an "administrative community" (Verwaltungsgemeinschaft) with the communities of Dogern, Lauchringen and Weilheim.

Health extension officers or health extension workers are professionals who work with communities to improve their health. They may work in government or nongovernmental organizations, and may specialize in public health, community health, or health promotion. They may work in urban areas, rural areas, or both. Health extension officers can play a vital role in helping to prevent disease and promote healthy lifestyles. They can help to identify and address community vulnerabilities, promote healthy eating habits and physical activity, provide information on health services and products, and support community-based efforts to improve health. The role of health extension officer has evolved over the years, growing in importance as the world has become increasingly complex and public-health challenges have multiplied. Today, health extension officers play an important role in the global effort to ensure that all people have access to quality healthcare and clean water, and that they can live healthy lives free from preventable diseases.

Fitzroy Ernest Wilson (18 November 1951 – 2 November 2021) was a Jamaican reggae singer who found fame as a member of the Clarendonians before working as a solo artist. Biography Wilson formed the Clarendonians in 1963 with Peter Austin, the duo going on to become one of the most popular groups of the ska and rocksteady era, and having several Jamaican number one hits. Wilson embarked on a solo career in 1967, releasing the "Money Worries" single. Further singles followed, with "Undying Love", "Storybook Children", and "If I Were a Carpenter" in 1968 (all produced by Coxsone Dodd), "Private Number" (for Joe Gibbs), and "Freedom Train" (for Lee "Scratch" Perry - one of the first Jamaican singles ever to be released in stereo) in 1969. In 1969, he got back together with sometime Clarendonian Freddie McGregor in the duo 'Ernest Wilson & Freddy', releasing the singles "Sentimental Man" and "Love Makes the World Go Round", and later "What You Gonna Do About It" and "Let Them Talk". One of Wilson's biggest international hit singles, "Let True Love Be", (1976), was done alongside Harold Butler & Four Corners. It was featured on Butler's 1978 album, "The Butler Did It". Wilson was also briefly a member of The Techniques.

His work has been nominated for several awards in the horror genre over the years. Cemetery Dance Publications recently published his Blue November Storms, a new novella, and The Illustrated Stephen King Trivia Book, which he wrote with Stephen King expert Bev Vincent. Acclaimed horror artist Glenn Chadbourne created over fifty unique illustrations for the book. He graduated from Shippensburg University in 2002 with a journalism degree. Brian Freeman lives in Pennsylvania and he is currently writing a new novel.

In financial accounting, a liability is defined as an obligation of a financial entity, such as a company, government, or individual, to pay a future financial obligation. Liabilities are measured at fair value and reported in the balance sheet. A liability may be classified according to its maturity date or the type of creditor to which it is owed. Long-term liabilities are those that will be settled in more than one year. Current liabilities are those that must be settled within one year. Short-term liabilities are those that will be settled within one month. Liabilities can also be classified according to the risk they pose to the financial entity. Financial entities may choose to classify liabilities into categories based on their level of risk. High-risk liabilities are those that pose a greater risk of not being paid, such as accounts receivable from customers who cannot or will not pay on time. Low-risk liabilities are those that pose a lower risk of not being paid, such as short-term debt. Financial entities must balance their liabilities against their assets to ensure that they have enough money available to pay all of their obligations when they fall due. If too much money is owed on the liabilities side of the ledger, the financial entity may need to borrow money from other lenders to meet its obligations. If too little money is available to cover the liabilities, the financial entity may have to sell assets or take out loans in order to raise cash.

Joanne Kyger (November 19, 1934 – March 22, 2009) was an American stage, film and television actress. Kyger was born in New York City, the daughter of Gertrude (née Kammerer) and Joseph A. Kyger, who was a theatrical agent. She attended the Professional Children's School in Manhattan. Kyger made her Broadway debut in the role of Sally in the original production of "The Music Man" in 1962. She appeared on Broadway in numerous productions over the next four decades, including "A View from the Bridge", "The Odd Couple", "Company" and "The Pirates of Penzance". Kyger also appeared in numerous films and television series throughout her career, including "The Paper Chase", "The Rockford Files", "Kojak", "Twilight Zone", "M*A*S*H", "Cheers", "Hart to Hart" and "Murder, She Wrote". Kyger died from complications from leukemia at the age of 78 in 2009.

Mehmet Aksoy (born 1939) is a Turkish-born mathematician and philosopher who has written on topics such as mathematics, logic, philosophy of mathematics, and the philosophy of science. Aksoy was born in 1939 in İstanbul, Turkey. He received his undergraduate degree in Mathematics from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1961 and his PhD in Mathematics from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1966. He has been a professor at the University of California at Berkeley since 1967, where he is now Emeritus Professor. He has also been a visiting professor at the Ecole Normale Superieure (Paris), the University of Edinburgh (UK), the University of Michigan (US), the University of Vienna (Austria), and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem (Israel). Aksoy's research has been in various areas of mathematics, including logic, set theory, functional analysis, probability theory, and statistics. He is particularly noted for his work on mathematical models of scientific theories and for his contributions to philosophical issues concerning mathematics and science. He has written numerous books and articles on these topics, including: "Foundations of Logic" (1981) "Mathematical Models of Scientific Theory" (1982) "The Logic of Conditionals" (1990) "An Introduction to Probability Theory" (1995) "Reasoning About Probability" (2000) "Philosophy of Mathematics: Second Edition" (2004)

The Thrill Hunter is a 1933 American pre-Code comedy film directed by George B. Seitz. Buck Jones stars as a habitual teller of tall tales, while Dorothy Revier plays the film star he tries to impress. Plot Braggart Buck Crosby rescues movie star Marjorie Lane when her horse bolts during location shooting. She invites him to dinner, where he regales the film crew with tall tales of his exploits. When someone notices his resemblance to a noted car racer, he takes credit for that, too. After he leaves, he is attracted to a commotion in an isolated cabin. Shots ring out, and he finds two men dead inside. They turn out to be members of the Blake gang, which just pulled off a $100,000 gold robbery. Buck finds a locket and keeps it, then claims the reward for shooting the two men. This latest exploit convinces director Ed Jackson to invite Buck to go to Hollywood and star opposite Marjorie in her next picture.

Evanès Boula is the current chief of the Sangha of Sidi Bou Said in Tunisia. He succeeded his father, Sidi Bou Said's last imam, in 2009. Evanès Boula was born on October 9, 1969 in Sidi Bou Said, Tunisia. He is the son of Sidi Bou Said's last imam, and he has been the chief of the Sangha of Sidi Bou Said since 2009. He has a degree in religious studies from Damascus University and a master's degree in Islamic Studies from the University of Tunis. Boula has worked as a teacher and Imam at several mosques throughout Tunisia, and he has also served as the secretary general of the Dar al-Ifta al-Misriyyah, a government-sponsored body that provides religious education to Muslim students. He has written several books on Islamic theology and jurisprudence, and he is currently working on a book on Hadith interpretation. Boula is a member of the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet, which was established to promote dialogue between government officials, opposition groups, and religious leaders after the Jasmine Revolution of 2011. He has also served as a member of the board of directors for several organizations, including Dar al-Ifta al-Misriyyah and the Arab Foundation for Democracy. Boula is married and has three children.

James Margetson (1600 – 26 August 1678) was an English lawyer and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1660 to 1678. Margetson was the son of Francis Margetson of Calverton, Sussex, and his wife Katherine Cookson, daughter of Nicholas Cookson of Bramber. He was educated at The King's School, Canterbury and Lincoln's Inn. He married Anne Smyth, daughter of Sir Thomas Smyth of Woodford, Essex on 25 September 1637. They had one son and two daughters. Margetson was a lawyer and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1660 to 1678. He was Commissioner for Assessment for Kent from 1661 to 1663, Commissioner for Assessment for Sussex from 1663 to 1668 and Commissioner for Trade and Plantations from 1668 to 1678. He was also Deputy Lieutenant for Sussex from 1668 to 1677 and Justice of the Peace for Sussex from 1661 to 1668. Margetson died at the age of 66.

Alfred Rewane (August 24, 1916 – October 16, 2016) was a Ghanaian educator and politician. He served as the ninth President of Ghana from 1981 to 1983. Rewane was born in 1916 in the town of Sefwi Wiawso in the Eastern Region of Ghana. He attended the Roman Catholic Mission School in the town and then proceeded to the University of Cape Town, where he earned a B.A. in 1938 and a M.A. in 1941. Rewane then returned to Ghana to teach at the Catholic Mission School in Accra, where he also served as president of the student union. In 1959, Rewane became headmaster of Legon College, a prestigious secondary school in Accra. He held this position until 1961, when he was appointed Minister of Education by President Kwame Nkrumah. Rewane served as Minister of Education until 1966, when he was appointed Minister of Finance. In 1969, Rewane was appointed Minister of Planning and Development and served in this position until 1971. In 1972, Rewane was elected to Parliament as a member of the Convention People's Party (CPP). He was subsequently re-elected to Parliament in 1974 and 1976. In 1980, Rewane was elected president of Ghana, defeating incumbent Jerry Rawlings by a narrow margin. During his time as president, Rewane oversaw rapid economic growth and increased social welfare programs. In molecular biology, the glutaredoxin 2 family is a family of bacterial glutaredoxins. Unlike other glutaredoxins, glutaredoxin 2 (Grx2) cannot reduce ribonucleotide reductase. Grx2 has significantly higher catalytic activity in the reduction of mixed disulphides with glutathione (GSH) compared with other glutaredoxins. The active site residues (Cys9-Pro10-Tyr11-Cys12, in Escherichia coli Grx2, which are found at the interface between the N- and C-terminal domains are identical to other glutaredoxins, but there is no other similarity between glutaredoxin 2 and other glutaredoxins. Grx2 is structurally similar to glutathione-S-transferases (GST), but there is no obvious sequence similarity. The inter-domain contacts are mainly hydrophobic, suggesting that the two domains are unlikely to be stable on their own. Both domains are needed for correct folding and activity of Grx2. It is thought that the primary function of Grx2 is to catalyse reversible glutathionylation of proteins with GSH in cellular redox regulation including the response to oxidative stress. These enzymes are not related to GLRX2. References

Goojje was a spoof website of Google China, which encouraged the real site to stay online and comply with Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China. The site was created after Google executives publicly threatened to shut down the Chinese site following the Operation Aurora cyber attack on Google China, which some computer security experts believe may have come from within China as in the GhostNet cyber spying operation. Google China executives had also publicly condemned the necessity of filtering search results in line with the Golden Shield Project (also known as the Great Firewall of China), which some commentators have stated appears to run counter to Google's mantra, Don't be evil. Goojje, founded on January 14, 2010 also allows searches to be run, but apparently uses Google and Baidu to do the actual searches. Google has demanded that Goojje stop using its logo, but Goojje refused until 2011.

Jacob Allen Abel (born November 18, 1987) is an American actor. He has appeared in the film adaptations of the young adult novels Percy Jackson (2010–2013), I Am Number Four (2011), and The Host (2013), along with portraying musician Mike Love in the biographical drama Love & Mercy (2014). Outside of film, he appeared in the recurring role of Adam Milligan on the CW series Supernatural (2009–2010; 2019–2020). Abel was also a series regular in the first season of the Netflix science fiction drama Another Life (2019). Life and career Abel was born in Canton, Ohio, the son of Kim and Mike Abel. He has a brother, Shaun. His first credited role was in the Disney Channel Original Movie Go Figure, playing Spencer. He later had a recurring guest role on CBS's short lived science fiction series, Threshold. He had numerous guest starring roles including Cold Case and ER. He was honored with a Rising Star award at the 16th Hamptons International Film Festival in October 2008 for his work in the film Flash of Genius. In 2009, Abel shortly appeared in the Peter Jackson film The Lovely Bones based on Alice Sebold's novel. He also had a regular role in the web series Angel of Death which ran for 10 episodes.

Rainer O. Neugebauer (born January 16, 1954) is an Austrian physicist and mathematician who works in the field of mathematical physics. He is a professor at the University of Vienna. Neugebauer was born in Vienna, Austria, on January 16, 1954. He received his doctorate in 1976 from the University of Vienna under the supervision of Gerhard Frey. From 1976 to 1978, he was a postdoctoral researcher at the universities of Chicago and Göttingen. From 1978 to 1983 he was an assistant professor at the University of Vienna, where he became a full professor in 1986. In 1983, Neugebauer moved to the University of California, Santa Barbara, where he became a Distinguished Professor in 1992. In 1993, he moved again to the University of Vienna as a professor of mathematics. He became a distinguished scientist at the Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in Bonn in 2002. Neugebauer's research focuses on mathematical physics, especially statistical mechanics and partial differential equations. He has made significant contributions to many fields of physics, including quantum field theory, statistical mechanics, fluid dynamics, and elasticity theory. Neugebauer is a member of the Austrian Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was awarded the Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Prize in 2006 and the Wolf Foundation Prize in Mathematics in 2013.

He completed his duties and was discharged in August 2021. He held two concerts entitled Ontact Concert: Arbor Day On shortly after his return, where he announced his forthcoming project. Regretting some of his music from previous works, Nam crafted an R&B and pop mini-album. Following a series of photo and video teasers, With and the lead single "Calm & Passion" were simultaneously released. Nam promoted the song by performing it on music chart programs across various television networks. The mini-album peaked at number eleven on South Korea's national Gaon Album Chart and has sold over 25,000 copies since its release.

Vaguely Noble (1965–1989) was an Irish-bred Thoroughbred racehorse who competed in the United Kingdom and France. The colt is best known as the winner of the 1968 Group one (G1) Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe when he defeated the best horses from England, France, Ireland and Italy. He was later a leading sire in Great Britain & Ireland and a Leading broodmare sire in GB & Ireland. Background Major Lionel B. Holliday bred Vaguely Noble who was foaled in 1965. Vaguely Noble was by Vienna (GB) who won six races and £27,970 before he was exported to France and then to Japan. His dam was the Lancashire Oaks winner, Noble Lassie (GB) was by Nearco (ITY) from Belle Sauvage by Big Game. Noble Lassie was the dam of several other horses, but Vaguely Noble was her only graded stakes winner. Vaguely Noble was inbred to Hyperion in the third and fourth generation (3m x 4f) and also to Bahram in the fourth generation (4m x 4f).

The semiconductor luminescence equations (SLEs) describe luminescence of semiconductors resulting from spontaneous recombination of electronic excitations, producing a flux of spontaneously emitted light. This description established the first step toward semiconductor quantum optics because the SLEs simultaneously includes the quantized light–matter interaction and the Coulomb-interaction coupling among electronic excitations within a semiconductor. The SLEs are one of the most accurate methods to describe light emission in semiconductors and they are suited for a systematic modeling of semiconductor emission ranging from excitonic luminescence to lasers. Due to randomness of the vacuum-field fluctuations, semiconductor luminescence is incoherent whereas the extensions of the SLEs include the possibility to study resonance fluorescence resulting from optical pumping with coherent laser light. At this level, one is often interested to control and access higher-order photon-correlation effects, distinct many-body states, as well as light–semiconductor entanglement. Such investigations are the basis of realizing and developing the field of quantum-optical spectroscopy which is a branch of quantum optics.

James Wesley Jobling (1876–1961) was an American historian and archaeologist. He was a professor of history at the University of Oklahoma from 1914 until his retirement in 1948. Jobling was born on October 18, 1876, in Van Wert, Ohio. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan in 1898 and his master's degree from the University of Chicago in 1899. Jobling then went to the University of Oklahoma, where he received his doctorate in 1903. Jobling began his career as a professor of history at the University of Oklahoma in 1914. He retired from teaching in 1948, but continued to work as an archaeologist until his death on October 29, 1961. Jobling is best known for his work as an historian and archaeologist. He wrote several books about American history and archaeology, including The American Indian Frontier (1930), The Osage Land (1935), and The Cherokee Nation (1938). He also edited two volumes of the Chronicles of Oklahoma series, Frontier Settlement in Oklahoma (1941) and Indian Life on the Oklahoma Frontier (1946). Jobling was also active in promoting historical education. He served as president of the American Historical Association from 1938 to 1939 and as president of the Southern Historical Association from 1942 to 1943. In 1945, he was elected to the National Academy of Sciences.

Adam Woodward (born 1992) is a British-American actor and singer. The Grand Prior's Award, also called the Prior's Cross, is an accolade conferred by the Sovereign of the Order of Malta on a Catholic cleric for outstanding service to the order. It is the highest honour that can be bestowed on a churchman by the Order, and is second only to the Grand Cross. The award is presented at the discretion of the Sovereign, on the recommendation of the Prior General. The recipient must be a clergyman in good standing with the Catholic Church, have made significant contributions to the order, and be deserving of esteem and respect from its members. The award is not given for services rendered to Malta alone, but also to the Catholic Church as a whole. The Grand Prior's Award was first instituted in 1787 by Grand Master Jean-André de La Valette to commemorate the life of Bishop Joseph Acciajuoli, who had died in combat during the War of Polish Succession. The first recipient was Bishop Antonio di Pietro Cibo. Since its inception, only five clerics have been awarded the Grand Prior's Award: Bishop Giuseppe Palumbo in 1892, Bishop Salvatore Graziosi in 1925, Bishop Lawrence Sullivan in 1948, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre in 1988, and Cardinal Raymond Burke in 2003.

Joseph T. Mohen (born July 19, 1956) is an American composer, sound artist, and music educator. Mohen was born in Pomona, California and raised in the San Francisco Bay Area. He studied composition with Pauline Oliveros at Mills College and with Elliott Carter at Yale University. He has also worked with other leading composers of the post-minimalist era, including Philip Glass, Terry Riley, and John Cage. Mohen's music is often described as "acousmatic" or "process music." His works often explore the relationship between sound and structure, using a variety of sonic techniques to create unique sonic experiences. He has been commissioned by numerous organizations, including the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Mohen is currently the Richard P. Feynman Professor of Music at Caltech.

Sir Howard Morley Robertson MC RA (16 November 1891 – 4 January 1967) was a Scottish architect. He is particularly noted for his work in the 1930s and 1940s in collaboration with his wife, Elizabeth Macmillan Robertson. Howard Morley Robertson was born on 16 November 1891 in Stirling, Scotland. He studied architecture at the Glasgow School of Art from 1912 to 1914, and then attended the Royal College of Art in London, where he received his diploma in 1916. Robertson began his professional career as an assistant to the architectural firm of Scott & Moffat. In 1920, he formed his own firm, Howard Robertson & Partners, and began working on a wide range of projects, including schools and churches. In the 1930s and 1940s, he and his wife Elizabeth Macmillan Robertson collaborated on a series of notable projects, including the Glasgow School of Art (1933), Aberdeen University (1937), and the University of Edinburgh (1939). Robertson retired from active practice in 1951, but continued to work on a limited basis until his death in 1967. He was knighted in 1944.

The Busan Gudeok Stadium (; Hanja: 釜山九德運動場) is a multi-purpose stadium in Busan, South Korea. It is currently used mostly for football matches. The stadium currently holds 12,349 spectators. The venue opened in September 1928. During the 1988 Summer Olympics, it hosted some of the Olympic football matches. It was also the main venue for the 1997 East Asian Games hosting the opening and closing ceremonies, as well as the athletics and football competitions. Professional football team Busan IPark have played their home games at the venue since 2015 as well as between 1987 and 2002. Additionally, non-league football team Busan Transport Corporation FC have played their home games at the venue since 2006. 1988 Summer Olympics During the 1988 Summer Olympics, held in Seoul, eight football games took place at the Gudeok stadium, including all three of South Korea's matches and one semi-final match. 180 players accompanied by 72 officials from nine countries competed for eleven days from September 17 through September 27, attracting a total of 146,320 spectators or 18,290 on average per day. A total of 675 million won was spent on the stadium before the tournament to improve the electronic scoreboard and other facilities.

Frederick Arthur Newton (16 September 1890 – 8 August 1924) was an English cricketer who played first-class cricket for Derbyshire between 1909 and 1919. Newton was born at Denaby Main, Yorkshire. He was an all-round sportsman and twice played as goalkeeper for Chesterfield F.C. in 1905/6 and 1906/7, and later played football for Whitwell St Lawrence. He made his cricket debut for Derbyshire in the 1909 season in July against Northamptonshire when he made 30 in his first innings. He only played one more match that season. In the 1910 season he played a dozen matches. Against Warwickshire he achieved his best first-class score of 87 in the first innings. In the second innings of this match Arnold Warren and John Chapman achieved a record 9th wicket stand. Newton played two games in the 1911 season, three in the 1912 season and a final game in the 1919 season.

Queen Hyosun (효순왕후 조씨; 8 January 1716 – 26 November 1792), also known as Empress Hyosun, was the last ruler of the Korean Joseon Dynasty. Born in 1716, Hyosun was the eldest daughter of King Yeongjo and Queen Injo. Yeongjo died when she was just six years old, and she was raised by her mother. In 1736, Injo was overthrown by her brother, King Sunjo. Hyosun and her mother were then imprisoned at Gyeongbokgung Palace. In 1751, after Sunjo's death, Hyosun and her mother were released from prison and made regents for Sunjo's young son, Crown Prince Sado. In 1752, Sado succeeded to the throne as King Yeongjo. Hyosun became Regent Dowager Queen in 1755 and Empress in 1760. She reigned until 1792, when she died at the age of 78. Hyosun was a skilled administrator and managed to keep the dynasty afloat during difficult times. She played an important role in reunifying the country after its separation into North and South in 1871. She is also credited with helping to promote traditional Korean values such as Confucianism and Buddhism during her reign.

A Wedding Invitation (分手合约 fēnshǒu héyuē, literal meaning: "Breaking the Agreement") is a formal document issued by one party to another, typically with the intention of arranging a marriage. A Wedding Invitation typically takes the form of a card, but may also be in the form of an email. The invitation may be sent to the prospective spouse's home address or work address, or alternatively it may be delivered in person. If sent electronically, it may be sent as an attachment or embedded in an email message. When received, the recipient will typically check for any errors and make any necessary changes before forwarding it on to their future bride or groom. The Wedding Invitation is generally delivered on or around the wedding day itself. If it is being sent electronically, it may be sent as early as possible in order to avoid any potential delays.

John Frederick Frelinghuysen (March 21, 1776 – January 8, 1873) was an American politician who served in the United States House of Representatives from 1815 to 1821 and in the United States Senate from 1821 to 1833. He was the son of New Netherland Governor Frederick Frelinghuysen and brother of New York Governor DeWitt Clinton. Frelinghuysen was born in Rensselaerville, New York on March 21, 1776. He attended the common schools and graduated from Yale College in 1798. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1800. He commenced practice in Poughkeepsie, New York and served as the city solicitor from 1801 to 1804. Frelinghuysen was elected as a Federalist to the Eighteenth Congress and served from March 4, 1815, until his resignation on October 27, 1821. He was re-elected as a Republican to the Nineteenth and Twentieth Congresses and served from March 4, 1823, until his resignation on January 8, 1833. Frelinghuysen was appointed by President Andrew Jackson as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York in 1830. He served until his resignation in 1833. He was elected as a Democrat to the Twenty-third Congress (March 4, 1837 – March 3, 1840). He served as chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs (Twenty-third Congress). Frelinghuysen was again

Bruno Donizati Sartori (Iturama, May 16, 1989), also known as Bruxo dos Vídeos (Wizard of Videos), is a Brazilian journalist, comedian and influencer marketing considered one of the pioneers in creating satires through the deepfake technique in Brazil. Sartori has gained notoriety with videos that satirize public entities such as Jair Bolsonaro, Sergio Moro, and Lula. History Bruno Sartori was born in Iturama, in the state of Minas Gerais, on May 16, 1989. At the age of four, he moved to the city of Unaí, where he spent his childhood. In this same city, he started working as a videomaker at the age of 15 with the production of humoristic content such as parodies and materials focused on the city's politics. After finishing high school in Unaí, at the age of 19, he moved to São José do Rio Preto in search of higher education, where he has an incomplete degree in Journalism and Law.

The Oriental Bank Corporation , or "OBC", was a British imperial bank founded in India in 1842 which grew to be prominent throughout the Far East. As an Exchange bank, the OBC was primarily concerned with the finance of trade and exchanges of different currencies. It was the first bank in Hong Kong and the first bank to issue banknotes in Hong Kong. History The bank was established in 1842 in Bombay, India, as the Bank of Western India. The bank moved its headquarters from Bombay to London in 1845, and opened branches in Colombo (1843), Calcutta (1844), Shanghai (1845), Canton (1845), Singapore (1846), and Hong Kong (1846). The Bank acquired the failing Bank of Ceylon in 1850, and obtained a royal charter for the merged institution under the name Oriental Bank Corporation in 1851. It was chartered in 1851 to allow competition with the East India Company's opium billing monopoly, which was unpopular in England at the time.

Maranhão is a state in Brazil. Its capital and largest city is São Luís. The state has an area of 5,589,000 square kilometers and a population of 2,880,000 in 2010. The state is located in the northeastern region of the country, bordering Pernambuco to the north, Bahia to the east, Pará to the south and Rio Grande do Norte to the west. The state is crossed by the São Francisco River. The name Maranhão comes from an Tupi-Arawakan word meaning "large water". The Portuguese first encountered the region in 1532 when they landed on the coast of what is now Pernambuco. They named the area "Malauana" after Captain Malauana, one of their captains. In 1536, King Manuel I of Portugal created the captaincy of Maranhão with its capital at São Luís de Maranhão. In 1821, Maranhão became a province of Brazil with São Luís as its capital. In 1890, it became a state of Brazil with São Luís as its capital.

Bakersfield is a city in Kern County, California, United States. The population was 116,742 at the 2010 census. It is the most populous city in the Bakersfield–Delano Metropolitan Statistical Area, which has a population of 328,844. The city is also the most populous city in the Central Valley. Bakersfield was founded by William B. Kern on April 4, 1887 as a stop on the Southern Pacific Railroad between Los Angeles and San Francisco. Kern named the town after his hometown of Baker'sfield, England. The city grew rapidly as a fruit-packing center and oil production center during the early 20th century. It was also the home of California State University, Bakersfield from 1902 to 1972. However, after CSUB became California State University, East Bay in 1972, Bakersfield's economy went into decline. Since the 1990s, revitalization efforts have helped to bring about a turnaround in the city's fortunes. Today, Bakersfield is a thriving metropolitan area with a diverse economy and a number of well-known institutions, including: California State University, Bakersfield; Anderson School of Engineering at Cal Poly Pomona; and Southern Methodist University. The city is also home to several wineries and breweries. Bakersfield is located at 33°8′N 118°21′W (33.12333°N 118.36667°W). Kenrick Reginald Hijmans Johnson (10 September 1914 – 8 March 1941), known as Ken "Snakehips" Johnson, was a swing band leader and dancer. He was a leading figure in black British music of the 1930s and early 1940s before his death while performing at the Café de Paris, London, in the Blitz during the Second World War. Johnson was born in Georgetown, British Guiana (present-day Guyana). He showed some musical ability, but his attraction to dancing was opposed by his father, who wished him to have a career in medicine. He was schooled in Britain, but instead of continuing on to university, he travelled to New York, perfecting dance moves and immersing himself in the vibrant jazz scene in Harlem. He returned and set up the West Indian Dance Orchestra, a nearly all-black swing band, with Leslie Thompson, a Jamaican musician. In 1937 he legally took over the band, causing Thompson and several musicians to leave. He filled the vacancies with musicians from the Caribbean, and the band's popularity grew.

Edmund Pendleton (September 9, 1721 – October 30, 1781) was an American lawyer, planter, and statesman from the colony of Virginia. He served in the Continental Congress and as U.S. Representative, Attorney General, and Minister to France. Edmund Pendleton was born in Williamsburg, Virginia on September 9, 1721 to Edmund Pendleton Sr. and his wife Elizabeth (née Harrison). The Pendletons were a prominent colonial family with ties to both England and the Virginia Colony. Edmund Sr. had arrived in Virginia as an indentured servant in 1650 and had become a prosperous planter by the time of his son's birth. Edmund Jr. was educated at William & Mary College in Williamsburg, where he became a member of Phi Beta Kappa in 1744. Edmund Pendleton began his legal career as a clerk for George Wythe and later served as Wythe's law partner. He became one of the most respected lawyers in colonial Virginia and was appointed Attorney General of the colony in 1772. In 1774, he was elected to the Continental Congress, where he played a leading role in securing ratification of the United States Constitution. He also served as U.S. Representative, Attorney General, and Minister to France during the latter years of the American Revolution. Edmund Pendleton died on October 30, 1781 in Richmond, Virginia at the age of 66. He was buried in Shockoe Hill Cemetery there. Edmund Pendleton was inducted into the National

Rachel Moy Quon (born May 21, 1991) is an American-Canadian former soccer defender. She played for the Chicago Red Stars in the National Women's Soccer League and for the Canada women's national soccer team. Early life Quon was born in Los Angeles, California, to a Canadian father and an American mother. She grew up in Lake Forest, Illinois, and attended Lake Forest High School. As a freshman in 2006, she was named All-Section and All-Conference. During her second year, she provided the most assists on her team and was voted All-State and All-Conference, and was named NSCAA All-American. She did not play high school soccer during her junior year, but scored 25 goals with 21 assists during her first two seasons. In 2009, she scored 15 goals and had 10 assists to lead the Scouts to a 2009 regional title and into the Class 3A sectionals. She was named the 2009 National Gatorade High School Player of the Year as well as Illinois State Player of the Year. She was also named to the 2009 Parade Magazine and ESPN Rise All-America teams. She left Lake Forest High School with 40 goals and 31 assists over just three high school seasons.

Kim Hak-sun (1924–1997) was a Korean human rights activist who campaigned against sex slavery and wartime sexual violence. Ms. Kim was one of the victims who had been forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese Imperial Army between the early 1930s up until the end of the Pacific War. She is the first woman in Korea to come forward publicly and testify her experience as a comfort woman for the Japanese military. Her testimony was made on 14 August 1991. In December 1991, she filed a class-action lawsuit against the Japanese government for the damages inflicted during the war. She was the first of what would become hundreds of women from Korea, China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Indonesia, and the Netherlands who came forward to tell their stories of their enslavement to the Imperial Japanese military. She was inspired to finally take her story public after 40 years of silence by the growth of the women's rights movement in South Korea. Kim died in 1997 and her court case was still ongoing. Mark John Banker (born January 15, 1956) is an American film and television producer and director. He is the co-founder and CEO of the production company Mark Banker Productions. Banker was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, the son of Margaret (née Morris) and John Banker, a heating and air conditioning contractor. He grew up in West Chester, Pennsylvania, graduating from West Chester Area High School in 1974. He attended Temple University in Philadelphia, where he studied film and television. After graduating from Temple in 1978, Banker worked as a production assistant on the television series "Hill Street Blues". He then moved to Los Angeles to work as a production assistant on the television series "Kojak". In 1982, Banker co-founded Mark Banker Productions with his then-wife Claudia Black. The company has produced a number of films, including "The Crow" (1994), "The Craft" (1996), "Sin City" (2005), "Watchmen" (2009), and "Annabelle" (2014). He has also directed episodes of several of his productions, including "Sin City", "The Crow", "Watchmen", and "Annabelle". Banker has been married to actress Claudia Black since 1982. They have two children: John Banker and India Rose Banker.

Judicial murder is the intentional and premeditated killing of an innocent person by means of capital punishment; therefore, it is a subset of wrongful execution. The Oxford English Dictionary describes it as "death inflicted by process of law, capital punishment, esp. considered to be unjust or cruel". Example An early case in which charges of judicial murder were raised was the Amboyna massacre in 1623, which caused a legal dispute between the English and Dutch governments over the conduct of a court in the Dutch East Indies that had ordered the execution of ten English men accused of treason. The dispute centered around differing interpretations of the legal jurisdiction of the court in question. The English believed that this court had not been competent to try and execute these EIC members, and so believed the executions to have been fundamentally illegal, thus constituting "judicial murder". The Dutch, on the other hand, believed the court to have been fundamentally competent, and wished to focus instead on misconduct of the particular judges in the court.

Arthur Edward Ochse (11 March 1870 – 10 January 1949) was an American historian, archaeologist and epigrapher who specialized in the study of inscriptions. Born in New York City, Ochse received his early education at the Friends' School there and then attended Columbia University, where he received a B.A. in 1894 and an M.A. in 1896. He then studied at the University of Berlin, where he earned his doctorate in 1901 with a thesis on ancient Egyptian inscriptions. He returned to the United States and taught at Colgate University from 1902 to 1904, before joining the faculty of Princeton University as a professor of ancient languages and civilizations in 1904. Ochse left Princeton in 1937 to become the first director of the Institute of Fine Arts at Boston University, a position he held until his retirement in 1946. In addition to his work as a historian and epigrapher, Ochse was also an expert on ancient Egyptian art and architecture. He was awarded the Légion d'honneur by France in 1944. Ochse died at Boston University in 1949.

Simon John Wolstencroft (born 19 January 1963) is a British singer and songwriter. He is the frontman of the rock band The Wolstencroft Band, which he founded in 1984. Wolstencroft has been awarded two BRIT Awards, four Ivor Novello Awards, and an Ivor Novello Award for Outstanding Songwriter. He has also been nominated for a Grammy Award and a Golden Globe Award. In 2009, he was made an Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE), for services to music. Wolstencroft was born in Kingston upon Hull, East Yorkshire, England, to John Wolstencroft (born 1930), a radiographer and nurse, and Patricia Wolstencroft (née Waddington; 1934–2017), a secretary. He was raised in nearby Goole. Wolstencroft first played the guitar at the age of 12, after being given one by his father. After leaving secondary school with no qualifications in 1983, Wolstencroft worked as a labourer and bus conductor before forming The Wolstencroft Band with school friend Andy McCluskey in 1984. Wolstencroft's first single, "The Lady Don't Rock 'N' Roll", was released in 1985 on Yorkshire's independent record label Emperor Jones Records. The song became a regional hit and led to appearances on BBC2's "Saturday Night Live" (

Amelia Jones (born July 14, 1961) originally from Durham, North Carolina is an American art historian, art theorist, art critic, author, professor and curator. Her research specialisms include feminist art, body art, performance art, video art, identity politics, and New York Dada. Jones's earliest work established her as a feminist scholar and curator, including through a pioneering exhibition and publication concerning the art of Judy Chicago; later, she broadened her focus on other social activist topics including race, class and identity politics. Jones has contributed significantly to the study of art and performance as a teacher, researcher and activist. Education and personal life She is the daughter of Virginia Sweetnam Jones and Edward E. Jones, a Princeton Psychology professor. She studied art history as an undergraduate at Harvard University and completed her M.A. at the University of Pennsylvania. She received her Ph.D. from UCLA in 1991. Her dissertation was later turned into a published book, Postmodernism and the Engendering of Marcel Duchamp (1994). On March 7, 1987, Jones married Anthony Sherin, a film editor. They divorced in 2005. In 2007, Jones married artist Paul Donald. She has two children, Evan and Vita, from her first marriage. Jones currently resides in Los Angeles, California.

Michigan Boy Boat is the third commercial vessel built in the United States. She was designed and built in Muskegon, Michigan by Steve Kapp and his father, Bob Kapp in 2004. The Michigan Boy Boat is a fiberglass sloop with a fiberglass mast and boom, a wooden hull, and an aluminum superstructure. She has a maximum cabin size of twelve passengers and can carry up to sixty-five passengers in her main salon, twenty-four in her forward cabin, and six in her aft cabin. She also has a headroom of four feet nine inches and a draft of three feet three inches. The Michigan Boy Boat was designed to be as comfortable as possible for her passengers. She has six air conditioning units, four toilets, and four showers. Her kitchen has a refrigerator, stove, oven, microwave oven, sink, and countertop. She also has a coffee maker, teapot, cups, plates, and silverware. There is also a dinette table that can seat six people. The Michigan Boy Boat is powered by two gasoline engines that produce eight horsepower each. She can reach speeds of fifteen knots (26 miles per hour) and has a range of seventy-two miles. The boat is registered with the United States Coast Guard and is licensed to carry passengers on Lake Michigan.

The Bliss bibliographic classification (BC) is a library classification system that was created by Henry E. Bliss (1870–1955) and published in four volumes between 1940 and 1953. Although originally devised in the United States, it was more commonly adopted by British libraries. A second edition of the system (BC2) has been in ongoing development in Britain since 1977. Origins of the system Henry E. Bliss began working on the Bliss Classification system while working at the City College of New York Library as Assistant Librarian. He was a critic of Melvil Dewey's work with the Dewey Decimal System and believed that organization of titles needed to be done with an intellectual mind frame. Being overly pragmatic or simply alphabetical, would be inadequate. In fact, Bliss is the only theorist who created an organizational scheme based on societal needs. Bliss wanted a classification system that would provide distinct rules yet still be adaptable to whatever kind of collection a library might have, as different libraries have different needs. His solution was the concept of "alternative location," in which a particular subject could be put in more than one place, as long as the library made a specific choice and used it consistently.

Richard le Scrope (c. 1350 – 8 June 1409) was an English bishop and academic. He was the son of Sir Hugh le Scrope of Bolton, and educated at Oxford University, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in 1377 and a Master of Arts (M.A.) in 1381. He became a Fellow of Oriel College, Oxford, in 1382, and resigned his fellowship in 1410. Scrope became Bishop of Durham in 1404, a post he held until his death in 1409. During his time as bishop, he reformed the diocese and improved the education of the clergy. He also restored churches and monasteries, and promoted industry and trade. He was also responsible for founding Durham Cathedral. Scrope was a prolific writer, and wrote both theological works and chronicles. Among his theological works are a treatise on the sacraments titled "De sacramentis" (1404), a work on penance titled "De penitencia" (1405), and a commentary on the Bible titled "Commentaria in Pentateuchum" (1407). His chronicles include a history of England from the time of Edward III to the death of Henry V (1399–1422), a history of Scotland from 1296 to 1402, and a history of Wales from 1282 to 1400. Scrope married Alice Neville, daughter of Ralph Neville, 1st Earl of Westmorland

Earl "Yogi" Strom (December 15, 1927 – January 10, 2002) was an American professional baseball player and manager. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Chicago White Sox from 1951 to 1955 and for the Baltimore Orioles from 1956 to 1958. He served as the manager of the Orioles from 1979 to 1982. Strom attended Oral Roberts University and played college baseball for the Golden Eagles. He was drafted by the White Sox in the second round of the 1950 amateur draft. Strom made his MLB debut with the White Sox in 1951 and played for them until 1955. After a season with the Orioles, he returned to Chicago, where he helped lead the team to a third-place finish in the American League (AL) in 1958. The following year, Strom was traded to the Detroit Tigers, where he played until his retirement in 1959. In his only season as manager of the Orioles, Strom led them to a fourth-place finish in the AL. Strom became a coach with the Tigers in 1960 and spent six seasons there before being named manager of the Cubs in 1974. He led them to three consecutive NL Central titles and two appearances in the World Series (WSO), but was fired after finishing fourth in 1976. He spent two seasons as manager of the Pirates before retiring from coaching at the end of 1978 season. After his playing career ended, Strom became a color commentator on MLB television broadcasts and served as a scout for several teams before retiring in 1992. He died at age

Rong Desheng (榮德生; 4 August 1875 – 10 November 1949) was a Chinese military general who served as the Commander of the Chinese Expeditionary Force during the Second Sino-Japanese War, and then as the Commander-in-Chief of the National Revolutionary Army. He also served as the President of the Republic of China from 1928 to 1937. Rong Desheng was born in 1875 in Wuhan, Hubei province. He joined the Beiyang Army in 1898 and participated in the Boxer Rebellion. He became a captain in 1901 and fought in the First Sino-Japanese War, where he was promoted to major general in 1911. In 1916, he fought against Sun Yat-sen's forces and was appointed Commander of the Fourth Military Region. In 1924, he was transferred to Beijing and became commander of the Beijing Military District. In 1928, he was elected president of the Republic of China under the Nationalist Party's banner. Rong resigned from his post in 1937 to become Chairman of the Central Military Commission, a position he held until his death in 1949.

Hildegard of Bingen , also known as Saint Hildegard of Bingen, was a German Benedictine abbess and philosopher. She is considered one of the most influential figures in the history of western monasticism and the development of medieval theology. Born around 1098 in Bingen, Hildegard was the youngest daughter of a wealthy noble family. After completing her education at a local convent, she became an abbess in 1139 at the age of only 30 years old. Over the next 25 years she built up a substantial community of women who followed her vision for a contemplative, religious life. In 1179, at the age of 68 years, Hildegard retired to a small hermitage near Rupertsberg. There she wrote some of her most important works, including On the Divine Love and On the Harmony of Divine Things. She died in 1214 at the age of 86. Hildegard is considered one of the most important philosophers and theologians in history. Her work has had a significant impact on both Eastern and Western philosophy, and she has been credited with introducing to Europe concepts such as monasticism, divine love, and the concept of ars spiritualis (the spiritual art).

Norwood Russell Hanson (August 17, 1924 – April 18, 1967) was an American philosopher of science. Hanson was a pioneer in advancing the argument that observation is theory-laden — that observation language and theory language are deeply interwoven — and that historical and contemporary comprehension are similarly deeply interwoven. His single most central intellectual concern was the comprehension and development of a logic of discovery. Work Hanson's best-known work is Patterns of Discovery (1958), in which he argues that what we see and perceive is not what our senses receive, but is instead filtered sensory information, where the filter is our existing preconceptions – a concept later called a 'thematic framework.' He cited optical illusions such as the famous old Parisienne woman (Patterns of Discovery, p. 11), which can be seen in different ways. Hanson drew a distinction between 'seeing as' and 'seeing that' which became a key idea in evolving theories of perception and meaning. He wanted to formulate a logic explaining how scientific discoveries take place. He used Charles Sanders Peirce's notion of abduction for this.

Haitian Vodou is an African diasporic religion that developed in Haiti between the 16th and 19th centuries. It arose through a process of syncretism between several traditional religions of West and Central Africa and the Roman Catholic form of Christianity. There is no central authority in control of the religion and much diversity exists among practitioners, who are known as Vodouists, Vodouisants, or Serviteurs. Vodou revolves around spirits known as lwa. Typically deriving their names and attributes from traditional West and Central African divinities, they are equated with Roman Catholic saints. The lwa divide up into different groups, the nanchon ("nations"), most notably the Rada and the Petwo. Various myths and stories are told about these lwa, which are regarded as subservient to a transcendent creator deity, Bondye. This theology has been labelled both monotheistic and polytheistic. An initiatory tradition, Vodouists usually meet to venerate the lwa in an ounfò (temple), run by an oungan (priest) or manbo (priestess). A central ritual involves practitioners drumming, singing, and dancing to encourage a lwa to possess one of their members and thus communicate with them. Offerings to the lwa include fruit, liquor, and sacrificed animals. Offerings are also given to the spirits of the dead. Several forms of divination are utilized to decipher messages from the lwa. Healing rituals and the preparation of herbal remedies and talismans also play a prominent role.

Airline passengers left behind almost $ 675,000 in spare change in 2013 . TSA can keep the money to spend on improving civil aviation security . The figure is $ 107,00 more than 2012 and double that collected in 2008 .

The Tanbark Trail is an hiking trail in Allegheny National Forest in northwestern Pennsylvania, which is usually described as a spur of the North Country Trail. It is known for visiting some of the least disturbed areas of the national forest, as well as several large rock formations and scenic glens along small streams. Route At its southern end, the Tanbark Trail departs from the North Country Trail near that trail's crossing of Forest Road 116 in southern Warren County. Trending to the northwest, the Tanbark Trail skirts Hearts Content Scenic Area and can be accessed from that attraction's parking lot. The trail then skirts an edge of the Hickory Creek Wilderness, after which the hiking is mostly level across a high plateau area. At about five miles the trail enters the territory of Allegheny National Recreation Area. At about seven miles, the trail begins a lengthy and occasionally steep descent into the valley formed by the Allegheny River, and ends across from a small parking lot on U.S. Route 62, within sight of the river and about 7.2 miles south of that road's junction with U.S. Route 6.
