is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Hiroaki Samura. It was originally serialized in Kodansha's Weekly Shōnen Magazine from May 2004 to October 2006, with a total of twenty-seven volumes. A movie adaptation of the series was released in Japan on February 9, 2009. The story follows Norio Moteki, a high school student who frequently finds himself in trouble with the law. One day, he is approached by a man named Jubei who offers him a job as a bodyguard. Norio is initially sceptical, but decides to take the job after hearing that it pays well. As Norio begins working for Jubei, he soon discovers that his client is a crime lord named Yagyu Saiki. Norio also becomes involved in a conflict between Jubei and Saiki, and must choose between protecting his friend and upholding justice. "Moteki" has been praised for its complicated plot and characters, and has been compared to Samura's other work such as "Blade". The manga has also been noted for its artstyle, which has been compared to the work of Hayao Miyazaki.

Marc Verica (born March 26, 1988) is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent. He was signed by the Washington Redskins as an undrafted free agent in 2011, out of the University of Virginia. He signed to play for the Cougars de Saint-Ouen l'Aumône, France for the 2012 season. Early years Marc Verica attended Monsignor Bonner High School in Drexel Hill, a suburb of Philadelphia. As a senior, he completed 81 of 160 passes for 899 yards and three touchdowns in nine games; he missed two games due to an injury and his team lost both. As a junior, he completed 112 passes in 222 attempts for 1,545 yards and eight touchdowns. Verica was named to league, county, and city all-star teams as a junior. His position coach in high school previously had coached former Cavalier quarterback Matt Schaub. In addition to Virginia, Verica was offered a scholarship by Wisconsin.

Although elements of fashion design copyright may be traced in Europe to as early as the 15th century, as of 2016 most countries (including the United States and the United Kingdom) fashion design does not have the same protection as other creative works (art, film, literature, etc.), because apparel (clothes, shoes, handbags, etc.) are classified as "functional items", excluded from protection by copyright laws. This explains the success of the knockoff businesses to the detriment of both the established labels, as well as of emerging designers, the latter ones being especially damaged, because they rely on relatively few designs. History French king Francis I gave out specific privileges related to the production of textiles. By 1711, in Lyon, illegalities were already being defined in regards to fashion materials, and in 1787, in England and Scotland fashion designers had fruitfully pushed their needs for protection into basic legislation. In 1876 Germany began protecting fashion patterns as well as models, and in 2002 European regulation on designs that were new and provided an aspect of fresh character or aesthetic were brought under protection. From 2004 to 2006 the "total production volume for clothing decreased by about 5% each year... [and by] 2006 the European union trade deficit for clothing was at 33.7 billion." These statistics show that while there are benefits of their advanced design legislation, the economic and external factors still hindered their industry growth in ways the U.S. can empathize with. As 2007 came to a close, WIPO, or the World Intellectual Property Organization, had registered twenty-nine international designs.

Recreo began as a small Hispanic homesteading community on the outskirts of Los Angeles in 1937. The small rancho was founded by José and Carmen González, who were among the first families to settle in the area.   In 1962, Recreo became a city and soon became a popular weekend getaway for residents of Los Angeles. The González family played a major role in the community's development, and José González was instrumental in establishing Recreo as a popular tourist destination. Today, Recreo is a thriving city with a population of over 10,000 people. Recreo is located in southeastern Los Angeles County on the eastern slopes of the San Gabriel Mountains. The city is bordered by Alhambra to the south, Pasadena to the northwest, La Cañada Flintridge to the north, and Rosemead to the east. The city is served by the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority (Metro).

(, literally "East settling") is the term for the High Medieval migration period of ethnic Germans into and beyond the territories at the eastern periphery of the Holy Roman Empire and the consequences for settlement development and social structures in the immigration areas. Generally sparsely and only recently populated by Slavic, Baltic and Finnic peoples, the area of colonization, also known as , encompassed (with relation to modern-day countries) Germany east of the Saale and Elbe rivers, the states of Lower Austria and Styria in Austria, the Baltics, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Hungary, and Transylvania in Romania. Historians have, since the 1980s, interpreted the to be a part of civil and social progress, called the High Middle Age Land Consolidation . In a pan-European intensification process from the Carolingian-Anglo-Saxon core countries to the periphery of the continent, societies progressed in culture, religion, law and administration, trade and agriculture.

Mohini Mohun Chatterji (1858 - 1936) was an Indian scholar and writer who contributed significantly to Hindi literature. She is best known for her novel Meghdoot (The Grasshopper), which tells the story of an Indian family during the British Raj. Mohini Mohun Chatterji was born in 1858 in Saharanpur, Uttar Pradesh, into a Brahmin family. She received her early education at home and then attended a convent school in Lucknow. She then studied at the Sorbonne and the University of Heidelberg, where she earned a degree in literature. Chatterji returned to India in 1883 and began working as a teacher. She later became the secretary to the governor of the United Provinces (now Uttar Pradesh). In 1909, she published her first book, a collection of poetry titled Ek Din Aan. Chatterji's novel Meghdoot was published in 1913 and quickly became a popular work. The novel tells the story of an Indian family during the British Raj and is considered to be one of Chatterji's finest works. Chatterji died in 1936 and was buried in Lucknow.

Aziz Çami (1893 – 15 December 1943) was a Turkish poet, writer, and politician. Born in 1893 in the town of Niğde, Aziz Çami studied at the local school before completing his education in Istanbul. He worked as a teacher before becoming a journalist and publishing his first book of poetry in 1926. He served as the editor-in-chief of the newspaper "Cumhuriyet" from 1934 until his death in 1943. Çami is best known for his poetry, which explores the themes of love, life, and nature. His work has been praised for its lyrical quality and its ability to communicate complex ideas in simple terms. He was also a noted political activist and was twice elected to the Turkish Parliament (1939 and 1945). Çami is considered one of the leading figures of Turkish modern poetry and has been credited with helping to revive the form after it had been forgotten during the 1920s and 1930s.

Amanda McKenzie is a public commentator on the climate crisis in Australia. She is the CEO and co-founder of the Climate Council, Australia's leading climate science communications organisation. Previously, McKenzie co-founded the Australian Youth Climate Coalition, and was National Director for four years. She has also served on Renewable Energy Expert Panels for the Queensland and Northern Territory governments. McKenzie was the founding Chair of the Centre for Australian Progress, and is a former Board Director at Plan International Australia and the Whitlam Institute. She has won numerous awards, including being recognised as one of Westpac's 100 Women of Influence, and a finalist in Telstra Young Business Woman of the Year Awards. Early life and career McKenzie was raised in the suburbs of Melbourne. She earned an arts degree at Melbourne University, followed by a law degree (honours) at Monash University. She initially planned to be a human rights lawyer, until she learned about climate change, which she says she realised was going to be ‘a human catastrophe as much as an environmental catastrophe'.

Chloride channel accessory 3, also known as CLCA3, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the CLCA3 gene. Chloride channel accessory 3 (CLCA3) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the CLCA3 gene. CLCA3 is a chloride channel accessory protein that functions in the body to control chloride ions fluxes through cell membranes. This protein is also known as the "calcium-release channel accessory 3" or "calcium-release channel auxiliary 3". CLCA3 belongs to the family of proteins that are known as chloride channel accessory proteins. These proteins are responsible for controlling the flux of chloride ions through cell membranes. The function of CLCA3 is to allow calcium ions to pass through the cell membrane and into the cytoplasm. This allows cells to regulate their calcium levels and perform other important functions. CLCA3 is located on the outer surface of the plasma membrane and interacts with other proteins that are involved in regulating chloride fluxes through cell membranes. This interaction allows CLCA3 to function properly and control calcium levels in cells. CLCA3 is expressed in various tissues throughout the body, including the brain, heart, and kidney. The role of CLCA3 in these tissues is not well understood, but it may play a role in regulating calcium levels or performing other important tasks. Karl-Erik Åström (18 April 1924 - 9 December 1993) was a Swedish cross-country skier who competed in the 1950s. He won two gold medals at the 1950 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships in the 18 km and the 4 x 10 km. Career Karl-Erik Åström made his only appearance in the international stage during the 1950 Nordic World Ski Championship which was held in Rumford, Maine. After being a reserve for the Swedish team in the 1948 Winter Olympics held in St. Moritz, he was selected in the same spot in 1950 but was then granted a spot in the men's cross country which was held on 3 February where he claimed the gold medal ahead of fellow Swedish competitor Enar Josefsson who was the favourite leading into the race. Two days later, he would be part of the Swedish team that won the 4x10km relay with Nils Täpp, Martin Lundström and Enar Josefsson.

László Kiss (born 2 July 1979) is a Hungarian teacher and politician, who has been the mayor of Óbuda-Békásmegyer (3rd district of Budapest) since 2019. He was also a member of the National Assembly (MP) for the district (Budapest Constituency X) from 2014 to 2018. Studies and professional career Kiss finished his secondary studies at the Pál Kinizsi Secondary School of Food Industry in 1997. He earned a degree of history teacher at the Faculty of Humanities of the Eötvös Loránd University (ELTE) in 2004. He obtained a degree in public education leadership from the Faculty of Economics and Social Sciences of the Budapest University of Technology and Economics (BME) in 2008. He obtained a law degree from the Faculty of Political Science and Law of the Károli Gáspár University of the Reformed Church in Hungary (KRE) in 2017, and is currently a student at the doctoral school there. His field of research is constitutional law and the enforcement of national rights.

Steven George Mandis (born in 1970) is a Canadian-born American physicist, who is currently the Herbert A. Simon Professor of Physics at Cornell University. Mandis was born in 1970 in Toronto, Canada. He obtained his B.Sc. degree in physics from the University of Toronto in 1988 and his M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of California, Berkeley in 1992 and 1996, respectively. He is currently a professor at Cornell University, where he has been since 2002. Mandis's research focuses on the theory of quantum mechanics, particularly the phenomena of quantum entanglement and quantum tunnelling. His work has led to the development of novel methods for measuring and manipulating quantum systems, as well as theories of quantum information and cryptography. He is also active in the fields of statistical physics and condensed matter physics, and has made significant contributions to our understanding of such phenomena as superconductivity, superfluidity, and ferromagnetism. Mandis has received numerous awards and honours including a MacArthur Fellowship in 2002, a Fermi Award in 2007, an American Physical Society Fellow Award in 2008, and a David E. Shaw Prize in 2013. He was also awarded the National Medal of Science by President Barack Obama in 2014.

The Freiämtersturm in December 1830 was a failed attempt by the Austrian government to put down a Prague-based uprising. The Freiämtersturm (English: "Citizen's storm") was a failed attempt by the Austrian government to put down a Prague-based uprising in December 1830. The rebellion, which began on November 14, 1830, had quickly spread across Bohemia and Moravia, two of the most restive provinces of the Habsburg Monarchy. Led by radical liberals and Czech nationalists, the rebels demanded more autonomy for their homeland from Vienna and an end to discrimination against their population. Initially, the Austrian government responded to the uprising with a combination of force and negotiation. However, by December 1830 things had become untenable. On December 3, a military unit led by General Heinrich von Olang was dispatched to Prague to put down the rebellion. However, von Olang's men were quickly overwhelmed by the rebels, who managed to seize several key locations in the city. On December 5, Emperor Francis I ordered von Olang to withdraw his forces and submit to civilian authority. As von Olang's men retreated into Prague, they were met by a furious mob that rioted and pillaged throughout the city. Ultimately, the Freiämtersturm was a failure. While von Olang's forces were able to put down most of the rebels, thousands were killed or captured in the process and much of Prague was destroyed. The uprising also demonstrated

Arthur Yap Chioh Hiong (; 1943 – 24 October 2017) was a Malaysian politician and businessman. He was the former Member of Parliament for the Kota Kinabalu constituency in Sabah, and the Minister for Transport and Communications from 2004 to 2008. Arthur Yap was born in 1943 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. He studied at the London School of Economics, where he graduated with a degree in economics in 1965. He then worked as an economic adviser to the Malaysian Prime Minister from 1971 to 1974. From 1975 to 1984, he was the managing director of Yap Brothers Sdn Bhd, a large Malaysian conglomerate. In 1984, Arthur Yap entered politics as the Kota Kinabalu MP for the Barisan Nasional coalition. He served as Minister for Transport and Communications from 2004 to 2008, during which time he oversaw major infrastructure projects such as the Kinabalu International Airport and the Beaufort Bridge. Arthur Yap died on 24 October 2017 at the age of 80.

Fra Bartolomeo or Bartolommeo (, , ; 28 March 1472 – 31 October 1517), also known as Bartolommeo di Pagholo, Bartolommeo di S. Marco, and his original nickname Baccio della Porta, was an Italian Renaissance painter of religious subjects. He spent all his career in Florence until his mid-forties, when he travelled to work in various cities, as far south as Rome. He trained with Cosimo Roselli and in the 1490s fell under the influence of Savonarola, which led him to become a Dominican friar in 1500, renouncing painting for several years. Typically his paintings are of static groups of figures in subjects such as the Virgin and Child with Saints. He was instructed to resume painting for the benefit of his order in 1504, and then developed an idealized High Renaissance style, seen in his Vision of St Bernard of that year, now in poor condition but whose "figures and drapery move with a seraphic grace that must have struck the young Raphael with the force of revelation". He remained friends with Raphael, and each influenced the other.

Arleigh Brantley Templeton (April 18, 1916 – February 3, 2002) was an American naval officer and politician who served as the 37th Governor of Florida from 1965 to 1969 and as a United States Senator from Florida from 1971 to 1987. Templeton was born in Pensacola, Florida, to Admiral Arleigh Burke and Margaret (née Bradley) Templeton. He attended the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland, and graduated with the Class of 1937. He served in World War II, where he commanded the USS Champlin (APA-6). After the war, he served as an aide to Vice Admiral Richmond K. Turner and as a senior instructor at the Naval Academy. In 1962, Templeton was elected governor of Florida on a ticket with U.S. Representative Claude Pepper. The Republicans won control of both chambers of the state legislature for the first time in over a century, and Templeton quickly established himself as a conservative leader. He cut taxes, increased spending on education and social programs, and raised eyebrows by declaring that "I am proud to be a Republican". His popularity declined during the Vietnam War era, but he won re-election easily in 1966 and 1968. In 1969, Templeton chose not to run for reelection; he instead entered the U.S. Senate, where he quickly became one of its most influential members. Marc Goosens was born on 12 November 1918 in Sint-Niklaas, Belgium, to a family of coal miners. He showed early signs of violence, assaulting his sister with a broomstick when he was just five years old. He also began sexually abusing young girls at the age of 10 or 11. Goosens' first known murder occurred in 1946, when he killed 16-year-old Jeanne De Clercq after luring her into his home with the promise of a job as a maid. He then raped and mutilated her body before dumping her body in a river. In total, Goosens is suspected of killing at least 11 women during the 1940s and 1950s; however, he was never convicted of any crimes. In 1965, Goosens met 17-year-old Christine Van Hees in a park near Sint-Niklaas. The two began dating and soon moved in together. Van Hees soon became suspicious of Goosens, who had begun behaving erratically and making strange comments about wanting to kill her. On 12 November 1968, after days of torture and abuse, Goosens finally killed Van Hees by stabbing her 36 times with a butcher's knife. Zubarah , also referred to as Al Zubarah or Az Zubarah, is a ruined and ancient fort located on the north western coast of the Qatar peninsula in the Al Shamal municipality, about 105 km from the Qatari capital of Doha. It was founded by Shaikh Muhammed bin Khalifa, the founder father of Al Khalifa royal family of Bahrain, the main and principal Utub tribe in the first half of the eighteenth century. It was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2013. It was once a successful center of global trade and pearl fishing positioned midway between the Strait of Hormuz and the west arm of the Persian Gulf. It is one of the most extensive and best preserved examples of an 18th–19th century settlement in the region. The layout and urban fabric of the settlement has been preserved in a manner unlike any other settlements in the Persian Gulf, providing an insight into the urban life, spatial organization, and the social and economic history of the Persian Gulf before the discovery of oil and gas in the 20th century.

McLovins are an American rock band formed in Los Angeles, California in 2006. The band consists of lead vocalist, guitarist and songwriter John McLaughlin (formerly of Mahavishnu Orchestra), drummer Michael Barbieri (formerly of Primus), bassist Scott Murawski (formerly of Primus) and keyboardist Brian Chippendale (formerly of Tortoise). McLovins released their debut album, "Supernatural Superserious", in 2007 on the French label Captured Tracks. The album was later re-released in 2009 on the American label Secretly Canadian. The band's second album, "Euphoria Morning", was released in 2010 on the same label. The album was recorded at the now defunct Studio G in Los Angeles with producer John Congleton. The band toured extensively in support of "Euphoria Morning" throughout 2010 and 2011, including a headlining tour of the United States and a run of dates with the experimental rock supergroup Sunn O))) as part of the "Black Mountain winter" tour. In early 2012, McLovins announced that they were taking a break from touring to work on new material. In September 2013, McLovins announced their third album, "Supernatural Superserious III", would be released later that year. Recording for the album took place over the course of two years at various locations around Los Angeles including Chipping House Studios, Sonic Ranch and The Blasting Room with producer John Congleton once again

Mussa Moloh (born in the mid to late 1800s) is regarded as the last king of the Fuladu kingdom in the Senegambia region of Africa. Moloh was known to work with colonial powers to keep power and thwart rebellions; this would later lead to his downfall. The Fulbe Empire The Fuladu kingdom was founded, born of rebellion led by Mussa Moloh’s father, Moloh Eggue, also known as Alfa Moloh, against the Mandinka who formerly ruled the Gambia region. Those Mandingo rulers who once owned the land now the Fulbe state remained inside the kingdom once belonging to them. The scape of this empire in demographical terms was wide and diverse, despite the Fulbes being generally regarded as a homogenous group. Being a diverse group ultimately led to cultural struggles of power leading Alfa Moloh to quarrel with some groups causing these groups to leave the Fulbe state. The core of Alfa’s following was the Fulbe Firdu. Consisting of roughly 30,000, the Firdu moved north to make permanent settlements in Tomari and Jimana, two of the former Mandingo kingdoms in the Gambia valley. Later, the Fulbe empire would turn into a state directly resulting from the efforts of Alfa’s son, Mussa Moloh.

Discant, or descant (descant), (, meaning "singing apart") originated as a style of liturgical setting in the Middle Ages, associated with the development of the Notre Dame school of polyphony. In origin, it is a style of organum that either includes a plainchant tenor part (usually on a melisma in the chant) or is used without a plainchant basis in conductus, in either case with a "note against note" upper voice, moving in contrary motion. It is not a musical form, but rather a technique. The term continued to be used down to modern times with changing senses, at first for polyphony in general, then to differentiate a subcategory of polyphony (either in contrast to organum, or for improvised as distinct from written polyphony). By extension it became the name of a part that is added above the tenor, and later as the name of the highest part in a polyphonic setting (the equivalent of "cantus", "superius", and "soprano"). Finally, it was adopted as the name of the highest register of instruments such as recorders, cornets, viols, and organ stops.

The Smith River (Tolowa: ) is a long and narrow river in the U.S. state of California. It is located in the northwest corner of the state, and flows generally northwest into the Rogue River. The Smith River has several tributaries, including the North Fork Smith River, Middle Fork Smith River, South Fork Smith River, and East Fork Smith River. The Smith River was named for Kit Carson Smith, an early fur trapper in the area. The river was used by the Tolowa people as a food source and trading route. European-American settlers first arrived in the area in 1851, and farming and logging were soon major industries. The construction of the Klamath Dam in 1968 resulted in the destruction of many tributaries of the Smith River, leading to a decline in its salmon populations. The Smith River is now a popular spot for fly fishing, whitewater rafting, and swimming. The Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest preserves much of the river's undeveloped wilderness character.

Herman Thomas Karsten (22 April 1884, Amsterdam – 1945, Cimahi) was a Dutch engineer who gave major contributions to architecture and town planning in Indonesia during Dutch colonial rule. Most significantly he integrated the practice of colonial urban environment with native elements; a radical approach to spatial planning for Indonesia at the time. He introduced a neighborhood plan for all ethnic groups in Semarang, built public markets in Yogyakarta and Surakarta, and a city square in the capital Batavia (now 'Jakarta'). Between 1915 and 1941 he was given responsibility for planning 12 out of 19 municipalities in Java, 3 out of 9 towns in Sumatra and a town in Kalimantan (Indonesian Borneo). He received official recognition from both the government through his appointment to the colony's major Town Planning Committee and by the academic community with his appointment to the position of Lecturer for Town Planning at the School of Engineering at Bandung. He died in an internment camp near Bandung in 1945 during the Japanese occupation of Indonesia. Biography

Front running, also known as tailgating, is the prohibited practice of entering into an equity (stock) trade, option, futures contract, derivative, or security-based swap to capitalize on advance, nonpublic knowledge of a large ("block") pending transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. In essence, it means the practice of engaging in a Personal Securities Transaction in advance of a transaction in the same security for a client's account. Front running is considered a form of market manipulation in many markets. Cases typically involve individual brokers or brokerage firms trading stock in and out of undisclosed, unmonitored accounts of relatives or confederates. Institutional and individual investors may also commit a front running violation when they are privy to inside information. A front running firm either buys for its own account before filling customer buy orders that drive up the price, or sells for its own account before filling customer sell orders that drive down the price. Front running is prohibited since the front-runner profits from nonpublic information, at the expense of its own customers, the block trade, or the public market. In 2003, several hedge fund and mutual fund companies became embroiled in an illegal late trading scandal made public by a complaint against Bank of America brought by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. A resulting U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into allegations of front-running activity implicated Edward D. Jones & Co., Inc., Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Strong Mutual Funds, Putnam Investments, Invesco, and Prudential Securities.

Mick Micheyl (born Paulette Michey; 8 February 1922 – 16 May 2019) was a French singer-songwriter and sculptor. Her songs won a number of national awards and she was considered the leading star of French song in the 1950s and 60s. Biography Micheyl was born Paulette Michey in Lyon in 1922 and studied at the Ecole Lyonnaise des Beaux-Arts; she started her career as a painter. In 1949 her song Le Marchand de Poésie (The Poetry Merchant), won a French song contest and she moved to Paris to become a singer. She recorded her first album with Pathé-Marconi Records in 1950, and sang in nightclubs and cabarets in the city such as Casino de Paris. Another of her songs, Un gamin de Paris (A child from Paris), was widely acclaimed. In 1953 she won the Grand Prix du Disque of the Académie Charles-Cros with her song Ni toi ni moi (Neither You Nor Me). She also appeared in a number of French films, including Little Jacques in 1953 and Paris Music-Hall in 1957.

Garden Path (foaled 1941) was a British Thoroughbred racehorse and broodmare who won the classic 2000 Guineas in 1944. In a racing career conducted entirely at Newmarket Racecourse the filly ran six times and won three races. She was one of the best British two-year-olds of 1943, when she won one race and was placed in both the Middle Park Stakes and the Cheveley Park Stakes. After winning on her first appearance of 1944 she became the first (and still the only) filly since 1902 to win the 2000 Guineas against colts. On her only subsequent race she was injured when finishing unplaced in the Derby. She was retired from racing at the end of the season and had some success as a broodmare. Background Garden Path was a big, good-looking brown mare bred by her owner the Edward Stanley, 17th Earl of Derby. Her sire, Fairway, had been a highly successful racehorse for Lord Derby, winning the St Leger and two runnings of the Champion Stakes. Garden Path's successes in 1944 enabled Fairway to win the sires' Championship for the fourth and final time. Garden Path's dam, Ranai, won two minor races before producing many good winners including the 2000 Guineas winner Watling Street (also sired by Fairway). Lord Derby sent the horse to his private trainer Walter Earl at his Stanley House stable in Newmarket, Suffolk.

Baskerville + Watson was an American contemporary furniture design firm that operated from 1970 to 1998. The company was founded by Charles Eames, who partnered with Watson to create furniture designs. Charles Eames and Norman McLaren were early pioneers of the modernist movement, and their design concepts were influential in the development of contemporary furniture design. In the 1950s, Eames teamed up with Ray Johnson to form the architecture and design firm Charles Eames Associates. The company's early furniture designs were experimental and innovative, and they introduced the concepts of modernist furniture design to the world. In the early 1960s, Eames began working on his own, and he partnered with Watson in 1970 to form Baskerville + Watson. The company's signature style was simple and contemporary, and their furniture was noted for its lightness and durability. Baskerville + Watson designed a wide range of furniture pieces, including chairs, sofas, tables, and lamps. They also created a number of catalogues and exhibition catalogues that documented their work. Baskerville + Watson ceased operations in 1998, but their legacy remains alive in the contemporary furniture design industry.

Steve Jansen (born Stephen Ian Batt, born 10 October 1971) is a former Dutch professional racing cyclist. He is the only cyclist to have won the UCI Road World Championships in the road race, time trial and mountainbike events. In 2005 he became the first rider to complete the Triple Crown of Cycling, by winning the Tour de France, Vuelta a España and Paris–Nice races. Jansen was born in Rotterdam, Netherlands. He started cycling at an early age and competed in his first amateur race at 14. By 17 he had become Dutch junior champion and in 1992 he turned professional with Rabobank. He won his first race as a professional at the Tour of Flanders. He first rode the Tour de France in 1994 and finished fourth overall. After three consecutive top five finishes, he won his first major stage race, the Vuelta a España, in 1995. In 1996, he won both the Giro d'Italia and the Tour de France, becoming only the second rider (after Bernard Hinault) to win both races in the same year. In 1997 he won his second Vuelta a España. In 1998 he retired from professional cycling after winning his third Tour de France. Jansen's success as a professional cyclist was matched by his success as a coach. He was head coach of Rabobank from 2000 to 2004 and then became head coach of Team LottoNL–Jumbo until 2008. In 2009 he joined Astana

The Last Post Fund is a Canadian charity that collects and distributes last messages from soldiers who have fallen in the line of duty. The fund was founded in 2007 by Canadian Forces veteran Dave Segal. The Last Post Fund is a Canadian charity that collects and distributes last messages from soldiers who have fallen in the line of duty. The fund was founded in 2007 by Canadian Forces veteran Dave Segal. The charity provides a valuable service to families and friends of those who have lost their lives, by preserving these final moments as a lasting memory. The Last Post Fund operates on a simple principle: to honour the sacrifice of those who have given their lives serving our country. The charity accepts donations from individuals, organizations and governments around the world, and uses these funds to purchase engraved pendants and coins to be distributed to the families of those who have lost their lives in the line of duty.

Michael James Thistle (born 5 August 1980) is a Scottish professional footballer who plays as a defender for Scottish Premiership club Rangers. Thistle started his career with Dundee United, making over 100 appearances for the club before moving to Rangers in 2002. He has since made over 400 appearances for the Ibrox side, winning two Scottish Premier League titles and two Scottish Cups. He also represented Scotland at under-21 level. He has since made over 400 appearances for the Ibrox side, winning two Scottish Premier League titles and two Scottish Cups. He also represented Scotland at under-21 level. On 1 January 2019, Thistle announced his retirement from professional football after 16 years with Rangers.

Lawrence James Baker (4 January 1827 – 5 October 1912) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 25th Attorney General of the United States from 1881 to 1885. He also served as Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower from 1953 to 1961. Baker was born on 4 January 1827 in Sharon, Connecticut, the son of Lawrence Baker and Mercy (Hart) Baker. He attended Yale University, where he was a member of the Skull and Bones Society, and then Harvard Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review. He practiced law in Boston before being elected as a Democrat to the US House of Representatives in 1874, serving two terms. In 1880, he was elected Attorney General of the United States, serving until 1885. He then resumed the practice of law in Boston. Baker served as Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower from 1953 to 1961. He died on 5 October 1912 in Lexington, Massachusetts.

Thomas Joseph Robert Hughes (born 1943) is a Professor of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics and currently holds the Computational and Applied Mathematics Chair III at the Oden Institute at The University of Texas at Austin. Hughes has been listed as an ISI Highly Cited Author in Engineering by the ISI Web of Knowledge, Thomson Scientific Company. A leading expert in computational mechanics, Hughes has received numerous academic distinctions and awards for his work. He is a research fellow of the National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering, American Academy of Arts & Sciences, the American Academy of Mechanics, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), the U.S. Association for Computational Mechanics (USACM), the International Association for Computational Mechanics (IACM), the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and has been elected as a foreign member of The Royal Society. He is a founder and past President of USACM and IACM, and past Chairman of the Applied Mechanics Division of ASME.

Yelena Vladimirovna Dudnik (; born 22 October 1972) is a Russian actress and singer. Dudnik was born in Moscow, Russian SFSR, Soviet Union. She is the daughter of actress Yelena Rudenko and actor Vladimir Dudnik. Dudnik made her debut in the theatre at the age of six, in a staging of the play "The Snow Queen". Dudnik has appeared in a number of Russian films and television series since the early 1990s. She became well known for her roles in the films "Mother" (2002), "The Master and Margarita" (2005), "The Brothers Karamazov" (2007), "War and Peace" (2008), and "The Death of Stalin" (2017). Dudnik has also had notable roles in international films, such as "The Pianist" (2002) and "The International" (2009). In 2006, Dudnik won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in the film "The Pianist". In 2011, she received an Honorary Award from the Moscow International Film Festival. Dudnik has released two albums: "Kolya" (2003) and "Yelena" (2011).

Odigbo is a Local Government Area in the Cross River State of Nigeria. It has an estimated population of about 408,000 people. The Local Government Area of Odigbo was carved out of the former Ebonyi State on 10th May 1991. It has an area of 1,788.5 square kilometers and is bounded on the north by the local government areas of Akpa-Ekpo and Abia State, on the east by Ekpoma, on the south by Isiala-Etche, and on the west by Ahiara Local Government Area. The administrative headquarters of Odigbo are in the town of Odigbo. The climate in Odigbo is tropical wet and dry with a hot summer season and a cool winter season. The annual mean temperature is about 26 degrees Celsius. The annual mean rainfall is about 2,000 millimeters. The main agricultural product is cassava, while other important crops include maize, sorghum, beans, pepper, cassava, cowpea and soya beans. There are also some oil palm plantations in the area. The people in Odigbo are mainly Igbo speaking with a minority of Hausa speakers. There are also some people who speak English and Arabic. The major religions in Odigbo are Christianity and Islam. Elvira Bierbach is a German heilpraktiker, an author, and a lecturer on alternative medicine. Elvira Bierbach was born in 1933 in the German town of Münster. After completing her schooling there, she studied medicine at the University of Münster. She completed her medical training in 1960 and began working as a heilpraktiker (healer) in Münster. In 1967 she moved to Berlin and began working as a heilpraktiker there. In 1978 she published her first book, Die Heilkraft der Mineralien und Kräuter. Bierbach has written several books on alternative medicine, including Die Wirkungsweise von Bachblüten (1983), Die Heilkraft von Kräutern und Pflanzen (1988), Der Weg zur Gesundheit – wie man mit dem Geist körperlich weiterkommt (1995), Das Heilmittel – die Geschichte einer Idee (2003), and Gesundheits-Woche – die Gesundheit der Zukunft (2007). She has also given lectures on alternative medicine throughout Germany and abroad. Bierbach has been married to her husband, Dr. Georg Bierbach, for over 60 years. They have two children, two grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.

Erik Jon Spoelstra ( ; born November 1, 1970) is an American professional basketball coach and former player who is the head coach for the Miami Heat of the National Basketball Association (NBA). Of Filipino descent from his mother's side, Spoelstra is the first Asian-American head coach in the history of the four major North American sports leagues and the first Asian-American head coach to win an NBA championship. Spoelstra served as assistant coach and director of scouting for the Heat from 2001 to 2008, during which time the team won the 2006 NBA Finals. He was promoted to head coach in the 2008-09 season. Following the addition of free agents LeBron James and Chris Bosh in 2010, the Heat made four consecutive NBA Finals appearances (2011–2014) under Spoelstra, winning the championship in 2012 and 2013. Spoelstra made his fifth appearance in the NBA Finals as head coach in 2020.

Noel Dempsey (born 6 January 1953) is a former professional footballer who played as a defender. Dempsey began his career with hometown club Cork City before signing for Wolverhampton Wanderers in 1974. He spent six seasons at Molineux, making over 200 appearances and helping the club to successive promotions to the top flight of English football. He then moved to Manchester United, where he made just over 100 appearances before retiring in 1984. Following his retirement, Dempsey served as assistant manager at Bohemian F.C. and then Preston North End before becoming head coach of League of Ireland side Dundalk in 2002. He remained in charge for six seasons, leading the club to two League of Ireland titles and an FAI Cup victory. He resigned in 2009, after a poor finish to the 2008–09 season, and was replaced by Harry Kewell. Dempsey has since worked as a pundit for RTÉ Sport and BBC Sport, as well as working as a coach with various youth teams. In January 2017, he was appointed manager of League of Ireland side Bray Wanderers.

Pontypool Rugby Football Club is a Welsh rugby union team based in the town of Pontypool. They play in the WRU Championship (Known as SWALEC Championship for sponsorship purposes) and due to the regionalisation of Welsh rugby in 2003 Pontypool RFC is now a feeder club to The Dragons regional team. Pontypool play their home matches at Pontypool Park. Their traditional home kit is Red, White and Black hooped shirt and socks with white shorts, although they did gradually shift to wearing black shorts post-2003. Pontypool RFC has a long history within Welsh rugby and is one of the most notable clubs, being present at the formation of the Welsh Rugby Union in 1881, but disbanding before the turn of the 19th century. The club reformed in 1901, the club's accepted formation date, and produced many notable Wales and British Lions international players; most notably the Jones brothers in the early 20th century and the Pontypool Front Row of Charlie Faulkner, Graham Price and Bobby Windsor in the 1970s. The club's 'Golden Era' is generally accepted as the 1970s and 1980s when under the coaching of Ray Prosser the first team won the Welsh Club Championship in 1973 and 1975.

The Beitunia killings refers to the consecutive murders of six people, including a pregnant woman and her unborn child, in the Israeli town of Beitunia on 1 and 2 October 2006. The killings took place over the course of two days, with the first victim being stabbed to death in her home shortly after midnight on 1 October 2006. In all, four other people were killed over the course of the next two days: a mother and her two children who were stabbed to death in their home on 2 October; a pregnant woman who was bludgeoned to death; and a man who was shot and killed while trying to help a victim of the first murder. The murders sparked national outcry in Israel, with many commentators calling for a swift and severe response from the Israeli authorities. On 3 October, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) announced that they had arrested a 17-year-old Palestinian youth named Muhammad al-Dura for involvement in the killings. The teenager was later found guilty of all six murders and sentenced to life imprisonment.

Abraham Whipple (September 26, 1733 – May 2, 1797) was an American patriot and statesman who served as the sixth Governor of Massachusetts from 1779 to 1785. Whipple was born in Groton, Massachusetts to Ebenezer and Sarah (Burt) Whipple. He attended the common schools and then Harvard College, where he studied law. He was admitted to the bar in 1757 and commenced practice in Groton. In 1770, Whipple married Sarah Clapp. Together, they had six children. Whipple served as a delegate to the Continental Congress in 1774 and 1775. He was also a member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives from 1777 to 1779 and from 1781 to 1785. In 1779, Whipple was elected Governor of Massachusetts and served until his resignation in 1785. During his term, he helped to pass the Massachusetts Constitution of 1780. Whipple served as a judge on the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts from 1790 to 1800. He died in Boston on May 2, 1797.

Paul Belloni Du Chaillu (July 31, 1831 – December 14, 1883) was a French explorer, hunter and naturalist. He is best known for his explorations in Africa, including the Congo basin and the Ivory Coast. Du Chaillu also made important contributions to the knowledge of the African elephant. Du Chaillu was born in Bordeaux, France on July 31, 1831. In 1853 he sailed for Africa on the ship La Reine des Neiges. He arrived in Gabon in 1854 and began exploring the Congo basin. He travelled up the Congo River as far as Stanley Pool, then turned south and travelled through the Ituri Forest to Lake Tanganyika. In 1857 he visited the Kasai region of what is now the Democratic Republic of Congo. Du Chaillu next travelled to the coast of what is now Angola. In 1860 he travelled up the Benguela River to its source. From there he went south to Luanda and explored the Cuanza Sul province of Angola. He then crossed the Congo River into the present-day Republic of Congo and explored its Upper Congo region. In 1862 he travelled through the forests of Cameroon to Bafoussam, where he met a group of Askaris (a type of African soldier). Casuistry is a process of reasoning by which judges, lawyers and other legal professionals try to reach just conclusions in cases. Casuistry can be used to justify any decision, even if the legal principle underlying it is invalid. Casuists may also use casuistry to deceive their opponents or clients. Casuistry is a key feature of the medieval judicial process, which was based on the principle of "lex talionis" or "an eye for an eye". This meant that people were expected to take revenge for wrongs done to them. As a result, casuistry developed as a way of justifying decisions based on this principle without actually doing anything. For example, if someone had been hurt by another person, the casuist might try to argue that the other person should be punished in exactly the same way. This was known as "strict liability". In more recent times, casuistry has been used more often to deceive people. For example, a lawyer might argue that a particular law is unconstitutional in order to get their client off the hook. Casuistry can also be used to justify unjustified actions by authorities. For example, during the Nazi concentration camps, Nazis often used casuistry to argue that prisoners were being punished for crimes they hadn't committed.

Within the field of anthropology and other social sciences, ethnography is a form of research that relies on a range of sources of data, but usually tends to rely mainly on participant observation. However, the term also refers to the product of this type of research, which of course normally takes a textual form. As a result, ethnography is also sometimes seen as a genre of writing, one used to describe patterns of human social interaction in particular contexts. Within the context of ethnography, the term 'realism' is often used to refer to the assumptions that some kinds of ethnographic work make about the phenomena to be investigated, and how these are to be understood. However, 'ethnographic realism' has also been used to refer to a style of writing that narrates the author's experiences and observations as if the reader were witnessing or experiencing events first hand. A work written using ethnographic realism may be referred to as a realist ethnography, and classified as a subgenre of ethnography.

Anarchism in Japan began to emerge in the late 19th century, with the first anarchist group formed in 1887. Anarchism in Japan has seen sporadic activity throughout its history, but has never achieved significant traction. Anarchism in Japan is currently represented by a small number of activists, most of whom are concentrated in the Tokyo area. Anarchism in Japan is a small and isolated movement, with only a handful of activists scattered throughout the country. The main anarchist groups active in Japan are the Revolutionary Anarchist Black Cross (RABC) and the Libertarian Socialist Forum (LSF), both of which are based in Tokyo. These groups engage in sporadic activity, promoting anarchist ideas and organising small protests and assemblies. Anarchism in Japan has never achieved significant mainstream traction, with the movement remaining a small and largely underground force. However, anarchists have been active in various struggles over the years, including the anti-war movement and the fight for social justice.

Raphael J. Sonenshein (born November 10, 1949) is an American lawyer, businessman and philanthropist. He has served as the president and CEO of the City of Houston, Texas since January 25, 2007. Sonenshein was born in Houston, the son of Frances (née Walsh) and Raphael J. Sonenshein, Sr. He received his B.A. degree from Wesleyan University in 1971 and his J.D. degree from Harvard Law School in 1974. Sonenshein began his legal career as an associate at the law firm of Baker Botts in 1974. He became a partner at the firm in 1981 and was its chairman and CEO from 1998 to 2007. During his tenure as CEO, Baker Botts became one of the largest law firms in the world with more than 1,000 lawyers worldwide. Sonenshein also served as a trustee of The Woodlands College Park from 1998 to 2007 and as a director of The Episcopal Church's Foundation for Global Service from 2000 to 2007. He is also a member of The Century Foundation, The National Academy of Arts and Sciences, The American Law Institute, and The Houston Museum of Fine Arts. Sonenshein was elected president and CEO of the City of Houston on January 25, 2007. Karpenisi is a town in central Georgia. It is the administrative center of the Karpenisi regional unit. According to the 2013 census, the town has a population of 5,569. Karpenisi is located in central Georgia, on the banks of the Rioni River. The town is situated on a highland plateau at an elevation of 1,500 meters above sea level. The climate is temperate and moderately humid. The region is known for its wine production. The origins of the town are lost in antiquity. The first documentary evidence of Karpenisi dates from 1404, when King David VI of Georgia granted a charter to the local lord, Ioakim II Kakabadze. In 1783, Karpenisi became an important trade center because of its location on the main route between Tbilisi and Kutaisi. In 1801, during the Russo-Turkish War (1801-1803), Russian forces captured Karpenisi and held it for two years. In 1811-1812, during the First Caucasian War (1801-1813), Russian forces again captured Karpenisi and held it for three months. The town rose to prominence in the late 19th century because of its wine production. Today, Karpenisi is an important trade and tourist center. The town has a number of cultural institutions, including a theater and a museum.

Robert Young Button (November 2, 1899 – September 1, 1977) served two terms as Attorney General of Virginia, as well as a fifteen years as Virginia State Senator. Button rose through the ranks of the Byrd Organization and became one of its leading members as it ultimately crumbled as a result of the Massive Resistance crisis. Early and family life Born on November 2, 1899, in Culpeper County, Virginia, to John Young Button (farmer and traveling hardware salesman), and his wife the former Margaret Agnes Duncan, Button attended the local public schools and graduated from Culpeper High School in 1917. He then attended the University of Virginia for five years and received an undergraduate and law (LL.B.) degree in 1922. He was a member of the prestigious Raven Society and Order of the Coif. On August 20, 1931, Button married nurse Kathleen Mary Antoinette Cheape (1907–2007), who converted him to the Episcopal Church, and they had a son and a daughter.

The Lamar Buffalo Ranch is a historic cattle ranch located in Lamar County, Texas. The ranch operated from 1871 until 1959 and during that time it was one of the largest and most successful ranches in the state. The ranch was purchased by the Lamar family in 1871 and operated by members of the family until 1959. The ranch was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1984. The Lamar Buffalo Ranch is located in Lamar County near the town of Nixon. The ranch encompasses over 1,000 acres and is located on the Llano Estacado, a high desert plateau that dominates much of central Texas. The ranch is bordered to the north by the Llano Estacado National Forest and to the south by the Rolling Plains National Battlefield. The Lamar Buffalo Ranch operated from 1871 until 1959 and during that time it was one of the largest and most successful ranches in the state. The ranch was purchased by the Lamar family in 1871 and operated by members of the family until 1959. During its operation, the ranch employed over 1,000 workers and produced over one million head of cattle. The ranch was also responsible for introducing genetics into Texas beef production, leading to improved beef quality across the state. Donald Paul Hodel (born May 23, 1935) is an American former politician who served as United States Secretary of Energy, Secretary of the Interior, and chairman of FreeEats.com, which disseminated push polls for the Economic Freedom Fund. He was known during his tenure as Secretary of the Interior for his controversial "Hodel Policy," which stated that disused dirt roads and footpaths could be considered right-of-ways under RS 2477. Hodel proposed that rather than reduce the production of CFCs to prevent ozone layer destruction, people should wear hats and use sunscreen. His plan was assailed by scientists and environmentalists, who pointed out the "broad and potentially disastrous effects that increased ultraviolet radiation would have on the Earth’s climate, food chains and individual species of plants and animals other than humans". Critics of Hodel’s "Ray-Ban Plan" sarcastically depicted animals and plants wearing sunglasses to protect against increased radiation, and called for his resignation.

David Jones (David Henry Jones; born 11 December 1984) is a Welsh professional track and field athlete who specialises in the 400 metres. He represented Wales at the 2008, 2012 and 2016 Olympics and won a silver medal at the 2013 World Championships. Jones also won the 400 metres gold medal at the 2007 IAAF World Championships. Born in Cardiff, Jones was raised in Bridgend and attended the local secondary school, Pencoed. He started competing in track and field aged eleven and represented his school at regional levels before making his senior debut for Wales at the age of seventeen. After finishing fourth in the 200 metres at the 2003 World Youth Championships, Jones improved his time to third place two years later as he became one of the youngest ever Welsh medallists in that event. He made his senior international debut on 5 July 2004, representing Wales in a 4 × 400 metres relay event at the European Championships in Athletics. A year later he improved upon his fourth-place finish from 2004 as he became Welsh 400 metres champion with a time of 43.87 seconds. Jones made his Olympic debut at the 2008 Beijing Olympics as a member of the Welsh 4 × 400 metres relay team which finished fifth overall. He improved upon this performance two years later as he helped Wales to a silver medal in the 400 metres event at the 2012 London Olympics. The Congo Reform Association (CRA) was a political and humanitarian activist group that sought to promote reform of the Congo Free State, a private territory in Central Africa under the absolute sovereignty of King Leopold II. Active from 1904–1913, the association formed in opposition to the institutionalised practices of Congo Free State's ‘rubber policy’, which encouraged the need to minimise expenditure and maximise profit with no political constraints – fostering a system of coercion and terror unparalleled in contemporary colonial Africa. The group carried out a global publicity campaign across the Western world, using a range of strategies including displays of atrocity photographs; public seminars; mass rallies; celebrity endorsements; and extensive press coverage to lobby the Great Powers into pressuring reform in the Congo. The association partially achieved its aims in 1908 with the Belgian government’s annexation of the Congo Free State and continued to promote reform until disbanding in 1913. Origins: E. D. Morel and the Casement Report

Career Born in Aalborg, Andreasen started his career as a youth player with AaB but soon moved on to Randers FC where he would have a better chance of making the 1st team. He signed his first professional contract with Randers in summer 2007. Andreasen made his debut for the Randers FC senior squad on 30 March 2008 in a game against AC Horsens. His first goal for the club was a game winner against FC Nordsjælland on 12 May 2008. After the game Randers manager Colin Todd stated that Andreasen had a bright future in front of him, due to his goal scoring ability. On 29 April 2009 Randers announced that they had decided to loan out Andreasen to TPS Turku in the finish Veikkausliiga until the end of the 2008-09 season. Andreasen enjoyed a successful loan spell at TPS, scoring 5 goals in 8 games for the club, as TPS finished 3rd in the 2009 Veikkausliiga.

Kim Annette Robertson (born 10 March 1957) is a New Zealand former track and field sprinter. She represented New Zealand at three Commonwealth Games, one World Indoor Championship, three IAAF World Cups and three Pacific Conference Games. She was also selected in the 1980 Moscow Olympic team in the 400 meters but did not compete due to the NZ Government boycotting the event. Early life Robertson was born on 10 March 1957, the middle child of Maurice Robertson and Eileen Hobcraft, in Mt Eden, a suburb of Auckland. Both her parents were athletes in their own right. Her father captained the New Zealand national rugby league team in the 1940s and 1950s and was inducted into the Legends of League (Hall of Fame equivalent) in 2000. Her mother was a sprinter, netball and basketball player for the Auckland province. Robertson was educated at Epsom Girls' Grammar School in Auckland, and Eastern Institute of Technology, Viticulture and Winemaking Dept, Napier, New Zealand.

45-year-old released ten-minute YouTube film showing him in Lake District . It follows the presenter as he drinks pints and learns how to herd sheep . Comes after co-host James May released series of films about jobless life . Clarkson also described yesterday how bored he was with unemployed life .

Ijahnya Christian (January 31, 1957 – April 4, 2009) was an American R&B singer and songwriter. Ijahnya Christian was born in Newark, New Jersey, on January 31, 1957. She attended the Newark Arts High School and later studied music at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston. Christian began her career as a backing vocalist for the R&B group The Emotions and recorded several albums with them between 1978 and 1985. Her first solo album, "Inner Secrets", was released in 1986 and received critical acclaim. Her subsequent albums included "Faithful" (1988), "Love Unlimited" (1990), "The Masterpiece" (1993), "Ijahnya" (1996), "All I Need" (1999), and "Unconditional Love" (2002). Her final album, "Unconditional Love", was released posthumously in 2009. Christian also wrote songs for other singers, including Whitney Houston, Toni Braxton, Janet Jackson, La Toya Jackson, Patti LaBelle, Dionne Warwick, Michael Jackson, Angie Stone, Celine Dion, Aretha Franklin and Stevie Wonder. Her songs have been recorded by performers such as Celine Dion, Whitney Houston, Toni Braxton and Aretha Franklin. Christian died of pancreatic cancer on April 4, 2009 at the age of 57.

Pritesh and Mansi Gandhi had been trying for a baby for ten years . They suffered five miscarriages and lost a baby after six months . Pritesh 's sister Hiral agreed to act as a surrogate to the couple . Three weeks ago they welcomed their son Krish .

Detmar Jobst Wilhelm Westhoff (born 28 February 1966 in Bonn) is a German art historian and curator. He is very committed to artistic projects that build a bridge between Asia and Europe, to young experimental artists, local cultural policy and monument protection. Education & early career Detmar Westhoff was born as the son of the art historian Dr. Hildegard Westhoff-Krummacher, who worked at the Westphalian State Museum of Art and Cultural History in Münster (LWL-Museum für Kunst und Kultur). While studying art history at the Johann Wolfgang Goethe University in Frankfurt am Main, he met the former director of the Guggenheim Foundation Thomas M. Messer who was visiting lecturer and at the same time visiting curator at the Schirn Kunsthalle where Westhoff started to work after graduation. From 2001 to 2006 he set up the fundraising department in the Kunstsammlung NRW (K20 / K21) and developed for example the KPMG art evening and the cooperation of Georg Baselitz with the publishing group Handelsblatt.

Lucy Douglas "C. Z." Guest (née Cochrane; November 3, 1892 – May 28, 1978) was an American actress, singer and dancer. She is best known for her roles in the films The Philadelphia Story (1940), Bringing Up Baby (1938), and For Whom the Bell Tolls (1940). Born in New York City, Guest began her career in vaudeville before making her Broadway debut in 1925. In 1929, she made her first appearance in a motion picture, and over the next few years appeared in a number of films. Her performance in The Philadelphia Story won her an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress. Guest starred in several more films over the next few years before retiring from acting in the early 1940s. She later became a television personality and was a regular panelist on the game show What's My Line? from 1950 until her retirement in 1975. Guest died in 1978 at the age of 85.

Ferguson Cheruiyot Rotich (born 30 November 1989) is a Kenyan middle-distance runner who competes in the 800 metres. He has a personal best of 1:42.54 minutes for the event. He represented Kenya at the 2013 World Championships in Athletics and was a gold medallist in the 4×800 metres relay at the 2014 IAAF World Relays. At the 2020 Summer Olympics he won the silver medal, finishing behind his countryman Emmanuel Korir. Career A relative late-comer to the sport, he made his first impact in the 2013 season at the age of 23. He won the 800 m at the Meeting Grand Prix IAAF de Dakar, setting a personal best of 1:45.40 minutes. In his first race in Europe he went under one minute and 45 seconds for the first time to take fourth at the Golden Spike Ostrava. He placed a narrow second to Anthony Chemut at the Kenyan trials in July, improving further to 1:44.38 minutes. This led to his selection for the 2013 World Championships in Athletics. At the competition he progressed to the semi-final and initially placed fifth, but was disqualified for a lane infringement. He ended the year with two performances on the 2013 IAAF Diamond League circuit, coming third at both the Weltklasse Zürich and the Memorial Van Damme. The latter race was the fastest in the year and Rotich's time of 1:43.22 minutes ranked him as the third fastest in the world that season, making it a rapid rise for the athlete who was unranked in 2012.

Martha G. Welch (born June 21, 1944) is an American physician and researcher specializing in the fields of infant and child development. Welch currently serves as an Associate Professor of Psychiatry in Pediatrics and Pathology & Cell Biology at Columbia University Medical Center (CUMC), where she is Co-Director of the Nurture Science Program. Welch's research focuses on the biological mechanisms of nurture and the ways they can be utilized to provide new interventions for the prevention and treatment of developmental and behavioral disorders. The term ‘nurture’ is used by scientists within the Nurture Science Program to describe mother/parent-infant/child interactions which have a foundational role in promoting optimal emotional and behavioral development, such as holding, touching, breast feeding and communicating emotionally. Education and early life Martha Grace Welch was born in Buffalo, New York and raised in Eggertsville, New York. Her paternal family is descended from the founders of the Welch's Grape Juice Company.

larry reid was arrested about 12:40 p.m. monday on u.s. highway 95 near boulder city, nevada . he was also charged with battery of a police officer, driving across a median, resisting arrest, not wearing a seat belt and possession of a gun while under the influence of alcohol . the nevada senator's office confirmed that larry reid is the democrat's brother, saying only that it is 'a private matter' .

A family in Texas became infested with birds when they returned home . According to the video maker , the birds came in through the chimney . The video maker initially thought the intruders were bats but now believes them to be sparrows . Despite the infestation , the family remain very calm throughout the video .

Charli , from Queensland , Australia , has turned CharlisCraftyKitchen into YouTube 's largest food channel in less than three years . The channels earns an average of 29 million views per month . Charli 's five-year-old sister Ashlee also stars in the how-to cooking clips . One of their most popular videos , which demonstrates how to make Frozen-themed popsicles , has received 57 million views in less than a year .

The Sultanate of Ifat, or Awfat was a medieval Sunni Muslim state in the eastern regions of the Horn of Africa between the late 13th century and early 15th century. It was formed in present-day Ethiopia around eastern Shewa or Zeila. Led by the Walashma dynasty, the polity stretched from Zequalla to the port city of Zeila. The kingdom ruled over parts of what are now Ethiopia, Djibouti and Somaliland. Location According to Al-Omari, Ifat was a state close to the Red Sea coast, 15 days by 20 days "normal traveling time". The state had a river (Awash River), was well peopled and had an army of 20,000 soldiers and 15,000 horsemen. Al-Omari mentioned seven cities in Ifat: Belqulzar, Kuljura, Shimi, Shewa, Adal, Jamme and Laboo. While reporting that its center was "a place called Walalah, probably the modern Wäläle south of Šäno in the Ěnkwoy valley, about 50 miles ENE of Addis Ababa", G.W.B. Huntingford "provisionally" estimated its southern and eastern boundaries were along the Awash River, the western frontier a line drawn between Medra Kabd towards the Jamma river east of Debre Libanos (which it shared with Damot), and the northern boundary along the Adabay and Mofar rivers. The Al-Omari territorial account of Ifat Sultanate implies a size of 300 kilometers by 400 kilometers, which may be an exaggeration, according to Richard Pankhurst.

Ravi Beefnah , 34 , parked his white Audi A5 outside the entrance of the dealership in Chelmsford , Essex , in February as a warning to other buyers . Two months later and Mr Beefnah 's protest is still there , with the owner claiming that Audi have failed to resolve his long-running complaint about the engine . Audi admits there was a problem with some of the engines and has offered to fix cars with the issue free of charge .

The I.O.O.F. Centennial Building is an historic building in Chicago, Illinois, United States. The I.O.O.F. Centennial Building is located on the north side of Lake Street in the Loop district of Chicago, Illinois. It was designed by the architectural firm of Holabird & Root and built in 1922 as the headquarters of the I.O.O.F., one of the largest fraternal organizations in the United States. The building was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1983. The I.O.O.F.'s initial investment in the building was $100,000, and it paid off quickly; within a year, membership had increased from 2,000 to 8,000 members. The building's success led to an increase in membership and donations, and by 1925, the organization had outgrown its original building and purchased a site on North Clark Street for a new headquarters. Construction on the new building began in 1926 and was completed three years later; it cost $1 million dollars and was even more impressive than its predecessor, featuring a columned atrium with a fountain in its center and marble floors and walls throughout. Since 1983, the I.O.O.F.'s Centennial Building has served as the headquarters of the IBO (International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers), which moved into the building in 1984 after purchasing it from the I.O.O.F.; today, it is one of Chicago's most important labor unions.

Ernest Hilbert (born 1970) is an American mathematician and philosopher who has made significant contributions to mathematics, logic, and philosophy. His work in mathematics has included the development of the finite element method, which is a widely used method for solving problems in engineering. Hilbert is also known for his work in philosophy, particularly in the areas of mathematics and mathematics education. He has written several books on these topics, and has been a visiting professor at several universities. He was the inaugural editor-in-chief of the journal Mind, and he currently serves on the editorial board of several other journals. Hilbert was born in 1970 in Saint Louis, Missouri. He received his bachelor's degree from Washington University in St. Louis in 1992, and his master's degree from Brown University in 1994. He then received his doctorate from Princeton University in 1998. Hilbert is currently a professor of mathematics at Harvard University.

Zlatan Ibrahimovic has had his four-game ban reduced by one match . Dimitri Payet received a two-game sanction after aiming expletives at the closed door of the match officials ` dressing room after a goalless draw with Lyon . The two clubs , bitter rivals of each other , put out identical press releases last Friday stating that they would no longer speak to Canal + until May 30 .

Hawkinge is now a town and civil parish in the Folkestone and Hythe district of Kent, England. The original village of Hawkinge is actually just less than a mile (c. 1.3 km) due east of the present village centre (roughly 51° 6'55.14"N, 1°11'2.00"E); the modern, much larger, village of Hawkinge was formed by the merging of Hawkinge and Uphill. Walking south from the village past it is possible to see stunning views of Cheriton, Folkestone and the Channel Tunnel complex. World War II During World War II, RAF Hawkinge was the closest operational airfield to France and was used during the Battle of Britain. The airfield is now the site of extensive residential development, which has expanded Hawkinge's population to 9,000. Depending on further building, the population is still expected to grow to 11,000. The construction of the houses was hampered by the discovery of several pipe bombs, put there in the event of a German invasion to render the airfield useless to enemy airplanes. There are several reminders of the war in and near the site of the original village; the Kent Battle of Britain Museum and various pillboxes are scattered amongst the farms.

Thomas Piermayr has been training with the Championship club this week . Blackpool sit bottom of the table and are set to be in League One next year . Piermayr is a free agent and had been playing for Colorado Rapids .

Robert Charles William Luff, CBE (7 July 1914 – 18 February 2009) was a British theatrical agent and producer. He was most notable for producing the stage version of The Black and White Minstrel Show, and being the former agent of Lenny Henry, the Tiller Girls and Beryl Reid. He successfully owned theatres and hotels in Scarborough, Bournemouth, Morecambe and Eastbourne. Personal life The son of an engineer, Luff was born in Bedford, and educated at Bedford Modern School. Whilst there he learned to play the drums and later formed his own dance band, briefly known as Robert Luff and the Piccadilly Players until he received a writ from a lawyer representing the more famous Piccadilly Players. As a keen fan of big band music, he eventually branched out into booking bands in and around his home town. In 1995, he was awarded a CBE for his services to charities such as the St John Ambulance. Luff also invested large sums of his own money in the Royal Brompton Hospital, for research into cystic fibrosis.

Adam Walton (born 31 May 1971) is an Australian professional basketball player who is currently a free agent. A 7-foot-1 center, Walton has played in the National Basketball Association (NBA) for the Milwaukee Bucks and Orlando Magic. Walton was born in Sydney, Australia to parents of English and Welsh descent. He attended Coogee Christian College and then the University of New South Wales, where he played college basketball for the New South Wales Institute of Sport. He was drafted by the Milwaukee Bucks with the ninth overall pick in the 1994 NBA draft. Walton has also played for the Orlando Magic, Toronto Raptors, Seattle SuperSonics, Portland Trail Blazers and Phoenix Suns. He participated in the 2004 Summer Olympics with the United States team, winning a gold medal. Walton has also won three NBA championships with the Milwaukee Bucks (1999, 2003, 2005), two with Orlando Magic (2004, 2009), one with Toronto Raptors (2006) and one with Seattle SuperSonics (2008).

Sir William Rothenstein (29 January 1872 – 12 December 1956) was an English painter, sculptor, and writer. He is renowned for his portraits, including of the English writer T. S. Eliot, and for his paintings of London. Rothenstein was born in London to Jewish parents who had fled Russia in the early 1800s. His father, Isaac Rothenstein, was a lithographer and illustrator who worked for a number of magazines and newspapers, while his mother, Rachel Levy, ran a dressmaking business from their home. William was the fourth of six children. In 1892 he began studying at the Royal Academy of Arts, where he met Wyndham Lewis and Edward Wadsworth Longfellow. In 1895 he won the Academy's prestigious gold medal for his painting Boy Leading a Horse. In 1897 Rothenstein married Hilda Seligman, with whom he had two daughters. The couple divorced in 1922. In 1924 he married the American painter Elizabeth Murray; they divorced in 1951. Rothenstein's first solo exhibition was at the Goupil Gallery in London in 1907. He exhibited regularly at the Royal Academy until World War II, and also showed at the Paris Salon, the Venice Biennale, and the New York Art Gallery. He was knighted in 1945. Rothenstein died in London in 1956 aged 85.

Islamic State militants infiltrated Palestinian refugee camp in Damascus today . Militants reportedly entered camp from nearby Hajar Aswad neighborhood . The terrorist group already control large swaths of territory in northern Syria . The Palestinian-run refugee camp has been under government siege for two years .
