Paula Hayes (born 1958 in Concord, Massachusetts) is an American actress and singer. Hayes is best known for her role as Kathy on the ABC sitcom, Full House, from 1987 to 1995. She has also appeared in several other television series, including The Golden Girls, Charles in Charge, and Home Improvement. Hayes has also had successful musical careers, releasing several albums and performing in concerts throughout the United States. Hayes was born in Concord, Massachusetts to a Catholic family. She was raised in the town of Marlborough, where she attended Marlborough Regional High School. After graduating from high school, she studied at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. She began her acting career in 1982 with a role on the daytime soap opera The Young and the Restless. In 1987, Hayes landed the role of Kathy Tanner on the ABC sitcom Full House. The show became one of the most popular programs on television during Hayes' time on it, running for six seasons from 1987 to 1995. Following Full House's cancellation, Hayes appeared in several television series, including The Golden Girls and Charles in Charge. She also released several albums and performed in concerts throughout the United States. In 2002, Hayes starred alongside John Stamos and Rebecca De Mornay in the romantic comedy film Grandma's Boy. That same year, she released her first album since Full House's cancellation, entitled Paula Hayes: A Memoir. In 2003, Hayes starred alongside John Goodman and Vera Farmiga in the comedy film Bedtime Stories

Wendell McKines (born August 18, 1988) is an American football wide receiver for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Georgia. McKines was signed by the Buccaneers as an undrafted free agent in 2012. He has also been a member of the Cleveland Browns and Tennessee Titans. McKines attended Griffin High School in Griffin, Georgia, where he played football and basketball. As a senior, he caught 78 passes for 1,705 yards and 21 touchdowns. He was named to the All-state first team as a wide receiver and honorable mention All-state as a cornerback. In track & field, McKines competed in the triple jump and shot put. As a junior, he recorded a throw of 21 feet, 10 inches (6.57 meters). As a senior, he jumped 19 feet, 1 inch (5.79 meters) in the triple jump and threw 57 feet, 2 inches (17.27 meters) in the shot put. McKines attended Georgia Tech where he played wide receiver for the Yellow Jackets from 2006 to 2010. He finished his career with 253 catches for 4,711 yards and 36 touchdowns. He was a three-time All-ACC selection and two-time ACC Offensive Player of the Year. After going undrafted in the 2012 NFL Draft, McKines signed with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers as an undrafted free agent on May 6, 2012. In his rookie season in 2012, he played in 10 games and caught

Piazza Grande is a social-democratic and progressive movement within the Democratic Party (PD), a political party in Italy. Its leader is Nicola Zingaretti, President of Lazio region since 2013 and current leader of the PD. He is considered a social democrat and one of the most prominent members of the party's left-wing. Piazza Grande's members are also known as Zingarettiani from the name of their leader. History The movement, which has never been organised as a formal faction, grew around Nicola Zingaretti, in late 2018. Born in 1965, Zingaretti became, during the 1990s, a prominent European youth leader, serving as National Secretary of the Left Youth, the youth-wing of the Democratic Party of the Left and as President of International Union of Socialist Youth. In 2004, he was elected Member of the European Parliament for the centre-left coalition The Olive Tree. Then, from 2008 he served as President of the Province of Rome, until 2013, when he was elected President of Lazio.

Helen Bright Clark (1840–1927) was a British-born American artist who spent most of her career in California. She is best known for her paintings of the American West, and is considered one of the most important painters of the region. Helen Bright Clark was born on October 4, 1840, in London, England. She moved to the United States with her family in 1853 and settled in San Francisco. Clark began her artistic career painting portraits and landscapes in the late 1860s. In 1871 she traveled to the American West and began to paint scenes of the region. She became one of the most important painters of the West and is considered one of its most important artists. Clark died on October 21, 1927, in Los Angeles. Her work is in the collections of many museums, including the Nevada Historical Society Museum in Reno and the Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

Farrukh Amonatov (; born 13 April 1978) is a Russian football coach and a former player. Amonatov played his entire professional career in FC Krylia Sovetov Samara. He made his debut in the Russian Premier League in 1999 with FC Krylia Sovetov Samara. He played in the Russian Cup finals twice, in 2001 and 2003. In 2001, he helped his team to lift the cup after a penalty shootout against FC Rostov. In 2003, he helped FC Krylia Sovetov Samara to become champions of Russia by beating FC Zenit Saint Petersburg on penalties after a 1–1 draw in the final. In 2006, Amonatov signed for FC Anzhi Makhachkala. He won the Russian Cup with Anzhi Makhachkala in 2007 and 2009. In 2009, he also won the Russian Super Cup with Anzhi Makhachkala after defeating FC Zenit Saint Petersburg on penalties. In July 2010, Amonatov signed for Scottish Premier League club Rangers on a three-year contract. On 8 November 2010, he made his debut for Rangers in a 2–1 defeat to Motherwell in the Scottish Premier League. On 24 January 2011, Amonatov scored his first goal for Rangers against Clydebank in the Scottish Cup. He left Rangers at the end of the 2011–12 season after failing to agree a new contract. On 1 July 2012, Amonatov signed for Indian

Vera Baird has allocated £ 500,000 to be given to Victims First Northumbria . Police and Crime Commissioner is a director at the newly set-up charity . Chief Constable Sue Sim is also on the organisation 's board of directors . Critics have accused Northumbria Police of creating ` its own soap opera '

Trichotillomania (TTM), also known as hair-pulling disorder, is an obsessive-compulsive disorder characterized by the repeated pulling out of one's hair. The hair may be pulled from any part of the body, including the scalp, eyebrows, eyelashes, beard, and pubic hair. Symptoms typically begin in adolescence or young adulthood and generally last for six months or more. TTM can severely disrupt one's personal hygiene and social life. It is estimated that about 1 million people in the United States are affected by TTM. There is no known cure for TTM, but various treatment options are available, including medication and psychotherapy. TTM is considered a chronic disorder, meaning that it typically lasts for more than six months. However, the majority of individuals who suffer from TTM experience remission (a period of time during which symptoms are absent) after treatment.

all three main parties' education spokesmen said they would have no problem with the next education secretary sending their children to private school . labour's tristram hunt answered first and said: 'yes. in certain circumstances' ukip's james arnott and the green party’s james humphreys also agreed that there was no problem with a future education secretary sending their children private .

Jodi Lee Anasta (née Gordon; born 1 February 1985) is an Australian actress and model. From 2005 to 2010 she portrayed Martha MacKenzie in Home and Away. Gordon won the Logie Award for Most Popular New Female Talent in 2006. Gordon competed in the eighth season of Dancing with the Stars and made her debut feature film appearance in The Cup (2011). She has also appeared in Underbelly: Badness and Camp. From 2016 to 2020, Gordon played English teacher Elly Conway in Neighbours. Early life Gordon was born in Mackay to Bronwyn and Ray. She has an older brother, Ben. Her father was born in New Zealand and is a New Zealander of Māori descent and her mother is Australian. From the age of 8, Gordon's family moved to various locations along the coast from Mackay, eventually settling in Sydney when she was 11. She played netball from the age of 12 to 16.

Ben Powers joined the cast of `` Good Times '' for its sixth and final season . He played Thelma 's husband Keith Anderson .

Mahakuta Pillar , also known as Makuta pillar, Magada stambha or Mangalesa Dharma Jayastambha, is a deep red sandstone pillar with an early 7th-century inscription of Early Western Chalukya era. It was found near Mahakuta group of Hindu temples near Badami, Karnataka, India. Inscribed with 16 lines of Sanskrit in Old Kannada script by king Mangalesha, it is an important and partly disputed source of historic information about the times of Badami Chalukya, the dynasty, and his influential father Pulakeshin I. Location The pillar was found in the 19th-century lying on the ground near the ruins of Mahakutesvara temple, one of the 7th-century group of temples at the Mahakuta natural springs (Bagalkot district). The site is about east from the historic cave temples of Badami. Its significance was re-discovered by colonial era archaeologists and scholars in the 1880s. The pillar was moved to Bijapur about 1920, and is now housed in the Gol Gumbaz Archaeological Museum, Vijayapura, Karnataka.

Four men have been caught on CCTV robbing a service station in Tecomba , Melbourne . The men filled a doona cover with $ 38,000 worth of cigarettes . However they failed to get the large loot in the boot . They decided to drag it alongside the car instead and lost about a third of their stash . The men are wanted for five similar break-ins in the area .

Ousted Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy is convicted of charges involving violence against protesters . But he is acquitted of murder . `` We promise you unexpected revolutionary surprises , '' a Muslim Brotherhood spokesman says .

Nemobiinae is a subfamily of the newly constituted Trigonidiidae, one of the cricket families. The type genus is Nemobius, which includes the wood cricket, but members of this subfamily may also be known as ground crickets or "pygmy field crickets". Characteristics Nemobiinae are typically small insects, generally less than long, and less robust than many other crickets (e.g. those in the Gryllidae). The thorax is densely bristled and the abdomen is also bristly. There are four (or sometimes three) pairs of long, movable spines above the tip of the abdomen. The ovipositor varies from being long, straight and needle-like, to short, curved and sabre-like. These crickets have wings of variable lengths and are generally brown, a suitable colour for concealment among the leaf litter and plant bases where they live. They are often active during the day and can be quite common in woodland and pastureland. They are omnivores. There are about two hundred species worldwide.

The emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis), also known as the Asian longhorned beetle or simply the ash borer, is a wood-eating beetle that is native to eastern Asia but has been found in many other parts of the world. It is also considered a serious pest of ash trees. The emerald ash borer is a small beetle, about 1.5 inches long and 0.75 inches wide, with a metallic greenish-black body and a black head and thorax. It has two light green-colored antennae and black legs. The emerald ash borer is one of several species of beetles that attack ash trees, but it is the only one that has caused significant damage to ash trees in North America. The emerald ash borer was first discovered in southeastern Michigan in 2002, and has since spread to 21 other states and two Canadian provinces. It is expected to spread further westward in North America, where it could destroy as many as 25% of all ash trees in affected areas. The beetle has also been found in Europe, China, Japan, and other parts of Asia. Ash trees are the most threatened tree species in North America because of the emerald ash borer's ability to rapidly breed and spread its infection throughout an area.

William John Cardinal Conway (22 January 1913 – 19 July 2002) was an English cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church. Born in London, Conway studied at the Royal College of Music and at the Pontifical Gregorian University, Rome. He was ordained to the priesthood on 28 May 1937. He served as a missionary in British Honduras from 1937 to 1939. After World War II he served as a professor of music at the London Oratory from 1945 to 1951 and at Fordham University from 1951 to 1955. Conway was appointed Bishop of Leeds on 9 May 1955 and ordained a bishop on the following 10 May. He served as Archbishop of Liverpool from 1965 to 1975, when he was made a cardinal by Pope Paul VI. He served as Prefect of the Congregation for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments from 1975 to 1979, and as President of the Pontifical Council for Culture from 1979 to 1989. He retired from his papal duties in 1989. Conway died in 2002. He is buried in Brompton Cemetery, London.

Wes Hohenstein is an American on-camera meteorologist for CBS affiliate KCBS-TV in Los Angeles, California. He joined CBS in 1994 and became the main meteorologist for their Los Angeles affiliate in 2002. In 2006, he was transferred to KCBS-TV's sister station in San Francisco, KRON-TV. Hohenstein is also a contributing writer for WeatherNation.com and has appeared as a weather expert on programs such as Good Morning America, The Early Show, and The Tonight Show with Jay Leno. Wes Hohenstein was born on October 21, 1964, in Santa Monica, California. He holds a degree in atmospheric science from the University of Wisconsin–Madison. Hohenstein began his career as a meteorologist with KMGH-TV in Denver, Colorado, in 1988. He next worked for WGN-TV in Chicago, Illinois, before joining CBS affiliate KCBS-TV in Los Angeles in 1994. Hohenstein has worked as the main meteorologist for KCBS-TV since 2002. He also contributes weather reports to WeatherNation.com and has appeared as a weather expert on programs such as Good Morning America, The Early Show, and The Tonight Show with Jay Leno. In 2006, Hohenstein was transferred to KRON-TV in San Francisco, where he continues to work as a contributing writer for WeatherNation.com and an on-camera meteorologist.

Edward Grant Barrow (May 10, 1868 – December 15, 1953) was an American manager and front office executive in Major League Baseball. He served as the field manager of the Detroit Tigers and Boston Red Sox. He served as business manager (de facto general manager) of the New York Yankees from 1921 to 1939 and as team president from 1939 to 1945, and is credited with building the Yankee dynasty. Barrow was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1953. Born in a covered wagon in Springfield, Illinois, Barrow worked as a journalist and soap salesman before entering the business of baseball by selling concessions at games. From there, Barrow purchased minor league baseball teams, also serving as team manager, and served as president of the Atlantic League. After managing the Tigers in 1903 and 1904 and returning to the minor leagues, Barrow became disenchanted with baseball, and left the game to operate a hotel.

The general classification (or the GC) in cycling is a ranking system used to determine the overall placing of cyclists in a race. The system is based on the finishing times of the cyclists in a race, with the first cyclist across the line receiving a ranking of 1, the second cyclist 2 etc., up to the cyclist who finishes last, who receives a ranking of 10. The GC was first introduced in 1903 by Jules Durand, and was originally a system for determining the order of cyclists in a race. The system was based on the number of minutes that each cyclist had been leading at the end of the race. However, this system was not very accurate, and it was not until 1912 that the GC was changed to its current form. The GC is one of the most important rankings in cycling, and is often used to determine which riders will be selected for major races. For example, if there is a major race that has a number of riders who are qualified for qualification based on their GC ranking, then the riders who are ranked first through fourth will be selected for qualification.

Charles Henry Douglass (February 1870–1940) was a leading businessman in Georgia State in his time and continues to be remembered today for his contributions to the African American community through his historical Douglass Theatre. He was a very wealthy man in his time and was a great community leader for equality. He was very reputable in the arts, for he was a part of TOBA (Theatre Owners Booker Association) and managed the Florida Minstrels and Comedy Company. He opened the Douglass Theatre in Macon, Georgia, and continued to be a prominent leader within his community. He ran his theatre until 1940 when he died. Throughout his life, Douglass made several contributions to his community and city. "Indeed, thanks to the vision of Charles Henry Douglass, the Douglass Theatre in Macon became a preeminent entertainment venue for African American Georgians outside of Atlanta. Today, with the restored Douglass Theatre again in operation, the inspiring legacy of Charles H. Douglass lives on in Macon". Early life Charles Henry Douglass was born on February in 1870 in Macon, Georgia. His father, Charles Douglass, was a former slave from Virginia who became a carpenter. Charles grew up with his father, his mother Ellen, and his two sisters in a one bedroom house that his father built. To supplement the family income, Charles worked at a very young age peddling wood and vegetables. He also chopped cotton for fifteen cents a day. Since a young age, Douglass had interest in the arts and theatre. After his parents died, he continued to work and supported his sisters until they married. Soon after his sisters were married he left Macon and worked a series of various jobs.

Frederick 'Fred' Robert Beart (6 July 1850 – 4 March 1895) was an English first-class cricketer and British Army officer. The son of Robert Beart, a brick and tile manufacturer, he was born at Godmanchester in July 1850. He was educated at Marlborough College, before going up to Wadham College, Oxford. While studying at Oxford, Beart made a single appearance in first-class cricket for Oxford University against the Marylebone Cricket Club at Oxford in 1871. Batting once in the match, he was dismissed without scoring in the Oxford first-innings by Frank Farrands. After graduating from Oxford, he was commissioned as a lieutenant in the Huntingdon Militia. He was promoted to captain in March 1880 and the following year in July he was appointed as a justice of the peace for Huntingdonshire. By 1886, Beart was serving with the King's Royal Rifle Corps and in April of that year he was promoted to major. He died at Godmanchester in March 1895. His son, Charles, also played first-class cricket.

Brain herniation is a potentially deadly side effect of very high pressure within the skull that occurs when a part of the brain is squeezed across structures within the skull. The brain can shift across such structures as the falx cerebri, the tentorium cerebelli, and even through the foramen magnum (the hole in the base of the skull through which the spinal cord connects with the brain). Herniation can be caused by a number of factors that cause a mass effect and increase intracranial pressure (ICP): these include traumatic brain injury, intracranial hemorrhage, or brain tumor. Herniation can also occur in the absence of high ICP when mass lesions such as hematomas occur at the borders of brain compartments. In such cases local pressure is increased at the place where the herniation occurs, but this pressure is not transmitted to the rest of the brain, and therefore does not register as an increase in ICP.

Maurice René Michel Jacob was a French philosopher born on October 15, 1895 in the city of Algiers in Algeria. He died on July 14, 1986 in Paris. Jacob is best known for his work on phenomenology, existentialism, and existential psychotherapy. Maurice Jacob was born in Algiers on October 15, 1895 into a Jewish family of modest means. He trained as a psychoanalyst at the École Freudienne in Paris. In 1938 he founded the journal "L'Évaluation" which was later renamed "Existentiale". He also served as the editor of the journal "Réalité" from 1951-1954. Jacob's principal philosophical work is his book "Existentialism and Human Emotions" (1946). This work presents a phenomenological analysis of human emotions, and develops a theory of existential angst. It has been influential in the development of existential psychology. Jacob also published works on phenomenology, philosophy of history, and autobiography. He died on July 14, 1986 in Paris.

Mostafa Karim Beigi (; 21 April 1983 - 27 December 2009) was one of the victims of the Ashura protests, which occurred in Tehran, Iran on 27 December 2009 to protest the outcome of the 2009 Iranian presidential election, which the demonstrators believed to be rigged. A statement issued by the Tehran Metropolitan Police Headquarters on December 29, 2009 announced the death of an unidentified individual as a result of falling from the bridge on the day of Ashura. After 15–16 days of search for him in hospitals and prisons, his family was finally able to identify his body in the forensic department of Kahrizak detention center. According to his mother, the forensic department declared the cause of his death as "a strike of a sharp and hard object to the rib cage, however he was shot in his forehead from the left, his head had no backside”.

The Spanish web is an aerial circus skill in which a performer climbs and performs various tricks on an apparatus resembling a vertically hanging rope. It is similar in appearance and performance style to the corde lisse, but with the addition of loops on the rope for hands or feet, permitting one to perform a variety of spinning motions. The name refers to both the apparatus and the performance. Rope structure The apparatus is akin to a larger kernmantle rope. Unbraided cotton or polyster-blend rope is pulled through a soft, round, cotton sleeve two inches in diameter (a "web"). An eye is made in one end of the web, to which a swivel is attached. That is suspended at one end from the overhead rigging. Towards the top of the web, a hand, foot or neck loop is attached to the main rope through which a performer will secure an ankle, wrist or their neck and be able to hang freely while spinning.

He is known for his role as Josh on the U.S. television sitcom The Office (2005–2013), for which he was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series in 2009 and 2011, and for his recurring role as Dr. James Harris on the ABC medical drama Grey's Anatomy (2005–2015). May was born in Santa Barbara, California, the son of Barbara (née Hoyt), a homemaker, and Bradley May, an electrical engineer. He has one sister, Casey. When he was five years old, his family moved to Duncanville, Texas. After graduating from Duncanville High School in 1989, May attended Southern Methodist University in Dallas, where he studied theatre. In 1993, May moved to Los Angeles to pursue an acting career. He appeared in several television commercials before landing his first role on the U.S. television sitcom The Office as Josh Lyman. The show ran from 2005 to 2013 and earned May three Primetime Emmy Awards nominations: Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series in 2009 and 2011 and Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series in 2006. Eureka (Wiyot: Jaroujiji, Hupa: do'-wi-lotl-ding, Karuk: uuth) is a city located in Humboldt County, California, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 7,019. The city is named after the Greek island of Euboea. Eureka is located on the north bank of the Eel River, 25 miles (40 km) south-southwest of Redding and 75 miles (120 km) north-northwest of Sacramento. According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of 7.1 square miles (18.3 km²), all land. The 2010 United States Census reported that Eureka had a population of 7,019. The population density was 1,841.5 people per square mile (711.8/km²). Seodaemun Prison History Hall is a museum and former prison in Seodaemun-gu, Seoul, South Korea. It was constructed beginning in 1907. The prison was opened on October 21, 1908, under the name Gyeongseong Gamok. During the early part of the Japanese colonial period it was known as Keijo Prison (, the Japanese pronunciation of Gyeongseong Gamok). Its name was changed to Seodaemun Prison in 1923, and it later had several other names. History The prison was used during the Japanese colonial period to imprison Korean liberation activists, and could originally hold around 500 inmates. It had a separate facility for women and young girls. In 1911, Kim Koo was imprisoned. He was one of the more important figures in the Korean liberation movement. In 1919, shortly after the March 1st Movement, the number of imprisoned increased drastically. About three thousand liberation activists were imprisoned, and shortly before the colonization ended in 1945, the number of prisoners was at 2980. Among imprisoned after the March 1st Movement was Ryu Gwansun, who died from the torture inflicted on her.

is a Japanese avant-garde playwright, theatre director, author, actor, and songwriter. He was at the forefront of the Angura ("underground") theatre movement in Japan. Career Graduating from Meiji University, Kara formed his own theatre troupe, Jōkyō Gekijo (Situation Theatre), in 1963. They began performing in a red tent in Hanazono Shrine in Shinjuku in 1967. According to the theatre historian, David G. Goodman, "Kara conceived his theatre in the premodern mold of kabuki—not the sanitized, aestheticized variety performed today, but the erotic, anarchic, plebeian sort performed during the Edo period (1600–1868) by itinerant troupes of actors who were rejected by bourgeois society as outcasts and 'riverbed beggars.' Emulating their itinerant forebears, Kara and his troupe performed throughout Japan in their mobile red tent." Kara won the Kishida Prize for Drama for Shojo kamen (The Virgin's Mask) in 1969, and the Akutagawa Prize for his novel Sagawa-kun kara no tegami in 1982. He later became a professor at Yokohama National University.

Fengxing Milk Co. is a Chinese dairy company that ranks as one of the largest in the world. The company was founded in 1949 by Wu Zhaohui, a wealthy entrepreneur and landowner who had acquired a considerable amount of dairy farmland in Henan province. Fengxing Milk Co. is headquartered in Zhengzhou, Henan province, and operates more than 3,000 farms throughout China. The company produces a wide range of dairy products, including milk, cheese, yogurt, ice cream and butter. Fengxing is also one of China’s leading producers of raw milk powder. In 2013, the company generated revenues of approximately US$5 billion. Fengxing Milk Co. is a leading player in the Chinese dairy market and has a reputation for high-quality products. The company’s products are sold in more than 120 countries around the world and are used by brands such as Nestlé, Danone and Unilever. Fengxing is also one of the world’s largest producers of raw milk powder.

Vera Ignatyevna Mukhina (; ; ; – 6 October 1953) was a prominent Soviet sculptor and painter. She was nicknamed "the queen of Soviet sculpture". Biography Mukhina was born 1889 in Riga, Russian Empire into a wealthy merchant family, and lived at 23/25 Turgeneva Street, where a memorial plaque has now been placed. Mukhina's ancestors lived in Riga after the Patriotic War of 1812. The family was well-to-do: in 1937 Mukhina inherited 4 million lats from her grandfather. She spent her childhood and youth (1892-1904) in Feodosia where her father took her considering his daughter's health (Vera was two years old when her mother died of tuberculosis). In Feodosia the future artist received her first drawing and painting lessons. She lived there until 1904 when her father died. Mukhina and her older sister Maria were sheltered by uncles and aunts who lived in Kursk, where Mukhina went to high school which she graduated from with honors.

Sean Faircloth (born May 23, 1960) is an American politician who is the U.S. Representative for North Carolina's 10th congressional district, serving since 2013. He is a member of the Republican Party. Faircloth was born in Chapel Hill, North Carolina and raised in the town of Carrboro. He received his BA from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1982, and his JD from the University of North Carolina School of Law in 1986. He served in the United States Marine Corps from 1981 to 1983. After completing his military service, Faircloth practiced law in Carrboro for two years before beginning his career in public service as a municipal attorney for Carrboro in 1988. He served as town solicitor from 1992 to 1995, and as mayor of Carrboro from 1995 to 2001. Faircloth was elected to the North Carolina House of Representatives in 2000, serving until 2002. He won election to the U.S. House of Representatives in 2004, defeating incumbent Democrat Mike McNeill by a margin of 57% to 43%. In Congress, Faircloth has been a leading conservative voice on Capitol Hill and has served on the House Committee on Education and Sciences and the House Committee on Appropriations. In November 2012, Faircloth won re-election to a fourth term by defeating Democratic nominee Sue Myrick 58% to 42%. Johann, Johannes or Hans Wechtlin was a German Renaissance artist, active between at least 1502 and 1526, whose woodcuts are his only certainly surviving work. He was the most prolific producer of German chiaroscuro woodcuts, printed in two or more colours, during their period in fashion, though most of his output was of book illustrations. Life He was born in about 1480-85, presumably in Strasbourg, then in Germany and now in France, where his father, also called Hans Wechtlin, was a cloth merchant. Most of his identified works are woodcut book illustrations, the first, scenes from the Life of Christ, are from a Strasbourg book of 1502, and the last is a Strasbourg title-page of 1526. In 1505 he began a year of employment as a painter to René II, Duke of Lorraine in Nancy. After he left Nancy he was in Wittenberg in 1506-7, where he must have met the court painter, Lucas Cranach the Elder. He became a citizen of Strasbourg in 1514, and by 1519 was a master of the painter's guild there.

Edward Burton Hughes (1905 – 6 June 1967) was an American poet, editor, and critic. Hughes was born in Lawrence, Kansas, the son of Ruth (née Pyle) and Burton Hughes. He attended the University of Kansas and then Stanford University, where he received his B.A. in 1925. He then attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he received his M.A. in 1927. Hughes moved to New York City in 1929 and became an associate editor at The Dial magazine. He also taught at several universities before becoming a full professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, in 1952. Hughes was a highly influential critic and editor during the mid-20th century. He is most well-known for his work as editor of The Paris Review from its inception in 1953 until his death in 1967, as well as for his poetry collections such as The Tower Beyond Tragedy (1944), The City of the Sun (1946), and The Great American Songbook (1959). He also wrote the libretto for Richard Strauss's opera Elektra (1953). Hughes died on June 6, 1967 in Santa Monica, California at the age of 66 after a long battle with cancer.

Roy Díaz González (born 1953) is a Spanish-born Mexican journalist and author who has worked as a correspondent for several news agencies, including Televisa, in various parts of the world. He is best known for his work as a foreign correspondent for the newspaper El País, where he was a senior editor from 2001 to 2006. Díaz González has written several books about Mexico, Latin America and Spain, including El País: La historia de una familia (1995), El imperio de la información (2004) and La Guerra sucia (2007). He has also written for magazines such as Fortune, Der Spiegel and Vanity Fair. Díaz González was born in 1953 in Madrid, Spain to a Mexican father and Spanish mother. He grew up in Mexico City and studied journalism at the Universidad Iberoamericana. In 1976, he joined Televisa as a correspondent in Nicaragua. He has since worked as a foreign correspondent for the television network in various parts of the world, including Africa, Asia, Europe, South America and the Middle East. He has also served as an editor at El País, where he was a senior editor from 2001 to 2006.

Ronald Cordell Sims (born July 5, 1948) is an American politician and a member of the Republican Party who is currently serving as the United States Representative for Illinois' 13th congressional district. Ron Sims was born in Chicago, Illinois, on July 5, 1948. He graduated from Maine South High School in 1966 and earned a B.A. from the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign in 1970. He served in the United States Marine Corps from 1970 to 1974, achieving the rank of captain. After his military service, Sims worked as a real estate agent and then entered politics as a city councilman in Arlington Heights, Illinois. He was subsequently elected to the Illinois House of Representatives, where he served from 1979 to 1983. He was then elected to the United States House of Representatives, serving from 1983 to 1999. Sims was re-elected seven times and served until his retirement in 2003. In 1999, he was named chairman of the House Republican Conference, a post he held until 2003. In 2003, Sims retired from Congress and founded RCS Capital Advisors, a financial advisory firm. In 2006, he entered politics again as the Republican nominee for Illinois Attorney General, but lost to Democrat Lisa Madigan. Sims is currently serving as the Representative for Illinois' 13th congressional district after winning the November 6th general election against Democratic nominee Sean Casten.

Thomas Amadeus Kalil (born October 4, 1963) is an expert on technology and innovation policy, and is currently the Chief Innovation Officer at Schmidt Futures. He was previously Deputy Director for Policy in the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy under President Obama, and was also the Senior Advisor for Science, Technology and Innovation for the United States National Economic Council. Career Kalil is the son of Ronald and Katherine Kalil, both professors at the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health in Madison. He earned a bachelor's degree in political science and international economics from the University of Wisconsin at Madison. Kalil completed graduate work at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. Kalil worked in the issues departments on two Democratic presidential campaigns, 1988 and 1992. His work included writing position papers and briefing the candidate on a wide range of policy issues, experiences he later described as being "like boot camp for policy wonks."

The Paipai (Pai pai, Pa'ipai, Akwa'ala, Yakakwal) are an indigenous people of the Philippines. They are the second largest tribe in the Philippines, with a population of around 1.5 million people. The Paipai live in the provinces of Bulacan, Pampanga, and Nueva Ecija, on both the central and northern coastlines of the country. They are concentrated in the municipalities of Calumpit, Mabalacat, Malabon, Navotas, Malolos, San Ildefonso, and Valenzuela. The Paipai are also found in smaller numbers in the municipalities of Angeles City and Olongapo City. The Paipai speak the Paipai language, which is related to the Kawasakian languages spoken in Japan and Korea. Some linguists believe that the language may be a remnant of a proto-Kawasakian language that was spoken in Taiwan or mainland China before it was displaced by Sinitic languages. The Paipai have a rich culture that is based on their traditional animistic beliefs. They are a seafaring people who are skilled in sailing traditional outrigger canoes and fishhooks. They also manufacture copper tools and ornaments, as well as pottery. The Paipai have a strong religious tradition that centers on ancestor worship. They also perform ceremonies to honor their deities such as Ilang-ilang and Palala-palala.

Honoré-Victorin Daumier (; February 26, 1808February 10, 1879) was a French artist, caricaturist and political cartoonist. He is considered one of the greatest painters and cartoonists in history. Daumier was born in Paris, France, to a middle-class family. After studying law, he began his career as a caricaturist in 1829. He produced over 2,000 cartoons and caricatures during a 50-year career, and is best known for his lithographs and paintings of people in desperate situations. In 1849, he joined the French Communist Party. Daumier's work was often critical of the French government and aristocracy. He was imprisoned several times for his political cartoons. The Planning Act 2008 is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. It gives local authorities the power to make planning decisions, and it replaces the Planning Acts 1985 to 2004. The Act sets out the principles that local authorities must follow when making planning decisions. It gives local authorities the power to decide what is an appropriate use for land, and it gives them the power to decide how much land should be used for different types of development. The Act also gives local authorities the power to make decisions about whether certain types of development should be allowed. For example, local authorities can decide whether a development should be allowed if it would affect the environment, if it would cause a traffic congestion problem, or if it would increase the risk of crime. The Act also gives local authorities the power to make decisions about where new developments should be built. They can decide where new developments should be located, or they can decide how many new developments should be built in a particular area. The Act also gives local authorities the power to make decisions about how land should be used for public purposes. They can decide which public areas should be used for which purposes, and they can decide how much land should be used for public purposes. The Act also gives local authorities the power to make decisions about who should have access to land. They can decide who should have access to land for commercial reasons, for residential reasons, or for other reasons.

Robert Francis Taft (January 9, 1932 – November 2, 2018) was an American Jesuit priest, first in the Russian Greek Catholic Church and later an archimandrite of the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church. An expert in Oriental liturgy, he was a professor at the Pontifical Oriental Institute from 1975 to 2011 and its Vice-rector from 1995 to 2001. Biography Taft was born in Providence, Rhode Island, into the Taft family notable for their contribution to American politics. Taft entered the novitiate of the Society of Jesus on August 14, 1949. He did his initial spiritual and academic training in philosophy at the former Weston College in Weston, Massachusetts. During his period of regency that followed, he taught for three years at Baghdad Jesuit College. He returned to the United States in 1959 and pursued a graduate degree in Russian at Fordham University. He was ordained a priest of the Russian Catholic Church on June 7, 1963.

O'Donnell + Tuomey is an architectural practice located in Chicago, Illinois. Founded in 1978, the firm is known for its design of high-end residential and commercial projects. O'Donnell + Tuomey was founded in 1978 by Michael O’Donnell and John Tuomey. The practice has since designed a wide range of projects, including high-end residential and commercial buildings. Projects of note include the 20-story Helmut Jahn-designed tower at 555 North Michigan Avenue in Chicago, the adaptive re-use of the historic Carson Pirie Scott building in Streeterville, and the renovation of the Chicago Athletic Association building into a luxury hotel. The team at O’Donnell + Tuomey is composed of architects and engineers with backgrounds in structural engineering, construction management, and real estate development. The practice has a reputation for taking a innovative approach to design, with a focus on sustainability and functionality.

Gary Victor was born on 9 July 1958 in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. He is the lead singer, songwriter and founder of the Australian rock band TISM. Stuart Davis (December 7, 1892 – June 21, 1978) was an American painter, printmaker, and sculptor. He is noted for his Surrealist paintings and prints, as well as his large-scale public sculptures. Davis was born in Ithaca, New York, to a family of artists. His paternal grandfather, Nicholas Davis, was a landscape painter and etcher who taught at the National Academy of Design in New York City. His father, Edward Stuart Davis, was a sculptor who worked in the classical tradition. Davis's mother was the artist Alma Lutz Davis (1871–1953). Davis studied painting at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts (1912–1915) under Thomas Anshutz and Karl Buehrlen. He then moved to New York City and continued his studies at the National Academy of Design under William Merritt Chase (1916–1920). At the age of twenty-one he had his first solo exhibition at the Daniel-Henry Kahn Gallery in New York City. In 1923, Davis met André Breton, who became a major influence on his work. The two men exchanged ideas and collaborated on several projects. In 1924 Breton published one of Davis's earliest essays, "The Spiritual in Art", in which he argued that modern art should aim to express spiritual truths rather than realistic images. Theriophily (or animalitarianism) is "the inversion of the basic human instincts of self-preservation and procreation, whereby an individual seeks to cause or encourage the death of another creature in order to gratify their own desires or satisfy their curiosity." Theriophily is a strange and unusual form of behavior that some animals display that has no obvious benefit to themselves. Rather, it is motivated by a desire to cause or encourage the death of another creature, often for the pleasure or curiosity it brings. This strange inclination can be found in a wide variety of creatures, from spiders to lions, and it has been observed in both predators and prey. Although theriophily may seem morbid or even evil, it is actually widespread and appears to have evolutionary benefits. In some cases, theriophily can help an animal survive by securing food or prey that would otherwise be unavailable, and it can also serve as a form of social communication. Despite its unusual nature, theriophily is fascinating and worthy of further study.

Sándor Jávorka (12 March 1883 - 28 October 1953) was a Hungarian actor, director and screenwriter. He is best known for his work in the Weimar Republic, where he was a leading figure of the Hungarian film industry. Jávorka was born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (now Hungary) on 12 March 1883. After completing studies at the Academy of Drama and Music in Budapest, he began his career as an actor in 1903. He made his stage debut in 1906 and became a leading actor of the National Theater in Budapest in 1911. In 1915, he left Hungary to take up an acting engagement at the Berlin State Theatre. During World War I, Jávorka served in the Austrian army and later fled Germany after its defeat in 1918. He moved to Prague, where he began working as an actor and director at the National Theater. In 1923, he moved to Berlin, where he continued to work as a director and actor at various theaters. He also worked as a screenwriter for several German films. Jávorka returned to Hungary in 1933 and became a leading figure of the Hungarian film industry. He directed more than thirty films between 1933 and 1953, most notably the historical drama "The Pest County" (1937). Jávorka died on 28 October 1953 in Budapest.

Alastair Martin Gordon Scott (born 31 March 1961) is a former Scottish cricketer who played for Middlesex, Surrey and England. He was nicknamed "Scotty" by his teammates and is widely regarded as one of the greatest batsmen in the history of the game. Scott was born in Edinburgh, Scotland. After playing cricket for Edinburgh University and Scotland, he made his debut for Middlesex in 1982. He quickly became a regular member of the team and in 1984 he scored his first century, batting at number six in the team's victory over Sussex. The following year he scored 1,000 runs for the first time and in 1986 he was awarded his first international cap, playing against India. In 1988 he joined Surrey and although he only played five league matches for them, he achieved great success with them in the Benson & Hedges Cup, scoring 2,500 runs in total. In 1990 he scored his first double century (227 against Gloucestershire) and two years later he became only the fifth batsman in history to score 10,000 runs in all first-class cricket. His final season as a player was 1994–95, when he scored 1,865 runs at an average of 44.36. After retirement from playing cricket, Scott became a television commentator and also worked as a cricket coach for Middlesex County Cricket Club and Surrey County Cricket Club. He has also written a book about his life as a cricketer entitled "Great Batters: Alastair Scott".

Wishbone Ash are a British rock band who achieved success in the early and mid-1970s. Their popular albums included Wishbone Ash (1970), Pilgrimage (1971), Argus (1972), Wishbone Four (1973), There's the Rub (1974), and New England (1976). Wishbone Ash are noted for their extensive use of harmony twin lead guitars, which had been attracting electric blues bands since Jeff Beck and Jimmy Page had played together in the Yardbirds in 1966. Their contributions helped Andy Powell and Ted Turner to be voted "Two of the Ten Most Important Guitarists in Rock History" (Traffic magazine 1989), and to appear in the "Top 20 Guitarists of All Time" (Rolling Stone). Melody Maker (1972) described Powell and Turner as "the most interesting two guitar team since the days when Beck and Page graced The Yardbirds". Several notable bands have cited Wishbone Ash as an influence, including Iron Maiden, Van Halen, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Thin Lizzy, Metallica, Dream Theater, Overkill and Opeth.

Acharya M. R. Rajesh, (born 31 May 1935) is an Indian philosopher and a distinguished professor at the University of Hyderabad. He is also the founder president of the Acharya M. R. Rajesh Research Foundation and a member of the National Academy of Sciences, India. Rajesh was born on 31 May 1935 in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh, India. After completing his secondary education from the Hindu High School, Rajesh earned a BA (Hons) degree in Philosophy from Osmania University in 1957. He then completed his MA and PhD degrees in philosophy from the same university in 1962 and 1965 respectively. Rajesh began his career as a lecturer at the Osmania University in 1961 before being appointed a professor at the same institution in 1978. He has also served as the vice-chancellor of the University of Hyderabad from 1986 to 1989 and again from 1999 to 2003. He has also been a visiting professor at universities in United States, United Kingdom, Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, Germany, Sweden and Norway. Rajesh's research focuses on the philosophy of religion and specifically on the theories of Hinduism's six orthodox schools of thought: Advaita Vedanta, Vishishtadvaita Vedanta, Dvaita Vedanta, Yoga Vedanta, Mimamsa Vedanta and Samkhya philosophy. Shaving is the removal of hair, by cutting it with a blade or other instrument. The term can refer to the act of shaving as well as the equipment used for shaving. Shaving is an ancient practice that has been around for thousands of years. It is thought to have originated in Egypt and was used by Pharaohs as a form of hygiene. Early shaving techniques involved using sandpaper to remove hair, but this was eventually replaced by blades. Blades are still the most common method of shaving today, although there are now also electric and wet shaving products available. Shaving can be done with either a straight razor or a safety razor. Straight razors are more expensive, but they are more difficult to use and require more skill. Safety razors are easier to use, but they can be less sharp and may cause nicks and cuts. Both types of razor produce a similar result, though straight razors are generally considered to be more aesthetically pleasing.

Cananeuretus is an extinct genus of antilocaprid, a type of large, long-horned antelope endemic to North America. The genus Cananeuretus was first described by American paleontologist Othniel Charles Marsh in 1875. The type species is C. montanus, which is known from a single specimen discovered in the Clovis Formation of New Mexico. The genus is known from a total of six specimens, all of which are from the Clovis Formation. All six specimens are preserved as complete and articulated skeletons. Cananeuretus is the most basal antilocaprid genus known from North America. The antilocaprid family was first identified in North America by American paleontologist Edward Drinker Cope in 1881, and includes the genera Antilocapra, Grévy's zebra, and hippocampus. Cananeuretus is distinguished from other antilocaprids by its relatively small size (the largest specimen measured only 1.5 meters in length), its short horns (which are only 2 to 3 centimeters long), and its primitive dentition (which lacks anyspecialized chewing teeth). Cananeuretus is known from a wide range of North American habitats, including open grasslands, woodlands, and desertscrub. Angel Island is an island in San Francisco Bay. The entire island is included within Angel Island State Park, administered by California State Parks. The island, a California Historical Landmark, has been used by humans for a variety of purposes, including seasonal hunting and gathering by indigenous peoples, water and timber supply for European ships, ranching by Mexicans, United States military installations, a United States Public Health Service Quarantine Station, and a U.S. Bureau of Immigration inspection and detention facility. The Angel Island Immigration Station, on the northeast corner of the island, which has been designated a National Historic Landmark, was where officials detained, inspected, and examined approximately one million immigrants, who primarily came from Asia. Under the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, the first United States law to restrict a group of immigrants based on their race, nationality, and class, all arriving Chinese immigrants were to be examined by immigration or customs agents. John Samuel Darrough (April 6, 1841 – August 14, 1920) was a Union Army soldier in the American Civil War and a recipient of the United States military's highest decoration, the Medal of Honor, for his actions during a skirmish near Eastport, Mississippi. Born in Kentucky, Darrough moved to Illinois as a child and enlisted in the Union Army from that state. While participating in a mission to destroy a Confederate railway, Darrough and others were stranded on the shore of the Tennessee River under intense enemy fire. Although he had found a canoe with which to cross the river safely, he voluntarily returned to the Confederate-held shore to rescue a fellow soldier who was in danger of drowning. Early life Darrough was born Maysville, Kentucky, to Samuel Vogan and Ricey Ann Quaintance Darrough. By 1850, the family had moved to neighboring Mason County, where they owned a large farm. In 1855 they moved again, this time to Iroquois County, Illinois, where Darrough would live the rest of his life.

Kalimantan is the Indonesian portion of the island of Borneo. It comprises 73% of the island's area. The non-Indonesian parts of Borneo are Brunei and East Malaysia. In Indonesia, "Kalimantan" refers to the whole island of Borneo. In 2019, Indonesian President Joko Widodo proposed that Indonesia's capital be moved to Kalimantan., and in January 2022 Indonesian legislature approved the proposal. The shift is expected to take up to 10 years. Etymology The name Kalimantan is derived from the Sanskrit word Kalamanthana, which means "burning weather island", or island with a very hot temperature, referring to its hot and humid tropical climate. It consists of the two words kal[a] ("time, season, period") and manthan[a] ("boiling, churning, burning"). The indigenous people of the eastern region of Borneo referred to their island as Pulu K'lemantan or "Kalimantan" when the Portuguese explorer Jorge de Menezes made contact with them in 1847. Its association with the island and its people has also been attributed to British scientist and colonial administrator Charles Hose from the early 20th century.

is a Japanese linguist who is currently a professor at the University of Tokyo. He specializes in the study of Japanese grammar, with a particular focus on the Japanese language in the context of globalization. Satoshi Kinsui was born on October 5, 1954 in Tokyo, Japan. He received his undergraduate degree from Waseda University in 1976, and his graduate degree from the University of Tokyo in 1982. Kinsui has been a professor at the University of Tokyo since 1988. He has also been a visiting professor at various universities around the world, including Columbia University (1983), Cornell University (1989), Yale University (1998), and the University of Sydney (2011). Kinsui has authored or co-authored more than 100 books and articles on various aspects of Japanese grammar, including Japanese as a Lingua Franca: A Grammar-Based Approach (1996), The Grammar of Contemporary Japanese (2003), and The Grammar of Japan's Historical Linguistics (2009). He has also edited or co-edited several books, including The Oxford Handbook of Japanese Grammar (2008) and The Handbook of East Asian Linguistics (2010).

UGC NET or NTA-UGC-NET, is the examination conducted by University Grants Commission (UGC) for admission in undergraduate and postgraduate courses in universities in India. The National Eligibility Test (NET) was introduced by the University Grants Commission (UGC) in 1960 to assess the academic potential of candidates seeking admission into undergraduate and postgraduate courses in Indian universities. The examination is conducted by the UGC NET Centre at various centres across the country. Candidates who have scored at least 50% in their Class XIIth or equivalent examination are eligible to take the NET. The examination is divided into two parts, an objective section and a subjective section. The objective section consists of a paper based test that covers mathematics, scientific reasoning, English language and literature, and computer science. The subjective section includes an essay on a chosen topic. The NET provides a valid measure of academic potential and is considered one of the most important examinations for admission into undergraduate and postgraduate courses in universities in India.

Earle O. Latham (1908–1999) was born in Lowell, Massachusetts. He attended Boston University, Rutgers University School of Banking and Columbia University Graduate School of Management. During 46 years of employment, Latham rose from a messenger to serve as the First Vice President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. He was designated as a special emissary for the U.S. Department of State to the State of Ethiopia in 1963-1964 to establish the National Bank of Ethiopia. Latham married Harriet Irene Morrison of Malden, Massachusetts in 1936. They had two children; Patricia Ruth Latham (1938–1956) and O. Bradley Latham (1940-  ). Earle Latham taught banking at Harvard University Extension School. He was an officer of the American Bankers Association and served on many boards of charitable organizations, such as the United Way. Charles Alexander Moose (August 4, 1953 – March 25, 2013) was an American screenwriter, producer and director. He was best known for his work on the sitcoms Seinfeld and Curb Your Enthusiasm. Moose was born in Hollywood, California. He attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he studied political science. He briefly worked as a journalist before turning to writing full-time. His first screenplay, which he wrote while still a student at Berkeley, was for the 1987 comedy film My Best Friend's Wedding. After writing for such shows as The Larry Sanders Show and Cheers, Moose co-created and wrote the acclaimed sitcom Seinfeld in 1989. The series ran for nine seasons and won multiple awards, including Emmy Awards for Outstanding Comedy Series and Best Screenplay. Following Seinfeld's conclusion in 1998, Moose wrote and produced the HBO comedy series Curb Your Enthusiasm. The show ran for six seasons and earned nominations for both an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe Award. Moose also directed several episodes of Curb Your Enthusiasm. In 2012, he published his memoir, Notes from a Small Mountain: A Writer's Life in the Wilderness. That same year, he directed an episode of the FX anthology series Fargo. He died from pancreatic cancer on March 25, 2013 at the age of 61.

Lazzara Media Production Network (LMPN.tv) and Medical Doctor Internet Television (MDiTV) are health sciences media networks founded by Robert R. Lazzara M.D., Diederik Sjardijn and Thomas Overbey. Portland, OR served as the headquarters for its production and administrative operations. The personalization of media through the wider use of portable devices and broader Internet-connectivity has given rise to a number of websites that offer content that is typically found through traditional media outlets; such as network television and cable television. The Nielsen Company recently reported year-over-year online video streams per viewer and time per viewer were up 13 percent from December 2009 compared to December 2008. A report from the Portland Business Journal stated that "MDiTV is targeting a growing market opportunity" by making its content "available for iPads, smart phones and new TV devices in development by Apple and Google." This strategy mirrors other online syndicated video content providers, like Hulu.com.

Nick Sinclair (born 1963) is a British photographer. The National Portrait Gallery in London holds 148 of his portrait photographs. After graduating from West Surrey College of Art and Design in 1986, Sinclair moved to Amsterdam, where he lived for three years. He spent a year, working on The Stage project with a portable studio, on a project commissioned for the Gemeente Archief Amsterdam. In 1987 he was commissioned by the Rijksmuseum Amsterdam to photographed people involved in Amsterdam's art world. In 1989, Sinclair moved to London. In 1990 "The Stage", together with six portraits of peers were exhibited at The Photographers' Gallery, in London. In 1990 he started work on the Parliamentarians project from which came the first of his photographs to be acquired by the National Portrait Gallery. The project, together with a series of photographs of scientists commissioned by Cable and Wireless was exhibitted and toured by the NPG in 1994. In 1998 the NPG exhibitted a series of portraits of senior doctors, commissioned and published by the British Medical Journal, as "With Head & Hand & Heart". Sinclair has completed several other photography projects, including images of student life at Green College, Oxford (1998) and "Scooterlands" 1999, photographs of classic scooters in Italy and India.

Eleonora Patacchini is an economist specializing in applied economics and applied statistics who grew up in Italy with her mother who was also a professor. She is a professor and associate department chair at Cornell University in the Department of Economics. Her research focuses on the empirical analysis of behavioral models of strategic interactions for decision making. Patacchini is an associate editor at Journal of Urban Economics and Statistical Methods & Applications. She is a columnist at the VOX CEPR Policy Portal where research-based policy analysis and commentary from leading economists are published frequently. She is also a co-editor of E-journal Economics and associate editor of the Journal of Urban Economics. Education Patacchini studied at the Sapienza University of Rome, where she graduated summa cum laude with a Bachelor's degree in the field of sciences. She went on to pursue a Master of Science in economics at the University Pompeu Fabra in Spain, after which point she returned to Italy to complete her Ph.D in statistics in 2003 at the Sapienza University of Rome. Patacchini then pursued her second Ph.D in the field of economics at the University of Southampton.

The University of Dundee is a public research university based in Dundee, Scotland. It is the fourth oldest university in the United Kingdom and one of the largest in Scotland with a student population of approximately 33,000. The University was established in 1451, and has since grown to become one of the leading universities in Scotland and the United Kingdom, with a reputation for excellence in teaching and research. The University of Dundee has a long history of involvement in research and education, with many of its alumni going on to distinguished careers both within and outside of academia. Its faculty are distinguished experts in their fields, with many holding positions at national and international institutions. The University has a strong focus on undergraduate teaching, with around 80% of its staff having been awarded degrees at either undergraduate or postgraduate level. The University of Dundee is a member of the Russell Group, the Association of Commonwealth Universities, and the European University Association. It has been ranked as the fourth best university in Scotland by The Times/Sunday Times Good University Guide 2013 and sixth in the UK by The Guardian University Guide 2014.

Tiny Moving Parts is an American rock band from Benson, Minnesota. The trio started playing together in junior high and have been together since then. After releasing their first album Waves Rise, Waves Recede, the Ocean Is Full of Waves, they followed up with their second, Moving to Antarctica on June 19, 2010. Their third album, This Couch Is Long & Full of Friendship, was released through Kind of Like Records on January 13, 2013. On June 12, "Clouds Above My Head" was released as a free download. L.A.P.D. (Love and Peace Dude, later Laughing as People Die, an eventual pun on "Los Angeles Police Department") was an American funk metal band formed in 1989 in Bakersfield, California. From 1989 to 1992, the member line-up was James "Munky" Shaffer, Reginald "Fieldy" Arvizu, David Silveria and Richard Morrill. The group has released one studio album, one extended play, and one compilation album. The band was originally formed by Shaffer, Arvizu, and Morrill. Still in need for a drummer, the band placed an advertisement in a local newspaper which was answered by Silveria. Shortly after this, the band recorded a demo album which was meant to be sent out to record companies. Realizing they would have to continue the band in a more populated area in order for them to expand, all of the members but Shaffer left Bakersfield and resided in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California (Shaffer later moved to Hollywood as well). In late 1989, the band hired a man named Arthur as their manager, resulting in them getting signed to Triple X Records. The band recorded and released their first extended play in 1989, but it suffered from poor distribution.

The 2010 Kazakhstan Cup was the 18th edition of the Kazakhstan Cup, an annual football cup competition in Kazakhstan. The competition was won by FC Tobol, who defeated FC Kairat 2–1 in the final. The 2010 Kazakhstan Cup began on 17 May 2010 with the first round and ended with the final on 2 June 2010. A total of sixteen clubs participated in the tournament, which was played in a single-elimination format. The first round consisted of four ties, with the winners of each tie progressing to the second round. The second round consisted of two ties, with the winners of each tie progressing to the third round. The third round consisted of one tie, with the winner of that tie progressing to the semi-final stage. The semi-final stage consisted of two ties, with the winners of each tie proceeding to the final stage. The final stage consisted of one match, which was played on 2 June 2010 between FC Tobol and FC Kairat. FC Tobol won the 2010 Kazakhstan Cup trophy after they defeated FC Kairat 2–1 in the final.

Paul Erich Otto Wilhelm Knuth (20 November 1871 – 14 January 1973) was a German mathematician, computer scientist, and academic. He is considered one of the most influential and prolific mathematicians of the 20th century. Knuth made major contributions to several fields of mathematics, including number theory, algorithms, and computer science. He also made significant contributions to linguistics, particularly in the field of parsing theory. Knuth is also well known for his book The Art of Computer Programming, which has been called "the Bible of computer programming". Knuth was born in Königsberg in East Prussia to a Lutheran family. After completing his Abitur at the Friedrich-Wilhelms-Gymnasium in 1890, he studied mathematics at the University of Königsberg (now the University of Kaliningrad) under Moritz Steiner and Alfred Tarski. He received his doctorate from the University of Königsberg in 1895 for a thesis on the theory of equations. In 1896 Knuth began his career as an assistant at the University of Göttingen under David Hilbert. There he met Richard Bachman, with whom he would form a lifelong collaboration. In 1902 he became a professor at ETH Zurich and remained there until his retirement in 1958. During his time at ETH Zurich, Knuth mentored many young mathematicians including Alfréd Rényi, Alfred Schmidt, and Heinrich Scholz. Knuth died in Zurich at the age

James Luther Bevel (October 19, 1936 – September 12, 2018) was an American civil rights activist and leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). A prominent figure in the American Civil Rights Movement, Bevel became the first black militant to lead a national civil rights organization. Bevel was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to parents who were both educators. He attended Delaware State College, where he developed an interest in social justice and joined the NAACP Youth Council. He then transferred to Howard University, where he earned a bachelor's degree in business administration in 1960. Bevel began his career as a civil rights attorney in 1961, working for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. In 1964, he co-founded the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE), serving as its executive director until 1970. Under Bevel's leadership, CORE became one of the most influential civil rights organizations of the era. In 1969, Bevel became president of the NAACP. In this role, he led the organization during its most dramatic period of growth and change. Under Bevel's leadership, the NAACP successfully campaigned for laws and policies that protected civil rights and promoted racial equality. Among these accomplishments were passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and landmark court decisions such as Brown v. Board of Education and Roe v. Wade. Bevel retired from his presidency in 1997, but continued to serve as an advisor to the NAACP until his death in 2018. He was awarded the Presidential Medal

Marvel Cave is a National Natural Landmark located just west of Branson, Missouri, on top of Roark Mountain in Stone County. The cave was known by the Osage Indians in the early 16th century, after a tribe member fell through the cave's main entrance, a sinkhole. There is evidence that in 1541 the Spanish explored the cave, but the first recorded expedition was in 1869, led by Henry T. Blow. The unofficial Stone County chapter of Bald Knobbers, a local group of vigilantes, were rumored to have taken people to the top of Roark Mountain, and thrown them in the sink hole. Marvel Cave was originally called Marble Cave, after explorers in 1882 saw what they thought was marble on the cave's ceiling. This started the Marble Cave Mining Company, although later it was realized that there was never any marble in the cave. The Marble Cave Mining Company ceased all operations after only four and a half years. William Lynch purchased the cave in 1889, and soon after opened the cave to the public. In 1950, Hugo Herschend leased the cave for 99 years. The Herschends made renovations to the cave, and later opened a theme park, Silver Dollar City, on the surface above the cave. Marvel Cave is known for being one of the largest caves in Missouri, having one of the largest cave entry rooms (the Cathedral Room) of any cave in North America, and for being one of the longest running tourist attractions in the Ozarks.

He has also made appearances on television shows such as "The Voice" and "The X Factor".

The game also features a combat system which allows Takaya to fight enemies using conventional weapons and magic spells. The ROY Files is an Irish-based British children's television show, filmed in Dublin, Ireland, which was broadcast by CBBC in the United Kingdom and ABC Me in Australia. It began airing 7 December 2015. The show centres on the title character Roy O'Brien, the 11-year-old animated son of a live-action family. The series is a spin-off from ROY, an Irish-British television show which ran from 1 July 2009 to 7 April 2015. It stars Jason Cullen (replacing Scott Graham as Roy), Simon Delaney, Cathy Belton and Martha Byrne. Plot The show gives an insight into Roy O'Brien's personal life. The episodes consist of O'Brien creating a scrapbook of his life - one which he has to hand in to History teacher and vice-principal, Mr Hammond. Cyrus (died 52 BC) was an architect of the ancient Near East. He is credited with the invention of the arch, which played an important role in the development of building construction. His work is also noted for its use of different colors and materials to create a unique appearance. Cyrus was born in Persia in about 521 BC. He studied architecture at the Academy of Art in Athens, and later became an assistant to the architect Iktinos. He returned to Persia in about 540 BC and began working on major projects there, such as the Palace of Darius I at Susa and the reconstruction of Persepolis after its destruction by the Medes. In about 546 BC, Cyrus was invited to Egypt by Pharaoh Thutmose III to help design the Great Palace of Karnak. This was one of the most important architectural projects of its time, and it is still in use today. Cyrus's other notable Egyptian projects include the Temple of Amon-Ra at Thebes and the tomb of Nefertari. Cyrus returned to Persia in about 538 BC and continued working there until his death in 52 BC. His most famous buildings include the Hall of Justice at Susa and the Gate of All Nations at Babylon.

Salvador Pirates was the name given to a group of pirates that operated in the Caribbean Sea in the early 18th century. The term "Salvador Pirates" was first used in 1718 by Spanish explorer Juan Fernández de Quirós, who referred to them as "los piratas salvadoreños". The group is thought to have consisted of a few hundred men, mainly from the impoverished and lawless province of El Salvador on the Central American isthmus. The pirates targeted Spanish ships travelling between Cuba and Hispaniola, as well as vessels travelling between the Spanish Main and the Spanish West Indies. They were particularly active in the late 1720s and early 1730s, but slowly began to decline in influence after their main prey switched to British ships. Many of their members were killed or captured by the Spanish Navy, while others surrendered or went into hiding. The term "Salvador Pirates" is now used mostly for historical purposes, although a few dozen individuals still claim to be members of the group.

Computerized Coloring Books is a collection of three games developed by Capstone Software and published by its parent company IntraCorp for both the DOS and Amiga operating systems. A port for Windows 3.1 was planned but never took place. The games are based on Bill Kroyer's film FernGully: The Last Rainforest, Don Bluth's film Rock-a-Doodle, and John Hughes's film Home Alone. The Rock-a-Doodle game was as released with Trolls and An American Tail: The Computer Adventures of Fievel and His Friends on the Capstone CD Game Kids Collection. Gameplay The games work as basic computerized coloring books, which require the player to fill in a lineart picture. There are 16 colors available, although they can be mixed to get up to 256 colors. The player can choose from a selection of backgrounds and add any characters to the picture, both of which are based on scenes and characters of the respective films. The products support a wide range of printers for the time of its release, including dot matrix, colour and laser printers.

Odd Blood is the self-produced second studio album by American experimental rock band Yeasayer. Recorded in the state of New York during 2009, it was released on February 8, 2010 in Europe and a day later in North America, with Secretly Canadian as the primary label. "Ambling Alp", "O.N.E.", "Madder Red", and "I Remember" were released as singles. Odd Blood peaked at number 63 on the US Billboard 200 and at number 64 on the UK Albums Chart. It reached number five on the US Billboard Independent Albums chart. Yeasayer followed the record's release with an extended tour throughout 2010. Odd Blood was mostly crafted with engineer Steve Revitte in a secluded cabin studio. During the sessions, Yeasayer experimented with different types of instruments and recording machines. Auxiliary musicians were hired to help with the process. The idea was to marry sonic experimentation with pop structures, while primary songwriters Chris Keating and Anand Wilder explored a variety of themes such as boxing, addiction, and paranoia. Odd Blood also contains several love songs. The album received largely positive reviews from critics. Praise centered on its cohesive merging of genres, especially the pop-influenced rhythms.

Gordon Wilkie (born May 3, 1940) is an American author, essayist, and critic who has written extensively about the arts. He is the author of seven books of essays, including The Art of the Novel and The Responsive Eye: A Personal History of the American Arts. Wilkie has also written for The New York Times, Harper's Magazine, and The New Yorker, and has been a regular commentator on NPR's Weekend Edition Sunday. Wilkie was born in Pawtucket, Rhode Island and raised in Westbrook, Maine. He received his B.A. from Wesleyan University in 1962 and his M.F.A. from Yale University in 1965. He taught at Yale from 1965 to 1975, when he moved to Paris to become a fellow at the Villa Medici. He returned to the United States in 1978 and has since lived in New York City and Cambridge, Massachusetts. Wilkie's work as an author encompasses both criticism and fiction writing. His first book of essays, The Art of the Novel, was published in 1979 and has since been regularly reprinted and translated into French, German, Spanish, Italian, Dutch, Danish, Swedish, Finnish, Norwegian, Polish, Romanian, Bulgarian, Chinese and Japanese. His most recent book is The Responsive Eye: A Personal History of the American Arts (2013). Wilkie's fiction includes two novels—The Innocent (1990), which was short-listed for the National Book Critics Circle Award; and Love & Other Demons (1996), which won the

Peter Meong Rhee (born September 18, 1961) is an American surgeon, medical professor, and military veteran. During his 24 years in the United States Navy, Rhee served as a battlefield casualty physician in Afghanistan and Iraq. Formerly a Professor of Surgery and the Chief of Trauma, Critical Care, and Burn and Emergency Surgery at the University of Arizona College of Medicine until 2016, he then served as the Chief of Surgery at the Marcus Trauma Center at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta, Georgia. Currently he is the Chief of Acute Care Surgery and Trauma at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, New York. He was a tenured Professor of Surgery at the University of Arizona until 2016. Now he is Professor of Surgery at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda Maryland, Morehouse School of Medicine and is a tenured Professor of Surgery at the New York Medical College in Valhalla, New York. He rose to national prominence when he served as the attending physician to U.S. Representative Gabby Giffords of Arizona, as well as other victims, following the 2011 Tucson shooting.

Tane Nikolov (9 March 1873 – 7 September 1944) was a Bulgarian revolutionary and politician. He was one of the most influential figures in the history of the Bulgarian Communist Party, and is considered one of the founders of the country's socialist system. Tane Nikolov was born on 9 March 1873 in Sofia, then part of the Ottoman Empire. He was educated at the St. Kliment Ohridski Sofia Boys School and at the University of Vienna, where he studied law. In 1895, he returned to Bulgaria and started working as a lawyer. In 1903, Nikolov joined the Bulgarian Revolutionary Committee, a secret organisation dedicated to overthrowing Ottoman rule in Bulgaria. The following year, he was arrested and imprisoned for two years in Constantinople. After his release, Nikolov resumed his law career. In 1908, he became a member of the Central Committee of the Bulgarian Communist Party (BKP), and later that year he was elected to its governing board. In 1910, he was appointed chairman of the party's regional committee in Plovdiv. In 1912, Nikolov led a failed attempt to overthrow the government of Ferdinand Dimitrov. He fled Bulgaria and went into exile in Russia, where he worked as a legal adviser to the Russian Communist Party (RCP). In 1917, Nikolov returned to Bulgaria and played an instrumental role in organising resistance to the Allied occupation forces. He served as deputy chairman of the BKP's

Lawrence Charles Kaufman (born November 15, 1947) is an American chess and shōgi player. In chess, he was awarded the title Grandmaster by FIDE for winning the 2008 World Seniors Championship (which he later retroactively shared with Mihai Suba). Kaufman had been previously awarded the title International Master in 1980. Background A longtime researcher in computer chess, Kaufman has made several contributions to chess-related works. He helped write the opening book for the pioneering program Mac Hack, co-developed Socrates II and its commercial adaptation, Kasparov's Gambit, edited the journal Computer Chess Reports, and worked on many other research and commercial chess engines. He is also known for his work on computer chess engine Rybka 3, and several books and articles, including The Evaluation of Material Imbalances. He helped develop the chess program Komodo with Don Dailey, with whom he had worked on the Socrates series of programs. After Dailey's death in 2013, Kaufman resumed his work on Komodo with Mark Lefler.
