The Belize Zoo and Tropical Education Center is a zoo located in Belize City, Belize. It is the only zoo in Belize and is open to the public daily from 9:00 am to 4:30 pm. The Belize Zoo was founded in 1962 by the late Dr. Oswaldo Sanchez, a well-known zoologist and conservationist. The zoo initially consisted of just a few animals obtained from local farms. By the early 1970s, the zoo had expanded its holdings to include a variety of animals from around the region, as well as crocodiles and monkeys from neighboring countries. In 1984, the zoo opened its doors to the public, and has since grown to encompass more than 1,000 animals representing over 100 species. The Belize Zoo is home to a wide variety of animals, including some of Belize's rarest and most endangered species. Among the zoo's most popular attractions are the mammals on exhibit including jaguars, black bears, raccoons, and toucans; the reptiles including an anaconda and three monitor lizards; and the invertebrates including over 100 types of spiders. The zoo also features an extensive educational program that engages children in hands-on learning about animal behavior and ecology.

Dickson Mounds is a Native American settlement in the Driftless Area of northeast Iowa. The site was first recorded in 1837 by a surveyor for the United States government. The mounds are believed to have been built by the Adena culture, which flourished from 800 BC to 200 AD. The site was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1970. The Dickson Mounds are located in northeastern Iowa, about north of Guttenberg and south of Mason City. They are situated on a high bluff overlooking the White River valley, and are visible from several miles away. The site is open to the public, and is currently administered by the University of Northern Iowa. The Dickson Mounds are a group of earthen mounds, which are approximately high and in diameter at the base. The mounds have been leveled and shaped by wind and rain over the course of hundreds of years, but they retain evidence of their original form. There are currently six mounds standing on the site; the others were destroyed by natural forces or destroyed and rebuilt over time. The Adena culture was one of the most significant Native American cultures in northeast Iowa. It flourished from 800 BC to 200 AD, and is known for its elaborate ceramics, which were often decorated with images of animals or monsters. The Dickson Mounds site was likely occupied by members of the Adena culture at some point in their history; it is possible that the mounds were built by this group as part of their

George Henry Lane-Fox Pitt-Rivers (22 May 1890 – 24 March 1957) was a Conservative Party politician in the United Kingdom. Pitt-Rivers was born in 1890, the son of George Lane-Fox Pitt-Rivers and his wife, Gwendolen Mary. He was educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he was president of the Union. Pitt-Rivers served in the First World War as a lieutenant in the Grenadier Guards, rising to the rank of captain. He married Frances Evelyn Hordern on 17 October 1918. After the war he resumed his studies at Cambridge, gaining a degree in jurisprudence in 1922. Pitt-Rivers became a barrister at Lincoln's Inn in 1923, and practised law until 1939. In 1935 he was elected to Parliament as MP for Maidstone, serving until 1945. In 1935 he was appointed Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, a position he held until 1938. In this role Pitt-Rivers played a leading part in drafting the Statute of Westminster 1931 which granted full independence to India. In 1938 Pitt-Rivers was appointed Home Secretary, serving until 1945. During his time as Home Secretary Pitt-Rivers presided over the implementation of the Emergency Powers Act 1939, which allowed for emergency rule during World War II. In 1943 Pitt-Rivers introduced legislation that created the Special Immigration Branch (later known as MI5), which is responsible for counterintelligence within the United Kingdom.

Leslie S. Klinger (born May 2, 1946 in Chicago, Illinois) is an American attorney and writer. He is a noted literary editor and annotator of classic genre fiction, including the Sherlock Holmes stories and the novels Dracula and Frankenstein as well as Neil Gaiman's The Sandman comics, Alan Moore's and Dave Gibbons's Watchmen graphic novel, the stories of H. P. Lovecraft, and Neil Gaiman's American Gods. Biography Klinger was born in Chicago, Illinois, on May 2, 1946. He received a B.A. in English from the University of California, Berkeley in 1967 and a J.D. from Boalt Hall School of Law at UC Berkeley in 1970. It was in law school that he developed his interest in Holmes, leading him to amass a collection of thousands of books about the detective. He practices law in the fields of tax, estate planning, and business in Los Angeles, California. He lives in Malibu, California, with his wife Sharon Flaum Klinger, who is a dealer in first-day-covers, their dog Jenny and their cat Mr. Giles.

Brother Rachid (born 1971, Morocco) is a Moroccan artist who lives and works in Paris. Brother Rachid was born in 1971 in the city of Rabat, Morocco. He studied Fine Arts at the University of Lille III in France, graduating with honors in 1995. After graduation, he moved to Paris, where he has been living and working since then. Brother Rachid's paintings explore the relationship between man and nature, exploring themes such as mysticism, spirituality, and the connection between humanity and nature. His paintings are often characterized by their delicate and intricate details, as well as their use of bright colors. Brother Rachid has exhibited his work in various galleries and museums throughout France and Morocco, including the Palais de Tokyo (Paris), the Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris (Paris), the Centre Georges Pompidou (Paris), and the Mohammed V Palace ( Rabat ). He is also the recipient of numerous awards, including the prestigious Prix Marcel Duchamp (1995), the Grand Prix National du Sculpture (1997), and the Grand Prix National du Graffiti (2005). Brother Rachid is currently working on a new project that will explore the theme of dreams.

Police interviewed witnesses and ruled the woman 's death an accident . Victim 's family sued the tourist and attempted to stop her from leaving .

Deb Lavender (born October 11, 1956) is an American politician who from 2015 to 2021 served in the Missouri House of Representatives. A Democrat, Lavender represented the 90th district, which comprises all or part of the cities of Glendale, Kirkwood, Oakland, Sunset Hills, Warson Woods, and Webster Groves in St. Louis County. In 2020, she unsuccessfully ran for the Missouri Senate against incumbent Republican Andrew Koenig. Early life and education Lavender was born and raised in Ridgefield, Connecticut. Her interest in government service developed while, as a teenager, she participated in Girls State, a leadership program sponsored by the American Legion Auxiliary. Through her experience with the Girls State organization, she learned to appreciate the importance and value of democratic government. In 1979, Lavender was graduated from Marquette University in Milwaukee with a Bachelor of Science in physical therapy. She worked throughout her time in school to pay her tuition and living expenses. Soon after graduation Lavender moved to St. Louis, where she has been a resident for over 35 years.

George Alphonso Headley OD, MBE (30 May 1909 – 10 November 1986) was an English composer and conductor. He also played the tenor saxophone and flute. Headley was born in London, England, the son of Alphonso Headley, a physician, and his wife, Marjorie (née Wigram). He studied at the Royal Academy of Music and the Royal College of Music with Lennox Berkeley. In 1938 he won the Mendelssohn Scholarship to study at the University of Chicago where he was taught by Walter Piston. Headley made his first recording in 1939 with the American Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini. He also toured with the British Symphony Orchestra as a clarinettist. In 1942 he moved to New York City and formed his own band which played at various venues including the Mocambo Club. His first composition for film was "The Song of Bernadette" (1943), which was followed by "The Inn of The Sixth Happiness" (1944), "The Star-Spangled Girl" (1945), "The Thief of Bagdad" (1948), "Queen Christina" (1956) and "Doctor Dolittle" (1967). His other films include "A Night To Remember", "The Guns of Navarone", "The Poseidon Adventure", "110% Richard Nixon", "Zulu", and "Tom Cruise's War of The Worlds". Headley returned to England in 1951 and became director

Friedreich's ataxia (FRDA or FA) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene. It is a progressive myopathy that results in muscle weakness and wasting, and can ultimately lead to death. FRDA is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene, which is located on the long arm of chromosome 2. The FMR1 gene produces a protein called frataxin. Frataxin is responsible for controlling the amount of muscle protein (muscle fiber) in cells. A mutation in the FMR1 gene causes an overproduction of frataxin, which leads to muscle weakness and wasting. There is no cure for FRDA, but there are treatments available that can help improve symptoms. Treatment options include medication, physical therapy, and surgery. Some people with FRDA may require life-long care.

WOWK-TV, virtual channel 13 (VHF digital channel 7), is an ABC-affiliated television station licensed to Portsmouth, Virginia, United States. The station is owned by the Hearst Television subsidiary of Hearst Corporation. WOWK's studios and transmitter are located on West Mercury Boulevard in Portsmouth. The station first signed on the air on December 10, 1953 as WNTM-TV, serving Hampton Roads. The station was founded by the Norfolk News & Advance Company, which also owned WNTM radio (1230 AM, now WTKR). In 1957, the station changed its call letters to WVBT-TV and became a charter affiliate of the ABC network. In 1978, Norfolk News & Advance Company merged with the Hearst Corporation. As a result of the merger, WVBT became a sister station to WNTM radio (now WTKR). In 1985, Hearst Corporation sold WVBT-TV and WTKR to the Gannett Company. In 1988, Gannett merged with USA Networks, which later became part of the NBCUniversal family of companies. In 2001, NBCUniversal sold WVBT-TV and WTKR to Hearst Corporation. In 2004, Hearst merged its three television stations into one company called Hearst Television Networks. In October 2006, Hearst announced that it would sell WVBT-TV and WTKR to the Sinclair Broadcast Group for $36 million; this sale was completed on January 3, 2007. Sinclair ran the stations under a local marketing

Archaeologists at the Natural History Museum in London and University College London found human skulls in Gough 's Cave in Somerset had been extenisvely shaped to create cups or bowls . The findings suggest people living in the late Ice Age indulged in ritual cannibalism , perhaps as a macabre way to revere their dead kin . The humans who lived at the cave were a group of Cro-Magnon hunter-gatherers

Thomas K. (Tom) Ascol is an evangelical Christian pastor, author, and President of Founders Ministries. He is currently the senior pastor of Grace Baptist Church in Cape Coral, Florida, where he has served for 33 years as of May 2019. Biography Tom Ascol has served as Pastor of Grace Baptist Church since 1986. Prior to moving to Florida, he served as pastor and associate pastor of churches in Texas. He has a B.S. degree in sociology from Texas A&M University (1979) and has also earned the M.Div and Ph.D degrees from Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary in Ft. Worth, Texas. His major field of study was Baptist Theology. He taught two years as an adjunct professor for New Orleans Baptist Theological Seminary at their Southwest Florida extension. He has also served as adjunct professor of theology for Reformed Theological Seminary and is a Visiting Professor for their Nicole Institute of Baptist Studies. He teaches adjunctively for the Midwest Center for Theological Studies and Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary through their Equip Center.

Jerome Adams "Jerry" Utley (January 7, 1881 – October 15, 1966) was an American professional baseball player who played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Philadelphia Phillies and Boston Braves from 1905 to 1917. He was a right-handed batter and outfielder, and is considered one of the greatest hitters in baseball history. Utley was born in West Chester, Pennsylvania, and played his first professional season with the minor league Johnstown team of the Appalachian League in 1902. He made his MLB debut with the Phillies in 1905 and led the National League (NL) in batting average in 1907, 1908, and 1911. He won three NL batting titles, led the NL in hits four times, and finished second twice. In 1912, Utley led the Phillies to their first pennant championship and their first World Series appearance. The Phillies lost to the New York Giants in five games. In 1916, he joined the Braves and led them to their first NL pennant. The Braves lost to the Chicago Cubs in six games in the World Series. Utley finished his MLB career with a .325 batting average, 521 home runs, 1,676 RBIs, and 1,955 runs scored. He also had a .929 fielding percentage at first base. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1955. Utley was a vocal opponent of baseball's reserve clause system and participated in an antitrust suit against MLB that was ultimately unsuccessful. Alice Cambridge (1 January 1762 – 1 February 1848) was a British socialite and philanthropist who is best known for her marriages to the wealthy British politician John Camberwell and the American tycoon James Butler. Born in London, England, Cambridge was the eldest daughter of the Anglo-Irish landowner Richard Cambridge and his wife Frances née Browne. She was christened on 1 January 1762 at St Clement Danes, London. Her father had been MP for County Galway in Ireland. Cambridge's mother was a sister of the dramatist Richard Brinsley Sheridan. Cambridge came from an affluent background and her parents ensured that she had a comfortable upbringing. She attended drawing schools in town and country, and made lifelong friends among the aristocracy and gentry. In 1779, Cambridge married John Camberwell, son of the 3rd Earl Camberwell and a first cousin of Prime Minister Frederick North. The couple had four children: Alice (born 1780), Richard (1782–1802), Frances (1784–1851) and Caroline (1787–1865). In 1802, Cambridge married James Butler, an American businessman who became one of the richest men in America. The Butlers had six children: Anne (1803–1864), Elizabeth (1806–1892), James (1809–1886), Butler (1812–1885), Edmund (1815–1885) and George (1819–1902).

Susan Marguerite Osborne (born April 5, 1944) was the Democratic mayor of Boulder, Colorado from November 17, 2009, to November 8, 2011. She was city council member from November 6, 2007, to November 8, 2011, and before that served as director of long range planning, energy and environment director, Community Development Block Grant assistant director and director, and neighborhood and historic preservation planner for the city of Boulder from 1977 until her retirement in 1999. Osborne was educated at Vassar College and University of Colorado at Boulder where she received a B.A. in sociology in 1974 and at University of Colorado at Denver where she received a M.A. in Urban and Regional Planning in 1977. After retiring, Osborne taught courses included History of City Planning, Housing Policy and Programs, Energy and Design, Behavior and Environment and several graduate and undergraduate studio classes at the University of Colorado. During this time, she also completed coursework and dissertation research for a doctorate in Design and Planning.

William Hall Eccles (24 March 1838 – 21 July 1912) was an English cricketer who played for Somerset and England. He was born in Chew Magna, Somerset and died in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset. Eccles was a right-handed batsman who bowled right-arm fast. He made his first-class debut for Somerset against Marylebone Cricket Club in 1859. He made five further first-class appearances for the county, the last of which came against Warwickshire in 1868. In his six matches for the county, he scored a total of 157 runs at an average of 10.40, with a high score of 34 not out. His bowling figures were also impressive, taking 21 wickets at an average of 17.14, with a best performance of 7/38. Eccles made his debut for England against Scotland in 1862. He played 11 further matches for the side, the last of which came against Ireland in 1877. In his 12 matches for England, he scored a total of 318 runs at an average of 14.83, with a high score of 45 not out. His bowling figures were also impressive, taking 36 wickets at an average of 23.11, with a best performance of 7/21. Eccles was also part of the England team that won the inaugural Test match against Australia in 1877. Eccles died from heart failure aged 70 years in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset

Douglas Hemphill Elliott (June 3, 1921 – November 24, 1990) was an American chemist and academic who served as the twelfth President of the University of Texas at Austin from 1970 to 1980. Elliott was born in Houston, Texas, on June 3, 1921. He received his B.S. in chemistry from Rice University in 1941 and his Ph.D. from the University of Chicago in 1945. After serving in the United States Navy during World War II, Elliott began his academic career at Yale University, where he served as professor of chemistry from 1947 to 1970. At Yale, Elliott was a member of the American Chemical Society and the Sigma Xi scientific society. Elliott became the twelfth president of the University of Texas at Austin in 1970 and served until 1980. During his tenure, UT Austin rose to become one of the most respected universities in America and Elliott himself was widely regarded as one of the country's leading educators. Elliott retired from UT Austin in 1980 and died two years later on November 24, 1990.

Michael Jones McKean (born 1976) is an American actor, comedian, and writer. He is known for his roles as George Michael Bluth in the Fox sitcom Arrested Development and as Ben Wyatt in the ABC sitcom Modern Family. McKean was born in Park Ridge, Illinois, the son of Diane (née Sacks) and Michael McKean. His father was a television producer and director, and his mother was an English teacher. He has two sisters, Rebecca and Maggie. McKean attended Lake Forest Academy, where he played football and was captain of the lacrosse team. He then studied at Middlebury College in Vermont, where he became involved in improvisational comedy. He graduated with a degree in English Literature in 1999. After graduation, McKean moved to New York City to pursue an acting career. He made his Broadway debut in 2002 in the revival of The Odd Couple as Oscar Madison opposite Matthew Broderick. In 2003, he played the role of Manute Bol in the Broadway production of The Mountain Goats' play The Night Country. In 2004, McKean appeared as George Michael Bluth on Fox's sitcom Arrested Development, for which he received critical acclaim. The show ran for three seasons before being cancelled in 2006. Salome (; , related to ,  "peaceful") is a figure from the New Testament who, according to the Gospels of Matthew and Mark, danced to the music of John the Baptist while wearing a tight dress that displayed her body. In classical antiquity, Salome was known as a minor character in the plays of Euripides and Seneca. She became well known through the works of Bram Stoker, who wrote the novel "Salome" (1897) and its subsequent stage and film adaptations. The story of Salome is set in Jerusalem during the time of the Jewish–Roman War (66-73 AD), shortly after the death of Jesus. Karl Andrew Pillemer (born October 15, 1954) is an American social anthropologist, who has written extensively on the anthropology of aging. He is the Victor S. Thomas Professor of Social Anthropology and Director of the Elder Research and Development Institute at the University of California, Irvine. Karl Pillemer was born in Cleveland, Ohio, to Helen (née Weinstein) and Karl Pillemer, both physicians. He grew up in a secular Jewish family and attended Hebrew school from age 4 to 12. He then attended the University of Michigan, where he received his B.A. in 1976. He then attended Harvard University, where he received his M.A. in 1978 and his Ph.D. in 1983. Pillemer began his professional career as a research associate at the Department of Social Anthropology at the University of Michigan from 1978 to 1982, where he worked with George Peter Murdock and Victor Turner. He then became a lecturer at Yale University from 1982 to 1985, where he worked with Ruth Benedict and Nancy Scheper-Hughes on a comparative study of death rituals among the Tsimane of Bolivian Aymara society. From 1985 to 1988, Pillemer was a research associate at the Department of Anthropology at Stanford University, where he worked with Ruth Benedict and Arnold van Gennep on a study of aging in traditional societies around the world. From 1988 to 1992, he was a professor of anthropology at Brown University, where he worked with Eleanor Leacock on a study of old age

Kathleen Williams (born February 16, 1961) is an American politician from Montana. A member of the Democratic Party, she served in the nonpartisan Environmental Quality Council of the Montana Legislature and the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks. In 2010, she was elected to the Montana House of Representatives and served three two-year terms before retiring. In 2018 and 2020, Williams ran, unsuccessfully, as the Democratic nominee for Montana's at-large seat in the United States House of Representatives. Early life and education Williams was born February 16, 1961, in a United States Army hospital in California. Her father was a U.S. Army soldier who served in World War II; much of her childhood was spent as a "military brat". When Williams was 11 years old, her 49-year-old mother was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Williams assisted her father in caring for her mother, who died when Williams was in her teens.

The Portland vice scandal (sometimes called the Portland vice scandal of 2001) was a high-profile corruption and sex scandal involving the police and city officials in the city of Portland, Oregon. It began to unfold in late 2000, when reports surfaced of the involvement of officers in a prostitution ring. In 2001, a detailed investigation by the Oregonian newspaper resulted in the conviction of 14 police officers, four city officials, and one private citizen. The scandal is notable for its unusually high level of public scrutiny of city government, as well as for the revelations about the involvement of some of Portland's highest-ranking officers. The resulting outcry led to major reforms within the Portland Police Bureau, including the establishment of an ethics commission and the development of new procedures for investigating officer misconduct.

Blandina Segale, more commonly known as Sister Blandina (23 January 1850 – 23 February 1941) was an Italian-born American Sister of Charity of Cincinnati and missionary, who became widely known through her service on the American frontier in the late 19th century. During her missionary work, she met, among others, Billy the Kid and the leaders of the Native American tribes of the Apache and Comanche. She served as an educator and social worker who worked in Ohio, Colorado and New Mexico, assisting Native Americans, Hispanic settlers and European immigrants. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santa Fe has opened a process to canonize Segale, for which it has received the permission of the Holy See. For this, she is honored by the Catholic Church with the title of Servant of God. She is the first individual in New Mexico's 400-year history with the Roman Catholic Church to have a cause opened for their beatification and canonization.

Soon-Yi Previn (; , ; born  February 17, 1967) is an American actress and musician. She has appeared in films such as The Princess Diaries (2001), Adaptation (2002), The Squid and the Whale (2005), The Social Network (2010), and The Fault in Our Stars (2014). Previn was born in Boston, Massachusetts, the daughter of jazz violinist Itzhak Perlman and actress Shirley Jones. She has two younger sisters, Tova and Talia. Her paternal grandparents were Jewish immigrants from Lithuania and Ukraine. Her maternal grandparents were Scottish-born actress Lillian Gish and playwright Eugene O'Neill. Previn attended The Chapin School in New York City. In 1987, Previn made her Broadway debut in a production of the musical Lost in Yonkers. That same year, she made her film debut as an uncredited extra in the drama Dead Poet's Society. Previn received critical acclaim for her role as Mia Thermopolis in The Princess Diaries (2001), for which she was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actress. She reprised her role in its 2003 sequel, The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement. For her performance in the 2010 film The Social Network, she won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. Mohamed Al-Darraji (born 6 August 1978 in Baghdad, Iraq) is an Iraqi-Dutch film director. He studied theater in Iraq, and cinematography and directing in England. He is known for his drama films, which focus on political affairs in the Middle East and their effects on interpersonal relationships. Personal life Al-Daradji was born and raised in Iraq. His aunt had lost a son in the Iran–Iraq War, and he cites her grief as a motivation for his films, which address both the terrible suffering and the hopefulness for the future felt by many Iraqis. In 1995, he fled to the Netherlands: “And now I am proud. [...] I am a refugee who came to Holland fifteen years ago, with one pair of trousers, dirty clothes, and one pair of shoes. I will tell myself this [...] and I will tell that to my family. I am proud of Holland that gave me this great energy and this great opportunity to find myself - that is really important for me.”

The Note Crisis was a political crisis in Soviet–Finnish relations in 1961. The Soviet Union sent Finland a diplomatic note on October 30, 1961, referring to the threat of war and West German militarization and proposing that Finland and the Soviet Union begin consultations on securing the defence of both countries, as provided for in the Finno-Soviet Treaty of 1948. The note coincided with the detonation of the Tsar Bomba, the most powerful nuclear test in history, and followed close on the heels of the Berlin Crisis and Bay of Pigs Invasion. The note precipitated a crisis in Finland: activating the military provisions of the treaty would have frustrated Finland's post-war policy of neutrality in international affairs and greatly damaged Finland's relations with the West. One of the crucial goals of Finnish foreign policy was to reinforce the credibility of Finland's neutrality in the eyes of Western powers which were skeptical of the country's ability to resist Soviet influence.

Shirley Ayorkor Botchwey (born 8 February 1963), nicknamed "Shirley the Stripper" or simply "Shirley Botchway", is a Ugandan pornographic actress, escort and model. Botchway was born in Kampala, Uganda, to an ethnic Banyankole family. She attended Queen Elizabeth School for Girls. In 1984, Botchway started working as a stripper and prostitute in Kampala, and soon became well-known in the city. In 1991, she moved to Johannesburg, South Africa, where she continued working as an escort and pornographic actress. She has since appeared in over 120 pornographic films. Botchway has two children, a daughter (born 1989) and a son (born 1993). She has been married twice, first to Barrister Charles Nambiye (1993–1995) and then to professional boxer Johan van Rooyen (2001–2005). Botchway divorced van Rooyen in 2005. In February 2006, she married her third husband, Ugandan businessman Ronald Kibuule. Botchway has been a vocal critic of Uganda's anti-pornography laws. In 2007, she was arrested under Uganda's pornography laws and spent six weeks in prison before being released on bail. In 2009, she was again arrested under the same laws and spent six weeks in prison before being released on bail again. In October 2010, she was arrested under the same laws and spent another six weeks in prison before being released on bail again

Grayson Murphy (born February 4, 1999) is an American college basketball player for the Belmont Bruins of the Ohio Valley Conference (OVC). High school career Murphy played basketball for Independence High School in Thompson's Station, Tennessee. As a junior, he averaged 18.6 points per game, 5.6 rebounds, 5.1 assists and 3.8 steals per game, while receiving Trophy House/Gateway Tire Player of the Year honors for Williamson County. Murphy was also named District 11-AAA MVP and led his team to a district title, earning tournament MVP. In a Region 6-AAA win over McGavock High School as a junior, Murphy had 43 points, 12 assists, nine rebounds and nine steals. In his senior season, he averaged 19.7 points, 8.9 rebounds, 5.2 assists and 3.1 steals per game. Murphy left as his school's all-time leader in points, rebounds, assists and steals. He committed to playing college basketball for Belmont over offers from Austin Peay, Lipscomb and Troy, among others.

Shake Ray Turbine was an American DIY punk band from San Francisco, California. Shake Ray Turbine was formed in the early 2000s by singer/guitarist Trey Spruill and drummer Zach Hill. The band's first release, a self-titled EP, was released on the independent label Lookout! Records in 2001. Shake Ray Turbine's first full-length album, "The Great American Nightmare", was released on Fat Wreck Chords in 2003. The album was recorded at the legendary Fudge Tunnel Studios in San Francisco and marked a departure from the DIY punk sound of the band's earlier releases, featuring more angular and electronic influences. Following the release of "The Great American Nightmare", Shake Ray Turbine toured extensively throughout the United States and Europe. In 2004, the band released a second full-length album, "No Control". The album again featured a more experimental sound, with songs that incorporated elements of electronic music and psychedelic rock. In 2006, Trey Spruill left Shake Ray Turbine to focus on his other project, The Tyde. Zach Hill continued to play with the band until 2007, when he was replaced by bassist Nathan McGowan. In 2009, McGowan left the band to join forces with fellow Bay Area punks FIDLAR. In 2010, Shake Ray Turbine released their third album, "Welcome to Reality". Giandomenico Majone (born March 27, 1932) is an Italian scholar of political science whose expertise is regulatory governance within the European Union (EU) as well as theories of delegation and their effect on the perceived democratic deficit of the EU. He is an Emeritus Professor of Public Policy at the European University Institute in Florence, Italy. Education Majone studied at the University of Padua in the early 1950s acquiring a Master of Arts in political economy in 1956, before enrolling at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, where he received a Master of Science degree in mathematics in 1960. In the early 1960s he studied at the University of California, where he earned a doctorate in statistics in 1965. In 1986 he was appointed professor of public policy analysis at the European University Institute (EUI), a post he held until 1995. He currently holds a position as an external professor at the EUI in addition to that of visiting distinguished professor at the EU Center and Graduate School of Public and International Affairs at the University of Pittsburgh.

Tuojiang Town is an ancient town and the seat of Fenghuang County in Hunan, China. It has an area of with a population of 112,200 (as of 2015). The town has 29 villages and 7 communities under its jurisdiction, its seat is at Fenghuang South Road . The town is famous for Ancient City of Fenghuang, it is one of the most important tourist destinations in Hunan and one of AAAA-rated tourist attractions. History The town of Tuojiang is an ancient town. it was City of Wuzhaisi which was the seat of Wuzhai Tusi formed in Yuan dynasty. Camp Fenghuang was established there in 1704 and Camp Fenghuang was upgraded to Military Department of Fenghuang in 1736, it became the seat of Fenghuang Military Department. Military Department of Fenghuang ceased to be a military unit, the county of Fenghuang was formed in 1912, it is the seat of the county. In 1942, the town of Zhengan was renamed as Tuojiang after the Tuojiang River which runs through it.

Paul Hendrickson (born April 29, 1944) is an American actor and singer. He is known for his roles as Deputy Sheriff Roy Coffee in the television series Lonesome Dove, and as Father Chuck in the film Sister Act. Hendrickson was born on April 29, 1944, in Tulsa, Oklahoma. He attended Tulsa Central High School and the University of Oklahoma, where he was a member of the Sigma Chi fraternity. Hendrickson began his acting career in stage productions before making his television debut in the 1968 episode "The Return of J.B." of the Western series Lonesome Dove. He reprised his role as Deputy Sheriff Roy Coffee for three seasons of the successful television series, from 1990 to 1992. Hendrickson's other notable television credits include appearances on The Waltons, The Virginian, The Six Million Dollar Man, The Streets of San Francisco, Murphy Brown, and Touched by an Angel. He has also appeared in several feature films, including Sister Act (1992), My Cousin Vinny (1992), Ed Wood (1994), and Dead Presidents (1995). Hendrickson has also released two albums: Paul Hendrickson Sings Rodgers and Hammerstein (1970) and Paul Hendrickson Sings Cole Porter (1972).

Robert Lee Holden Jr. (born August 24, 1955) is an American actor, known for his roles as Ozzie Nelson in the Fox sitcom That '70s Show (1998–2006), and as Deputy Sheriff Hank Hill in the CBS sitcom King of the Hill (1997–2013). He currently stars as Agent Dale Cooper on the CW series Twin Peaks. Holden was born in Corpus Christi, Texas, the son of Robert Lee Holden Sr., a truck driver, and Barbara Jean (née Wright), a schoolteacher. He has two sisters. Holden initially studied at the University of Texas at Austin, but dropped out after one year to pursue an acting career. He first appeared on television in 1978's The Dukes of Hazzard episode "The Return of J.B. Pennington". He began his career on the hit Fox sitcom That '70s Show, playing Ozzie Nelson for six seasons from 1998 to 2006. In 2003, he played Dr. Jonathan Goodwin in the film The Contender. Holden also appeared on King of the Hill as Deputy Sheriff Hank Hill from 1997 to 2013. He has made guest appearances on various TV series, including ER, CSI: Crime Scene Investigation, Judging Amy, and Boston Legal. Holden has also appeared in several feature films, including The Omen (1976), Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982), Twins (1988), and Armageddon (1998). The Luxburg-Carolath Cemetery , commonly known as Carolath Cemetery, is a historic cemetery in the town of Luxburg, Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It was founded in 1839 and contains the graves of many prominent Germans of the 19th century, including the writer Theodor Fontane. The Carolath Cemetery is located in the town of Luxburg, about northeast of Schleswig. It covers an area of . The cemetery was founded in 1839 by Johann Friedrich Carolath, who had purchased a plot from the bishopric of Schleswig. The first interments took place that year. Among the cemetery's early notable residents were Theodor Fontane (1819-1892), who was buried there in 1892, and Heinrich Heine (1797-1856), who was buried there in 1856. Other well-known residents include the painter Christian Wilhelm Ernst Neumann (1795-1860), the composer Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy (1809-1847), and the poet August von Platen (1781-1861). Today, the Luxburg-Carolath Cemetery is a popular tourist destination. It contains the graves of many prominent Germans of the 19th century, including the writer Theodor Fontane.

Liu Weiguo (, ; born 3 May 1992) is a Chinese footballer who currently plays for Chinese Super League side Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao. Club career Liu Weiguo started his football career when he joined Shandong Luneng's youth academy at the age of 14 and was promoted to the club's first team in 2011. He played as the fourth-choice goalkeeper throughout the 2011 season. In November 2011, he transferred to Chinese Super League promoted side Dalian Aerbin to seek more playing time. On 18 July 2012, he made his debut for the club in the fourth round of the 2012 Chinese FA Cup in which Dalian won 2–0 against Shenyang Shenbei. On 5 August 2012, then manager Aleksandar Stanojević decided to replace Yu Ziqian, who had made many mistakes in several games throughout the 2012 season, with Liu who made his league debut for the club in a 1–1 draw against Shanghai Shenxin. Liu remained as the club's first-choice goalkeeper for the rest of the season after his outstanding debut. He later became the second-choice goalkeeper after Zhang Chong transferred to the club from Dalian Shide in 2013.

Sandra Adams Dodd (born July 24, 1953, Augusta, Georgia) is an unschooling advocate. Her articles have been published in homeschooling journals (particularly, Home Education Magazine), in her books "Moving a Puddle" and "Sandra Dodd's Big Book of Unschooling", and are available on her personal website. Articles she has written have been translated into several languages, and her "Public School On Your Own Terms" was featured in "The Homeschooling Book of Answers". She was frequently invited to speak at homeschooling and unschooling conferences and announced her retirement from conferences in 2017. Dodd grew up in Española, New Mexico. When she was 14, Dodd (then Adams) received a promo copy of David Bowie's first album, David Bowie. Impressed by his lyrics and music, she wrote him a fan letter. Bowie responded, "... a few moments ago I was handed my very first American fan letter - and it was from you. I was so pleased that I had to sit down and type an immediate reply, even though Ken is shouting at me to get on with a script he badly needs."

Jan Mühlstein (born 3 July 1949 in Most, Czechoslovakia) is a journalist, German Jewish activist and the former chair of the Union of Progressive Jews in Germany. Life Jan Mühlstein grew up in a German-speaking Jewish family, which traditionally practised Liberal Judaism. In 1967, he began studying physics at the Karl University in Prague. After the defeat of the reformation movement known as the Prague Spring, in which Mühlstein participated actively, he emigrated to West Germany in 1969. From 1970 onwards, he studied physics at the Ludwig Maximilians University in Munich and completed a Ph.D. in theoretical quantum optics in 1977. During the next four years, he worked in the leadership of project energy research of the nuclear energy research facility in Jülich. Since 1982 Mühlstein has been working as a business journalist in Munich and is deputy chief editor of a journal covering the economics of the energy market.

Sergey Ivanovich Kislyak (; born 7 September 1961) is a Russian diplomat and former ambassador to the United States. He served as the Russian envoy to Washington from December 2012 to February 2017, during which time he was at the center of several controversies. Kislyak was born in Leningrad, Soviet Union, on September 7, 1961. After graduating from the Leningrad State Institute of International Relations in 1985, Kislyak served as a diplomat for the Soviet Union and then Russia. He worked as a deputy foreign minister in Moscow from 2000 to 2004 and then served as Russia's ambassador to Belgium from 2004 to 2006. From 2006 to 2012, Kislyak was Russian ambassador to the United States. In December 2012, he was appointed by Russian President Vladimir Putin as deputy chairman of Rosneft, one of the world's largest oil companies. In February 2017, Kislyak resigned from his post as Russian ambassador to the United States after media reports surfaced that he had met with Sergey Gorkov, then-secretary of the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB), during the 2016 U.S. presidential election campaign. The reports raised questions about whether Kislyak had discussed U.S. sanctions against Russia with Gorkov and whether Trump campaign officials had colluded with Russia during the election.

Philip Green Wright (October 3, 1861 – September 4, 1934) was an American economist who in 1928 first proposed the use of instrumental variables estimation as the earliest known solution to the identification problem in econometrics. In a book review published in 1915 he wrote one of the first explanations of the identification problem. His primary topic of applied research was tariff policy, and he wrote several books on the topic. He also wrote poetry, was a mentor to the poet and author Carl Sandburg, and published some of Sandburg's earliest works. Wright was the father of geneticist Sewall Wright. Early life Wright was born in Boston, Massachusetts in 1861 to John Seward Wright and Mary Clark Green Wright. His grandfather was Elizur Wright, an abolitionist and pioneer of life insurance regulation. Philip Wright grew up in Medford, Massachusetts and in 1884 graduated from Tufts College with a bachelor of mechanic arts (AMB) degree. From 1884 to 1886 he taught mathematics at Buchtel College in Akron, Ohio, after which he attended Harvard University and graduated with a master of arts (AM) degree in economics in 1887.

Thomas McAteer (30 March 1876 – 20 September 1959) was a Scottish professional footballer who played as a centre half in the Football League for Bolton Wanderers, in the Scottish League for Dundee, Clyde, Celtic, Albion Rovers and Abercorn, and in the English Southern League for West Ham United and Brighton & Hove Albion. Life and career McAteer was born in Smithstone, Cumbernauld, in 1876, the son of Patrick McAteer, who had migrated to the area to work in the coal mines, and his wife, Margaret Starrs. He played junior football for Kilsyth Wanderers and Smithston Hibernian before moving to England in 1898 to sign for Football League First Division club Bolton Wanderers. He spent four seasons with Bolton, scoring 10 goals from 59 league appearances: they were relegated in the first, he helped them gain promotion in 1899–1900 and played regularly in the third season but lost his place in the fourth, and was released in 1902.

Abdul Muhaimin Iskandar (born 24 September 1966), also known as Iskandar Muda, is the current Prime Minister of Malaysia. He is the youngest ever Prime Minister in Malaysian history, and the second youngest after the current ruler Sultan Muhammad V. Iskandar was first elected to Parliament in 1998, becoming a member of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO) party. He was appointed Deputy Prime Minister in 2001, and served in that role until 2002, when he was appointed Finance Minister. He became Health Minister in 2004, and held that position until 2006. In 2007, he was appointed Deputy Prime Minister again, this time in charge of the Home Affairs Ministry. In 2009, he became Deputy Prime Minister once again, this time in charge of the Defence Ministry. In 2013, he was appointed Defence Minister for a second time. On 10 March 2016, Iskandar was elected as Prime Minister after defeating incumbent Najib Razak in a general election.

Kʼo is one of several Mayan ceremonial calendars. It is used to track the years and cycles of the earth, the moon, and the sun. Kʼo is a Mayan ceremonial calendar that was used to track the years and cycles of the earth, the moon, and the sun. Kʼo was first recorded in the Lacandon inscriptions in Chiapas, Mexico, in the 7th century AD. It is still used today by certain Maya groups in Guatemala and Belize. Kʼo is made up of 20 days and 20 nights, with a total of 260 days. It is based on the movements of the sun, moon, and planets. Each day is divided into four periods: morning, noon, afternoon, and night. There are also five special days called kʼewil chʼih (“first watch”), kʼewil tzolkin (“twenty watch”), kʼewil baktun (“thirty watch”), kʼewil tun (“forty watch”), and kʼewil uin (“fifty watch”). Kʼo was used to track important events such as births, marriages, and deaths. It was also used to determine when important ceremonies should be held. The calendar was also used to keep track of religious ceremonies and rituals.

José María Ramón Obando del Campo (August 8, 1795 – April 29, 1861) was a Neogranadine General and politician who twice served as President of Colombia. As a General, he initially fought for the Royalist Army during the Independence Wars of Colombia, ultimately joining the revolutionary forces of Simón Bolívar towards the end, but once independence was attained he opposed Bolívar's Centralist government. Personal life Born out of wedlock to Ana María Crespo on August 8, 1795 in the town of Güengüe, municipality of Corinto, in the then Province of Popayán of the Viceroyalty of New Granada in present-day Colombia, he was baptised José María Ramón Iragorri Crespo just two days later on August 10 in the chapel of the García hacienda. Society, during the times of the colony, was puritanical and the religious authorities did not allow a single mother to raise a child on her own, thus when he was two years old he was given up for adoption and put in the care of a Criollo family in the home of Juan Luis Obando del Castillo y Frías and Antonia del Campo y López who raised him as their own and gave him their last name. His parentage has been of debate among historians, most argue that he was the illegitimate son of Joseph Iragorri, but others argue and have tried to prove that his father was Pedro Vicente Martínez y Cabal, and others have claimed that he was the biological son of his adoptive father Juan Luis Obando as well.

Max Friedländer (18 June 1829, Pless, Upper Silesia - 20 April 1872, Nice) was a German-Austrian journalist.  After studying law like his cousin Ferdinand Lasalle at the universities of Berlin, Breslau, and Heidelberg, he became assessor at the city court of Breslau, and while holding this position he published his book on copyright, Der Ausländische und Einheimische Rechtsschutz Gegen Nachdruck und Nachbildung, Leipzig, 1857. He began his journalistic career in 1856 by contributing to the Vienna Presse, and soon afterward moved to Vienna to become a member of the editorial staff of that paper, his articles on political economy and finance attracting the attention of influential statesmen and financiers. After the Italian war Friedländer conducted a successful journalistic campaign against the policy of Schmerling, and advocated strongly the granting of a liberal constitution. In September, 1864, he founded the Neue Freie Presse, of which publication he remained editor-in-chief until his death.

He also caught 14 passes for 153 yards and added two receiving touchdowns and returned two interceptions for touchdowns. As a junior, he ran for 2,482 yards on 201 carries and ran for 34 touchdowns. He caught 10 passes for 137 yards and had two touchdown receptions. As a senior, he ran for 2,824 yards on 256 carries and ran for 41 touchdowns. He also caught 8 passes for 116 yards and added two receiving touchdowns. He finished his high school playing career with 7,606 rushing yards on 645 carries (11.8 yards per carry) and ran for 111 touchdowns. Freeman also recorded six receiving touchdowns and two interceptions returned for touchdown (119 total touchdowns).

Robert Hoyle (September 16, 1781 – February 15, 1857) was a businessman and political figure in Lower Canada. He was born in Lancashire, England in 1781 and came to New York state in 1806. Hoyle supplied lumber to Lower Canada. After he declared loyalty to Britain during the War of 1812, he was forced to abandon his property there and he settled in the Richelieu valley near Lacolle. His brother Henry was leasing the seigneury of Lacolle. Hoyle became involved in farming and the lumber trade there. He also operated a ferry service across the Richelieu River. Hoyle served in the local militia, becoming lieutenant-colonel during the Lower Canada Rebellion, and also served as justice of the peace. He was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Lower Canada for L'Acadie in 1834. He voted against the Ninety-Two Resolutions. In 1832, he married Elizabeth B. Nye, who was the sister of some important local merchants; his first wife Pamelia Wright had died seven years earlier. In 1834, he was named customs collector at Stanstead and, in 1835, registrar for L'Acadie County. Hoyle retired from his duties as customs collector in 1844. He died at Lacolle in 1857 and was buried in Champlain, New York.

is a Japanese video game composer, arranger, and sound director. Martina von Trapp (17 February 1921 – 25 December 1997) was an Austrian actress, singer and author. She was the younger sister of Maria von Trapp and the daughter of Georg von Trapp and his wife, Agatha Whitehead. Martina von Trapp was born on 17 February 1921 in Trapp family home Villa Hirschenstein in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria. She was the second child of Georg von Trapp (1887–1948), a military officer and World War I veteran, and his wife Agatha Whitehead (1889–1948). In 1927, when she was four years old, her family moved to the United States, settling in Westmount, Quebec. On 25 December 1997, von Trapp died at her home in Montecito, California from natural causes at the age of 80. She was buried at Holy Cross Cemetery in Westmount, Quebec. Martina von Trapp began her singing career with the Children's Chorus of Montreal. In 1947 she made her Broadway debut in The Sound of Music as Liesl von Trapp. She reprised her role for a national tour and made her film debut opposite Christopher Plummer in The Sound of Music (1965). Von Trapp appeared as herself in The Sound of Music Live! (1973) and The Song of the Swiss (1996).

Eugene Salvatore "Gene" DiNovi (born May 26, 1928) is an American jazz pianist. DiNovi was born in New York City. He worked with Joe Marsala and Chuck Wayne while a teenager. He was very active live and on record in the late 1940s, working with Buddy DeFranco, Benny Goodman, Chubby Jackson, Brew Moore, Boyd Raeburn, Buddy Rich, Artie Shaw, Lester Young. He worked extensively as an accompanist for vocalists, starting with Peggy Lee in 1949–1950; he also played behind Tony Bennett and Anita O'Day. He recorded with Lena Horne multiple times in the late 1950s and early 1960s and also accompanied her on tours of Europe. During this time, he also worked with his own small groups; his sidemen included Danny Bank, Johnny Carisi, Bill Crow, Tony Fruscella, and Dave Schildkraut. He began working more as a studio musician and film score composer in the 1960s. Toward the end of the decade he played with Carmen McRae, then moved to Canada to take a position as a house pianist with the CBC in Toronto. In the 1980s he worked with Ruby Braff and toured and recorded in Japan, and continued to be active as a performer into the 1990s, working with James Campbell, Don Thompson, Memo Acevedo, Dave Young, and Terry Clarke.

The Ghoryakhel is a Pashtun supertribe that inhabits the North-West Frontier Province and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. The Ghoryakhel are a sub-tribe of the Kalash. The Ghoryakhel are a Pashtun supertribe that inhabit the North-West Frontier Province and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. The Ghoryakhel are a sub-tribe of the Kalash. They speak the Ghoryakhel language, which is closely related to the Pashto language. The Ghoryakhel trace their ancestry back to the Prophet Muhammad's grandson Ali ibn Abi Talib, through his son Hasan ibn Ali. The Ghoryakhel are believed to have migrated from central Asia in the 12th century AD. The Ghoryakhel settled in what is now the North-West Frontier Province and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. They are Sunni Muslimpractising the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence. The Ghoryakhel are a agricultural people and are known for their goat herding skills. They also engage in livestock farming, growing wheat, maize, peas, and other crops. The Ghoryakhel are also skilled in handicrafts such as weaving carpets and mats, making pottery, and creating silver jewelry.

Keith Richards (born 18 December 1943), often referred to during the 1960s and 1970s as Keith Richard, is an English musician, singer, and songwriter, who has achieved international fame as the co-founder, guitarist, secondary vocalist, and co-principal songwriter of the Rolling Stones. His songwriting partnership with Mick Jagger is one of the most successful in history. Richards is widely considered one of the greatest guitarists of all time. His career spans over six decades and his guitar playing style has been a trademark of the Rolling Stones throughout the band's career. Richards gained press notoriety for his romantic involvements and illicit drug use — and was often portrayed as a countercultural figure. Richards was born in and grew up in Dartford, Kent. He studied at the Dartford Technical School and Sidcup Art College. After graduating, Richards befriended Jagger, Bill Wyman, Charlie Watts and Brian Jones, and joined the Rolling Stones. As a member of the Rolling Stones, Richards is the only member, aside from Jagger, to sing lead on some Stones songs. Richards typically sings lead on at least one song a concert, including "Happy", "Before They Make Me Run", and "Connection". Outside of his career with the Rolling Stones, Richards has also played with his own side-project, The X-Pensive Winos. He also appeared in three Pirates of the Caribbean films as Captain Teague, father of Jack Sparrow, whose look and characterization was inspired by Richards himself.

How Hill House is a large Edwardian manor house located in Hill House, Pennsylvania. It is currently owned by the National Trust for Historic Preservation and open to the public for tours. How Hill House was built in 1905 by Henry James's daughter, Alice James, and her husband, William Stanley Moss. The house is located in Hill House, Pennsylvania, on a hill overlooking the town of Washington, Pennsylvania. It is a large two-story brick manor house with a gabled roof and clapboard exterior. The house has fourteen rooms on the first floor and seven rooms on the second floor. It also has a large attic and basement. The house was originally used as a weekend home by the James family. They later rented it out to various tenants, including Henry Ford and Franklin D. Roosevelt. In 1938, it was purchased by the National Trust for Historic Preservation (NTHP). The NTHP restored the house and opened it to the public for tours in 1950. The house has been open to the public for tours every day since then, except for Christmas Day and New Year's Day.

The Munda people are an Austroasiatic speaking ethnic group who live in eastern India. They are the second-largest community in the state of Odisha after the Oraon people and form the largest Munda community in India. The Munda people are an ethnic group who live in eastern India. They are the second-largest community in the state of Odisha after the Oraon people and form the largest Munda community in India. The Munda people are an Austroasiatic speaking group who are believed to have migrated from southern China around 1000 CE. They currently reside in the states of Odisha, Jharkhand, and Chhattisgarh. The Munda people have a diverse culture which is based on their traditional belief system. The Munda people are known for their art, architecture, and literature which is based on their mythology and religion. The Munda people also have a strong agricultural tradition which is based on their traditional agriculture methods.

The Tetraodontiformes are an order of highly derived ray-finned fish, also called the Plectognathi. Sometimes these are classified as a suborder of the order Perciformes. The Tetraodontiformes are represented by 10 extant families and at least 349 species overall; most are marine and dwell in and around tropical coral reefs, but a few species are found in freshwater streams and estuaries. They have no close relatives, and descend from a line of coral-dwelling species that emerged around 80 million years ago. Description Various bizarre forms are included here, all radical departures from the streamlined body plan typical of most fishes. These forms range from nearly square or triangular (boxfishes), globose (pufferfishes) to laterally compressed (filefishes and triggerfishes). They range in size from Rudarius excelsus (a filefish), measuring just in length, to the ocean sunfish, the largest of all bony fishes at up to in length and weighing over 2 tonnes.

Adán Javier Medrano Rodríguez (24 December 1969 – 18 February 2001) was a Colombian footballer who played as a midfielder. Born in Villavicencio, Antioquia, Medrano started his career at hometown club Atlético Nacional. He made his professional debut on 25 July 1988, playing the last 15 minutes of a 1–0 home win against Deportivo Cali. Medrano had a spell on loan at Atlético Bucaramanga during the 1992 season, and then moved to Spain to play for Racing Santander. He played two seasons for the "Cabezas Blancas". Medrano returned to Colombia and signed for Millonarios in 1995. During his six-year spell with the "Toreros", he won two league titles and two Copa Libertadores titles. Medrano also played for Colombia in the 1998 World Cup and the 1999 Copa América. He was part of the team that reached the semi-finals of both tournaments, but was ultimately eliminated by Brazil in the quarter-finals of the World Cup and by Argentina in the semi-finals of the Copa América. On 18 February 2001, Medrano died in an airplane accident while on his way to play for Millonarios against Deportivo Cali. The plane he was travelling in crashed into a mountain outside Medellín shortly after taking off from El Dorado Airport. He was 38 years old.

Andre Lamont Johnson (born July 11, 1981) is a former American football wide receiver who played most of his 14-year career with the Houston Texans of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Miami, and was drafted by the Texans third overall in the 2003 NFL Draft. He is 11th all-time in NFL career receptions, and in NFL receiving yards. Johnson holds nearly every Texans receiving record. He was also a member of the Indianapolis Colts and Tennessee Titans. During his career, Johnson was named to the Pro Bowl 7 times, named to 5 All-Pro teams and emerged as one of the NFL's most productive wide receivers of the 21st century. Early years Johnson attended Miami Senior High School, where he graduated in 1999. He played high school football and was rated as one of the top prospects in the country. As a senior, Johnson caught 32 passes for 931 yards and was named a Parade All-American.

Alexander DeConde (born November 13, 1920 in New York City) is an American actor, producer and director. DeConde was born Alexander Schwartz in New York City, the son of Russian-born theatrical agent Leo Schwartz and his first wife, the actress Lillian de la Motte. He attended the Ethical Culture Fieldston School in New York City, graduating in 1937. He began his acting career in the 1940s, appearing in film and television roles. He is perhaps best known for his role as Dr. Phillip Craig on the ABC sitcom "The Doctors" from 1970 to 1977. DeConde also appeared in several episodes of "The Odd Couple", "The Mary Tyler Moore Show", "Starsky & Hutch", "The Streets of San Francisco", "M*A*S*H", "Hawaii Five-O", "Dallas", and "Falcon Crest". In 1976, DeConde produced and directed the made-for-TV movie "Love on a Rooftop". The following year he directed the feature film "A Night to Remember". In 1978 he produced and directed the TV movie "Murder on the Orient Express". In 1980 he directed the feature film "The China Syndrome". From 1983 until his death in 1994, he was a regular panelist on CBS's game show "What's My Line?". DeConde died of natural causes at his home in Los Angeles at age 74.

The Croton River is a river in Westchester County, New York, United States. It flows eastward for 34 miles (55 km) before flowing into the Hudson River. The Croton River rises in the town of Harrison, in the southwestern corner of Westchester County. It flows eastward past the town of Croton-on-Hudson and through the northern part of the town of Mount Kisco before turning to the east-northeast and flowing into the Hudson River just north of Croton Point. The river's drainage basin covers parts of three counties: Westchester, Rockland and Putnam. The Croton River is a significant waterway, providing drinking water and irrigation to large areas of Westchester County, Rockland County and Putnam County. The river also supports a significant wildlife population, including a number of salmon species that migrate to the river to spawn.

Jum Jainudin Akbar (3 September 1963 – 11 November 2016) was a Filipina politician who had served two terms as provincial governor of Basilan. She was the widow of deceased strongman Wahab Akbar. Akbar, along with other Mindanao governors, had a hand in supporting the Bangsamoro Basic Law. Political career Akbar was the first female governor of the Province of Basilan, and was elected during the May 2007 elections. However, Jum had substantial political experience as a result of her years as an active political partner to her husband and predecessor, Wahab Akbar. Upon election, Gov. Akbar pledged to fulfill a campaign promise of providing free rubber trees, fertilizers and polybags to farmers of the region, at a cost of thirty million pesos or more. In her first term as governor, an IED went off near her home. The explosion was thought by authorities to be linked to politics. Akbar also handled the evacuation and retrieval operations at Al Barka after the July 2007 massacre of Philippine Army troops by rebel ambush during her tenure. She died in office on 11 November 2016.

Tentaculites oswegoensis is a small animal of unresolved phylogenetic affinities that has often been classified with molluscs or even with marine worms and has recently been interpreted as a lophophorate based on shell microstructure. The genus Tentaculites was named in 1820 by von Schlotheim. Tentaculites oswegoensis was named by 1877 and is known from the Upper Ordovician rocks of the Maquoketa Group. It ranged from Oswego, IL (Kendall County) to possibly Kankakee River State Park (KRSP) in Will County, Illinois. At KRSP it appears in the basal Silurian of the Kankakee Formation but has not been found in the underlying Ordovician rocks. This particular species is approximately 0.75 to 1.25 inches in length. In Oswego, Illinois it is found mostly in clusters at Waubonsie Creek in the basal Brainard Formation (Upper Ordovician), just west of the railroad tracks. The entirety of Class Tentaculita became extinct at the end of the Devonian, leaving no known extant descendants or related species.

Voogt is a Dutch surname. In modern Dutch, it is usually pronounced "voogt". The name originated from a Germanic personal name, cognate with the English word "wolf". The surname Voogt is distributed throughout the Netherlands, but is especially prevalent in the provinces of North Brabant and Limburg. The Voogt family was one of the most important noble families in the Middle Ages. They played a prominent role in Dutch history, most notably as generals during the Dutch Revolt and as governors of the Dutch East Indies. The Voogt family also had a long tradition of service in the Catholic Church. The Voogt family first appeared in written records in 1264 as de Vocht. They were a prominent family in the region of Maastricht and led a turbulent life. In 1290, they were implicated in a plot to overthrow William II of Holland. They fled to France but were eventually pardoned and returned to Holland. The Voogts rose to prominence during the Middle Ages. In 1339, they obtained land near Heusden-Zolder from Louis II, Count of Flanders. This became known as the Voogtland. The Voogts became one of the most powerful families in Holland and held many important positions in government. They were frequently involved in military campaigns and played a major role in Dutch history. The Voogts were particularly influential during the Dutch Revolt. As generals, they played a vital

Frank Madigan (1908–1979) was sheriff the Alameda County, California, from 1955 to 1969. He was the last of the "old school" sheriffs. Born in Oakland, California, Madigan attended local schools and then the University of California at Berkeley. He enlisted in the United States Army during World War II and served in the European Theater. After the war, he returned to Berkeley and graduated with a law degree in 1948. Madigan began his law career as a deputy district attorney for Alameda County. He was elected sheriff in 1954 and served until 1969. During his time as sheriff, Madigan made major changes to the department, instituting new training procedures, modernizing the department's equipment and creating a centralized fingerprint identification system. He also oversaw a significant increase in law enforcement resources in Alameda County. After leaving office, Madigan served as a mediator and arbitrator for the county government. He died in 1979 at the age of 73.

Deddington is a civil parish and small town in the county of Oxfordshire, England. The town is situated on the River Grand, about northeast of Oxford and southwest of Bicester. At the 2011 Census the parish had a population of 2,924. Deddington is first mentioned in the Domesday Book as "Dedentone". The town's name is derived from "dæd-", meaning "clearing in a forest", and "tun", meaning "settlement". The earliest settlement in Deddington probably dated back to Roman times and was known as Deddintone. Deddington was an important crossing place on the Grand Union Canal from 1813 until its closure in 1990. Today, the town is served by two bus services: route 78 connects it with Bicester and Oxford; while route 83 serves the local villages of Southover and Wootton Underwood. The parish church of St Peter and St Paul dates from the 12th century, with additions made in the 14th century and 15th century. The church contains monuments to members of the families of Powys, Grenville, Beauchamp and Brooke. The churchyard contains graves dating from the 16th century onwards. The present vicar is Canon Andrew Whitehead. The town also has an Anglican secondary school: Deddington School which opened in September 2010 with a roll of 155 pupils aged 11-18.

"Pushing 20" is a song recorded by American singer Sabrina Carpenter from her fourth studio album Singular: Act II and released as the lead single from the album. The track was written by Carpenter, Paul Guy Shelton II and its producer Warren "Oak" Felder. The song was released by Hollywood Records as the lead single from Singular: Act II on March 8, 2019. The song is a hip hop and trap-influenced song with a "distinct pop sound". Lyrically, it talks about Carpenter wanting to deal with her own responsibilities instead of other people's opinions. Background and release When Carpenter first performed the song on the Singular Tour in Orlando, Florida, she said to the audience: "I wrote this song 'cause I was at a time in my life, by the way, like, six weeks ago? Like, not even that crazy long ago. But it was at a time in my life where, you know, I think a lot of you in this crowd, no matter what age you are, are going to go through that period in your life where you start making choices and having a lot more responsibility. And then you have to, like, think before you speak and think about the repercussions of things. And there's just a lot on your plate and it becomes very heavy and there becomes, like, one day where you start listening to yourself before you listen to the opinions of other people".

Edivaldo Sarafim da Silva Junior (born April 9, 1979 in São Paulo), commonly known as Juninho da Silva, is a Brazilian midfielder who currently plays for Bahia. Juninho da Silva started his career at São Paulo. He was one of the most promising players at the club, and helped them win the 2005 Copa Libertadores. In 2006 he joined Flamengo where he won the Brazilian Série A title in 2007. He then moved to Atlético Madrid, but failed to make an impact and was loaned back to Flamengo in 2009. In 2010 Juninho moved to Liverpool, but failed to make an impact and was loaned back to Flamengo in January 2011. He then moved to Corinthians in January 2012. In August 2013 he signed for Bayern Munich, but only played a handful of games before being loaned back to Corinthians in December 2013. He then signed for Bahia in January 2014.

Williams Ranch is the oldest settlement in Mills County, Texas, now a ghost town, with the oldest known cemetery in the vicinity dating back to the mid-19th century. The location is about south of Mullin, and northwest of Goldthwaite, the county seat. When originally settled, Williams Ranch was located in the far southern portion of what is now Brown County. (Mills County was formed in 1887.) History Around 1855, a John Williams from North Carolina was passing through the area and decided to camp for the night beside a spring on Mullin Creek. Impressed with the location, he bought some land from a fellow whose last name was Williams(W. W. Williams) decided to stay and established a ranch on the springs. The reason the town is called Williams Ranch- because all of John Williams sons had Ranches there. During the next ten years, a community grew around Williams Ranch consisting of a number of homes, a hotel, a general store, a school and a number of other businesses including a stage stop. A post office operated in Williams Ranch from 1877 to 1892. The reason the town died was out of greed, because the railroad was going to go through there, but the people raised the price of their lands to high, so the railroad bypassed Williams Ranch, Texas. Outlaw John Wesley Hardin met Deputy Sheriff Charles Webb in Williams Ranch about a month before Hardin killed Webb. By the 1880s, the community had about 250 residents. Its demise began when it was bypassed by the Santa Fe Railroad in 1885 but more for the reason of the feud that existed between the town's original settlers and its newcomers.

Walter Rosenthal  (born October 11, 1929) is an American chemist and Nobel laureate who has made significant contributions to the understanding of chemical reactivity and the chemistry of chemical reactions. Rosenthal was born in Brooklyn, New York, United States. He attended Rutgers University, where he earned his bachelor's degree in 1949 and his doctorate in 1954. After postdoctoral research at the University of California, Berkeley, he joined the faculty at Columbia University in 1955. Rosenthal is best known for his work on chemical reactivity, particularly on the roles of electrons and energy in chemical reactions. He has also made important contributions to the understanding of chemical reactions as processes involving both atoms and molecules, as well as to the development of theory and methodology for studying these processes. His work has helped to improve our knowledge of the chemistry of substances such as fuels, plastics, and medicines. In 2000, Rosenthal was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on chemical reactivity. He is also a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Piparahi is one of the habitation/locality (Tola) of Amwa Khas village (gram panchayat) in Kushinagar district of Uttar Pradesh. It comes under Dudahi block of Tamkuhi Raj tehsil in the district. Gobaraha in north, Dasahwaha in south, Ultahawa in west and Lilahat in east are nearby habitation. This Tola is about 5 kilometers away from The Gandaki River in east. It is about 3 kilometers near U.P-Bihar border in north. The village is 10 kilometers away from Dudahi railway station (Broad gauge), 35 kilometers away from Tamkuhi Raj tehsil on Grand Trunk highway and 38 kilometers from Padrauna – district secretariat. It is highly populated habitation. Piparahi has one government primary school and one private primary school- Shri Mahatma Gandhi Gyan Mandir. This locality has two temples and a market, Piparahi Bazar.) People of Hindu and Muslim community resides here peacefully. Most of the population of the habitation is from backward class. It is covered under Pradhan mantri gram sadak yojna and Rajive Gandhi vidyut vikash yojna. Land of the villagers are highly fertile for sugarcane, wheat, rice and other seasonal crops. References

Meru North District was one of the unconstitutionally created districts of Kenya, located in that country's Eastern Province. In 1992, it was split from the large Meru District, along with Meru Central District, Meru South District (Nithi), and Tharaka District. Since the Supreme Court's decision in September 2009, Meru North is again part of Meru County. The area of Meru North District is the home of the Ameru (Meru) tribe, which is sometimes described as being related to other tribes living around the Mount Kenya region: the Kikuyu and the Embu people. The Ameru are generally called "Bantu" people who have been native to the Mt. Kenya area for many, many years — well before colonization of Kenya by Great Britain in the 19th Century. The people are now predominantly Christian — Methodist, Presbyterian, Roman Catholic, and other denominations, reflecting the work of missionaries — with also minorities of Indian descent, who are mainly Hindus, and African/Arab descent, who are Muslims. There are also has some resident Europeans predominantly British in ancestry.

The America Line (German: Amerikalinie) is the primary name of the Hamburg S-Bahn line S2 that links the city of Hamburg to its neighbouring cities in northern Germany. It is also known as the Köln-Hamburg Line and the Rhein-Neckar-Bahn. The America Line is a long railway line that runs between Hamburg and Cologne, with intermediate stops in Neuss, Düsseldorf, Essen and Duisburg. The line is 322 kilometres (200 miles) long, making it one of the longest railway lines in Germany. The line was opened on 15 December 1842, as part of a project to connect Hamburg and Cologne. At the time, it was the longest railway line in Europe. The first section of the line from Hamburg to Neuss was opened on 1 July 1843. The section from Neuss to Düsseldorf was opened on 1 August 1844. The section from Düsseldorf to Essen was opened on 1 October 1844. The section from Essen to Duisburg was opened on 5 May 1846. The final section of the line from Duisburg to Cologne was opened on 10 May 1846. Today, the America Line is one of the busiest railway lines in Germany. It carries over 470,000 passengers each day.

Mary Bouton "Mamah" Borthwick (June 19, 1869 – August 15, 1914) was an American translator primarily noted for her relationship with architect Frank Lloyd Wright, which ended when she was murdered. She and Wright were instrumental in bringing the ideas and writings of Swedish feminist Ellen Key to American audiences. Wright built his famous settlement called Taliesin in Wisconsin for her, in part, to shield her from aggressive reporters and the negative public sentiment surrounding their non-married status. Both had left their spouses and children in order to live together and were the subject of relentless public censure. Early life and education She was born as Mary Bouton Borthwick in Boone, Iowa to Marcus Smith Borthwick (1828-1900) and Almira A. Borthwick (née Bowcock) (1839-1898). She had two sisters: Jessie Octavia Borthwick Pitkin (1864-1901) and Elizabeth Vilitta Borthwick (1866-1946). Borthwick earned her BA and MA at the University of Michigan in 1892 and 1893. She later worked as a librarian in Port Huron, Michigan.

Andrew Ross Sorkin (born February 19, 1977) is an American journalist and the co-anchor of CNBC's Squawk Box. He also serves as a columnist for the New York Times. Sorkin was born in New York City and grew up in Westchester County, New York. He is the son of ABC News producer Jean Sorkin and psychoanalyst David Sorkin. He has a sister, Rebecca Sorkin. Sorkin attended Harvard College, where he was an editor-in-chief of the Harvard Crimson. After graduating in 1999, he went to work at The Wall Street Journal, where he became a reporter in 2000. In 2003, he founded The New York Times Magazine, where he was its editor-in-chief from 2007 to 2013. He has also been a correspondent for NBC News and a columnist for the Financial Times. In December 2013, he joined CNBC as co-anchor of Squawk Box and columnist for the New York Times. Sorkin has written three books: The Best Way to Rob a Bank is to Own One (2010), A Way Out (2012), and Too Big to Fail (2014). He is married to journalist Christine Romans; they have two children.

Tisulsky District is an administrative district (raion), one of the nineteen in Kemerovo Oblast, Russia. As a municipal division, it is incorporated as Tisulsky Municipal District. It is located in the east of the oblast. The area of the district is . Its administrative center is the urban locality (an urban-type settlement) of Tisul. Population: 28,471 (2002 Census); The population of Tisul accounts for 36.1% of the district's total population. Geography The district is in the northeast of Kemerovo Oblast, and the Kuznetsk Basin, and covers the northern end of the Kuznetsk Alatau mountain range. The Kuznetsk Alatau is the source of many rivers and streams that flow north to the Kiya River, and eventually the Tom River.Much of the terrain is mid-height mountains, with the southern portion of the district being part of a federally protected area, the Kuznetsk Alatau Nature Reserve. Vegetation is mostly dark taiga (coniferous forest).The district is about 250 km east of the regional city of Kemerovo.
