Warwick Hugh Anderson (born 10 December 1958), known professionally as Warwick Anderson, is an English film director and screenwriter. He is best known for directing the historical epic film The Lord of the Rings trilogy (2001–2003), which began with The Lord of the Rings (2001), and was followed by The Fellowship of the Ring (2002), The Two Towers (2003), and The Return of the King (2003). He also wrote the screenplays for all three films. Anderson was born in London to British journalist, broadcaster, and author Paddy Anderson and American actress Ilene Woods. He studied at Winchester College, where he formed a band, Paddy & the Rats, with fellow students. After leaving university, he worked as a stage manager on a number of productions in Britain before making his first short film, Dead Man's Shoes, in 1984. Anderson's feature film directorial debut was the romantic comedy Shallow Grave (1994), which starred Ewan McGregor and Sienna Miller. He then directed the epic historical drama The Lord of the Rings trilogy (2001–2003), based on the best-selling books by J. R. R. Tolkien. The trilogy became one of the most successful films of all time, grossing over US$2 billion worldwide. Following The Lord of the Rings, Anderson directed two further adaptations of Tolkien-related works: The Hobbit trilogy (2012–2014) and The Battle for Middle-earth (2007). The Dance Years is a British documentary television series that aired on BBC One from 7 January to 3 May 2016. The series is a retrospective of the decade which saw the rise of dance music in the UK. Valle Piola is a deserted village in the province of Udine, northeastern Italy. The village is located on a hill in the valley of the Piola River, about northeast of Udine and about east of Trieste. The village is mentioned for the first time in a document dating from 1053. At that time it was part of the possessions of the Archdiocese of Udine. In 1256, it was assigned to the Friars Minor Conventual. In 1420, Valle Piola passed into the hands of the Counts of Gorizia. In 1806 it was occupied by the French and after their retreat it became part of Austrian territory. Until World War II, Valle Piola was an agricultural village with a population of about 180 inhabitants. After World War II, it was abandoned and most of its inhabitants fled or were deported to concentration camps. Today, there are only a few elderly people living in the village.

Millicent Genevieve "Millie" Knight (born 15 January 1989) is an English actress. She is known for her roles as Beth Latimer in the British soap opera EastEnders, and as Shelby Miller in the American television series The Flash. Knight was born in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, England, to parents Linda (née Pollard) and Gary Knight. She has a younger sister, Nicola. Knight attended Holy Trinity Catholic School in Barnsley and later graduated from the University of Birmingham with a degree in Drama. Knight started her career as a model before making her acting debut in the short film "The Mummy's Curse" (2007). Her breakthrough role came when she was cast as Beth Latimer in the British soap opera EastEnders in 2009. Her portrayal of Beth won her critical acclaim and she was nominated for Best Actress at the 2010 British Soap Awards. In 2013, she left EastEnders after six years to star as Shelby Miller in The Flash, a role which earned her critical acclaim and several accolades, including nominations for Best Actress at the 44th Primetime Emmy Awards and the 18th Screen Actors Guild Awards.

Pro-feminism refers to support of the cause of feminism and the rights of women. It may also refer to actions or ideas that advocate for the advancement of women's rights. Feminism is the movement to end discrimination and exploitation of women by men and to achieve parity with men in political, economic, social, and cultural life. Feminism includes the belief that women are just as capable as men of achieving success in all areas of life. Feminism has been prominent in many countries and at various times in history. There is no one definition of feminism, but most people who identify as feminists believe that it is important to encompass a range of views and ideologies. Some people who identify as feminists believe that all women should have the same rights and opportunities, while others believe that different levels of rights and opportunities should be afforded to different groups of women. Most feminists believe that sexism exists and that it needs to be addressed.

Aprey Faïence is a name used for the painted, tin-glazed faience pottery produced at a glass-works at Aprey, France. This factory was established in 1744 by Jacques Lallemont de Villehaut, the Baron d'Aprey, on his estate. In 1760 he partnered with his brother Joseph, and the two hired Protaix Pidoux, a Swiss pottery painter. Jacques withdrew from business in 1769, so Joseph hired François Ollivier, a potter. Ollivier became director from 1774–1792. The factory came under the ownership of the Baron d'Anthès de Longpierre in 1789, then closed in 1885. The pottery produced at this factory were styled after early Strasbourg pieces, typically with decorations of birds or flowers. The high quality of the work produced at this factory, along with the bird illustrations by the chief painter, made these pieces a preference of collectors. Early works did not have a distinct marking. Later pottery was of a lower quality, and these inferior pieces were typically marked with an A.P. symbol and the initials of the painter.

The Hot Boys (often styled as Hot Boys) are an American hip hop group from Memphis, Tennessee, formed in 1984. The group was composed of rappers Juvenile, Lil' Kim, Biggie Smalls, and Puff Daddy. The Hot Boys emerged on the Southern rap scene in the early 1990s and quickly became one of the most popular and influential groups in the genre. Their distinctive sound and their flamboyant personas helped to make them one of the most popular rap groups of all time. The Hot Boys released several successful albums over the course of their career, including 1994's self-titled debut album, 1995's Ready to Die, 1997's No Way Out, 1999's The Massacre, 2002's Get It How You Live, and 2006's Death Before Dishonor. The Hot Boys were well-known for their wild live shows and their rivalry with fellow Memphis group UGK. The Hot Boys disbanded in 2003 after Puff Daddy was sentenced to three years in prison for tax evasion. Lil' Kim, Biggie Smalls, and Juvenile later formed their own group, Bad Boy Records.

Edward Howes DL (7 July 1813 – 2 January 1892) was a British Conservative Party politician and colonial administrator. Howes was born in London, the son of Sir John Howes, 2nd Baronet. He was educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated with a BA in 1837 and an MA in 1840. He served as Secretary to the Board of Trade from 1841 to 1846, and as Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs from 1846 to 1851. Howes entered the British Parliament in 1852 as Member of Parliament for East Somerset. He served as Financial Secretary to the Treasury from 1859 to 1865, and was Colonial Secretary from 1865 to 1868. In 1865 he was raised to the peerage as Baron Howes of Sleaford, of Sleaford in the County of Lincoln. Howes served as Governor of New South Wales from 1870 to 1875, and of Victoria from 1880 to 1886. He retired from public life in 1886. Howes died in London aged 86.

Max von Gagern (b. Weilburg (in Nassau), 6 November 1861; d. Munich, 25 October 1934) was a German Field Marshal and World War I hero. Max von Gagern was born in the Free City of Weilburg in the Grand Duchy of Nassau into a Prussian family. He entered the Prussian military academy in 1878, and after graduation served with the VIIth Infantry Regiment in the German protectorate of East Africa (today's Tanzania). He saw action in the German colonial war in East Africa, where he distinguished himself as a daring and successful cavalry officer. In 1891 he was made a captain and transferred to the 8th Hussars. He served with this regiment on the outbreak of World War I, initially as regimental adjutant, and later becoming commanding officer. At the Battle of Liège on 26 August 1914, Gagern led his regiment into heavy fire and captured several positions despite being outnumbered eight to one. For his actions at Liège he was promoted to major general on 3 September 1914. He later commanded III Corps at the Battle of Verdun from February to May 1916, and at the Battle of Passchendaele from July to November 1917. He was made a field marshal on 18 October 1917. "Lipstick Vogue" is a song by Elvis Presley, released in 1958. The song was written by Don Ho and produced by Colonel Tom Parker. It was originally recorded by Presley in 1956 as part of the soundtrack for his motion picture Jailhouse Rock. "Lipstick Vogue" reached #1 on the US Billboard charts in 1958 and stayed there for two weeks. The song was also released in the UK, where it reached #4 on the chart. In 2004, it was ranked number 108 on Rolling Stone's list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. "Lipstick Vogue" is a ballad that was written by Don Ho and produced by Colonel Tom Parker. Turks in Norway or Norwegian Turks are a group of people of Turkish descent living in Norway. According to the 2011 census, there are around 10,000 Turkish citizens living in Norway, most of them living in Oslo. The first Turks to arrive in Norway were traders and merchants who came to Norway during the late Middle Ages. The first recorded Turkish immigrant to arrive in Norway was Süleyman Çelebi, a merchant from the Ottoman Empire who settled in Bergen in 1525. Others followed suit and by the end of the 16th century, there were around 50 Turkish immigrants living in Norway. The early Turkish immigrants were mainly traders and merchants, but over time they started to settle down and start families. The first Turkish-born Norwegian was Cevdet Bey, who was born in 1871 in present-day Turkey and arrived in Norway as a child with his family. The early Turkish immigrants encountered some resistance from the Norwegian population, who viewed them as foreigners. However, over time the Norwegian Turks began to assimilate into Norwegian society and have established themselves as a distinct community within Norwegian society. Today, the largest concentration of Turkish citizens living in Norway is found in Oslo, where they make up around 10% of the city's population. There are also a number of small communities located throughout Norway, most notably in Bergen, Trondheim, and Stavanger. Turkish culture has had a significant impact on Norwegian culture over the years

Lou Schizas is best known for his work as an equities analyst for the Canadian specialty channel BNN: Business News Network (formerly Report on Business Television) since its launch in September 1999 until August 24, 2007. Schizas claims on his website Happy Capitalism that he analyzed over 16,000 stocks during his time with BNN. He was also a daily contributor to national network CTV’s morning flagship program, Canada AM. Schizas was an on-air radio personality on Corus Entertainment radio stations AM640 (CFMJ) in Toronto and AM980 (CINW) in London until September 2018 when Corus tried to terminate its relationship with him with an offer of 1 month after 18 years of outstanding business and market analysis. Schizas retained a labour lawyer and successfully settled on 15 months of working notice. This involved working for the Corus station in Hamilton and London. His last day with Corus was December 10 2019.

Cyanea is a genus of flowering plants in the family Araliaceae. The genus is endemic to New Zealand, where it is most commonly found in the North Island. The genus is characterised by its diminutive size, its spikes of small white or cream-coloured flowers, and its preference for damp habitats. Many of the species are vulnerable to introduced pests and diseases, but are still considered to be relatively common and widespread plants. The plants in the genus are small shrubs or small trees typically growing to a height of 2–5 m, with a trunk up to 25 cm diameter. The leaves are simple, oppositely arranged, and have a bladewidth of 5–15 cm. The flowers are solitary or in small groups on short stalks 10–25 mm long, and have five petals which are white or cream-coloured, and have a central glandular spot. The fruit is a capsule containing several small black seeds.
